Title: matthe udbhava: Pramod to play Udbhava’s Anant Nag for today’s milieu
Content: In 1990, director Kodlu Ramakrishna ’s film, Udbhava, which had Anant Nag in the lead, was a trendsetter of sorts. So, when the filmmaker announced a sequel to it, 30 years later, it raised a lot of eyebrows. The film, Matthe Udbhava is set for release this week, and according to its leading man Pramod , it is a follow up to the events of the original film. “After Geetha Bangle Store and Premier Padmini, I was looking for a film that would allow me to showcase what I am capable of as an actor. There were several offers, but I was a bit wary about taking on anything, as I had done a film that got stalled midway. I wanted to work on good films that would see the light of day. When Kodlu Ramakrishna sir approached me for a role in Matthe Udbhava, I was not sure whether to do it, considering that he comes from a different school of filmmaking. A friend suggested that I meet Kodlu sir and decide whether to do it or not. Once he narrated the script, I realised that this is exactly what I was looking for — a role that would let me showcase the actor in me,” says Pramod.Like Anant in Udbhava, Pramod’s character in Matthe Udbhava has a way with words and looks at using anyone he meets to his advantage. “He is a total opportunist. In fact, one of the action sequences in the film is for him to impress the heroine. At that point, there is no romance between them, and he sees her purely as a means to an end,” he says, adding, “The hero is not bad; he’s just street smart. I get to play Udbhava’s Anant for today’s milieu,” says the actor.

Title: SJ Suryah joins Venkat Prabhu’s Maanaadu
Content: Venkat Prabhu’s Maanaadu , which will be headlined by Simbu, has an array of actors joining the team. The latest to join the film is SJ Suryah . The versatile actor even took to social media to tweet, “What a story, what a narration.” So, ask Suryah about being part of the film and he smiles, “It was truly a mind-blowing narration and script. I thoroughly enjoyed the story and immediately said yes to the project. Venkat Prabhu is a good and successful director. But this movie definitely will be his best. Sammaya irundhadhunga.”He also says that he’s happy to work with Simbu. “Simbu and I go back a long way. We used to chat and party together sometime ago. But both of us got busy with our respective work. I am happy to join with my friend Simbu again.”Bharathiraja, SA Chandrasekar, Premgi Amaren, Karunakaran , Y Gee Mahendra, Daniel Annie Pope and Manoj Kumar are also part of the film. Kalyani Priyadarshan plays the female lead and Yuvan Shankar Raja will compose music for the film. It was also announced recently that Simbu’s name in the film will be Abdul Khaaliq.

Title: Dhanush-Karthick’s action thriller will roll from May
Content: Even as Dhanush is juggling between Karthik Subbaraj’s Suruli, Mari Selvaraj’s Karnan and Anand L Rai ’s Bollywood film, Atrangi Re, he’s signed on another film. The actor will team up with Karthick Naren for an action thriller, which will go on floors in May.Giving us details, Arjun Thyagarajan, who’s producing the film, tells us, “We were working with Dhanush on another film that was being directed by Ramkumar . But it’s a big-scale venture and we needed a lot of time for pre-production work. So, we thought we’d do another film with Dhanush in the interim and that’s how this movie came about.”Arjun says he was already in discussion with a few other filmmakers before zeroing in on Karthick. “We’ve been in talks for six months. Karthick has grown from film to film, and this one will take him to the next level. I can only say that it’s an action thriller and we have almost locked the rest of the cast and crew, including music composer GV Prakash ,” he informs.

Title: Dual celebration for Abhay Vakil
Content: Actor Abhay Vakil ’s birthday coincides with that of his mother, Asha Arun Vakil . And the mother-son duo recently celebrated their big day at a SoBo restobar with family and friends from the telly industry. The party was attended by Vipul Roy and his fiancée Melis Atici, Madirakshi and Bhardwaj Mundle, Nivedita Basu, Rishina Kandhari, Hemant Chaddha, Rushad Rana and Mithil Jain among others.Abhay said, “My mother would have liked a quiet evening at home, but she did not want to deprive me of a fun birthday, so she agreed to this joint party attended by her friends as well as mine.” He said, “While I never listen to David Guetta and Justin Bieber , my mother is in love with English music.” The mother and son made a happy picture as Abhay danced to Justin Bieber’s 'Let me Love you' with her and then rocked the floor in Ranveer Singh ’s steps with Vipul Roy and Mithil Jain on 'Khalibali' ('Padmaavat').

Title: Sudeep launches a new hotspot in Bengaluru
Content: Kalki Koechlin and her boyfriend Guy Hersberg are one of the most adored couples in Bollywood. He is a pianist from Jerusalem, Israel. The actress often shares pictures of him and their daughter Sappho. Recently, on her beau's birthday, she shared a special post for him and we can't get enough of them.

Title: ‘We have decided not to use the film’s first look poster anymore’
Content: The first look poster of RA Vijaya Murugan ’s Cocktail, which released on Monday, starring Yogi Babu in lead role, opened to mixed response as a section of people were upset with it. The poster had the comedian dressed up as Lord Murugan and a bird behind him. Cinematographer-director PG Muthiah , who is producing the movie, apologised about the same through his Twitter account. He asserts that cocktail is the name of a species of bird which is found in Australia He opens up, “We never had any intention of hurting anyone’s feelings. Yogi Babu’s appearance as Lord Murugan is part of a dream sequence in the film. I think a certain section of people expressed their displeasure because of the name cocktail associated with it. Anyway, we have decided not to use that poster anymore for promotion. The movie is an out-and-out fun entertainer, and we are planning to release the film by this month end.”According to him, Cocktail is about four married friends who get stuck in a terrible situation. “How they handle the issue with utmost care forms the fun part in it,” he says, adding, “Yogi Babu is one among the four friends. Sayaji Shinde , Mime Gopi, Swaminathan and other newbies play pivotal roles in the film, the story of which unveil in two days’ time.”

Title: Sudeep launches a new hotspot in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Levels Pub & Kitchen, located at JP Nagar 4th Phase, hosted its official launch party recently. Owners Kiran, Rajkumar, Raanna, Ajay, Keshav Gowda and Manjunath, threw a star-studded bash, which had Sudeep , Rakshitha, Prem and Akul Balaji among others, in attendance. “Sudeep arrived at the party and cut the ribbon and cake. It was a memorable evening,” said Raanna. Guests were seen enjoying delicious food and cocktails at the bash.

Title: Romance is the toughest genre for me: Prajwal Devaraj
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Rock bands put up spectacular shows at fests in the city
Content: Bengaluru witnessed a musical weekend with power-packed performances by popular bands. Hindi rock band Euphoria and music director Amit Trivedi serenaded the crowd at IIM Bangalore’s cultural festival, Unmaad. Amit, along with his talented team of singers, sang some of his popular compositions, including Daryaa from Manmarziyaan . Euphoria returned to IIM-B after 16 years, having performed twice before, in 2002 and 2004. Palash Sen , the frontman of the band, took to social media and recollected the performance, writing, “IIM-B rocked Euphoria with their love, respect and warmth... We took stage at the OAT and then at the legendary LSquare, where it is a tradition to end all parties with Maaeri at 4 am. We went and didn’t end the party, but started a brand new one. The campus echoed with the sound of a 20-year-old song, and an 18-year-old relationship with this prestigious institute. Last night will be etched in history and campus folklore.. Still can’t believe all this is real...Rehne de, mera yeh Vehem pe hi Yakeen.(sic.)."Meanwhile, at Dhwani, the cultural fest at St. Joseph’s College of Commerce, city-based band Best Kept Secret performed original songs and covers of popular numbers like Coldplay’s Hymn For The Weekend and Maroon 5’s Memories, among others, and had the audiences tapping their feet and swaying to their music.

Title: Aari, Losliya, Srushti in a suspense action thriller
Content: Recently, it was announced that Bigg Boss Tamil fame Losliya Mariyanesan will be playing the female lead in Friendship, which has cricketer Harbhajan Singh in the lead. And now, Aari has announced his next that will star Losliya and Srushti Dange in the lead. Directed by debutant Trichy Albert Rajaa , the film will also have Yogi Babu and Senthil in important roles.Albert says, “This film will be a suspense action thriller, where we chronicle events that happen in one night. Losliya and Srushti are the two female leads. There is no scope for romance in the film. Both of them have interesting and important roles with equal weightage. Yogi Babu will bring in the comic relief and Senthil plays his father. We will begin shooting for the film from February 21 in Chennai.”The team will also be shooting in places like Puducherry, Bihar and some portions in Malaysia. C Sathya will score the music. “There will be a bit of horror element, too,” says Albert, who quit his teaching job to pursue his passion for filmmaking . He says, “I was a government school teacher. Ever since I was young, I was fascinated with films and filmmaking. I thought it was time to pursue my dream. So, I quit my job and here I am.”

Title: ​Darshan is like a brother to me: Prajwal Devaraj
Content: Challenging Star Darshan shares a close connect with the Devaraj family, so it was no surprise seeing him at the audio launch of Prajwal’s film. Speaking about their rapport, Prajwal says, “He’s like my elder brother — our friendship goes way back. After Tarak , he and my father, Devaraj, became really close. They share a special bond. I have often felt jealous of their connect, because I have known Darshan longer. But he’s part of the family and is like the eldest son in the house now.”

Title: Cabinet nod likely to all-weather port at Vadhavan in Maharashtra
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Union Cabinet is likely to give its in-principle approval for an all-weather port at Vadhavan , 140 km north of Mumbai, which will be one of the top 10 container ports in the world.

Sources said the shipping ministry wants to start the work to develop this port during the next financial year, 2020-21. The container port with 20-metre draft will have capacity to berth world’s longest container ships. As per the plan, after developing the port, the shipping ministry will allocate berths to private operators under the public-private-partnership (PPP) mode.

The individual terminals can be given to private players through competitive bidding where they will be investing in berths, equipment and other utilities, sources said. The upcoming port has the potential to attract large ocean carriers given the deep water depth at the site and the close proximity to major industrial locations in the western region.

The Centre’s move to give in-principle approval to the project gains importance considering that the Maharashtra Maritime Board (MMB) in May last year had started "internal discussions" on building the new port at Vadhavan in Palghar district on the public-private-partnership (PPP) model and had cited delays in getting central government approval for the project.

Title: Deliver on promise of justice: Nakodar police firing victims' families to CM
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

JALANDHAR: Families of four youths killed in the 1986 Nakodar police firing claimed on Tuesday that Punjab CM Amarinder Singh and Jalandhar MP Santokh Singh had promised them justice during the 2019 parliamentary polls, but did little to ensure it in the past year.

The families, flanked by human rights activists and members of Sikh groups, made the statement on the 34th anniversary of the incident in which policemen had fired at people protesting against the sacrilege of Guru Granth Sahib in a gurdwara of Nakodar. Addressing a press conference here, firing victim Ravinder Singh's father Baldev Singh, flanked by sisters of the other three victims, said former CM Parkash Singh Badal protected officers responsible for the firing and now CM Amarinder Singh's government was denying them justice. "There are striking similarities between Bargari sacrilege-Behbal Kalan police firing case and the Nakodar case. In 1986 too, students were peacefully protesting after burning of Birs of Guru Granth Sahib in a gurdwara. In both cases, justice is being denied," he said.

Baldev said the Congress would meet the same political fate like that of Badals' if it did not deliver justice in the case.

Baldev said after former MLA H S Phoolka and Kharar legislator Kanwar Sandhu raised the issue in the Punjab assembly last year, sleuths of state intelligence department approached him to talk about compensation. "I told them to arrange a meeting with the CM, so that I could tell him how the four young Sikhs were gunned down. One them was killed in police custody. Police had even refused to give their bodies for cremation," he said.

He said they could procure one part of the Justice Gurnam Singh Commission's report, which was formed by the then Surjit Singh Barnala government to probe the incident, but the second part of the report had gone missing.

He said the second part contained affidavits and statements of witnesses which incriminated police officers. "It is not available in Punjab assembly records. We have been chasing other files related to the case too, but crucial records have gone missing. Punjab government should order a time-bound probe to prosecute officers and find out how the second part of the probe could go missing," he said.

Advocate Satnam Singh Bains, who has been working on Punjab Documentation and Advocacy Project, said when reports of even the British period were available in records or archives, it was difficult to understand how reports and records of 1986 could go missing. "Even General Dyer faced court martial. But, in this case, Punjab Police officers were allowed to go scot-free, even as they killed four youths in firing without any provocation. The British government gave compensation to the victims of Jallianwala Bagh," he said. "In this case also, state government should announce a compensation and order a time-bound probe," he added.

Paramjit Kaur Khalra and other activists of Khalra Mission Organisation, Punjab Human Rights Organisation general secretary Gurbachan Singh, and Alliance of Sikh Organisations leader Sukhdev Singh were also present at the conference.

Title: Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt give couple goals as they attend Armaan Jain’s wedding reception
Content: MUMBAI: Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt made the perfect couple as they attended Armaan Jain and Anissa Malhotra’s wedding. Ranbir and Alia were clicked with mom Neetu Kapoor in what looked like the perfect family picture. There were reports that Rishi Kapoor’s health scare would keep Ranbir and Alia away from Armaan’s wedding ceremonies. They both were missing from the previous events that were attended by Kareena Kapoor Khan and other members of the Kapoor family A source reveals, “Now that Rishi is better they decided to attend Armaan’s reception. Also them coming together at his reception are only going to add fuel to the fire that they will most probably get married sometime in 2020. Neetu is extremely fond of Alia and has already made her a family member of the Kapoor khaandan.”Ranbir and Alia are yet to confirm or deny these marriage reports but industry sources speculate that they will be next in line after Armaan.

Title: Waheeda Rehman: It’s love for photography that has brought me to Varanasi: Waheeda Rehman
Content:
Waheeda Rehman captured the city on her camera, she also went for a boat ride in the Ganga BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Waheeda Rehman (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Waheeda Rehman wore a mask to avoid being recognized and roamed about like a regular tourist. At the ghat she clicked pics of the Ganga aarti (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Waheeda Rehman (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Varanasi has been muse to photographers world over. Joining the brigade is veteran actress Waheeda Rehman who was on a personal two-day visit to the city on Friday and Saturday. She flew back to Mumbai on Sunday. “It is love for photography that has brought me here and I must say the city is beautiful,” said the Sahib Biwi Aur Ghulam and Guide actress, who spent Saturday evening clicking photographs of the famed Ganga aarti organised by Ganga Seva Nidhi at Dashshwamedh Ghat.Waheeda Rehman (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Keeping her visit low profile, the Chaudhvin Ka Chand actress donned a mask to avoid attention freezing every moment of the aarti in her camera. Like a regular tourist, she walked from Dashshwamedh Ghat to Darbhanga Ghat, where she was putting up in a heritage property.Earlier in the day, she went for the morning boat ride her camera always ready to click the scenic beauty of the ghats from the boat.Waheeda Rehman wore a mask to avoid being recognized and roamed about like a regular tourist. At the ghat she clicked pics of the Ganga aarti (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)She also went for a walking tour of the city on Saturday. “During the heritage walk Waheedaji saw the Bengali deori and Bhartendu Bhawan and was all ears when the culture and tradition of the old part of the city was explained to her constantly clicking pictures of the life in the lanes. She also relished Banarasi cuisine of kachori and jalebi during the walk,” says Shashank Basu, a senior guide who took her on the guided tour.Waheeda Rehman (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Title: Aditya Roy Kapur: I don’t come across as someone who could do action, but it is my first love
Content: It wasn’t a planned move. It so happened that Mohit and I were discussing a script. Our last collaboration (Aashiqui 2, 2013) had resonated well with the audience, and we didn’t want to do something similar in our second outing together. I am glad that Mohit sees me differently, and offered me Malang, which has action in it. I have grown up watching action movies. That’s my first love! I enjoy watching action stars like Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jackie Chan and Jean-Claude Van Damme. In fact, I was a karate kid, with good jumping and attacking skills. I think action is in my blood.Acting is something that I stumbled into. I was a VJ, who casually auditioned for London Dreams (2009), and surprisingly bagged the role. From then, one thing just led to another. Since I never planned to become an actor in the first place, there was no thought about genres at all. I wasn’t even sure what to pick up and what not to, I just kept taking up whatever came my way. It is only after Aashiqui 2 that I realized acting is what I want to do. The films that worked for me have been from the romance and drama genres, and so, I was offered similar films. No one ever thought that I could do action films, and personality-wise, I don’t come across as someone who could like action, so I guess I wasn’t approached for such roles. I have been waiting for an opportunity to perform action, and when Mohit offered me Malang, I jumped with joy. I needed to build my physique to look convincing on screen while beating up 30 people. I worked on it and this is the end product.Yes, absolutely. Mohit gave me my first lead role and the character struck a chord with the audience. With Malang, he is showcasing another side of me. I think Mohit brings out these sides of me, which even I am unaware of. He is a very special person in my life.I don’t really care about fashion. I like to look good, but I end up wearing the same things. Of course, I am not saying that I will dress up like this forever, I do leave room for improvement. As far as being an introvert is concerned, I resisted social media for the longest time. I finally took the plunge after my team members told me how important it is to be active online. However, after being active initially, my interest has fizzled now. I don’t feel obligated to be active on social media, I do it when I feel like it. I am not in it for the number of followers. I am active on social media during film promotions, as it is part of my job. Being in the public eye all the time tires me. Therefore, there are times where I disappear, rejuvenate and do things I like to do, away from the public glare. I don’t know if I will ever want to give away that part of my life.I am still trying to understand the repercussions of not being as active on social media. I would want to strike a balance. It is not that I am socially awkward, or that I have a problem talking in front of people, it’s just that I don't find myself being gregarious all the time. However, I don’t want to enter a space where my career is getting affected by it. I don’t want to be ‘out of sight, out of mind’.Working with Anil sir has been like attending a master class. His energy and passion for acting are infectious. He loves working, learning and being the best version of himself. If he is working with a young team, he makes it a point to learn something from them. On the first day of the shoot, he asked me what I was eating. I was on a strict diet for this film, and when I told him that, he took the number of my caterer. The next day, he came on the set and told me, ‘Hey, I am on your diet. I am feeling much healthier’. I was surprised to see his enthusiasm. I just hope to be as dedicated as he is. Though he is a senior, he wanted to hear, rather than being heard on the set. He wanted Mohit to direct him, he wanted to be told things.Now, that’s been an amazing experience. Working in a movie that has (Mahesh) Bhatt saab coming back to direction after a gap of 20 years. is surreal. The film also stars his daughters Pooja (Bhatt) and Alia (Bhatt), and even Sanjay Dutt, who is like his brother. The set feels like a sacred place. I also feel that I am a much better person and a much better actor after working with him. I joined the film after a few days after it went on floors, and Bhatt saab knew that I was jumping on a moving train as an actor. When you join in a little late, the others are already in the thick of things. However, he guided me and got me in sync with the rest of them in no time.Let it remain a mystery whether I am single or not (laughs!). As far as Diva is concerned, I don’t know how our meeting over dinner was taken out of context. Both of us, at different occasions, have rubbished these rumours. Following reports about my impending wedding, my mom asked me, ‘Is there something I should know?’ and I told her, ‘No!’. Diva and I have been friends for a while, but there’s nothing more to it.

Title: Coronavirus scare hits tourism industry in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
Eastern Temples of Khajuraho. Getty Images

BHOPAL: Coronavirus scare has affected the tourism industry in Madhya Pradesh . After the outbreak of the viral disease, large number of bookings of Chinese nationals were cancelled suddenly in Khajuraho leading to almost 15% decline in the tourist footfall.India on Sunday also temporarily suspended e-visa facility for Chinese travellers and foreigners residing in China in view of the coronavirus outbreak that has killed more than 400 people, infected over 20 ,000 others and spread to 25 countries.This year the number of foreign tourists also declined and the tourism industry attributed the drop in the footfall to the ongoing unrest over pro and anti CAA ( Citizenship amendment act) agitations across the country. Archaeological survey of India (ASI) sources in Khajuraho said, “ this year there is a general decline in both foreign and domestic tourists.”This year there was a “ very good” flow of Chinese tourists to Khajuraho. They were following Delhi, -Jaipur- Agra- Orchha -Khajuraho -Benaras circuit, said Mahendra Sharma , owner of a hotel in Khajuraho and office bearers of the hotel owners association at the international tourist centre.“ This was a new trend for Khajuraho and Orchha that a large number of Chinese nationals were arriving when the number of international tourists went down”, he said adding, “ in every 100 international tourists, the number of Chinese would be 10 to 20. Recently there was a group of 300 also.”Balbeer Goutam, president of the Guide association of Khajuraho said, “ I deal with French tourists and there numbers declined unprecedently this year. Chinese tourists compensated the shortfall to some extent and I would use my skills in English to explain the temples and their history to them.”“But”, he paused and added, “ as the luck would have it, they too stopped coming because of the corona outbreak.” Only those who had already reached India before the trouble started visited Khajuraho and appreciated its beauty, he said.One of the world heritage sites, Khajuraho temples are looked after by the ASI which include their conservation and entry of tourists.

Title: Amid coronavirus fear, Chinese executives to give Auto Expo a miss
Content:
Chinese delegates will keep away from the Auto Expo in wake of coronavirus concerns

GREATER NOIDA: Chinese nationals employed by automobile companies – even those stationed in India for weeks – will give the Auto Expo a miss amid rising apprehension in India over the coronavirus outbreak. The decision was taken, at virtually the last minute, as automakers feared that the presence of Chinese nationals may discourage visitors from coming to their pavilions. Also, concerns expressed by government officials during interactions may have prompted the companies and event organisers to take the unprecedented step.The decision means that hundreds of Chinese nationals who were slated to visit the event (which opens for media tomorrow and for the public from Friday) will now sit in their hotel rooms in Delhi, Gurgaon and even Greater Noida (which hosts the expo), but not enter the Expo venue.More than 20% space, or over 8,000 sq m of the total 40,000 sq m at the Expo, has been reserved by Chinese companies. These include top companies such as SAIC (China’s biggest seller and owner of MG Motors), FAW (entering through the Haima brand), Great Wall Motors (largest Chinese SUV maker), and BYD (maker of electric buses and batteries). Apart from them, many smaller Chinese companies have also partnered Indian makers and thus would have been present at the Expo.“As a proactive measure, Great Wall Motors has decided to excuse Chinese officials from visiting the Expo. We believe in taking utmost caution when it comes to local concerns and ensuring safety of those visiting our pavilion,” Hardeep Singh Brar , director (sales & marketing) of the company, told TOI. The company has decided to cancel the fam-visit of a large contingent of Chinese journalists that it was getting to India, while also postponing the visit of its global president Wang Fengying.Siam, the organiser of the event, also confirmed that Chinese nationals will not be visiting. “All Chinese companies participating at the Expo have confirmed that their exhibit area would be manned by their Indian employees and representatives. None of these stalls would be manned by anybody who has come to India recently from China,” Siam president Rajan Wadhera said. “As all arrivals from China have now stopped, there will be no visitors and delegations from China at the Motor Show.”Siam itself is taking steps to apprise Expo visitors of the safety measures they need to take, and how to notice any symptoms of the coronavirus. It is also installing hand sanitizers at various places at the expo.MG Motors’ parent SAIC has also decided against getting any of the Chinese officials stationed at its India factory at Halol in Gujarat. Also, staff returning from China has been kept in single rooms and instructed not to share premises with others.Ankur Bhatia, Indian partner of China’s FAW and owner of Bird Electric, said that Indian officials are now being deployed to man the booths. “Many of the Chinese staff are actually trying to even fly back home as they fear that travel advisories against the country may keep them stranded here for long.”The absence of Chinese officials will mean that meetings fixed by Indian parts suppliers, and other partners, will not take place now. “It will have to be undertaken at some other time. We had no other option but to postpone,” Bhatia added.A parallel component fair, that accompanies the vehicles expo, will also not have visitors from China. “Around 30 companies from the Chinese group have confirmed that their stand at components expo (at Pragati Maidan in New Delhi) would be managed by their Indian counterparts in their absence. As travel of Chinese nationals to India has now been stopped, there will be no representatives from China at the show,” components body ACMA said.

Title: Male troops won’t accept women commanders: Government to SC
Content:
The Centre told the SC that male troops are not yet prepared to accept women officers (File photo used for rep... Read More

NEW DELHI: The Centre has told the Supreme Court that women may not be suitable for command posts in the Army as male troops are not yet prepared to accept women officers. It also cited greater family demands and the danger of them being taken prisoner of war to oppose the plea of a few women officers for command posting after getting permanent commission.“The composition of rank & file being male, and predominantly drawn from rural background, with prevailing societal norms, the troops are not yet mentally schooled to accept women officers in command,” it said.It also said male and female officers cannot be treated on a par in the matter of postings because of their different physical standards and exposures, and reservations over exposing women officers to combat situations.Senior advocate R Balasubramanian and lawyer Neela Gokhale told a bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and Ajay Rastogi that induction of women to such posts would change the dynamics of the armed forces. They contended physiological limitation is further accentuated by the “challenges of confinement, motherhood and childcare”.Opposing the Centre’s plea, Meenakshi Lekhi and Aishwarya Bhatti, representing the women officers, told the court that many of them displayed exceptional bravery in adverse situations. They informed the court it was Minty Agarwal who, as flight controller, had guided Wing Commander Abhinandan when he shot down a Pakistani F-16 for which she was awarded the Yudh Seva Medal . Earlier Mitali Madhumita was awarded the Sena Medal for her bravery when terrorists attacked the Indian embassy in Kabul.But the Centre said armed forces require sacrifices and commitment beyond the call of duty by the entire family of service personnel involving separation and frequent transfers, affecting the education of children and career prospects of the spouse. “...it is a greater challenge for women officers to meet these hazards of service owing to prolonged absence during pregnancy, motherhood and domestic obligations towards their children and families, especially when both husband and wife happen to be service officers,” it said.Balasubramanian told the court that the Centre is agreeable to permanent commission to women officers who have served up to 14 years in the Army but not above that. He said those above 14 years of service would be permitted to serve till 20 years without PC and those past 20-year service would be released with pensionary benefits.He said all aspects were considered by the Centre while formulating a policy, like national security and operational effectiveness, and it was difficult to allow women officers in command posts. He said it would be a situation of extreme physical, mental and psychological stress for the organisation and the government if a woman officer is taken PoW, and it is best avoided by keeping them away from direct combat.“Future wars are likely to be short, intense and lethal, besides being prosecuted at very short notice. The boundaries between conventional and counter insurgency/terrorist operations have blurred in the present hybrid nature of warfare. The non-linear battlefield has rendered the erstwhile rear areas as much vulnerable as the battlefront. Therefore induction of women officers into Indian Army , hitherto a male bastion, needs to be viewed in the perspective of changed battlefield environment,” he said.“The officers are expected to lead their men from the front and need to be in prime physical condition to undertake combat tasks. Inherent physiological differences between men and women preclude equal physical performance resulting in lower physical standards and hence the physical capacity of women officers remains a challenge for command of units,” the government said.But the bench also hinted that complete bar against women officers for holding command posts was not right and the Army should allow them as per organisational requirement and suitability.The court said there was resistance when women were being inducted in police force but they are doing extremely well. “A change of mindset is required with changing times. You need to give them opportunity and they will serve to the best of their capabilities,” the bench said.

Title: Despite SC collegium’s 3 iterations, Centre sits on appointment of HC judge
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Supreme Court of India

Title: Quess Corp: Quess who’s India’s largest private employer?
Content: BENGALURU: Next time you see an Amazon delivery executive in your locality or walk into a Samsung store for after-sales service, you will probably be dealing with an employee of Quess Corp — a company you most probably haven’t heard of.Going by its latest quarterly filing, the Bengaluru-based company, which provides staffing solutions for some of the biggest brands in the country, now has the largest roster of employees and associates — 3.85 lakh — in the private sector in India.Growing at 38% every year since 2016, Quess has shot past Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), which remains the largest overall employer with 4.46 lakh on the rolls, but of whom about 90,000 are overseas, pegging its India workforce at about 3.6 lakh, according to people briefed on the matter. TCS does not provide a geographic split of its employee base and a company spokesperson declined to comment for the story.The development underlines a growing shift in the economy as companies like Quess have benefited from the demand for outsourced workers in areas ranging from e-commerce delivery to facilities management for commercial buildings.There is, of course, a significant difference in the skill levels of staff at TCS, which mostly employs engineers, and Quess, which depends largely on ‘grey-collar’ workers.Quess’s employees function as outsourced service providers for its over 2,000 clients, including Samsung, Amazon, Reliance , Vodafone India and Bajaj Finance , according to a report from ICRA. The company has about 5,000 workers overseas in markets like Singapore.“There are many countries which have a population smaller than the number of employees we have. The scale of our impact on the Indian job market is not well-known, especially the role we play in formalizing the job economy,” said Quess Corp's Group CEO Suraj Moraje, a former McKinsey & Co partner who joined the company in November.The development comes at a time when traditional sectors such as automobiles, telecom, FMCG and even IT services have seen layoffs for reasons like slowing growth and consolidation. At the same time, new economy companies continue to grow, fuelled by a record year of capital inflows.Investors tracking the space say the shift is happening not only because of the scarcity of jobs, but also because wages have increased substantially in the segment. “This area is exploding and these grey-collar jobs now have salaries which compare with entry-level compensation in IT/ITes companies,” says Anand Lunia, founding partner at venture capital firm India Quotient, adding that wages for delivery boys have risen faster than inflation over the last decade.Lunia was an early investor in Rebel Foods, which owns brands like Faasos and Behrouz Biryani, where salaries of delivery personnel are about Rs 20,000 – compared to Rs 6,000-7,000 in 2010, which inflation-adjusted, would have been about Rs 10,000-12,000 now.“Their aspiration is a steady job, which is a big reason why companies outsource these jobs since attrition is high and there is also not always a steady demand for these roles,” he said.According to Moraje, the average salaries at Quess range between Rs 12,000-Rs 40,000 for 70% of its workforce, about 75% of whom are in the age group of 21-35. While he declined to give an attrition number, the firm interviews over 1 million people a year. “We need to make sure that employees and associates have a career path so that our recruiting costs and retention rate improve,” he says. The company says it provides benefits such as provident fund and insurance to its entire workforce, and for many of them, this is their first formal employment.Quess, which was started by serial entrepreneur Ajit Isaac over a decade ago, has grown at a fast clip through a slew of acquisitions and the backing of Fairfax, owned by Canadian billionaire Prem Watsa . The company was listed in 2016. Local rival TeamLease, also based in Bengaluru, had about 2.28 lakh employees and trainees as of December 2019. Other major players in the space include global giants like Adecco and Randstand.“Companies are focusing on their core activities, while outsourcing activities that can be done by a specialised company; Quess Corp fits in there. Companies are wary of employing full-time when they can find gigs to fill in the jobs,” said Mahesh Vyas, MD & CEO at CMIE (Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy). He added that whether benefits are provided or not will be critical to measure if such employment are sustainable. “If a larger part of the labour force is getting into engagement that does not give social security, in a generation’s time, we could have a problem.”

Title: Bid being made to mislead people on Budget, says PM Narendra Modi
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PM Narendra Modi and BJP chief JP Nadda during the BJP Parliamentary Party meeting at Parliament House in New ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday said an attempt was being made to mislead people about the Union Budget as now critics had also come around to acknowledge that the Budget was the best which could have possibly been crafted in the challenging global economic situation.

“An attempt was made to mislead people about the provisions of the Budget but now even those who had criticised are praising it as the the best possible in the prevailing global economic scenario,” sources quoted Modi as telling members of the BJP parliamentary party.

The PM’s comments came on a day when the Sensex jumped more than 800 points and were seen as meant to motivate BJP MPs to defend the Budget against opposition attacks.

During his address to party MPs, Modi hailed the just-concluded Bodo accord and the agreement to settle members of the Bru-Reang tribe in Tripura, terming them “historic” successes of his government.

These would usher in an era of peace in the north-east which has suffered decades of bloodshed and violence, he said, adding that his government had also curbed Naxalism and boosted development in areas hit by extremist Left violence.

Modi said the northeast states used to see frequent blockades and ‘bandhs’ that would bring life to a standstill for days but things had changed for the better.

External affairs minister S Jaishankar and health minister Harsh Vardhan gave a presentation on the novel coronavirus, and how their ministries were dealing with the situation.

Title: No decision yet on all-India NRC, MHA tells Parliament
Content:
A protest against NRC and CAA (File photo)

NEW DELHI: No decision has been taken till now about preparing a National Register of Citizens (NRC) at the national level, the home ministry has said in reply to a Lok Sabha question. The careful formulation reflects the stated position that there has been no discussion in government over an all-India NRC .The ministry also informed the LS on Tuesday that it was talking to states having concerns regarding the National Population Register (NPR) updation proposed between April and September this year. The written reply to a question also clarified that collecting Aadhaar details for NPR was optional.On a specific query as to whether it will be mandatory to disclose information about other documents like passport, voter ID and driving licence, if held, and if non-disclosure would attract fine, the home ministry said “the respondent must provide information true to the best of his knowledge and belief”. However, it added that no documents shall be collected for NPR.Importantly, junior home minister Nityanand Rai informed MPs in reply to a separate query that no decision had been taken “till now” regarding an all-India NRC.According to sources, the office of Registrar General of India (RGI) that handles the NPR exercise has already reached out to West Bengal and Kerala where the governments have decided to put the process on hold over objections to new queries on data and place of parents’ birth as well as law and order concerns. Office of RGI is learned to have explained that conducting NPR is a constitutional obligation. Also, NPR had earlier been prepared in 2010 followed by updation in 2015.States are also believed to have been told that no documents were to be shown during NPR and information would be recorded as declared by the respondent.Sources clarified that while a respondent must provide information true to the best of his knowledge and belief, there will be no compulsion to fill up fields in the NPR form in case details are not available or the respondent is not comfortable declaring them. “The columns in such cases will be returned as blank,” said an officer.In Video: No decision taken on implementation of NRC yet: Centre

Title: Shaheen Bagh shooter an AAP worker: Police
Content:
Baisla, who was nabbed from the spot, allegedly claimed that he and his father were AAP members and had enroll... Read More

Father, brother say no AAP link

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police claimed on Tuesday that the 29-year-old man, Kapil Baisla (alias Gurjar), who had fired in the air at the Shaheen Bagh protest site while shouting pro-Hindu slogans on Saturday evening is an Aam Aadmi Party worker. This was confirmed by DCP (crime branch) Rajesh Deo.Baisla, who had been nabbed from the spot by the police, allegedly claimed during interrogation that he and his father, Gaje Singh , were members of AAP and had enrolled with the party in early 2019. The police claimed the crime branch had got deleted data from Baisla’s phone retrieved through forensic experts and found a series of photographs validating his alleged claims.The police denied allegations that it had leaked the photographs. Sources claimed that the photographs had been sent to Kapil Baisla by a third person, who had clicked them at the event. These images were also shared on a WhatsApp group, which has dozens of members.The photographs show AAP’s Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh putting the party cap on Baisla and the latter meeting AAP netas. It also had some pictures of Baisla posing with guns. The photographs are from 2019 and were saved on back-up. “Before reaching the spot, Baisla had logged off from WhatsApp and uninstalled it but he was asked to log back and the photographs were found saved in WhatsApp image folder,” said a source. Delhi Police’s SIT has now launched an investigation to establish if there was any kind of conspiracy. The Crime Branch has taken Baisla on a two-day remand and will interrogate him to find out if anyone had asked him to carry out the shooting. His father and brother are also expected to join the investigation. The police went to Baisla’s house but found the father missing. They had arrested his friend, Sarthak, on Tuesday for assisting him.DCP (Crime) Rajesh Deo said Baisla had said he had joined AAP along with a dozen other people, including his father, in early 2019. Cops said they had found several tweets by AAP workers on May 4, 2019 announcing Baisla’s father Gaje Singh, then the district president of BSP, and Baisla joining the party in presence of senior AAP members.However, Baisla’s father Singh and his brother, Sachin, who have gone missing, put out a video message from an undisclosed location, saying that they had nothing to do with AAP. “Every year during elections, a number of parties approach us and they make us wear their party cap or symbol as a mark of respect. We have nothing to do with AAP, this is being done to malign us. No one from our family has been with AAP,” said Sachin. Gaje said AAP netas had approached him during an election campaign and put their cap on him. “They had asked me to join, but I have nothing to do with the party. Even BJP had approached me but I refused them too,” he said.Meanwhile, police have established the sequence of events before the shooting. Baisla and Sarthak took the DND to reach Maharani Bagh from east Delhi’s Dallupura. They travelled on Baisla’s KTM bike. After reaching Shaheen Bagh, Baisla gave his phone to Sarthak and asked him to hand it over to his family.The cops have also identified the man who had supplied the pistol to Baisla seven years ago and a manhunt has been launched to nab him. Baisla’s interrogation reports cite him saying: “I had hidden the pistol in my trouser while travelling, but since it had become uncomfortable, I stopped and entered a bathroom at Holy Family Hospital and hid it under my jacket,” he said. Cops have booked Baisla and Sarthak for attempt to murder and under sections of the Arms Act.In Video: Shaheen Bagh shooter seen with AAP leaders in pictures recovered by Delhi Police

Title: ‘Love jihad’ not defined under laws, no case reported: Government
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The home ministry on Tuesday said the term ‘love jihad’ — popularly used to describe cases of allegedly forced inter-faith marriages — was not defined under existing laws and no such case had been reported by any central agencies.

In reply to a question by LS MP Behanan Benny asking if the government was aware of Kerala HC ’s observation that there was no case of ‘love jihad’ in the state, junior home minister G Kishan Reddy referred to Article 25 of the Constitution, which provides for freedom to profess, practice and propagate religion subject to public order, morality and health.

“Various courts have upheld this view, including Kerala HC. The term ‘love jihad’ is not defined under extant laws. No such case of ‘love jihad’ has been reported by any of the central agencies. However, two cases from Kerala involving inter-faith marriages have been investigated by the National Investigation Agency ,” he said.

The NIA had probed the case relating to inter-faith marriage of Kerala girl Hadiya, a Hindu who converted to Islam, to Shafin Jahan. It also probed a similar case of another Hindu girl from Kerala, Athira, who had alleged that she was being lured into embracing Islam.

Title: Nirbhaya case verdict today: Delhi HC to decide on hanging plea today
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The Delhi HC will give its verdict on the Centre’s plea challenging the stay by a trial court on execution of ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Can the Nirbhaya death row convicts be hanged separately, since at least two of them have exhausted their mercy plea? Delhi high court may answer this question on Wednesday as it gives verdict on the Centre’s plea challenging the stay by a trial court on execution of the four convicts, since one of them had filed a mercy plea before the President.

After an urgent hearing on Saturday followed by marathon proceedings on Sunday, Justice Suresh Kumar Kait had reserved orders on the Centre’s plea arguing that pendency of the mercy plea of one convict in a case of multiple death row inmates can’t be used as a ground to stay hanging of those who have exhausted all available legal options or are yet to exercise it.

A day after the trial court postponed indefinitely the execution of the four men, the Centre and Delhi Police had challenged it, accusing the condemned prisoners of “testing the patience of the nation”.

Before the HC website reflected that judgment will be pronounced on Wednesday, Nirbhaya’s parents on Tuesday mentioned the issue before Justice Kait and pleaded for an expeditious decision.

The trial court on January 7, had issued black warrants for the execution of all the four convicts in Tihar Jail at 7am on January 22. But they could not be hanged due to pendency of mercy petition of one of them. Later on January 17, the trial court fixed February 1 for the hanging at 6am, but the court was forced to stay the execution again as the counsel for three convicts — Pawan Gupta , Vinay Sharma and Akshay Thakur — urged it to adjourn the matter “sine die” saying their legal remedies were yet to be exhausted.

While the mercy plea of Mukesh Singh and Sharma were rejected by the President, Gupta has not yet filed it even as Thakur’s mercy plea filed on February 1 is pending.

Solicitor general Tushar Mehta had contended it is a deliberate and calculated design of the convicts to “frustrate mandate of law” by getting their execution delayed and they were not entitled to any more time. But advocate AP Singh — appearing for Gupta, Thakur and Sharma — had opposed the petition questioning the “hurry to execute the death sentence in this case only... Justice hurried is justice buried.”

The counsel for the convicts also protested against the fresh plea wondering how it can be entertained when the Centre was never a party in the case proceedings before the trial court. Senior advocate Rebecca John, appearing on behalf of Singh, had said that the “Centre has sought the setting aside of the order of the Patiala House court” when “an earlier HC order has clearly said that any order of the trial court should be challenged in apex court only.”

Title: New Income tax slab: 80% may switch tax regimes: Government
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre expects up to 80% of tax assessees to move to the new flat rate regime as data analysed showed a very large number of assessees didn’t use the benefit of housing rent allowance (HRA) or the deductions allowed for investments . Of the nearly 5.8 crore assessees who filed returns for the last fiscal, 55.4 lakh had claimed HRA, which is roughly 9.5% of the base. Within this, around 43 lakh had annual HRA of under Rs 1 lakh. Around 42,000 assessees had said their annual HRA was over Rs 4 lakh, or more than Rs 33,500 a month.Under the new regime proposed in the Budget, allowances such as HRA and LTA will be added to the income and taxed. Currently, these allowances are not counted while calculating the taxable income. Individuals are also allowed claim a deduction for home loans if living in the property.The government has maintained the new tax regime, which offers lower rates due to reworked slabs, but without exemptions , will benefit a large section of taxpayers. It has said taxpayers should work out calculations and decide if they want to move to the new system or stick to the existing one.On Sunday, the government had also said around 9% of taxpayers or 48 lakh availed of the Rs 2 lakh deduction for investments in provident fund, life or medical insurance. There were just around 3.8 lakh persons who had claimed exemptions of over Rs 4 lakh.Tax department officers said the government expected as many as 80% of tax assesses to shift to the new regime, after doing the calculations, as it made life simpler apart from lower rates. Officials said even those who may need to pay a marginally higher amount may be attracted by the lack of hassles in the flat rate.Government expects to take a hit of around Rs 40,000 crore based on this assumption. Officials have argued that a large number of taxpayers are not in a position to take advantage of all exemptions at the low levels of income. It was only the upper middle class and the rich who claimed the exemptions and that this segment will have the option to stick to the current regime.

Title: Sensex gains 917 points, sharpest in 5 months
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: The sensex rallied 917 points on Tuesday on the back of an easing of global crude prices and encouraging manufacturing data. Brokers said that the rally was also fuelled by global measures to control the coronavirus outbreak and short-covering after the 987-point fall post-Budget on Saturday.Tuesday’s surge in the BSE’s benchmark index was its sharpest gain since the thousand points-plus rally on September 23, 2019, after the government reduced the rate of corporate tax to 25%.After international crude oil prices moderated to $54.86 per barrel, the rupee firmed up 11 paise per US dollar. Oil prices eased as energy demand is expected to slip on the back of setbacks to trade in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. The sensex closed at 40,789, up 2.3% or 917 points, recovering its post-Budget losses. The NSE Nifty too firmed up to 11,979, rising 271 points.Data released by the government on Monday evening showed that manufacturing sector activity, as measured by the purchasing manager’s index (PMI) climbed to a near-eight-year high in January.Titan Industries, which declared its results on Tuesday, was the biggest gainer, rallying nearly 8%. Other top gainers were ITC, HDFC, Bajaj Finance and Tata Steel.“Markets are in a phase of pre- & post-adjustments to the Budget. 12,100 (for the Nifty) remains a key resistance zone on the upside, which looks difficult to be crossed on a sustainable basis at least in the first attempt,” said Manav Chopra, head of research-equity, Indiabulls Ventures Ltd.According to Umesh Mehta, head of research at Samco Securities , Saturday’s post-Budget crash was a knee-jerk reaction but as investors realised that the Budget would aid in the long-term growth of the economy, the market picked up. “With the Budget overhang gone, investors are breathing a sigh of relief and are back to making fresh calls. Additionally, January auto sales numbers were comparatively decent and with no other negative news, the Indian bourses saw a sudden rally today,” he said.Another positive for the equity markets was the rally in the government bond markets, which saw yields on government securities dip after the government announced that it would stick to its last year’s numbers despite a higher fiscal deficit this year.After the Budget, market attention is now shifting to the Reserve Bank of India ’s monetary policy meeting on Thursday. “The meeting will throw a light on the inflation trajectory as well as provide an economic outlook going forward. Further, the decline in oil prices and rupee appreciation is working in favour of the Indian markets. However, concerns regarding coronavirus still persist and we may witness volatility in the short-term,” said Ajit Mishra, VP-research, Religare Broking.Dealers believe that there would have been short-covering because despite the sharp rally, foreign investors made limited purchases. FIIs bought equities worth Rs 366 crore on a net basis on Tuesday, according to provisional exchange data.

Title: Day 2: Protesters throw garbage on roads in Patna, dump carcasses
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: The sanitation scenario in the state capital worsened as the Group-D employees of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) continued with their strike on the second consecutive day on Tuesday.

Around 4,500 daily wage sanitation workers are on strike against the urban development and housing department (UDHD) decision to end the services of daily wage workers and outsource the sanitation work to some other company after March. Earlier, the department had decided to outsource the services from February 1 itself.

The workers staged protest at PMC headquarters in Maurya Lok Complex. They threw garbage on the busy thoroughfares, including Ashok Rajpath and Fraser Road, while people living in residential areas had to bear with the stink as the door-to-door waste collection remained suspended.

The protesters and members of Patna Nagar Nigam Staff Union (PNNSU) barged into the PMC office and dumped carcasses of dogs and pigs outside the chamber of mayor Sita Sahu and PMC commissioner Amit Kumar Pandey. They also removed the garbage bins and dumpsters from roadside at several locations in the city.

Hemant Kumar, a sanitation worker, said, “We are throwing waste on the road to draw the state government’s attention towards our demands.”

Residents of many areas had to cross the roads and streets littered with garbage and slush, overflowing dustbins and choking drains.

Priya Rathore of Kadamkuan said, “All the roadside bins have been removed. People have started throwing garbage on roadside. Where else we will throw the household garbage.”

Arshita Singh, a student of Shri Arvind Mahila College, complained that the residents were throwing garbage at college gate. “Pigs, cows and stray dog are roaming freely on roads. I have never witnessed such situation in the last four years. It is a government failure to keep the city clean and green,” she said

“Although garbage is collected from homes at old Patliputra Colony through private sanitation workers, it is just dumped outside the park. What is the point of allocating so much money in their budget when PMC can’t hire workers through outsourcing,” Rajat Kumar of Doctor’s Colony in Kankarbagh asked.

Suchita Choudhary, a resident of Boring Canal Road, said the municipal body should allocate a temporary space to dump garbage or else make temporary arrangement as dustbins in households were overflowing.

Title: Mayor meets minister in support of PMC workers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: Amid sanitation workers’ strike for the second consecutive day on Tuesday, mayor Sita Sahu met urban development and housing department (UDHD) minister Suresh Sharma and demanded that Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) should be authorized to make Group-D appointments in the civic body under Section 38(B) of Bihar Municipal Act, 2007.

The mayor raised the concerns of agitating sanitation workers while submitting a charter of five demands to the minister and UDHD secretary Anand Kishor. “We have submitted our demand to minister and secretary and urged them to revoke the department’s order to do away with the daily wage sanitation workers. We are not opposing the decision of the Lokayukta, but the sanitation workers should continue to work with the PMC,” she told this newspaper.

The Lokayukta had found several discrepancies in the functioning of daily wage sanitation workers in several municipal bodies in the state and decided to end their services from February 1. Later, the department extended that deadline to March 31.

“We have demanded regularization of the workers working in the PMC for a decade and regularization of payscale of daily wage workers,” Sahu said.

The minister, however, said, “It is not our decision to end the services of sanitation workers and avail the services through outsourcing. The services of daily wage group D employees have been stopped in many municipal bodies in the state.”

He further said: “In the interest of the sanitation workers, the department has extended the deadline till March 31. The workers should return to work. We will consider their demand.”

UDHD secretary said a meeting would be convened to consider the issues raised by Patna mayor.

Meanwhile, Patna Nagar Nigam Staff Union (PNNSU) president Chandra Prakash said the UDHD has to revoke its decision.

“We are not against the decision of outsourcing companies but the daily wagers working for more than a decade should get their rights. The PMC board had taken the decision to regularize the workers who have been working for 10 years,” he said and added: “The strike will continue until our demands are met. The recruitment process of workers should be completed by February 19. All the workers should be regularized and get their rightful place.”

Sunita Devi, a sanitation worker said, “What will I do after March 31? I have been working here for the last six years and helping my husband in family income.”

Another worker, Anil Kumar, said it is a do-or-die situation for them. “I support a family of five. Whatever I earn is spent on my kid’s education and home rent. Where will we go,” he asked.

Minister offers olive branch to protesters: UDHD minister Suresh Sharma held a meeting with the officials concerned on Tuesday and said the daily wage Group D employees will be given priority in selection of sanitation staff by the company to be outsourced after March. “Besides, they will also get the benefits of Bhavishya Nidhi Yojana and Karamchari Rajya Bima Yojana,” he said.

Patna Nagar Nigam Staff Union president Chandra Prakash, however, rejected the offer and said: “We will fight for our rights till last breath. The department can’t force us to leave our rightful place.”

Title: Commuters get respite from truck parking on Digha-Danapur canal road
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: Commuters and residents got respite from the parking of trucks on Digha-Danapur canal road following the Patna DM’s order on Monday.

Earlier, the residents and commuters faced tough time in passing through Digha-Danapur canal road due to long queues of trucks parked on its both sides throughout the day. Thousands of commuters use this road connecting Danapur with J P Setu. DM Kumar Ravi issued on Monday ordered that no truck will be parked on the canal road after 5am. Besides, he also ordered that heavy vehicles on JP Setu will be allowed only between 10pm and 5am.

A senior traffic police officer said: “At times, truck drivers get stuck in the city and fail to cross J P Setu before the fixed time. As a result, they park their vehicles in Phulwarisharif, Khagaul and Digha-Danapur areas, which led to frequent snarls, especially on the Digha-Danapur canal road.”

He added: “Police officers have been deployed in the areas to keep a check on truck drivers. Besides, regular monitoring is being done on all such roads in order to ensure hassle-free vehicular movement.”

Commuters travelling on the Digha-Danapur canal road heaved a sigh of relief. “Trucks used to be parked since morning leading to traffic jam on the canal road. However, on Tuesday, we had a respite from that as there was no truck parked there,” said Amit Sinha, a resident of Saguna Mor.

The DM has also asked the officials concerned to prevent overloaded trucks from moving on JP Setu and towing away vehicles breaking down on the bridge or either side of it.

Instructions were also issued to reduce traffic congestion on the New Bypass Road from NH-30 to Anisabad. The DM has asked ADM (law and order) to make proposal of foot overbridges (FoBs) on the stretch.

Divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said traffic congestion on the New Bypass Road will be reduced soon as the 95km-long state highway-78 is ready for vehicular movement. The highway from Bihta in Patna district to Sarmera in Nalanda will provide direct connectivity to trucks and other vehicles going to Bhojpur.

Title: NRC not even in the womb, says JD(U) MP
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: JD(U)’s Munger MP Rajiv Ranjan Singh alias Lallan Singh on Tuesday defended the party’s support to Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in the Lok Sabha and raised a demand for fresh caste census in the country.

Speaking in the debate on the motion of thanks on the President’s address in Lok Sabha, Lallan also said people are linking CAA with National Register of Citizens (NRC), which is “not even in the womb”. “When NRC will come in the womb, all of us will see what exactly it is and do the needful,” he said.

On anti-CAA protests across the country, Lallan said, “Nobody knows about the reality of the misconception being spread about CAA. When a debate was held on the Citizenship (Amendment) Bill (CAB) in the Parliament, all of us supported it. Nobody said back then about which section of the CAB to be opposed…Maybe I would have supported the Bill out of lack of knowledge. We are having a debate today as well and I would be grateful if anyone could tell me about which section of CAA is being opposed by them.”

Speaking on the issue of caste census, Lallan said, “Reservation introduced by Mandal commission took the caste census of 1931 as the base. However, no caste census was done after 1931. There is a need to conduct fresh caste census so that actual status of different castes can be ascertained.”

He also raised the issue of special category status for Bihar, which has been a long pending demand of the JD(U). “Bihar legislative assembly had passed a resolution that the state be accorded special category status and special package be given to it. The Centre should look into it,” Lallan said.

Title: Police arrest gang of four highway robbers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik rural police on Monday arrested four people in connection with a pick-up van robbery that took place on January 18 near Tehere village on the section between Malegaon and Dhule.

The suspects have been identified as Gorakh Gangurde, Sunil Dagale, Rohit Gangurde, and Niranjan Mangale. According to police, they were arrested from Dindori and Ozar Township areas, and have confessed to have committed the crime.

“In the wee hours of January 18, the suspects had stopped the driver of the pick-up vehicle, threatened him with a country-made firearm and had decamped with the vehicle, driver’s cellphone and cash — all amounting to Rs 5.60 lakh,” a police officer said.

Working on the instructions of SP Arti Singh, the Local Crime Branch (LCB) personnel checked the modus operandi of the crime and arrested the suspects.

“After robbing the pick-up vehicle, the criminals disassembled it four days later at Khedgaon. They had decided to sell off the spare parts and distribute the money among them,” the officer said.

“We got information that the trolley of the pick-up was sold to a person in Niphad taluka. We detained him for questioning and he gave us the name of the man who helped the criminals in disposing away other spare parts,” he added.

The police said that they have recovered spare parts of the vehicle concerned, the van used for committing the crime, two another pick-up vehicles on which the spare parts were fixed — all worth Rs 13.62 lakh.

“We are investigating if the suspects had committed similar crimes in the past. A large number of people travel by the Mumbai Agra highway and other highways passing through the rural district on a daily basis. Given the possibility of such people getting robbed during the night hours, personnel of all police stations conduct patrolling on the highways and other important roads in their respective jurisdictions,” he added.

Title: ‘Failed’ candidates add to talent pool too
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

By Sujaya Banerjee

At one organisation I worked, we regularly hired fresh chartered accountants to join as management trainees in the audit department. We would hire them in large numbers and be left with a handful at the end of every 12-18 months. Most of the trainees left for better assignments/roles, as they found audit work repetitive and non-stimulating, especially on the back of three years of audit work they had already completed as a part of their CA articleship.

A new president for the audit team joined soon thereafter and described this as insanity — doing the same thing repeatedly and expecting a new outcome each time. His frustration forced us to go back to the drawing board to explore new solutions to build talent pipelines for the audit function.

The exercise proved to be an eye-opener as we began exploring all the alternate talent pools available to us across entry levels from inside and outside the organisation. Externally, we had commerce graduates and those with master’s in commerce as available pools, and we could also perhaps consider more CAs for the next-level roles. We listed the following:

* Engineers already familiar with the plants’ operations could be included through the internal job posting process

* QA/QC or procurement executives who may want a career in audit

* CAs already in the system who would want to explore joining mid-level positions

* BCom and MCom graduates who generally have no placement support in college

We brainstormed till we suddenly hit upon an interesting talent pool we had not considered before — CA ‘inter-fail’! This group is large in India, given the stringent pass marks in the CA exams, and has no real career opportunities in except accounting-related jobs. We clarified with our talent-acquisition teams that we would treat them as graduates with 3-plus years of work experience and immediately set about finding this group. We hired 20 in the first year and soon hit a treasure trove. This pool was mature, diligent with great humility to learn and deliver results. We had a great experience and 100% retention in Year 1. We had now tasted blood.

We hired another 30 in the next year and this became a great success story of new talent contribution and retention. This experience urged us to question the stigma of ‘Failed’ on many who attempt competitive exams and don’t pass tests for coveted programmes like IIT-JEE, CAT and UPSC.

What happens to the large numbers who fail these exams every year? Even worse, what about the ones who attempt these exams several times and are not successful. If we remove the stigma and our bias of failure, it is imminently possible to find people with aspiration, with otherwise great academic records, good critical thinking, analytical thinking capability, general knowledge and good communication skills. What’s more, many are humbled by the experience of having failed and are open to new learning opportunities and alternate careers. In fact, early wins in their new careers can quickly lift confidence levels that have taken a beating with repeated failure experiences.

Every year, 12 lakh of the 14 lakh candidates who attempt IIT-JEE do not clear the JEE Main. The cut-off for JEE Main is often 100 — How normal does that sound? CAT has about 2 lakh exam takers, out of which 5,000 pass to make it to some IIMs and 5,000 make it to other leading MBA schools. There are other entrance programmes for various streams that also have stringent cut-offs, with large numbers not making it to the programmes they intended to join. Despite this, the latest India Skills Report indicates only 46.21% of graduates and post-graduates are employable from these talent pools. In fact, it also indicates that at least 40% of the employable management students remain invisible to recruiters because they lie beyond the top 1,000 campuses. Also, interestingly, the report indicates that at least 60% of management graduates do not make it to deserving jobs as they lack the appropriate levels of English needed. There are various reasons attributed to poor employability, ranging from K12 education, selection procedure to graduate colleges, curriculum, quality of teaching, student interest and the lack of corporate involvement.

Unfortunately, most of these reasons have a huge part to play in this challenge that has no quick and easy solutions. Most graduates/post-graduates are left to their own devices to improve if there is sufficient awareness around the gaps to enhance their employability quotient.

Robust entry-level programmes offered by employers can help, but many organisations do not invest in these development efforts and leave new talent to their own devices to learn on the job.

At entry levels, employers broadly look for a mix of aptitude, language, personality and domain skills in selecting the right candidate. The detailed fine-tuning normally happens based on the job role they may be hiring for. College learning outcomes rated as most important are oral communication, critical thinking, ethical judgment, working effectively in teams, written communication and the real-world application of skills and knowledge.

Interestingly, these attributes can be developed better through a liberal arts programme rather than the technical, science, math courses that we have come to value to the exclusion of other streams.

A diverse workforce is a catalyst for growth

Conscious and unconscious biases, trapped in old thinking and past practices, may well be in your way if you find yourself with a too narrow a talent pool. It is time to throw out the uncreative, plug-and-play hiring, and open your organisation to well-considered, inclusive and innovative hiring approaches that can reap richer dividends:

* Foster a culture that embraces diversity in a powerful way to attract great employees. Up to 67% of job searchers want to work for companies that have a diverse workforce. Especially the ‘woke millennial’ generation values this to consider you a contemporary employer

* Organisations need to deliberately reach out to diverse pools that can bring socio-cognitive diversity (people with different education, exposures, experiences, religious beliefs). Gender, generational diversities, persons with disabilities — many of which will need to be deliberately sought until we strengthen these talent pools in society

* Consider diverse interview panelists as well to represent the diversity you want to see in the workplace

Conscious and unconscious biases are more significantly in our way than we would like to admit. Community, socio-economic class, appearance, education, past failures and our likes/dislikes and experiences with this can very significantly come in the way of giving people opportunities. Constant awareness training and communication around the theme of biases and leaders’ role-modelling inclusion is a powerful way of combating this.

Here’s how you can stop expeditious hiring by not repeating past patterns and old thinking — look for hidden talent to expand the pool:

* Deliberately explore education streams and disciplines you have not hired before. Focus on the attributes you need most for the job and identify talent pools who could deliver to these attributes or could be trained easily, if you had no past policy/practice/resource constraints to access them. Explore, experiment, include!

* Veterans/retirees are a good pool to explore even as we are heading to become the youngest talent pool in the world. Experienced retirees are often knowledgeable, disciplined, committed people, and now — with increased life expectancy and longevity — can become great mentors to talent and a great pool to pick from

* Seasoned gig workers in addition to talent-on-demand — this labour pool can save employers cost and can deliver high-quality services with greater flexibility

* Apprenticeship programmes can offer a good source of entry-level talent that can be groomed and prepared through backward integration to create a robust talent pipeline through offering on-the-job-training exposures

* Customers, not current, but if you know of their talent and they know & like your organisation and there are no conflicts of interest, then why not?

* If you exclude 50% of your talent pool, no wonder you find yourself in a war for talent. While most organisations are making commendable efforts to attract entry-level female talent, including lateral hiring, there is a challenge of both availability and inclusion, which are symbiotically linked to each other. More deliberate actions in this space can increase the talent pool and enable a significantly talented and educated diverse group become economically relevant

Enhancing inclusion in the workplace and making this a pre-condition to leadership positions, both internally and while hiring, can help increase retention and enable organisations accrue the many benefits of a diverse workforce — increased productivity, teamwork, creativity and innovation. Here are some good questions to ask to get started:

* What are our organisation’s definitions of ability, competence, performance?

* How can we deliberately create an inclusive culture?

* How can we keep our brand promise of being an equal opportunities employer?

* How can we redefine our hiring policies and practices to remove biases trapped in past habits?

* Can we consider revisiting the education criteria we have defined for our jobs, so we can explore new talent pools not considered? (Failures from competitive exams; candidates who don’t speak good English (English can be learned!); persons with disability)

* Can we ask diverse employees for suggestions on improving initiatives for attracting more diverse talent?

* Can we consider late-career progressions and figure out how to include talented women through flexible schedules on the gig economy?

Talent acquisition is a powerful mechanism for not only changing the culture of your organisation by including new groups and providing new opportunities, but also shaping the society. Talent is abundantly present, if only we moved out of the quagmire of past habits and deficit narrow thinking, to find fresh treasure troves of real talent.

(The writer is founder & CEO of Capstone People Consulting )

Title: Sussanne Khan gets HC relief
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Swati Deshpande | TNN

Mumbai: In a relief for Sussanne Khan, ex-wife of actor Hritik Roshan, the Bombay high court on Tuesday upheld an arbitral award in her favour over a claim of over Rs 2.5 crore. A bench of Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog and Justice Bharati Dangre dismissed a plea by Mudhit Gupta and Emgee Properties of Goa.

The bench said, “On a deeper scrutiny of the award, we are satisfied about the exercise of juridical power by the arbitrator and the refusal to interfere in the same by the learned single judge on a footing that it is not permissible to reassess or re-appreciate evidence or examine the sufficiency of evidence.”

Gupta, represented by counsel Simil Purohit and Lexim Associates, had challenged the legal validity of a 2018 arbitral award that upheld the claim of Khan, who is the sole proprietor of Sussanne Khan House of Design.
