The HC observed, “Akin to a banyan tree which is characterised by aerial roots which hang from its leaves, the submissions of Purohit float all over in the air desperately, in an attempt to cling on and envelope the case of his opponent and begin its life as an epiphyte.”

The HC also observed that Khan’s counsel Sharan Jagtiani and Parinam Law argued that the arbitrator “hit the bullseye” and rightly granted her the claim as “one flowing from the contract”. The contract was of 2013 and pertained to her “professional designing services” being hired for a villa project in Goa.

“There being no error apparent on the face of award and no grounds for interference being in existence”, the HC refused to “inter-meddle”. Thus, putting a quietus to the dispute at its end. The order can be challenged and taken to the apex court.

Title: Bihar: Man kills wife for opposing illicit relation
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

BIHARSHARIF: A woman was strangled in Nalanda on Monday night for opposing her husband’s alleged illicit relation with the wife of his elder brother.

According to police sources, the accused was identified as Munna Kumar of Powari village under Harnaut police station area. Bum Shankar Singh , the father of the deceased Neha alias Nilu Kumari, said in his police complaint that he had got his daughter married to Munna in 2015. “Munna always ignored and tortured my daughter, calling her ugly. Later, it was found that he was in relationship with the wife of his elder brother. When my daughter opposed it, she was beaten up and strangled on Monday night,” Singh, who is from Langarpur under Barh police station area in Patna district, alleged in his police complaint.

He said some villagers informed him about the incident over phone late Monday night. When he reached Powari with Harnaut police, he found the body of his daughter lying in one of the rooms with no one in the house. He alleged that she was also tortured for dowry. Two other family members of Munna have been made accused.

Harnaut police station house officer Chandra Shekhar Singh said the body was handed over to her father after postmortem at Biharsharif Sadar hospital. He said action will be taken after getting postmortem and investigation reports expected in a couple of days.

Title: Patna: Two cops injured as SI aspirants go on rampage
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: Over 500 aspirants for different posts in state police went on a rampage near Gandhi Maidan in the city on Tuesday demanding CBI inquiry into alleged leak of question papers of Bihar police sub-inspector recruitment examination.

At least two constables were injured when protesters pelted police with stones at JP roundabout. Police resorted to lathicharge and arrested four of the protesters. The incident took place around 12 noon when candidates marched towards JP roundabout from Bhikhna Pahadi while alleging question papers leak.

The results of preliminary examination conducted by Bihar Police Subordinate Selection Commission (BPSSC) was declared on January 28. Exams were conducted in two shifts across 495 centres on December 22. At least 5.85 lakh candidates had appeared in examination for altogether 2446 posts of police sub-inspector, sergeant and assistant jail superintendent.

Gandhi Maidan police station SHO Sunil Kumar said all efforts were made to pacify candidates but they blocked traffic near Magadh Mahila College and pelted stones on the policemen deployed near JP roundabout.

“They started forcibly closing shops in the area and marched forward after which water cannon was used to disperse them. The protesters started pelting stones on police personnel and two constables were injured. Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse them. Four persons were arrested,” he said.

The agitating students alleged that questions and their answer keys were leaked on social media even before the commencement of examination. “We demand CBI inquiry into question paper leak,” they chanted.

When contacted, BPSSC’s OSD-cum-spokesperson Ashok Kumar Prasad told TOI that no incriminating material had surfaced before the commission to support candidates’ allegations of paper leak. “One Dilip Kumar, along with other candidates, had met us with a piece of paper claiming that it was a part of the leaked question. However, that was not true. They were convinced and returned. We are looking into the involvement of touts or coaching institutes in instigating the candidates,” he said, adding none of the district magistrates across state informed the commission about any paper leak.

He said 50,072 candidates cleared the preliminary examination. “The commission provided data of disqualified students and reasons behind their failure to qualify for the main exam. We had lodged 10 FIRs across the state where OMR sheet or questions were uploaded to social media sites,” he said and added that mostly failed candidates were involved in the protests.

Prasad said the commission is to conduct main examination either in the last week of April or first week of May after which physical efficiency test would be conducted for recruitment against the vacant posts.

Title: Intermediate exams: 94 examinees expelled
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Altogether 94 examinees were expelled for using unfair means whereas three impersonators were caught while writing the papers for others on the second day of Intermediate examination conducted by Bihar School Examination Board on Tuesday.

Two of the impersonators were arrested from Khagaria and one from Banka district.

According to a BSEB official, Madhepura had the maximum 18 expulsions, followed by nine each in Rohtas and Siwan, seven in Aurangabad, eight in Madhubani , five each in Nalanda and Saran, five each in Patna, Nawada, Arwal and Supaul, two each in Sitamarhi, Samastipur, Saharsa, Khagaria and Sheikhpura, and one each in Motihari, Sheohar, Darbhanga, Bhagalpur, Munger and Begusarai.

BSEB chairman Anand Kishor said the expelled candidates would be barred from the rest of the examination. “I have asked the invigilators to strictly monitor each and every candidate till the last day of the exam,” he said.

Around 8.07 lakh candidates appeared for Class XII chemistry, political science and English for vocational stream students at 1,283 centres across the state.

Meanwhile, regional centres at Patna, Gaya, Bhagalpur, Darbhanga, Muzaffarpur, Purnia, Chhapra , Munger and Saharsa have shifted to its permanent office buildings on Tuesday. The new regional centres of Bihar Board were inaugurated by CM Nitish Kumar on January 27.

Title: Nitish Kumar: JD(U) new national team likely after Delhi results
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: JD(U) is likely to announce its national office-bearers soon after the Delhi assembly poll results on February 11.

Sources in JD(U) said party president and Bihar CM Nitish Kumar , during his recent stay in the national capital, discussed the issue with senior party leaders. “Though the reconstitution of national team is already due following the re-election of Nitish as the party’s national president in October last year, the matter got a fresh momentum after unceremonious expulsion of Prashant Kishor and Pavan K Varma from the party,” a senior leader told TOI on Tuesday.

Kishor and Varma were expelled from JD(U) for “anti-party activities” on January 29 this year after months of their bitter differences with Nitish over Citizenship (Amendment) Act and certain related issues.

Their expulsion led to further shrinking in the strength of the party’s national office-bearers. Poll strategist Kishor was appointed JD(U)’s national vice-president by Nitish himself on October 16, 2018. Now that Kishor is out from the party, there is no vice-president in JD(U). Varma was the JD(U) national general secretary.

In November 2016, when Nitish had announced his first national team, there were nine national general secretaries, six national secretaries and one treasurer.

“In the last three years, three of the nine general secretaries left the party after Nitish decided to realign with the BJP in 2017. One more general secretary, Harivansh, quit the post after he was elected deputy chairperson of the Rajya Sabha in August 2018. In the meantime, Sanjay Jha and Afaque Ahmad Khan were made new general secretaries. Thus, there were seven general secretaries in the party till Varma was expelled, bringing down the number to six,” pointed out a party leader.

Title: Coronavirus in Patna: Two return from China, kept in isolation in Bettiah & Bhagalpur
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Two persons, who had returned from China last week, have been kept in isolation at their homes in Bettiah and Bhagalpur as a precautionary step against the deadly coronavirus (CoV).State surveillance officer Dr Ragani Mishra said, “As of now, no symptoms of CoV have been detected in any of them. But as a precautionary measure we have kept them under observation for 14 days.”Earlier, two people were kept under observation in Sitamarhi and Saran. “We tested both coronavirus suspects, one from Sitamarhi and the other from Saran. Their test reports ruled out CoV,” Mishra said.Amid fears of spread of a CoV spread, at least 4,295 people in the border areas and 1,467 passengers at Gaya airport have been subjected to thermal screening till February 2. However, no positive cases of coronavirus have been reported in state so far.The state health department has alerted hospital superintendents, civil surgeons, and officials at state airports and border areas to keep a check on people travelling from China and Nepal.“We have started working in various parts of the state, especially in the districts situated near the Nepal border. Camps are being set up in the border areas for keeping an eye on people with even minimal symptoms,” Mishra said.She added: “More than 3,381 health workers have been appointed to spread awareness about the deadly disease in every district. DMs are also holding Gram Sabha meetings with panchayat members and anganwadi workers. Altogether 275 gram sabha meetings have been held so far for which 783 Panchayati Raj Institution members were appointed by the health department.”In the state capital, doctors have advised residents not to panic, but take precautions. PMCH medical superintendent Bimal Kumar Karak said coronavirus has symptoms similar to viral fever and respiratory problems.“People should take extra care of themselves as well as their family members. They should make sure they wear masks while commuting on the roads. Besides, they should seek medical aid even if they get a simple cold or cough,” Karak said.City residents are worried about the coronavirus scare . “Being an asthma patient, I frequently get breathing issues. These days, I have to take extra precautions due to coronavirus. I make sure that I don’t leave my house without wearing a mask. I have asked my family members and friends to do the same,” Ankita Sinha, a resident of Saguna Mor, said.

Title: Two construction firm staff killed, RLSP man shot at
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA/BEGUSARAI: Two workers of a private road construction company were shot late on Monday evening adding to the soaring number of murder cases in Begusarai . This politically volatile district saw 97 murders till November last year, according to the state crime record bureau.

The latest incident, which took place at Bharaul village under Bachhwara police station, came barely 48 hours after two youths were killed under Balia police station in the district.

The murders of the two construction workers came to light on Tuesday morning when local residents spotted the two bodies lying in a pool of blood. Reports said the two workers---Md. Qaiser Alam (25) and Rajnish Kumar (26)—were shot dead while they were asleep at the company’s base camp office at Bharaul.

The police have not rule out the extortion angle as the reason behind the killing of the two workers of Sona Infra Private Ltd, which was awarded the contract for the construction of a 2.5 km road under the Mukhya Mantri Sadak Yojna. Sources said a local gangster had demanded extortion money from the caretaker, Rajnish Kumar, last week.

“The matter was reported to the local police but they did not pay any heed. The extortionists had given a deadline for the payment of extortion money,” said an engineer with the company supervising the construction work, which was stalled after the extortion demand and subsequent threats to the workers.

Begusarai SP Awakash Kumar admitted that the Bachhwara police were informed about the firing by anti-socials at the base camp office a few days ago. “The police had asked the officials to inform before resuming construction work, which they did not do. This gave the criminals a chance to attack at the base camp,” the SP said.

Kumar, however, parried questions on police’s failure to deploy forces at the camp office as a precautionary measure. Teghra SDPO Ashish Anand, who visited the spot on Tuesday morning, said the camp office of the company is located at an isolated place, which made the task difficult for the police.

The bodies of Md. Qiser Alam, a resident of Vaishali district, and Rajnish Kumar, a native of Muzaffarpur district, were handed over to their families after the post mortem examination at the Sadar hospital.

The spate of murders has raised a question mark over the law and order situation in the district. Last year, the state government had created a new post of DIG and posted an IPS officer Rajesh Kumar to bring the situation under control. “Despite the posting of a DIG-rank officer, the spate of murders continues. There is no fear of law,” said a local businessman Navin Kumar.

Even Union minister and BJP MP from Begusarai, Giriraj Singh, had no qualms about admitting that the residents were living under fear due to the deteriorating law and order situation in the district. “The situation is not up to the mark in Begusarai,” the MP’s representative Amrendra Kumar Amar said.

CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar had also assailed the Begusarai police for their failure to check crime in the district.

Title: Bihar: Actor alleges ‘cheating’ by boyfriend from Munger
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: A 35-year-old actor from Mumbai has alleged physical and monetary exploitation by her boyfriend over four years on the pretext of marriage. The youth, Rahul Kumar, came in contact with the TV serial actor through Facebook about five years ago.

The actor, who claimed to have worked in the TV serials like Nimki Mukhiya, Gathbandhan and Crime Alert, got the ‘treachery’ of Rahul printed and pasted on the boundary walls and electric poles of Tarapur, a sub-divisional town in Munger district . Rahul, employed in a private firm, is now posted in Katihar.

The actor on Sunday contacted Tarapur SDPO Ramesh Kumar and submitted a petition seeking justice for her. In her petition, she alleged that Rahul exploited her both physically and economically for over four years on the pretext of marriage. The actor, who originally hails from Sultanpur in Uttar Pradesh , told the police that she got suspicious when Rahul asked her to transfer her ancestral property in his name and also made an agreement of marriage in Katihar civil court to win over her confidence.

“He (Rahul) started avoiding me when I turned down his proposal. I told her that it was not possible before marriage. I got suspicious when he didn’t pick up my phone calls,” the actor told the SDPO, who later assigned the Tarapur SHO to look into the matter.

When contacted, Tarapur SHO Amrendra Kumar said, “The woman met me yesterday. But I couldn’t spare much time for her as I had some other important assignments.” The SHO, however, said the accused’s family doesn’t live in Tarapur and has shifted to Katihar where he is posted.

The SDPO said police have limited role to play in such case. “But what is important is the woman’s claim of handing over Rs5 lakh to Rahul in the name of marriage. But that is not sufficient to initiate action against the accused. Moreover, the incident didn’t take place under our jurisdiction. That may be a technical problem,” the SDPO told this newspaper over phone on Monday.

Rahul’s father Anant Singh, whose name also figured in the pamphlets pasted on the walls and electric poles of the town, said the woman was trying to exploit his young son. “It’s true that my son and the woman know each other. They became friends through social media a few years ago,” he added.

Singh said the woman started exerting pressure on Rahul after she came to know about his marriage being finalized somewhere else. “She didn’t disclose to Rahul that she is already married and a mother of two. How could a married woman be allowed to solemnize her second marriage under the Hindu Marriage Act? For that, she has to divorce her husband first,” Rahul’s father said.

Even as the probe is underway in Munger, the actor has left for Katihar. “I will not let him go scot free. He (Rahul) is learnt to have ruined the career of at least four other girls on the pretext of marriage. One of them fell victim when he was doing his MBA,” the actor claimed.

Title: VCs’ opinion sought on inter-university transfer
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: Raj Bhavan has sought the opinion of the universities in Bihar on the draft statute relating to the inter-university transfer of non-teaching staff and also the modalities of appointment of new staff in colleges and universities.

In a letter sent to the vice-chancellors of all the universities, the law officer of Raj Bhavan has clarified that if no suggestion is received within 10 days of the receipt of the letter, it would be assumed that the university is in agreement with the draft statute.

Earlier, the governor-cum-chancellor had constituted a three-member committee comprising the VCs of Patna University, Nalanda Open University and Maulana Mazharul Haque Arabic and Persian University to draft the statute concerning the service conditions of non-teaching staff of colleges and universities. The committee prepared the statute and submitted it to Raj Bhavan last month. Now the same has been forwarded to the universities for their consideration and suggestions, if any.

Soon after the receipt of the Raj Bhavan letter PU, vice-chancellor Rash Bihari Prasad Singh constituted a committee consisting of PU registrar, deputy registrar, students’ welfare dean and librarian to study the draft statute minutely and give its opinion on the various provisions made therein.

Meanwhile, the Patna University Teachers’ Association and the Patna University Employees’ Association have opposed the proposed changes in the service conditions of PU employees, especially pertaining to their inter-university transfer. They pointed out that right since its inception, PU is governed by a separate Act, while all other universities in the state are being governed by a common Act. They threatened of agitation if the PU Act was amended.

Title: ED attaches Bhagalpur gangster’s property worth Rs8cr
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BHAGALPPUR/PATNA: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) on Tuesday attached movable and immovable property valued at Rs 8.38 crore of notorious gangster Jai Prakash Mandal and his close relatives under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PLMA), 2002.

ED sources said the central agency initiated the probe into the ill-gotten property of Mandal on the recommendation of EOU, which was created to carry out investigation into the wealth of people amassed through unlawful means. Mandal is a resident of Naya Tola under the Industrial police station area in Bhagalpur district.

Altogether 12 FIRs related to loot, extortion, dacoity and gambling were lodged against Mandal, which prompted the ED to initiate investigation into illegal wealth in his name and also of his close relatives. Chargesheets were also filed in seven cases for contravention of various sections of IPC and Gambling Act.

The attached property included 45% part of Sri Ram Valley (includes flats, commercial area, parking area) at Mauza Fatehpur, Bhagalpur, worth Rs 4.07 crore, Shree Shopee Mart at Bhagalpur worth Rs 2.25 crore, land and structural part of JP Ratna Filling Station (HP Petrol Pump) in Bhagalpur worth Rs 7 lakh, two residential houses in the name of his wife Ratna Devi in Bhagalpur worth Rs 48 lakh, 37 landed property of Mandal, his wife and son Pravin Mandal worth Rs 1.25 crore.

The list of the property confiscated by the ED also included six vehicles valued at Rs 20.56 lakh and bank deposits worth Rs 1.96 crore. The ED claimed that the accused amassed movable and immovable property to the tune of Rs 8.38 crore in the name of his wife and son, mostly through cash transactions.

A senior official of the central financial probe agency said, “The accused have also diverted the land acquired out of proceeds of crime into various projects like marketing complexes in the name of Shoppe Mart, development of high-rise buildings with a developer, petrol pumps and residential buildings.”

ADG, EOU, Jitendra Singh Gangwar said the state police have launched a major crackdown against the criminals who have accumulated property through unlawful means. “The crackdown will continue in future,” he said and urged the people to inform the EOU about such anti-socials without any fear from them.

The ADG made it clear that the identity of the people sharing information about such anti-socials would be kept secret.

Title: Traffic hit as PU students block road
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PATNA: Vehicular traffic came to a standstill for several hours on Ashok Rajpath on Tuesday as students of Patna University (PU) and two of its constituent colleges – Patna College and B N College – staged protests over police’s failure to arrest the people who had attacked a Saraswati idol immersion procession and injured several students near Patna College on January 31.

The protesters blocked the road, burned tyres, forcibly shut down shops and shouted slogans like ‘Bharat Mata ki Jai’ andr ‘Jai Shri Ram’. The protests continued for around four hours.

The protesting students were also demanding payment of compensation to those injured in January 31 violence, their free treatment and raid on Lalbagh locality.

Mukesh Hinduja, a first-year student of PG Hindi department of Patna College, said inmates of Saidpur hostel and Minto hostel were carrying out the Saraswati idol immersion procession from PU campus to Rani Ghat on the night of January 31 when the trouble started.

“The procession was carried out with permissions from PU administration and district administration. ASP, DSP, SHO of Pirbahore police station and RAF jawans were keeping an eye on the procession. As soon as we reached near Lalbagh, the lights went out and the locals started throwing bombs and firing in air,” Hinduja said.

In the clash, one Avinash Kumar, a first-year economics student of B N College, sustained burn injuries. Satish Kumar, another first-year political science student of the same college, had also sustained bullet injury.

In retaliation, the students pelted stones targeting residential colonies at Lalbagh, in which several people, including police constables, were injured.

Ravi Kumar, a second-year political science student of B N College, said police had lodged complaint against 47 students of PU, Patna College and BN College for no reason. “We want justice for the students who got injured in the clash and arrest of the culprits who were behind the incident,” he said.

SHO of Pirbahore police station Rizwan Khan assured the students that the police would arrest those involved in the clash soon. “We are in the process of identifying the troublemakers,” the SHO said.

Title: E-sellers bet big on vintage cars, bikes
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Chennai: Want to buy a 1920s Austin? Or a 1940s Impala of the sort that you have long admired in black and white Bollywood hits?

You could now get your choice of vintage car and bike models from online platforms which are diversifying into this niche — but growing — category as a way of offering more choice for collectors and enthusiasts, opening up a sector which was hitherto a closed community.

Online pre-owned vehicle platforms including OLX, Mahindra First Choice Wheels and Droom among others are offering vintage cars and motorcycles (dating from the 1920s-1970s) as well as collectible cars and bikes for retro and vintage enthusiasts.

Although a small market, it is a growing one helped by online platforms stocking and selling parts for these rare vehicles.

OLX said its vintage car listings have doubled in 2019 compared to 2017.

Vintage bikes too, have emerged to be a popular category with 4,000+ bikes being listed in 2019. Overall, ad listings of vintage bikes attracted over 1 million views while vintage cars witnessed over 800k views per month in 2019.

OLX data also showed that the same cities were showing interest in both vintage cars and bikes — Chennai, Bengaluru, Delhi, Mumbai, Pune, Thiruvananthapuram, Coimbatore and Kochi.

For vintage bikes, there is a high demand from Hyderabad while Ooty and Jaipur are also attractive markets for vintage cars.

Mahindra First Choice Wheels has been seeing growing interest in older cult marques. “People come asking for older Harley Davidson, Jawa bikes and vintage Porsche and Mercedes models even though the actual sales are still quite small.”

Online marketplace Droom has also been offering vintage cars and bikes as an option.

“We offer this category but the pool is very small. There are only under 5,000 units of vintage vehicles in India (between 1920-1970 vintage). The rest are all collectibles,” said Sandeep Aggarwal, founder, and CEO, Droom.

According to OLX VP-auto Sunny Kataria, the interest in vintage models on online platforms is mostly as an investible category.

“Vintage automobiles are a prized possession not only among collectors but are seen as a lucrative alternative asset class by HNIs who see this as an appreciating asset. Traditionally, collecting vintage cars was a niche hobby but the rise of online marketplaces has breathed a new lease of life for these marvels from the past,” he added.

According to automotive writer and vintage car enthusiast Ranojoy Mukerji online purchase of vintage vehicles will face road blocks like incomplete papers.

“These are cars which often don’t have ownership documents or documents regarding providence,” he said.

“So you buy a vintage vehicle based on trust and people often buy from friends and trusted dealers. Everything in this market is underground although sometimes the ticket sizes are quite big.”

Last year a couple of cars were sold at a price of Rs 2.5-Rs 3 crore, he added.

Title: Corona virus lockdown may create hiccups for Motown
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Chennai: The lockdown in Wuhan province of China due spread of Coronavirus could disrupt the production schedule of Indian vehicle makers — both petrol/ diesel as well as electric.

Currently stock levels are tight due to the BS4 to BS6 changeover and the Chinese new year. Added to that, say parts sourcing officials in OEMs including Mahindra, Maruti and Toyota, if the lockdown continues beyond the February 9 deadline, production of vehicles may get affected.

Wuhan is a hub for electric and electronic parts and even though Indian car or bike makers may not be directly sourcing from them, tier-1, tier-2 or tier-3 component suppliers do have strong Chinese supply links. China is a huge part of the global sourcing network and the current blockade will begin to pinch once the existing stock in shipments, factories or dealerships start running out. The electric vehicle industry will be worse affected because it is more import — and China — dependent particularly for lithium ion cells.

“Right now Wuhan is completely shut down. Other provinces like Wuxi, Shenzhen and Guangzhou are supposed to open from February 9. So companies that have suppliers in any of these places are stuck. Wuhan is not likely to open up before February 16. And when it opens, there will be such a crush that getting materials out of China will be a problem with the ports clogged,” said Hemant Sikka, president-CPO, Powerol & spares business, M&M. Mahindra, is covered till February 15. “The trouble is if you need 4,000 parts for a vehicle and only 2 of these are unavailable, your assembly line gets stuck,” said Sikka. “Most of the imports from these provinces are electronic parts like chips or the PCB. “We have enough stock for one more week but the trouble is the window is only for two weeks after which we have to switch to BS6,” said Sikka. “So a lockdown like this creates more problems.” Of course most companies are in wait and watch mode right now.

“Our tier-I and tier-II suppliers are not yet effected, however we are continuously monitoring the operations of tier-III and tier-IV suppliers to grasp any possible slowdown that may come forth,” said Naveen Soni, senior VP, sales & service, Toyota Kirloskar Motor.

Electric vehicles makers will be worst hit.“Considering the fact that the Indian EV market is not evolved enough to sustain an end to end manufacturing of all components, manufacturers are compelled to import certain parts from China and other markets. Corona virus has spread beyond China and has also affected Taiwan, Korea and other southeast Asian countries resulting in disruption of export at major ports,” said Naveen Munjal, MD, Hero Electric.

“Due to the Chinese new year, heavy shipments were supposed to begin from January 31, now it will come in March,” said Sohinder Gill, director-general, Society of Manufacturers of Electric Vehicles. Beyond that, the biggest road block will be lithium ion cells which are all imported, said Gill.

Title: Deposit cover of Rs 5L made operational
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mumabi: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has operationalised the government’s decision to hike deposit insurance cover to Rs 5 lakh from Rs 1 lakh with effect from February 4. “With a view to providing a greater measure of protection to depositors in banks the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the RBI, has raised the limit of insurance cover for depositors in insured banks from the present level of Rs1 lakh to Rs 5 lakh per depositor with effect from February 4, 2020 with the approval of Government,” RBI said in a statement. Speaking to TOI, Rajkiran Rai , MD & CEO, Union Bank of India, said banks have not yet been notified of the increase in premium. “But we do expect the cost of insurance to go up,” he said.

Finance ministry officials have indicated after the Budget that the rates will be uniform and the rates would not be risk-based. “The banks cannot pass on the hike in premiums to its customers, according to the norms. The premium won’t go up substantially in any case and may be hiked to 12-13 paise (per deposit of Rs 100 a year),” finance secretary Rajiv Kumar said in a media interaction. According to Rai, so far all the claims on deposit insurance have been from co-operative banks.

Title: Patna: Wife’s illicit relation cost teacher life, brother held
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on Tuesday arrested slain TPS College associate professor Shivnarayan Ram’s youngest brother Virendra Ram (45), his friend Shailendra Kishore (48) and four others for their alleged involvement in the murder under Kankarbagh police station on January 29.

Police said Virendra, who is unmarried, was having illicit relation with Shivnarayan’s wife for over ten years and decided to get rid of him. Shivnarayan (52) was shot dead near Postal Park when he was going to the college on foot from his residence in East Indira Nagar.

According to police, Virendra is in merchant navy while Shailendra owns a medical shop named Dhanmati Ambika Agency on Govind Mitra Road. The four other arrested were identified as Vikash Kumar, Dheeraj Kumar, Amarjeet Kumar and Prem Sagar. They are aged between 25 and 30 years.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said the pistol used in the crime had been seized. “Six cellphones, a two-wheeler used in the crime and one live cartridge were also seized from them,” he said.

The SSP said the family members quarrelled frequently as Virendra was having illicit relation with Shivnarayan’s wife. “The deceased used to live in another room separate from his wife inside family residence,” he said. Police came to know about the family tension during investigation.

Sharma said it was Kishore who had paid Rs2 lakh to Prem on January 30 for completing the task a day before. “Vikash had shot the professor in his head from behind,” he said, adding criminals had attempted to kill Shivnarayan even on January 22, but failed. “Virendra had returned from sea in November last year,” he said.

Out of the four criminals, only Prem and Amarjeet had earlier been to jail for consuming liquor.

Title: Youth forced to marry in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In yet another case of Pakadua vivah , a youth was forced to marry a girl at gunpoint after being kidnapped from village Chanda under Athmalgola police station in rural Patna on December 7 last year.

The matter was reported to police on January 2 after which an FIR was lodged with Athmalgola police station on Monday on the written complaint of the victim.

SHO Uttam Kumar said the victim is 21-year-old Bittu Paswan. Quoting the FIR, the SHO said his fellow villager Vivek Yadav had asked Bittu to accompany him to Nalanda on December 7 last year. “Both went to Nehusa under Harnaut police station where Bittu observed that marriage preparation was going on in the house where he was taken by Vivek. After spending few hours, Bittu got suspicious and tried to flee from the spot. However, he was captured,” the SHO said.

He said Bittu was forcibly married to a girl at gunpoint and was sent back to Chanda. He said after two days of marriage, Bittu received threat calls to keep mum and live with the girl. “Out of fear, he fled to Delhi. He retuned recently after which we contacted him and got an FIR lodged,” the SHO said.

He said Bittu told police that he had visited the girl’s house twice earlier. “Vivek had taken him there on both the occasions. The matter is being investigated. Vivek along with Indal Paswan and Rudal Paswan from girl’s family had been made named accused in the FIR,” he said.

Bittu’s father Devendra Paswan told this newspaper on phone that he is a sharecropper in the village. “The girl lived with us for three days after which her family members took her back. We had been threatened by few people who knew the girl’s family,” he added.

Title: Sheikhpura violence: 35 women among 235 booked
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

BIHARSHARIF: The Sheikhpura police on Tuesday lodged an FIR against 235 people, including 35 women, for rioting, blocking roads, trying to set a shrine on fire and misbehaving with policemen on February 2.

A large number of irate supporters and sympathisers of Ariyari block president of JD(U) Amit Vashisht alias Nand Kishore Kushwaha, who was killed on February 1, had blocked road for several hours near Patel Chowk in Sheikhpura the next day.

They also partially damaged a shrine near Dallu Chowk and misbehaved with policemen. Kushwaha was killed in a clash between two groups during Saraswati idol immersion procession at Sanayya village under the Ariyari police station area in the district.

SHO of Sheikhpura sadar police station Chandan Kumar said 200 men and 35 women were booked for rioting. He said the protesters had blocked road near Patel Chowk and set a shop on fire near sadar hospital, besides burning logs of wood near Dallu Chowk.

Meanwhile, SHO of Korma police station Ranjan Kumar was injured while trying to calm two warring groups during immersion of Goddess Saraswati’s idol at Deeh Kosumbha village on Monday.

Title: Buyer of minority stake in pvt co has to deposit 50% of cost
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Promoters with a 75% stake can now make an offer to buy out minority shareholders from an unlisted public or private firm, according to a February 3 notification by the ministry of corporate affairs ( MCA ) on amendments to the Companies Act . Prior to this notification, only promoters with a 90% stake could buy out the remaining 10%.

“Majority shareholders through special resolution always had an ability to cause reduction of capital and achieve squeeze-out of minority shareholders,” said Economic Laws Practice partner Darshan Upadhyay. “The new provisions provide an avenue under compromise and amalgamation arrangements to approach company law tribunal for such takeovers. The minority shareholders, subject to the prescribed threshold and conditions, will have the right to object,” Upadhyay added.

Promoters choose to squeeze out minority shareholders to exercise greater control over the firm and to take advantage of easier compliance norms. The February 3 notification also stipulated that promoters must determine the offer price after taking into account the fair value of the company and that 50% of the total acquisition cost must be deposited in a separate bank account.

“MCA has now introduced these rules to provide for the takeover offer...The application made for such a takeover with company law tribunal must give details of the valuation of shares done by a registered valuer, considering such parameters of valuation as provided in the rules,” said J Sagar Associates’ partner Lalit Kumar .

Squeezing out minority shareholders in Indian companies has always been difficult. Some local arms of multinationals in which the foreign parent holds more than 90% still haven’t been able to push out minority shareholders despite these companies getting delisted from stock exchanges years ago.

It may be a challenge to implement the new rule in certain companies like Tata Sons , which reportedly was valued at $49 billion, said industry observers. If Tatas intend to buy out minority shareholder Shapoorji Pallonji (SP) Group from Tata Sons, then existing shareholders__public charitable Tata Trusts and Tata companies__will have to deposit half of the total payout for the acquisition with a bank. But, public charitable trusts are restricted by law from investing in equity shares of a company.

“The new provisions may have some unintended consequences that need to be protected. For example, in a downside situation majority shareholders (promoters) should not be allowed to force the investors to exit at a price lower than their investment value. The shareholders’ agreement would have to be negotiated to provide some entranced provisions to block such actions,” said Upadhyay.

Title: TVS Motor Q3 net dips 32%; declares 210% interim dividend
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Chennai: TVS Motor Company recorded just over 32% drop in net profits at Rs 121.1 crore for the third quarter ended December 2019 on the back of lower sales. The board has declared an interim dividend of 210% or Rs 2.1 per share.

However, this includes a provision of Rs 76.04 crore towards National Calamity Contingent Duty (NCCD) which the company had reversed in the previous quarter based on a favourable ruling by CESTAT.

However, following the Supreme Court directive that NCCD is leviable, the company, has reinstated the provision of Rs 76.04 crore as an “exceptional item”.

Profit After Tax for Q3FY20 before factoring in the exceptional item is Rs 184.2 crore, up just over 3%.

TVS Motor's Q3 two-wheeler sales including exports was at 7.73 lakh units down from 9.5 lakh units last Q3. Motorcycle sales were flat at 3.25 lakh units as against 3.78 lakh units last year. Scooter sales were down to 2.8 lakh units as against 3.54 lakh units last Q3. Total three-wheeler sales, however, grew by 22% to 48,391 units from 39,629 units in the quarter ended December 2018. The total exports grew by 22.6% to 2.17 lakh units up from 1.77 lakh units last year. TVS stock fell 3.5% on the BSE on Tuesday to close at Rs 454.6.

Title: Modi govt pursuing divide and rule policy: Kanhaiya Kumar
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

DARBHANGA: CPI functionary and former JNU Students’ Union president Kanhaiya Kumar on Tuesday said the nationwide protests against CAA, NRC and NPR were an inclusive fight for protecting the democracy and Constitution of India.

“The NDA government is trying to polarise people on the basis of religion in pursuance of ‘divide and rule’ formula of Britishers. Deluge of promises by the central government was followed by drought of actions. This is neither a fight by any political party nor by people of a religion. This is for strengthening the secular fabric of the nation,” Kanhaiya said while addressing a public meeting at Raj Ground here as part of his ‘Save Constitution, Save Citizenship Satyagraha’ yatra.

The former JNUSU president had started his yatra from Bapudham Ashram in West Champaran on January 30. “People are protesting the divisive laws enacted by the Centre at most places we have visited under this yatra. We can call it a household protest against the sectarian law,” he said.

Attacking the Narendra Modi government at the Centre on the issue of unemployment, Kanhaiya said, “Unemployment rate has hit a 45-year-high in the country and controversial laws like CAA have been brought to divert the attention of common people.”

He added, “Before taking over as PM, Modi used to say in 2014 general election rallies that he would not allow anyone to sell the country, but national assets like LIC and Air India are today on the verge of being sold. Migration of people from Mithilanchal is highest in the country due to poverty in the region.”

Kanhaiya concluded his speech by inviting people to attend the rally scheduled to be held at Gandhi Maidan in Patna February 29 to mark the culmination of his yatra.

Title: Liquor worth Rs 1.23 crore seized in Araria
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

ARARIA: The excise officials with the help of local police seized about 12,356 litres of India made foreign liquor (IMFL) of over Rs1.23 crore from four trucks near Haria Bara toll Plaza situated on Araria-Forbesganj NH-57 on Monday. The trucks were coming from West Bengal . Three truck drivers were arrested.

Police sources said the huge quantity of IMFL was being taken to Samastipur. The trucks had Punjab registration numbers.

Araria SDPO K D Singh said a truck was intercepted on a tip-off. “The driver was arrested and he revealed that three more trucks full of IMFL with Punjab registration numbers were parked in the same area,” the SDPO said.

Araria excise superintendent Ashutosh Kumar said three trucks parked near a dhaba at Araria Zero Mile were seized.

The arrested drivers were identified as Prem Singh and Jagdip Singh from Dugri police station area under Ludhiana district and Guruprit Singh from Sahnewal police station area in Punjab. They did not disclose the names of the kingpin.

According to excise and police sources, around 69,00 criminal cases have been registered under different sections of Bihar Prohibition and Excise Act 2016, in which about around 8,000 offenders have been arrested so far. Besides, 25,000 litres of IMFL and around 15,000 litres of country-made liquor have been seized in the district till date.

Araria DM Baidyanath Yadav also admitted that the neighbouring areas in West Bengal have become a hub for smuggling liquor in Bihar and four police constables will be deployed near Jahanpur toll plaza under Jokihat on NH-327 E as the vehicles carrying liquor mostly pass through that route.

Title: Coronavirus in Nashik: Doctors sensitized about how to combat coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Senior medical officer of Nashik civil hospital Pramod Gunjal shared insights about the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) with government doctors and private practitioners in the city at a workshop on Monday.The workshop was organised by Rotary International Nashik Enclave, in association with the Nashik branch of the Indian Medical Association (IMA), Nashik Municipal Corporation and Nashik civil hospital.Gunjal said that the Government of India had started screening the passengers arriving at the Mumbai, Delhi and Kolkata airports from countries affected by the virus. The suspected people and their close family and friends would be surveyed under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP).Gunjal said that all the agencies were working towards checking patients suffering from influenza like illnesses and severe acute respiratory infection.He further guided the doctors on which samples of the suspected patients were required and how they should be sent to the National Institute of Virology in Pune.Former president of IMA Nashik Avesh Palod said that many myths and rumourS surrounding coronavirus that went viral on social media were busted at the workshop.President of IMA Nashik Prashant Deore assured co-operation on behalf of the medical fraternity in combating the outbreak.Asha Venugopal, a member of the Rotary Club, thanked medical officer Pramod Gunjal for making the doctors and laymen aware about coronavirus.

Title: Official: Delete names of voters featuring in two places
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

UDUPI: Udupi district voter’s list observer Munish Moudgil on Tuesday directed the Udupi district administration to delete names of voters that feature in two places, from the place where the voter is not an ordinary resident.

It is possible for the Election Commission to ascertain such cases using a software, which cross references the photographs of voters in voters’ lists.

This list is then given to booth level officers for physical verification, Moudgil said. During verification, names of voters will be removed from the place where they are not residing anymore, Moudgil, commissioner, survey, settlement and land records and ex-officio director Bhoomi and UPOR, said. “The district administration should take into consideration objections of political parties and work towards preparing a voters list that is free from errors and duplication, to ensure successful conduct of polls,” he said.

While undertaking the task of revision of voters list, directions given by the Election Commission on ensuring population to voters’ ratio for every assembly or parliamentary constituency should be followed. It there are variations, officials should undertake field visits to reverify the same, he said.

Title: Coronavirus effect: Out-of-bounds China market hits Rajasthan businesses
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The out-of-bounds China market is having a ripple effect on businesses in Rajasthan with jewellers in Jaipur estimating that postponement of Hong Kong jewellery show could shave off the industry business worth Rs 150-200 crore. Besides, marble, granite and tourism industries are also feeling the heat.Ajay Kala, secretary of Jaipur Chamber of Commerce & Industry, who is a regular at the Hong Kong International Jewellery Show, said, “Yes, the show has been postponed to May. More than 150 jewellers from Rajasthan participate in the show which has over the years become an important showcasing platform for us. But now, there is lot of uncertainty for the next 10 days at least. All the businesses will suffer significantly in case the situations worsens in China.”Jewellers in Jaipur say they used to generate business worth Rs 150-200 crore at the show which is now at stake.Besides gems and jewellery, importers and manufacturers of furniture, stationery items, toys and other raw material are also in a bind, not knowing the next step to take.“Chinese products are 15-20% cheaper which a major reason why many companies have stopped making them here. Now, it is difficult to import and the industry is keeping its fingers crossed. If the coronavirus problem persists, the companies may have to start making those products again,” said Digvijay Dhabriya, chairman of PHDCCI-Rajasthan. The stone industry is facing a similar dilemma. Arrivals of buyers, who would earlier come and mark the stone blocks for import to China, have stopped following visa freeze. Interestingly, much of the machinery used by the stone industry is from China.“Now, there is no scope to replace parts of the machines if need arises. The impact will be significant if the virus problem continues to prevail. A significant part of the exports go to China and it will certainly impact the industry,” said Ashok Dhoot, vice-chairman, Centre for Development of Stones, a subsidiary of RIICO. The travel and tourism industry is also losing steam as travellers from other countries have started cancelling bookings after nCov cases were reported in India.A tour operator said, “Visitors from other countries have also started cancelling bookings fearing that India might also witness a spread of the virus. While no cases have been found in Rajasthan, nCov cases in Kerala have made foreign tourists, who had plans to visit India, apprehensive.”He said the cancellations will affect the hotel industry in the midst of the peak season.

Title: Flyover at Dwarka to be shut for two months
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The flyover on the Mumbai-Agra highway on the stretch between Dwarka to Meenatai Thackeray Stadium would be closed for traffic within a month by the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) for connecting it with a new 2.3-km flyover that is under construction.

NHAI officials said the work of the new flyover from K K Wagh College to Jatra Hotel is going on at a fast pace. The work of putting slabs on the beams is underway from both the sides. Once the work of putting slabs at the K K Wagh College end is done, NHAI is planning to start linking the existing flyover with the new one.

A senior official of NHAI said, “In about a month’s time, the work of putting slabs on the flyover beams would be over. Once we get the police permission, the stretch of the Dwarka flyover from Dwarka to Meenatai Stadium would be closed for traffic, to link this stretch with the new flyover. The work of joining the two flyover would take another two months.”

However, the stretch of the flyover from Dwarka to Indiranagar will remain open for vehicular traffic. Those coming from Mumbai side can descend at Dwarka junction from the down ramp and those who want to take the flyover towards Mumbai can use the other ramp to take the flyover.

The official added that currently they have completed 60% work of the new flyover and by December-end, the entire flyover would be ready and thrown open for vehicular traffic. The work of the new flyover began in November 2018. Officials said they needed three more months to complete the work.

Police commissioner Vishwas Nangare Patil said, “The ban on heavy vehicles from entering the city from 8am to 10pm, which was put into effect from Monday, would put drivers of heavy vehicles into the habit of not entering the city. The aim is to ensure that heavy vehicles like goods trucks, private passenger buses do not use the Dwarka junction. This rule will also help when the flyover is closed for traffic.”

Union minister for road transport and highways Nitin Gadkari had laid the foundation stone of the new flyover in November 2016 in view of the large number of road accidents taking place on this stretch of the highway. The actual work began in November 2018.

Box: Transport association unhappy

Official-bearers of Nashik Transport Association presented a memorandum to the city police to reconsider its decision of banning heavy goods vehicles in the city from 8am to 10pm daily.

President of the association Rajendra Phad said the alternative routes suggested by the police were narrow and have a rush of small vehicles. They also argued that arranging workers for taking delivery of goods after 10 pm would also be difficult for the traders.

Title: Jaipur: Man who raped 10-year-old girl sent to police custody
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Pouches,wrappers lead to maximum plastic waste in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

SDC Foundation in association with IIP on Tuesday established the seventh plastic bank in the city at DAV Inte... Read More

DEHRADUN: A recent brand audit of plastic waste in the city has revealed that wrappers of milk, biscuits, namkeen etc are contributing to maximum plastic waste in Dehradun.

The survey, ‘The Great Dehra Plastic Waste Brand Audit 2020’, conducted by city-based Social Development for Communities (SDC) Foundation, found that several popular brands of milk and food products were contributing the most significant amount of plastic waste. The organisation has demanded that these companies should take responsibility of collection and disposal of the single-use plastic in which their products are packaged as per the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016 which mandate that companies are responsible for the waste that they generate under the ‘Extended Producer Responsibility’ specified in the rules.

Anoop Nautiyal, founder, SDC Foundation, told TOI that the plastic waste collected during the brand audit was categorised into three categories — branded waste, non-branded waste and non-woven plastic bags. Among the branded waste were 72 packets of namkeen, 66 packets of biscuits, 61 packets of chips, 50 packets of instant noodles,and around 80 milk pouches . According to Nautiyal, all this plastic waste was found in a 10 bigha area near Ashirward Enclave at Vasant Vihar, dumped in dustbins as well as on the ground. Around 27 kg of non-branded plastic waste was also collected by the auditors as well as 4.7 kg of non-woven plastic bags.

Rishabh Shrivastava of SDC Foundation told TOI that “it is clear that branded manufacturers have emerged as major plastic polluters.” “The audit highlights the blatant violation of plastic waste management rules by the companies and it is important that they implement the legal doctrine of ‘Extended Producer Responsibility’ in order to create plastic- free cities and towns.”

Reacting to the audit, Anand Vardhan, secretary, forest and environment, said that “being a green state, Uttarakhand has already initiated a conversation with all the companies who sell their products in plastic packets seeking their explanation on how they are planning to dispose the plastic waste.”

“We have written letters to companies who sell their products in plastic packets to find out what they are doing about plastic waste management. We are still awaiting their replies,” he added.

Meanwhile, SDC Foundation in association with the Indian Institute of Petroleum (IIP) on Tuesday established the seventh plastic bank in the city at DAV Inter College, Prem Nagar. The plastic bank aims to facilitate source segregation, collection and recycling of single-use plastic waste getting generated in households and local communities. The plastic waste collected will be converted into diesel at IIP.

Title: Solar unit manufacturers against grid support charges
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: Maharashtra Solar Manufacturers Association (MSMA) has demanded that there should be no grid support charges on power generated from the solar roof tops for the captive use.

The association, which has around 450 members, has also stated that banked solar power units may be charged at nominal rates up to Re one per unit.

“If the grid support charges are levied on the total units generated by solar roof top, then no one will install solar roof top as the cost of solar roof top unit will be higher than the cost of electricity supplied by the MSEDCL,” the MSMA has said in a memorandum submitted to the competent authorities.

The association has also highlighted that no state electricity regulatory commission has approved such grid support charges for net metering systems anywhere in India. “So it will be very wrong precedence by electricity regulatory commission to approve such charges as it is against the spirit of natural justice,” MSMA president Pradeep Kulkarni said.

The solar manufacturers have also brought to the notice some of the ground realities that allegedly rule out any scope for the grid support charges.

“The consumer uses his or her own premises for installation of the solar roof top system. The consumer invests in roof top project either by cash or by taking loan from some banks or institutions. Moreover, customer enters into an annual maintenance contract with the company who has installed the roof top project by making sizable payment,” the MSMA said.

Solar unit manufacturers have been alleging that the provision of the grid support charges were not part of the draft regulation released by Maharashtra Energy Regulatory Commission (MERC). “These specific charges were introduced in final regulations is more surprising. We have no option but to raise our voice against it in a democratic manner,” Kulkarni said.

When contacted, regional MSEDCL authorities said it would be inappropriate to comment on the policy decision taken by the energy regulator itself. An official mail sent to MERC remained unanswered till Tuesday evening.

Title: Pay sanitation worker as much as class-IV staffer: Rajasthan HC to govt
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan High Court asked the state government to pay salary equivalent to class-IV sanitation worker to a woman employee getting a meagre salary of Rs 240 per month. The court has further asked the government to pay the arrears within two months since the day of filing the petition by the woman.

The bench comprising Justice Sabina and Justice NS Dhadha gave these orders while rejecting the appeal filed by the state government against the order of single bench in favour of Geeta Devi.

Geeta Devi filed a petition in the high court in 2013 stating that she was appointed as a sanitation worker in Government Sanskrit College in 1986. She continued to get a salary of Rs 100 per month till 2010, when her salary was increased to Rs 240 per month by the college authorities. “It is a pity that this woman was getting a negligible salary and has not been regularized by the college authorities despite her continuous service. In 2018, a single bench had given order in our favour and asked the state to provide her salary equivalent to that of a sanitation worker in a government department, still the state government went against the order in an appeal to deny dues to the woman. Now, the division bench has given order in our favour and said that the order of the single bench is fair and calls for no interference,” said Anoop Dhand, counsel for the petitioner.

In the proceedings, state government had maintained that the woman works for only half-an-hour, thus she was not regularized. “To this, we said that for sweeping the dust and garbage, does anybody need a full day. That’s how sanitation workers work and can’t be expected to pick up a broom continuously for eight hours,” he added.

A single bench of high court comprising Justice Ashok Kumar Gaur, in his judgment on July 4, 2018 had said, for the job of a sanitation worker, an employee can’t be denied regularization with a plea saying he or she works for half-an-hour. The court then had also said that non-availability of sanctioned post should not come in the way of the petitioner getting minimum pay of a class-IV employee.

Title: Mixed response to demand for rickshaw ban on Jalna Road
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: MLA Pradip Jaiswal seeking a ban on the movement of auto-rickshaws, especially the ones operating on seat-sharing basis on the busy Jalna Road , has evoked mixed reactions. While a section of citizens has supported the move in the wake of growing traffic congestion on the road, many have opposed the move owing to connectivity issues.

In a letter submitted to state transport minister Anil Parab, Jaiswal has requested the ban on auto-rickshaws on a particular stretch of Jalna Road — between Mahaveer Chowk and Chikalthana. He accused auto-rickshaws of causing traffic indiscipline, leading to congestion on road. The MLA said that these vehicles can be held responsible for some of the fatal accidents held in the past.

Notably, diesel-run auto-rickshaws have been already banned in the city limits, citing pollution reasons. Aurangabad police had imposed enabling provisions of the Bombay Police Act to ban entry of diesel auto-rickshaws into municipal limits.

Diksha Lohe, a resident of Jawahar colony, said that it makes no sense to ban the movement of auto-rickshaws on Jalna Road as it would cause huge inconvenience to public. “The city still does not have an effective connectivity through public transportation buses and banning these vehicles in such circumstances would be illogical. Citizens must get a better alternative before arriving at any such extreme decision,” she said.

Pankaj Pathak, a resident of the Seven Hill area said, traffic police have to play a crucial role in regulating traffic at Jalna Road. “It is the duty of traffic cops to regulate vehicular traffic on roads. The authorities cannot introduce blanket ban on the movement of any vehicles for any non-compliance. Auto-rickshaws cater to commuting needs of citizens in the best possible way and must not go off-roads on Jalna Road,” he said.

On the other hand, residents using two-wheeler or four-wheelers for commuting within city limits have welcomed the proposal of banning auto-rickshaws on Jalna Road.

Title: Jaipur cops to ask marriage hall owners to put CCTV cameras, submit guest list
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Police would also take help of JMC and the fire department to ensure marriage lawns comply with various other ... Read More

JAIPUR: Two days after a 10-year-old girl was raped at a wedding hall, Jaipur police said they would urge marriage lawn owners to install CCTV cameras at various points.

Police also said prior to organising a wedding ceremony, lawn owners will have to provide them with a list of guests, including names of food caterers, people engaged in decoration, band and lighting.

The girl, who had accompanied her parents to a marriage engagement ceremony, was raped by a 36-year-old man late on Sunday night.

Police, however, managed to arrest the accused, who was a caterer for serving snacks at the function, within 24 hours. The accused, identified as Raju from Bhind in Madhya Pradesh, raped the girl in one of the toilets at the marriage garden, and left her in an unconscious state with severe injuries to her private parts.

The accused was one of those serving food. Police said the accused, in an attempt to overpower her, might have grabbed her by the neck as there were marks on her neck and head.

“CCTV camera footage is a handy tool these days in solving various crimes. In the past, we had witnessed cases of theft from wedding venues. Thus, we are going to make it compulsory for every marriage lawns to have working CCTV cameras. We are also aiming at time-to-time check of these CCTVs through local police station level,” said police commissioner Anand Srivastav.

He added that police would also take the help of JMC and the fire department to ensure marriage lawns comply with various others norms like proper lighting, parking and guards.

“We are also planning to ask the marriage lawn owners to provide us list of people engaged in wedding management right from food caterer, decorator, people engaging in bringing DJ at the wedding, videographer and photographer and others prior to organising a marriage at a lawn. It is necessary for us to have the proper credentials of these people. In the rape case too these things proved handy to make a prompt arrest,” he added.

Police would soon issue an official order in this regard by using its magisterial powers under Section 144 of CrPC.

Title: Rajasthan: 2 get 20 years in jail for raping 13-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Fight BJP’s ‘Dushashans’ by boycotting NPR: Mamata Banerjee
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee (File photo)

BONGAON/RANAGHAT: Drawing on the Mahabharata, Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday likened BJP to a party of “Dushashans” against whom the people of her state should fight back using every means possible, including refusal to provide family data to census officers updating the NPR.

“Don’t tell them (census personnel) everything. Don’t provide documents like land or house papers and ration cards even if they ask for them. Don’t entertain them even if they come with West Bengal government identity cards. Some religious fanatics may reach your home with false identity cards,” Mamata told a large gathering of people from the border districts at Bongaon Stadium in North 24-Parganas.

She called NPR “the first step towards NRC” and part of a larger BJP ploy to bulldoze its way through any pocket of resistance. “They are now talking bullets to silence voices of dissent,” she said.

Mamata’s remark about “Dushashans” appeared to be a retort to Bengal BJP chief and MP Dilip Ghosh ’s “Shikhandi” barb at Trinamool Congress in the Lok Sabha while speaking on protests against the tweaked citizenship law in Kolkata and other parts of the country. “Unfortunately, these Shikhandis are in power there (Bengal). The police did nothing (against anti-CAA protesters). I opposed it. Now I am being defamed. I am a patriot,” PTI quoted Ghosh as saying.

While Dushashan disrobing Draupadi is seen as the most vile act in the Mahabharata, comparisons with Shikhandi are meant to invoke cowardice because the transgender warrior was used as a human shield to kill Bhishma at Kurukshetra.

Don’t tell them everything. Don’t give documents like land or house papers and ration cards even if they ask. Don’t entertain them even if they come with Bengal govt ID cards.

Title: Pedestrian signals missing on Jalna Road & other areas
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: The local civic body, among other authorities, has failed to set up pedestrian signals on the Jalna Road and other busy areas of the city despite a long-pending demand for the same.

The historic city of Aurangabad witnesses huge movement of tourists and these visitors also face difficulties due to the absence of pedestrian signals.

Pedestrians have to face problems while negotiating heavy vehicular traffic in the city, especially on the busy Jalna Road, Jalgaon Road and Beed bypass road along with popular areas such as Gulmandi, Nirala Bazaar and Connaught place to name a few.

Sharad Advant, of the advocacy group Marathwada Janta Vikas Parishad, said it is sad that Aurangabad does not have a single pedestrian signal despite a surge in vehicular population to above 11 lakh.

“The absence of pedestrian signals exposes hundreds of pedestrians to the potential risk of traffic accidents every day. While a pedestrian is considered the king of the road in road safety parlance, needs of this category have been neglected in Aurangabad,” he said.

Pedestrian signals are instruments installed at busy roads and intersections to notify pedestrians when it is safe to cross the road. Several modern pedestrian signals have countdown timers built into their circuit so that they can display the seconds remaining before the signal changes. While bigger cities such as Mumbai and Pune have had pedestrian signals for long, residents of Aurangabad continue to wait for the desired facility.

Citizens living along the Jalna Road said the lack of speed-breakers coupled with the absence of pedestrian signals has made the road very prone to accidents.

“Children and senior citizens fail to properly gauge the movement of vehicles on the Jalna Road. We told our elderly and very young family members to not step out unless they are accompanied by someone,” said Nakshatra Mule, a resident of Manjeet Nagar.

When contacted, a senior RTO official said the proposal for setting up the pedestrian signals would be put before the next meeting of the district road safety committee. “The district road safety committee has representation from different stakeholders, including the civic body, and it would be an ideal platform to discuss the demand,” they said.

Title: Uttarakhand police launches 24X7 WhatsApp helpline number for women safety
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand police on Wednesday launched a dedicated 24x7 WhatsApp Helpline Service to help women in distress in the state.

Police officials said that women in any emergency situation can register their complaint on the number — 9411112780.

Ashok Kumar, director general (law and order) told TOI, “Women from across the state can use this WhatsApp helpline number to get police help. There would be dedicated staff to look into the complaints and swift response would be ensured.”

Women who are not able to make a call can send photos and videos related to a particular incident at any hour of the day and the police will reach out to them on immediate basis, added the official.

Women who don't want to go to a police station can also register their complaints on the WhatsApp helpline service, which will come under Women Safety Cell at police headquarters in Dehradun.

DG Kumar said that the helpline will be very helpful for women facing eve-teasing in public space.

“After receiving a complaint, the women safety cell will send the complaint to the concerned district and police station. Also, the follow up on the action taken in the complaint will be done regularly,” the official added.

Title: Dragonflies to draw people to wetlands
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Scarlet Rock Glider

AURANGABAD: Pankaj Korapde , a researcher from Beed, has a unique way of attracting people to wetlands . He uses dragonflies to entice children and people of all age groups in various districts, including Aurangabad , Jalna and Parbhani, to establish a connection between people and wetlands.

Koparde, assistant professor, MIT World Peace University, Pune, feels that due to the lack of connection, wetlands are fast polluting or vanishing. He said that species conservation is intimately linked to habitat conservation. “For dragonflies, freshwater and forests are essential, which we, as a species, too need for survival. By taking dragonflies as a model insect, we want to sensitise people about the condition of wetlands and what they can do to conserve them. The Marathwada Dragonfly Mapping Project is a citizen science project wherein anyone, irrespective of their profession or academic background, can contribute towards research and conservation of freshwater resources of the Marathwada” Korpade said.

So far, 150 people from Marathwada have joined the project and have shared information about dragonflies spotted in the region.

According to Shravan Paralikar, research assistant of Marathwada Dragonfly Mapping Project, youngsters today are serious about their environment and what kind of planet they want to live-in. “The citizen science project provides an interface to people of Marathwada to learn about their dragonflies and think about the best ways to conserve their freshwater resources,” Paralikar said.

When asked about the reason why dragonfly was selected for the project, Korpade said that dragonflies evolved around 300 million years ago so they are evolutionary marvel and due to their colour and unique appearance people get attracted to it. “If you just tell people that water is important and one should not pollute its sources, they won’t get the message. So, we are using an insect to attract people which is called flagship species concept,” he said.

Korpade is carrying out the research under Prakriti Research Fellowship run by Carpe India Pvt Ltd and Grind Master Machines Pvt Ltd. Workshops have been held at schools and colleges in Aurangabad and Jalna. More such workshops and programmes are scheduled in Aurangabad and Parbhani districts.

Title: Nashik professor bags best teacher award by SPPU
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Savitribai Phule Pune University

NASHIK: City-based chemistry professor Vivek Bobde’s name has figured in the list of award winners declared by Savitribai Phule Pune University .

Bobde, who teaches in HPT Arts and RYK Science College, will receive the Best Teacher award under the urban and non-professional category. The varsity gives away these awards every year and the ceremony would take place on February 10 in Pune.

“It is a matter of pride for me for being recognised by the varsity for my contributions for the last 28 years. I enjoy teaching and I wish to continue doing that for as long as I can,” Bobde said.

Apart from teaching and yielding results, several varsity duties and co-curricular activities have been the criteria for the professor to receive the award. For the last 10 years, he is the co-ordinator of Internal Quality Assurance Cell (IQAC) that’s responsible for the co-curricular and extra-curricular activities of the college.

“I have published nearly 65 research papers and have guided 12 PhD and two MPhil students in their research. Being a member of the syllabus forming committee, I have helped in overhauling the syllabi of various courses,” Bobde added.

Bobde had received his doctorate from IIT-Bombay in Protein Design. He hails from New Delhi and is an alumnus of Delhi University. He settled in Nashik when he was offered a position in the college.

“These students are humble, disciplined and focused. I have always seen full attendance in my classes,” Bobde said.

All his 12 PhD students and 17 staff members will accompany him to Pune to be a part of the proud moment.

Title: CAA protesters turn walls at Jama Masjid into virtual canvas
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Indore: Ongoing protest against CAA, NRC, NPA at Jama Masjid turn innovative and artistic on Tuesday after some painters used walls as canvas to showcase various incidents including the firing at agitators near Jamia Milia Islamia University in New Delhi. The protesters have displayed posters of freedom fighters of different religions to spread the message of communal harmony.

“With the help of paintings, artists have remembered martyrdom of Mahatma Gandhi, who want people of this country to live with harmony but we can see incidents such as open firing at agitators in Jamia area,” Zaib Pathan, management committee member of Samvidhan Bachao Andolan, told TOI. Meanwhile, Congress corporator from Ward 58 Julekha Anwar Qadari has written to district collector urging him to stop ongoing survey of food and civil supply department of BPL ration card holders.

“Currently, people of my ward are protesting against CAA, NRC and NPA and during this, field workers of food and civil supply department are carrying out the survey that is creating confusion and fear among locals. This is leading to an untoward situation for field workers and therefore, the survey should be stopped,” the letter read.

According to food and civil supply officials, the survey is about to complete in rural areas of district but in city, it could not be started in some parts, especially dominated by minority community, due to resentment among people.

“The food and civil supply department’s survey is meant to examine eligibility of ration card holders and it shouldn’t be linked with any other scheme or propaganda,” district collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav said.

According to senior administrative officials, creating any hurdles in the survey can be considered as obstruction to government work and it leads to appropriate actions in such matter.

Title: Firewall breach. 528 phones running on one IMEI number
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Indore: The firewall has been breached — 528 cellphones were found running on one IMEI number — raising serious security concerns for smartphone users. Indore police busted a gang involved in cloning of IMEI (International Mobile Equipment Identity) by ascertaining that as many as 528 mobile phones are being operated in district using the same unique identification number. In initial action, local police has seized as many as 62 smartphones worth Rs 10 lakh from users.

“When contacted, users of mobile phones having same IMEI number claimed to have found them either on road or purchased them from second-hand market. Users are being questioned thoroughly while appropriate action will be taken against those involved in changing IMEI number,” ASP (Crime branch) Amrendra Singh said. He added that police have managed ascertain presence of as many as 528 mobile phones with same IMEI number being operated in Indore, which is a serious security concern.

“Chances are there that these could be stolen phones or their IMEI could have been changed to hide identity of SIM number, model of mobile phone of that of user. We have sent a list of mobile numbers having same IMEI number to police headquarters in Bhopal for them to approach ministry of home affairs, New Delhi to decide further course of action,” Singh said.

He added that the ministry will be urged to oust these mobile phones with same IMEI number out of network through Central Equipment Identity Register (CEIR).

Title: Gujarat: Jobless man vents anger at girlfriend by burning his car
Content:
Fire brigade douse the flames of the burning car in Vadiwadi.

VADODARA: In a repeat of 90s Bollywood potboiler ‘Anjaam’ on Vadodara streets, a jobless IT engineer from Ahmedabad did a SRK stunt by burning his car out of frustration over his girlfriend. According to police, local people of Vadiwadi near RC Dutt Road witnessed the similar scene on Tuesday morning, albeit, the ‘love interest’ in this case was not present at the scene.The 23-year-old man from Ahmedabad set his sedan on fire in the narrow lane behind Bombay Shopping Centre after his girlfriend stood him up. The frustrated man first broke the windshield and glass panes of his car with stones. Later he collected garbage and dumped it in the car and finally set it afire. The man also allegedly pelted stones at passers-by and onlookers who gathered at the spot.Locals informed the police control room and the fire brigade. Believing it to be a case of vandalism, police reached the spot to to arrest the man, but understood that it was his own car after talking to him. When cops wanted him to come with them to Sayajigunj police station, the man at first refused, but later agreed to go with them in an auto-rickshaw. Meanwhile, the firemen doused the fire.The man continued to stay mum even at the police station despite repeated coaxing till his father arrived from Ahmedabad. When his father reached the police station, he finally opened up and said that it was act out of rage over his girlfriend who did not meet him as promised. However, he did not divulge details about the girl to cops or his father.“We let him leave as the father did not want to register any case. It was anyway a personal problem,” said inspector S G Solanki of Sayajigunj police station.In Video: Girlfriend refuses to meet techie; this is what he did
