Title: Anganwadi workers resume work, postpone strike till March 10
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Dehradun: Protesting anganwadi workers on Tuesday agreed to resume work and postpone their protest till March 10 after Doon mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama visited Dharna Sthal at Parade ground and met the protesters. On behalf of the chief minister, he assured the women that a committee will be formed by March 10 to look into their demands and in all likelihood, their honorarium will be increased from the next financial year, starting April.

The mayor also assured the workers that all of them will get paid for the days that they sat on protest and that none of them will be terminated from work. Some protesting anganwadi workers had received termination notice earlier.

“The state government totally recognises the efforts and sincerity that anganwadi workers put in at their work. We will try to meet all their demands with the onset of the new financial year,” said the mayor.

“The anganwadi workers have decided to resume their work, hoping that they will not be harassed by officials upon joining office for going on strike. We all had been fighting for our basic human rights. The mayor showed us a ray of hope, so we have decided to call off the strike for now, till March 10,” said Rekha Negi, president, Anganwadi Workers Union of Uttarakhand.

Anganwadi workers have been on the warpath against the administration for almost two months now, demanding Rs 600 per day wages and the status of a regular state government employee.

The district programme officers in some districts had sent termination letters to anganwadi workers through WhatsApp, triggering fresh resentment among the protesters. In Bageshwar, more than a dozen women were sacked through WhatsApp. Around a dozen protesting women lost their jobs in Dehradun as well.

Title: Bamu facilitates online certification for students
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: In a key initiative, Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) has facilitated a free of cost online certification for students with an aim to prepare them for the corporate world. The university has introduced the training as part of tie-up with Infosys Ltd.

“We have faciliated InfyTQ certification in which students can undergo the training module designed and obtain certification by themselves. The initiative will further open many doors of opportunities for students and give them an edge to survive and excel in the technical word,” Girish Kale, training and placement officer of Bamu said.

Referring to Infosys data, Kale said that over 4.98 lakh learners were registered for the InfyTQ certification in 2019. “InfyTQ is basically technical examination. Students scoring 65% and above in the certification examination will get Infosys certificate as an endorsement of their industry-readiness. It will also offer on-the-spot job interview opportunity for entry-level technical roles at the company. Each certified student will be given an opportunity to appear for niche roles as well,” Kale said.

Students pursuing BE, B.Tech, ME, M.Tech, M.Sc, MCA and MCM and graduating in 2021 can register for the certification. All head of the departments (HoDs) of the varsity and affiliated colleges have been asked to make students aware of the InfyTQ certification. For registration dates and further process, Bamu authorities concerned can be reached on tpo@bamu.ac.in , it was said.

Bamu which has jurisdiction over Aurangabad , Jalna, Beed and Osmanabad districts of Marathwada, is considered as one of the oldest universities in Maharashtra having over 410 affiliated colleges and different university departments.

Title: Married man gets 10 years jail for raping minor
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: A 22-year-old man living in Gorwa was sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 10 years on Tuesday for abducting and raping a 16-year-old girl with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The convict Ikram Shah alias Akram Dewan, who was also already married, had lured the girl with promise of marriage and the duo fled to Ajmer on April 10, 2017. While staying at a guest house, Dewan raped the girl. They were found by Gorwa police after some days and brought back to city as the girl’s mother had lodged a complaint.

According to her mother’s complaint, the girl had gone out to buy ice-cream but did not return till late evening. Her parents searched for her at relatives’ homes and other places but could not find the girl. Next day, Dewan’s wife who knew the girl’s family went to meet them to inform that he had not come home since two days and she suspected that her husband had taken the girl away. The girl’s mother then approached police.

After she was brought back to Vadodara, Dewan was arrested and the girl’s medical check-up revealed that she had been raped. Later, during the trial the additional public prosecutor submitted medical and forensic evidence which were upheld by the court of additional sessions judge K M Sojitra.

While convicting Dewan, the court stated that it also took into consideration the fact that Dewan and rape survivor were involved in a romantic relationship. However as the girl was minor at the time of crime, Dewan was convicted and also fined of Rs 13,000.

Title: Kerala nun rape case: Hearing on objection to discharge plea on February 11
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

KOTTAYAM: A court here on Tuesday adjourned the preliminary hearing on the objection filed by the prosecution against the discharge petition filed by bishop Franco Mulakkal in the nun rape case to February 11. Bishop Mulakkal , who is the accused in the case, did not appear before the court. His counsel sought time for hearing following which additional district court 1 judge G Gopakumar adjourned the case.

The counsel of the bishop had filed the discharge petition on January 25. His counsel had argued that the offences levelled against him won’t stand and the case was based solely on the statement of ‘case witness 1’ who had a personal grudge against the bishop. The counsel also argued that most of the prosecution witnesses are not in good terms with the church.

The nun had, on June 27, 2018, filed a complaint with the Kottayam police chief about the sexual abuse between 2014 and 2016. The chargesheet in the nun rape case was filed on April 9, 2019. Bishop Franco Mulakkal, who faces charges of wrongful confinement, rape, unnatural sex and criminal intimidation in the case, can get life imprisonment or imprisonment of not less than 10 years if proved guilty.

Title: Pune: 10 used AK-47 bullets found in railway sleeper coach
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

PUNE: The Pune railway station is on high alert after 10 used bullets of an AK-47 assault rifle were found in a sleeper coach of the Azad Hind Express on Tuesday morning.

The cartridges were discovered on one of the coaches after the train was moved into the railway yard.

“The train had reached Pune around 9.30am and was taken to the yard for washing and cleaning. The staffers found the ammunition in the waste bin of a washroom of the S2 coach,” RPF’s divisional security commissioner Arun Tripathi told TOI.

“The matter has been forward to the Government Railway Police, but we are also investigating the matter,” Tripathi said.

Of the 10 bullets recovered, seven were spent rounds, while three were cartdidge shells. “These are not live cartridges, but it is a serious matter, regardless. We have sought the passenger chart of this coach and are in contact with our counterparts in other cities to check if an FIR was lodged in this regard,” Tripathi added.

The train connects Howrah Junction in Kolkata to Pune. “The RPF contingent at the station is on alert and checks are being conducted,” a source said, without divulging any details on the steps being taken.

“We have prepared a panchanama and submitted the cartridges as unclaimed property. No FIR has been lodged, but we have made an entry of the cartridges found in the general register maintained at the police station. We have launched an investigation to establish the identity of the passenger travelling with the cartridges,” inspector Surendrasinh Goud from the Pune railway police station said.

Title: Mangaluru: Sood focuses on online outreach
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Praveen Sood

MANGALURU: Twitterati can now reach out to DG&IGP Praveen Sood online. The state’s top cop who as Bengaluru city police chief was active on the microblogging site, has taken to Twitter within 72 hours of taking over the baton from his predecessor Neelamani N Raju. The state police down the line will make its presence felt on Facebook, as Sood feels that Twitter and Facebook complement each other.

Sood told TOI, “I am finding my feet as the head of the police force of the state, and recognise it is vitally important for the state police to make its presence felt online, just like some other police units in cities, especially the Bengaluru city police.” The Twitter handle that Sood opened @DgpKarnataka is apart from his personal handle @Copsview, and will be used to report achievements of what personnel in khaki do across the state. It will also give information on policy issues, he said.

Admitting that while there are ready models available for the state police Twitter rollout, Sood said he will need some time to put together a team that can operate this police handle in a professional manner. “Since my role as the head of the police is quite different from what it was when I was the top cop of the Bengaluru city police, the Twitter content will have to be modified to suit the responsibilities that this role bestows on me and my earlier experience will stand me in good stead,” he said.

Noting that when he took over as DG and IGP and searched for an account for this designation, he could not find one. The account has since been created, Sood said adding, “It is still not active, but you can understand the intent. It may take a week or so before the handle becomes active,” he said. The handle will be used to inform netizens of steps that the state police intends to take to meet his objective of citizen-centric policing, he said.

“The handle will also focus on cyber security and women’s security as it is the best possible medium to create awareness on issues that affect the common man and netizens alike,” he said.

Sood admitted he will have to start from scratch on Facebook, as the state police does not have a Facebook page, and a strategy must be developed to harness this social media platform. “There should be a full-fledged and operational page some six months down the line,” Sood asserted.

Title: Jewellery worth Rs 90 lakh looted at Khagaul in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Four armed criminals looted jewellery worth around Rs90 lakh from a showroom at Jairam Bazaar under Khagaul police station in Patna district around 3pm on Tuesday.

The criminals thrashed jewellery showroom owner Sujeet Kumar when he had tried to resist. They also took away the DVR of CCTV cameras installed inside and outside. The criminals had covered their faces with mufflers and clothes.

Sources said the showroom is around 250 metres away from Khagaul police station. Sources said all the police personnel were busy at nearby Kothwan where MLC Ritlal Yadav’s daughter is to get married in the night.

The shopowner told the media that criminals were speaking in a dialect different from the one used in Patna area. “They had earlier come around 11am and asked to purchase jewellery for marriage. I told them to come later. The estimated cost of looted jewellery is around Rs90 lakh,” he said.

SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma reached the spot. SHO Mukesh Kumar Mukesh said the criminals had come on foot and sprayed some anaesthetic agent on Sujeet, who remained unconscious for over 2 hours.

Title: 7 booked for duping dozens of Rs 21 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: The Sayajigunj police booked seven persons for duping dozens of investors in the city of Rs 21.65 lakh. The accused disappeared a couple of months ago with all the money. According to the police, Jyoti Soni filed a complaint of cheating after the accused disappeared locking their office . Soni alleged that she was introduced to the accused Surat Raval, Deepak Dhimore and Dilip Lori in March 2018. They claimed to be directors of a private company formed in 2013. They offered Soni to become an agent and bring in investments for their scheme. Soni was promised 7% commission on the investments . Soni agreed and submitted her identity proofs and bank passbooks. She then roped in others who invested money in the firm. tnn

Title: Docs remove 57 tumours, save uterus
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Indore: Surgeons at MY Hospital removed 57 tumours from uterus of a 30-year-old woman on Tuesday.

The woman was diagnosed with tumours in her uterus that had prevented her from conceiving for last 10 years following which she was referred to MY Hospital. Team of surgeons including Dr Somen Bhattacharya, Dr Deepa Joshi and Dr Avinash Patwari performed the marathon two-and-half hour surgery to remove all the tumours, hospital sources said. The surgeons managed to save the uterus, they said. TNN

Title: Lohegaon airport reels from declining passenger traffic
Content:
Lohegaon airport has recorded a 23% dip in international passengers and a 6% drop in domestic flyers in 2019. ... Read More

PUNE: The Lohegaon airport has recorded a 23% dip in international passengers and a 6% drop in domestic flyers in 2019.An airport official attributed the decline to the problems that beset the aviation industry last year. “Quite a few flights were discontinued. The struggle for daytime slot remains a constant worry and a major roadblock in getting new flights,” the official said, adding that they were hoping for some improvement in numbers in the summer schedule, which starts from the end of March.“Last year the aviation sector faced — and continues to face — a major crisis. Jet Airways had shut, affecting flight movements at many airports. It also affected the international growth of the airport, as Jet operated two flights, to Singapore and Abu Dhabi . Those slots are still empty. Before this, Lufthansa grounded a flight to Frankfurt, as they don’t have aircraft for the route,” the official added.Pune MP Girish Bapat, who heads the airport’s advisory committee, recently said he was told by airlines that starting new flights was not profitable, even as Indian Air Force remains reluctant to give daytime slots. He said he would meet airlines in the this regard after the budget session of the Parliament.Pune airport witnesses 175 flights movements, down from the 200 recorded earlier. “The next fiscal is crucial for the airport. The new terminal building, which is expected to be a game-changer, will be ready by mid-2020,” another airport official said.Aviation analyst and expert Dhairyashil Vandekar, said factors other than the sector’s larger problems needed to be looked at. “The other reasons include the general slowdown in economic activity, and high fares charged by airlines to new airports like Shirdi, Nashik, Kolhapur, Belagavi and Dharwad. Another important reason is the inability of the Lohegaon airport officials to improve the passenger experience,” he said.

Title: MVA pips BJP again, wins Ytl MLC bypoll
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Sena’s Dushyant Chaturvedi celebrating after the results

Yavatmal: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) has dealt yet another blow to the BJP on Tuesday as its candidate Dushyant Chaturvedi, hailing from Nagpur, won the legislative council seat from Yavatmal local self-government bodies constituency. He defeated Sumit Bajoria of the BJP by a margin of 113 votes in the by-election.

The seat was held by the NCP till 2016 and the same was allotted to Shiv Sena as per the seat-sharing agreement between the saffron alliance partners. The bypoll was necessitated as Sena’s Tanaji Sawant had resigned after he was elected to the legislative assembly from Bhum Paranda constituency in Osmanabad district.

The voting took place at seven polling stations on January 31.

In all, there were 489 voters from local self-government bodies such as zilla parishad, municipal corporation, municipal councils and panchayat samitis. Dushyant polled 298 votes, while his nearest rival Sumit got 185. Six votes were found invalid. Counting of votes took place at the local Bachat Bhavan.

District collector and chief returning officer Ajay Gulhane declared the result immediately after the counting and later handed over the certificate to the winning candidate.

District guardian minister and Shiv Sena leader Sanjay Rathod, senior Congress leader and former minister Shivajirao Moghe were among the leaders who reached the collector’s office to congratulate the victorious MVA candidate.

Speaking to TOI after his victory, Dushyant said the result was on expected lines. He promised to do whatever possible for him to solve the problems of the farmers during the his 28-month tenure as MLC. He also expressed gratitude towards the voters and MVA leaders.

The MLC bypoll had become a prestige issue for local biggies like Sanjay Rathod of Shiv Sena and BJP MLA Madan Yerawar. Rathod finally had the last laugh as he outwitted Yerawar and retained the seat for the party.

Title: Joshi finalizes 48 new public toilets, 50 more in next fiscal
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Mayor Sandip Joshi has finalized the construction of 48 new public toilets across the city, especially in market areas. Joshi has also planned construction of 50 more public toilets in the next financial year.

The mayor held a review meeting with the officials of health department and all ten zones on Tuesday. “I received suggestions from many people regarding the lack of public toilets during my interaction with people at ‘Walk and Talk With Mayor’, ‘Breakfast With Mayor’ and also through suggestion boxes campaign etc. I have decided to spend my entire mayor fund of Rs6 crore per annum on construction of public toilets. The plan for 48 public toilets has been finalized under current fiscal’s mayor fund. The tendering process and bhoomipuja will be performed before March 15. The construction will be completed within four months,” he said.

Joshi added that the additional 50 public toilets will be constructed by utilizing funds from next fiscal’s mayor fund. “I held meetings with owners of petrol pumps last month. In all, 87 petrol pumps opened toilets for public. The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has appointed Swachhata Doots to keep these public toilets clean. Name and numbers of Swachhata Doots have also been displayed at the toilets,” he said.

Currently, the NMC operates public toilets with 562 seats — 360 for men and 202 for women — at 68 locations across the city. There are 352 urinals in these public toilets while bathing facility is available at 112 public toilets.

Joshi has also directed the officials to ensure proper cleanliness at the existing public toilets. “All public toilets are maintained by private agencies and NGOs. Therefore, there should be no negligence towards cleanliness of the public toilets,” he said.

Joshi has also directed the NMC officials to convert standard-sized abandoned city buses into mobile toilets of which a few will be especially for women.

Title: 6,581 more students to sit for HSC exam in division
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NASHIK: This year, more than 1.66 lakh students are expected to appear for the HSC (Class XII) examination in the Nashik division which comprises four districts of Nashik, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar.

The Nashik division officials of the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary & Higher Secondary Education said that compared to 2019’s figures, over 6,000 more students would be appearing for the HSC examination this year.

“This year a total of 1,66,478 students have registered for the examination commencing on February 18. Last year, 1,59,897 students had appeared for the examination,” the officials said.

While the number of boys appearing for the examination this time has increased by about 3,500, the number of girls has swelled by nearly 2,500 in the arts, science, commerce and HSC vocational streams.

“This year, 96,393 boys have registered in comparison to last year’s 92,064 boys. Similarly, 70,085 girls have registered for the Class XII examination this year whereas only 67,833 girls had appeared for it last year,” the officials added.

From Nashik district alone, 42,802 boys and 32,541 girls are going to appear for the examination making it a total of 75,343 students from the district which is the highest in the division.

From Dhule, 25,264 students have registered for the examination whereas 49,403 have registered from Jalgaon and 16,468 have registered from Nandurbar.

As the number of students has increased by 6,581, the board has increased six examination centres in the division. Earlier, there were 228 examination centres in the four districts with Nashik having 90, Dhule 44, Jalgaon 71 and Nandurbar 23 centres.

This year, the board has increased five centres in Nashik and one at Nandurbar with a total of 234 examination centres.

Title: Kerala nun rape case: Hearing on objection to discharge plea on February 11
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

KOTTAYAM: A court here on Tuesday adjourned the preliminary hearing on the objection filed by the prosecution against the discharge petition filed by bishop Franco Mulakkal in the nun rape case to February 11. Bishop Mulakkal , who is the accused in the case, did not appear before the court. His counsel sought time for hearing following which additional district court 1 judge G Gopakumar adjourned the case.

The counsel of the bishop had filed the discharge petition on January 25. His counsel had argued that the offences levelled against him won’t stand and the case was based solely on the statement of ‘case witness 1’ who had a personal grudge against the bishop. The counsel also argued that most of the prosecution witnesses are not in good terms with the church.

The nun had, on June 27, 2018, filed a complaint with the Kottayam police chief about the sexual abuse between 2014 and 2016. The chargesheet in the nun rape case was filed on April 9, 2019. Bishop Franco Mulakkal, who faces charges of wrongful confinement, rape, unnatural sex and criminal intimidation in the case, can get life imprisonment or imprisonment of not less than 10 years if proved guilty.

Title: Objections raised on ward reservation process
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: A day after draws were held to fix reservation of wards, the election department of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has received objections on the process. Several questioned the process followed for the reservation, while, on the other hand, civic authorities said that they followed the procedure laid down by the election commission.

In a public event organised at Dr. Babasaheb Marathwada Ambedkar University (Bamu) auditorium on Monday, civic officials announced the wards for which reservation was directly fixed by the Election Commission of India (ECI).

Draws were held to assign reservation for the remaining wards. Subsequently, out of the 115 wards, 22 were reserved for SC, 2 for ST, 31 for backward class of citizens (BCC) or other backward class (OBC) and remaining 60 seats for the open category. A total of 58 seats bagged women reservation, of which 11 were reserved for SC-women, 1 for ST-women, 16 for BCC-women and 30 for women (general) candidates.

The process, however, did not go well with many of the aspiring candidates. Several people, including existing corporators, had to miss their opportunity of contesting from the ward in which they have been working because of the SC, ST and BCC reservations assigned to those wards.

According to civic activist Rahul Ingle, the reservation of Cidco N-3, N-4-Parijat Nagar (number 76) is questionable. “The ward had OBC reservation in 2005 and in 2015, it was reserved for women (open). But, the ward had never seen an SC candidate in the last three elections. Therefore, it should have been marked as an SC ward this time,” Ingle said.

Rupchand Waghmare, an independent corporator from Ekta Nagar, had his ward assigned for an ST candidate. He said that ST population in his ward was not high for it to be assigned as an ST ward.

When asked, head of election department and deputy commissioner Kamlakar Phad said that several people had reached out to him with their concerns on the reservation process. “They do not understand the rotation system of the election commission based on which the reservations were directly assigned to the wards. The wards reservation was decided based on previous three elections of the municipal corporation. I have not received any applications so far. They have a seven-day window to objections. When received, these objections will be sent to to the ECI for consideration,” Phad said.

The AMC election is likely to be held in the first week of April.

Title: Demolition order triggers STP money-back demand
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The National Green Tribunal’s demolition order of the Chikhali sewage treatment plant has left the PCMC in a tight spot, with opposition parties and activists demanding the recovery of the expenditure from the civic officials involved in its planning and construction.

The NGT order of January 30, 2020, stated that the sewage treatment plant (STP) was constructed within the prohibitive zone (the blue floodline) and lacked necessary permissions. The order directed the PCMC to immediately demolish the STP and take steps to construct it elsewhere in accordance with the law. “The entire exercise (demolition) shall be carried out within one month,” the NGT order stated.

When contacted, municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar said, “We received the copy of the NGT order on January 30. We will seek legal opinion before taking any decision.”

Residents of River Residency and other nearby housing societies had opposed the STP project when it was launched early last year. They then moved the NGT in April 2019. However, the PCMC began the STP construction along Indrayani river in Chikhali in July last year.

A resident said, “Had the PCMC not gone ahead with the project despite our strong protest, public funds would not have been wasted? The funds should now be recovered from the civic officials who implemented the project.”

As per a senior civic official, the STP aimed at reducing the pollution in Indrayani river. “The project cost was Rs 15 crore, of which Rs 1.5 crore has already been spent. If the under-construction STP is to be demolished, we will have to acquire land for it elsewhere and this could take a long time,” he said.

Datta Sane, NCP corporator from Chikhali, came down heavily on the civic administration for wasting public funds on the project. He demanded that the money be recovered from the civic officials who proposed the project, approved it and gave its work order.

Parag Gandhi, who represented the petitioners in the case, said, “Our main contention was that the PCMC had not obtained permissions from the MPCB and the state irrigation department for STP construction. We also showed photographic evidence of the inundated STP site during the monsoon. No construction is permitted in blue floodline area.”

Title: Uttarakhand to monitor air quality across all 13 districts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The state pollution control board has also decided to monitor air and water quality of the industrial sites in... Read More

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand Environment Protection and Pollution Control Board (UEPPCB) has decided to monitor air quality across all 13 districts under its ‘State Air Quality Monitoring Programme.’ The body has also planned to monitor the air quality of Dehradun, Rishikesh and Kashipur round the clock. Till now, air quality was monitored manually barely twice a week and 104 times annually at five locations of these three cities. The 24x7 monitoring of air quality will be done at a cost of Rs 5 crore, officials said.

The move assumes significance as forest fires deteriorate state’s air quality every year and the state fails to provide air quality data on time from the hill districts where devastation from forest fires is the maximum. Also, the number of industries is growing at a significant pace which is further contributing to air contamination. At present, air quality of only six cities – Dehradun, Rishikesh, Haridwar , Kashipur, Haldwani and Rudrapur — is monitored under National Air Quality Monitoring Programme. The air quality of these cities has gone below acceptable standards. PM 2.5 levels in these cities are more than 40 and PM 10 levels are over 60. They have been tagged “non-attainment cities” in view of air pollution.

The state pollution control board has also decided to monitor air and water quality of the industrial sites in the states. “As more and more industries are coming up, we are taking steps to ensure that they adhere to pollution control norms. The inspection of air and water quality will be done on a regular basis in industrial sites,” SP Subudhi, member secretary of UEPPCB, told TOI.

Checking water pollution in rivers (other than Ganga and Yamuna) is yet another priority, as per the state government. “Water quality is currently monitored at 56 points under State Water Quality Monitoring Programme. But soon, we will add 44 additional points to this list,” said Harak Singh Rawat , state forest minister.

Also, UEPPCB will make attempt to involve youths in solid waste management. “We have serious scarcity of data to actually set up some baseline to execute works. Thus, we will involve meritorious students of national-level institutes in collecting data. We will fund their research works,” added Subudhi.

Title: Boy dies after falling off school bus in Malappuram
Content:
Farseen Ahammed

MALAPPURAM: In yet another accident caused by a vehicle of an educational institution in the district, a Class III student died after falling off a moving school bus at Kuruva near Malappuram on Tuesday morning.According to Kolathur police , the incident occurred around 10am when nine-year old Farseen Ahammed of Kuruva AUP School boarded the bus from Karuva Centre , which is 1km away from the school.Preliminary investigation conducted by police and motor vehicle authorities revealed that the door of the bus, which had moved just 100m after Farseen boarded it, opened when the school bag of Farseen, who was standing near the door steps, accidentally stuck on the handle. The door suddenly opened when the he tried to move inside. Farseen couldn’t balance himself and fell off the vehicle. Police said he died on the spot as the rear wheels of the bus ran over him.Road Transport Officer (Enforcement), Malappuaram G Gokul said a showcause notice has been issued to the school authorities prior to suspension of the permit of the bus service, as the school authorities failed to follow motor vehicle rules. “Absence of door attendant was the reason for the accident. It is mandatory to appoint a door attendant in school bus and it was a serious offence committed by school authorities,” he said. Meanwhile, he ruled out the allegations of local people that bus was overloaded.There is a nodal officer in every school who has to review the facilities in their vehicles on a daily basis as MVD authorities cannot inspect each vehicle every day, school authorities are responsible to ensure safety of vehicle and students, said Gokul.According to MVD, there are around 2,000 educational institution vehicles operating service in the district and it is alleged that many schools in the district are using very old vehicles and are employing inexperienced drivers. The most common rule violation is overloading. Rules specify that the number of children in vehicles should not exceed one-and-a-half times the permitted seating capacity if the children are below 12 years.After a school bus accident in Malappuram town in October 2016, in which a girl was killed, the motor vehicle department and police had announced stringent measure to review fitness of vehicles. But in 2018, a Class IX student of Cheekode higher secondary school near Edavannappara was killed after she fell off the bus when the front door of the over-loaded bus accidentally opened.Gokul said in the backdrop of the latest incident, MVD has decided to deploy special squad to put the vehicles ferrying students under surveillance.

Title: Don’t extol Maoists: CM to opposition
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Twaha Fasal and Allan Shuhaib

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Reaffirming that the government was not responsible for National Investigation Agency (NIA) taking over the Pantheerankavu UAPA case , in which two young CPM workers were taken into custody for alleged Maoist links, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan accused the opposition of trying to ‘extol’ Maoists for political gains.

It may be their past practice that prompted the opposition to accuse the government when police slapped UAPA provisions against people taken into custody for unlawful activities, he said on Tuesday.

“It’s not in consultation with the political dispensation that police decide what particular provisions and acts should be invoked against people taken into custody. There is no truth in the allegation that the government wilfully handed over Pantheerankavu UAPA case to NIA,” he said.

Vijayan said as per the provisions in the NIA Act — passed by the Centre when P Chidambaram was the home minister — the agency can take over cases on its own. “State consent is not required to take over such cases. NIA took over the case even before the case came under the scrutiny of a committee, headed by retired HC judge, that ascertains whether police decision to evoke UAPA provisions against the accused were correct or not,” he said.

The chief minister was replying to an adjournment motion notice by IUML leader M K Muneer to discuss the fresh crisis that Allan Shuhaib and Twaha Fasal face following Kannur University’s decision to oust them for want of mandatory attendance. Muneer said the opposition was not interested in a discussion on who promulgated UAPA or who set up NIA.

“The chief minister should specify what evidence made Kerala police arrest the youngsters. The role of NIA came only after the state police slapped UAPA on them. It’s said that some literature was seized from them, this includes a copy of CPM’s party constitution. Police claim the boys were under surveillance for the past five years and Allan had written pro-Maoist slogans when he was a class IX student. This is absurd,” he said.

Muneer asked the government to evoke 7B provision in NIA act, that gives a chance to bring the investigation back to the state police.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala echoed the demand only to be ruled out the chief minister who said the case could be handed back to the state police only if the Centre agreed to do so. “Do you mean that I should go to Amit Shah with a request letter? There seems to an insatiable quest to justify Maoists in a bid to hit the CPM,” he said.

Opposition exited the house after the speaker denied permission for the motion.

Title: I-T tribunal quashes decisions favouring city cos
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) has reversed decisions given in favour of seven companies by the Commissioner of Income Tax (CIT) appeals office at Nagpur, in cases involving allegedly suspicious entries of share capital and share premium.

The rulings include one passed in favour of M/s Gupta Coal (India) Corporation Limited (GCICL), headed by city businessman Padmesh Gupta. The companies under the Gupta Group had featured in the list of major Non-Performing Assets (NPAs) of the country.

The case was argued by Dr Milind Bhusari on behalf of the department, relying on a Supreme Court decision of March 2019 in a similar matter.

Following searches and other actions, the income tax department had reported a number of questionable accounting entries over receipt of share capital and premium from various companies in the firms. As the amount was added into the taxable income, the companies filed an appeal before the CIT (appeals) office. An order was issued in their favour, said a source privy to the matter.

In March 2019, however, the Supreme Court in Income Tax vs NRA Iron an Steels Private Limited ruled in the department’s favour, which was an independent matter. The apex court directed that even if the entires may look perfectly legal, attempts have to be made to pierce the veil if the transactions defy the general business logic. This led to the department here taking up the cases at ITAT.

Some of the cases are as old as 2014, the source said. The ITAT order says that CIT (appeals) had issued orders in the assessees’ favour way back in 2014, but much has changed since then with regards to judgments of various higher forums on such matters. In the light of the Supreme Court decision in NRA Iron and Steels case, the earlier orders of the CIT (appeals) have been set aside.

Income tax sources says routing unaccounted funds back into a business through share capital entries is a common practice often busted by the taxmen. Share capital is subscribed at a heavy premium by the companies. This means a share worth Rs10 is purchased at Rs100, shelling out premium of Rs90.

In many cases, the share capital is subscribed by a maze of shell companies. Often, the very logic of offering heavy premium for any business appears to be questionable leading to income tax action. The very intention will be now probed even if the deals may look perfectly legal on the face of it, said a source.

Title: Savitribai Phule Pune University to start one-year Urdu foundation course
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The Urdu foundation course will start from the 2020-21 academic year. (File photo)

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) will start a one-year foundation course in Urdu from the academic year 2020-21.

Any student who has completed at least Class X can apply. The aim is to impart skills in Urdu reading, writing, listening and speaking.

“The course is being funded by the university. Pune being a cultural city, there are many working professionals who may want to learn the language.Those who love poetry, ghazal or history have a high affinity for Urdu,” said Sadanand Bhosale , head of the Hindi department.

Saleem Shaikh, an advocate and social activist who proposed to the SPPU vice-chancellor to start the course, said, “The University of Pune had an Urdu department which shut down about 40 years ago. Nowadays, even non-Muslims want to learn the language to enhance their knowledge of shayari, ghazal etc. The course will benefit many as the university will teach Urdu right from the alphabets.”

Bhosale said there will be two regular contractual teachers and as many visiting professors from other colleges. “The syllabus has already been framed. Learning Urdu will help in translational studies. Currently, we only have Hindi, Marathi and English translational skills, but this will enhance our scope. Whether to increase the level of the course till postgraduation will be taken up by the officials later,” he said.

The first batch of the foundation course will consist of 30 students. It will initially function from the Hindi department.

The modalities of the admission will be uploaded on the university website in due course.

After receiving the proposal, SPPU VC Nitin Karmalkar set up a committee under Sadanand Bhosale to work out the feasibility of the course. The committee consists of subject experts Azmat Dalal, Abdul Bari, Uzma Tasneem, apart from Anjali Kurane, professor of anthropology at SPPU.

Title: VMC’s CCTV pole knocked down by bus
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: A private bus knocked down a CCTV camera pole of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) in Nagarwada area on Tuesday . The operator has been asked to pay damages to the civic body. The incident took place on Tuesday evening when the bus operated by a city-based operator to ferry students as well as staffers of various companies was passing by the Nagarwada crossroads. The bus hit the CCTV pole and it fell on the road obstructing traffic. The bus driver panicked and left the spot with the bus. The bus was identified using CCTV footage and the operator was contacted. The operator agreed to pay VMC Rs 20,000 for the damage. tnn

Title: Cancer survivors spread awareness about illness
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: In a programme held at the Government Cancer Hospital (GCH) on the occasion of World Cancer Day on Tuesday, survivors shared their stories to raise awareness about early signs, diagnosis and treatment of the disease.

The hospital, being developed as State Cancer Institute, treats patients from across Maharashtra as well as other states.

Geeta Uday Pol, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2016, shared her personal experience. She said that she had a habit of conducting annual health check-up. “Right before my birthday on August 9, 2016, I was diagnosed with a lump in my breast in the mammography. I only shared the revelation with my husband, an Army colonel, who offered his wholehearted support. He told me that the way I supported him when he fought Kargil War, he will also support me when I fight cancer,” she said.

Pol later completed her treatment and now visits different hospitals in the city and counsels cancer patients on prevention and management.

Similarly, Popat Pandit and Prabhakar Pongshe shared their stories as cancer survivors.

The Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) acting dean Kailash Zine, medical superintendent Suresh Harbade and officer on special duty at the GCH Arvind Gaikwad felicitated the survivors for carrying the responsibility of raising awareness about cancer.

Title: Heritage preservation club at Tennur school for spreading word on artefacts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Trichy: To create awareness among children on conserving archaeological artefacts, a Heritage Preservation Club was inaugurated at Tennur higher secondary school on Tuesday.

An exhibition of archaeological artefacts, which were found around Trichy, was also conducted as part of the event. The objective was to make students learn history by showing them artefacts that were used during those days, said P Vimala, head mistress of the school.

Inaugurating the club, C Siva Kumar, curator (in-charge) of government museum, Trichy said the idea of the club was to inculcate interest on archaeology and historical artefacts among children.

It’s very usual that people try to hide archaeological materials they own. By educating children on informing the authorities concerned on such findings will help unravel many historical events. Such artefacts were not only source of interesting stories, but also help us know about our ancestors and ancient civilisation, he said.

Members of Tiruchirappalli Notaphily Society displayed close to a century old nose studs and bangles made of stones that were used by people of the region. Coins used during Chera, Chola, Pandiyan and Nayak, East India Company and post-independence period were also displayed during the event.

By exposing students to such ancient artefacts, will wanted to make them capable of recognizing rare artefacts, noted philatelist P Vijay Kumar said.

Title: Tomar in STF net for extorting Rs 45.5L from colonizers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Indore: Special Task Force ( STF ) Indore on Tuesday formally arrested Rajendra Singh Tomar alias Raju Guide for allegedly extorting Rs 45.5 lakh from colonisers and land owners, which the investigators dubbed as ' terror tax '. He is currently lodged in district jail.

STF stumbled on Raju during investigation into alleged fraud committed in the name of allotting plots to people at Shanti Paradise colony in Harsola village of Mhow. STF had earlier arrested one Sachin Soni, Damyanti Bai and Shailendra Agrawal for the crime in project developed by Golden Project Limited, a subsidiary company of Golden Forest India Limited, superintendent of police (STF) Padmavilochan Shukla said.

“Investigation revealed that the accused publicized the projects as approved by renowned banks and finance companies for housing loan and allotted plots to over 200 people,” Shukla said.

He added that it also came to fore that infamous goon Raju was involved in the project and had collected ‘terror tax’ of Rs 45.5 lakh by threatening the colonizers and land owners there. Interrogation of other people suspected in the case was underway, while search is on for one Amit Agrawal, who was associated with Shanti Paradise.

Title: Boy dies after falling off school bus in Malappuram

Meanwhile, he ruled out the allegations of local people that bus was overloaded.There is a nodal officer in every school who has to review the facilities in their vehicles on a daily basis as MVD authorities cannot inspect each vehicle every day, school authorities are responsible to ensure safety of vehicle and students, said Gokul.According to MVD, there are around 2,000 educational institution vehicles operating service in the district and it is alleged that many schools in the district are using very old vehicles and are employing inexperienced drivers. The most common rule violation is overloading. Rules specify that the number of children in vehicles should not exceed one-and-a-half times the permitted seating capacity if the children are below 12 years.After a school bus accident in Malappuram town in October 2016, in which a girl was killed, the motor vehicle department and police had announced stringent measure to review fitness of vehicles. But in 2018, a Class IX student of Cheekode higher secondary school near Edavannappara was killed after she fell off the bus when the front door of the over-loaded bus accidentally opened.Gokul said in the backdrop of the latest incident, MVD has decided to deploy special squad to put the vehicles ferrying students under surveillance.

Title: Maharashtra women’s commission chief Rahatkar resigns
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: Maharashtra State Commission for Women (MSCW) chairperson Vijaya Rahatkar, who had moved the Supreme Court against the Bombay high court’s observation that she had not demitted office despite the change in government, tendered her resignation from the post to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Tuesday.

Rahatkar’s resignation followed the Supreme Court’s order on Tuesday dismissing her special leave petition (SLP) against the high court’s order on January 22. “We are not inclined to interfere with the impugned (under challenge) order. The SLP is, accordingly, dismissed,” the SC bench of Justice R Banumathi and Justice A S Bopanna said on Tuesday.

On January 22, the HC bench of Justice S C Dharmadhikari and Justice R I Chagla, while hearing a PIL filed in 2013 by Pune-based activist Vihar Durve, observed, “We expect the learned AGP (additional government pleader) to apprise all concerned of the position in law that the chairperson cannot continue and hold the office when the present political dispensation is keen to appoint a chairperson of its choice. We expect that before the next date we will be informed about the appointment of the new chairperson.”

The high court’s observation came after AGP N M Mehra told the bench that the state would initiate the process of appointing the chairperson to the MSCW. Mehra told the bench that the present chairperson was Vijaya Rahatkar and she had not demitted office. Mehra submitted that though Rahatkar was aware that the office was held by her at the pleasure of the government and that she was appointed under the erstwhile political dispensation, she was yet to demit office or resign from the post.

Rahatkar took an exception to the HC’s observations in her SLP before the Supreme Court, claiming that her appointment was not political in nature and was subject to provisions under the Maharashtra State Commission for Woman Act, 1993. She said in the SLP, filed through lawyer Nishant Katneshwarkar, that her post was statutory and had nothing to do with the change in the state government. The HC was compelling the state government to remove her from the post of the chairperson of the commission and make a new appointment, the SLP stated.

In her resignation letter, Rahatkar said she was re-appointed the commission’s chairperson on February 18, 2019, for a period of three years. “However, I myself have decided to resign from the post,’’ she said.

Rahatkar said she had earlier served the first term from 2016-2019, when she was able to take up several issues relating to women and that that she received cooperation from all the departments.

Title: Self-report if exposed to China travellers: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: Family members, friends, colleagues and other close contacts of the China-returned travellers should also report themselves to health officials in case of developing flu-like symptoms, medical experts said in the wake of the novel coronavirus threat.

They said it would help in containing the spread of the contagion. “Coronavirus is airborne and can spread through droplets. Close contacts, who are exposed to the travellers returning from China, are being tracked by health officials. But it is also their responsibility to self-report if they develop any illness,” Sudhir Patsute, head of the civic-run Naidu hospital, said.

“The novel strain of the coronavirus has governments and health experts worldwide on their toes. However, one of the oldest and most effective methods of containing a contagious virus has always been contact tracing. This is the most simple and efficacious way to contain the virus. But in addition to health officials, it calls participation from the society,” Patsute said.

In contact tracing method, health officials find out who the suspected persons (in this case travellers returning from China) have been in contact with. Thereafter, they are quarantined and tested. “Officials draw information about the people who have come in contact by interviewing the travellers. They then try to understand about people who have been exposed to the traveller in the preceding days and weeks as there are chances that the virus may have infected these people too,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.

Eye surgeon Sanjay Patil, president of the city chapter of Indian Medical Association said, “In Punjab's Faridkot, a traveller who returned from Canada via China refused to get himself admitted at the government-designated isolation ward. Health authorities had to seek help from the police to get him isolated. Community’s cooperation is crucial in containing the virus spread.”

Title: Army looks at desi vendors for improved ammunition
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: The Army is looking at Indian vendors for development of prototypes of ammunition, which can penetrate a 530mm thick armour of enemy tanks from a 2km range to enhance the lethal effect of its battle tanks.

The Director General of Mechanised Force recently invited an expression of interest from Indian vendors for the development of a prototype of Armour Piercing Fin-Stabilized Discarding Sabot (APFSDS) ammunition. The newly developed ammunition will be fired from the T-72 and T-90 battle tanks.

As of now, the army’s primary tank ammunition is the 125mm APFSDS. “The advent of superior protection technologies has improved armoured fighting vehicles, including those of our likely adversaries. They can defeat the penetration capability of current anti-tank ammunition,” the notice inviting the EoIs stated.

Depth of penetration is a major consideration for countering and defeating enhanced protection level for AFVs. A senior army officer said, “The present in-service ammunition has a DoP of 460mm. Therefore, there is a requirement to indigenously develop an improved APFSDS ammunition to enhance the lethality of our battle tanks.”

The armour is made from composite materials. Unless the ammunition has the capability and hits at a particular angle from specific range, it will not break the armour.

The Defence Acquisition Council headed by defence minister Rajnath Singh had approved this project in September 2019, another senior officer said. “The mechanised forces want to procure over 80,000 rounds of this ammunition,” he added.

Currently, the Ordnance Factory Board supplies this ammunition to the army. “The board has already developed a prototype of ammunition. At the same time, the High Energy Materials Research Laboratory and Armament Research and Development Establishment laboratories of Defence Research and Development Organisation are working on the prototype,” the officer said.

A senior DRDO scientist said, “The development of this ammunition is underway.”

Title: FTII student’s film wins at Mumbai fest
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: A film by a student of the Film and Television Institute of India won the Pramod Pati Special Jury Award for most innovative/experimental film at the recent Mumbai International Film Festival (MIFF).

Payal Kapadia, a direction student from FTII’s 2012 batch, won the award for her film “And What Is The Summer Saying”.

FTII director Bhupendra Kainthola received the award on Kapadia’s behalf from the festival’s chairman Shaji Karun. Governor Bhagat Singh Koshiyari was also present at the award ceremony with the state cultural affairs minister Amit Deshmukh.

Educational visit for cops

As many as 125 officers of the city police went to the FTII’s Law College Road campus for an educational visit on Tuesday.

The team, led by police commissioner K Venkatesham and joint commissioner Ravindra Shiswe, included additional commissioners, deputy commissioners, among others.

The officers were given a tour of the campus and briefed about its landmarks and its history. A movie was also screened for them at the campus theatre.

Title: Aurangabad: International film festival begins today
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The 5-day-long 7th Aurangabad International Film Festival (AIFF) will begin at the Prozone Mall from Wednesday. The fest will see screening of 40 films from across the world.

“It is aimed at showcasing the best of films produced recently and in the past in India and other parts of the world to film enthusiasts. The AIFF is a platform for aspiring filmmakers, technicians, artists and young film enthusiasts to learn and understand artistic as well as technical aspects of cinema,” the organisers said.

The Aurangabad International Film Festival (AIFF) is organized by the Yashwantrao Chavan Pratishthan, Mumbai’s Aurangabad Regional Centre, Nath Group and the Mahatma Gandhi Mission (MGM). The film festival will witness competition of Indian films, jury award, short-film competition, master class and seminar, audio-video lecture and film appreciation workshop apart from film screening.

Title: Engineering student loses Rs 24 lakh to franchise trap
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: A 23-year-old engineering student, eager to start a branded retail outlet of a smartphone company, fell for the lies peddled by two cybercrooks and lost nearly Rs24 lakh in the process.

The Wanowrie police have booked the fraudsters — a man and a woman — for duping Abhijit Sanjay Satav between October and December last year.

Satav, the son of a businessman from Handewadi, is a final-year electronics and telecommunication engineering student. Police said Satav saw an ad while he was browsing the internet.

“Satav, who is computer savvy, was tempted by the (fake) advertisement of the mobile phone company. He clicked on the ad and entered his details,” inspector Salim Chaus said.

From then on, the suspects — posing as representatives of the smartphone company — began to send him e-mails and text messages, offering to let him open a franchise outlet.

“The complainant, without verifying the suspects’ credentials, believed their claims and agreed to their demands. He transferred varying sums under the pretext of different charges to the suspects’ bank accounts,” Chaus said.

“I became friendly with the suspects after I contacted them via an online ad,” Satav told TOI, and refused to go into any more detail.

In all, he transferred Rs23.67 lakh. He realized he had been duped when the suspects stopped contacting him. He eventually approached the cybercrime police.

After a preliminary probe, an FIR was registered with the Wanowrie police. “We are in the process of collecting details of the bank accounts and calls made by the suspects to the complainant,” Chaus said.

Title: Sewage plant at Elamkulam gets government nod
Content:
The existing 60-year-old sewage treatment plant at Elamkulam

KOCHI: State government has accorded administrative sanction to set up a new sewage treatment plant at Elamkulam at a cost of Rs 16.52 crore under Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (Amrut) scheme. The order in this regard was issued on January 25 after the decision of the state-level high-powered steering committee.According to the earlier plan, the project would cost Rs 13.70 crore. However, as per revised estimate, the project cost would be Rs 16.52 crore. The committee gave administrative sanction for the work on the condition that Kochi corporation should meet the excess amount from State Annual Action Plan (SAAP) savings.The new plant with 5MLD capacity is coming up on nearly 20 cents on the plot, where the current plant, which is six decades old, manages to treat 3 to 3.2MLD sewage from five divisions with much hiccups.“A joint venture of two agencies — Mary Matha and Tomar — will set up the plant in one year. We will soon sign an agreement with them. The DPR of the project is ready. Only the structural plan of the plant is to be done by the agency. The new plant will be commissioned next year. We will dismantle the old plant, which started functioning in early 1960s, once the new plant becomes operational,” said an Amrut official.Amrut mission officials attribute the escalated cost for the new plant to three bizarre reasons. The first one is that there are very few contractors or firms in the field of municipal sewerage treatment in the state and hence the bidders are fewer. Though it is a small project, all mechanical components and machinery for each unit are required. Third reason is high water table in the proposed area and special precautions have to be taken during the excavation for foundation.The new plant will rely on moving bed biofilm reactor (MBBR) method to treat sewage waste. The conventional method takes more time to settle the sludge for treatment while MBBR method demands only short retention time to settle the sludge.“The benefit of the MBBR method is that it requires only a small area to set up the sludge settling tank. Primary step involves screening, where non-biodegradable waste and oil is separated from the sewerage. Secondary is aeration, biological treatment and settling, and tertiary stage is filtering and chlorination of the overflowing water from the secondary stage depending on the reuse purpose. Since the retention time is less, we only need a small tank compared to the tanks in conventional method,” said the official.

Title: Maharashtra to deploy drones to identify illegal sand mining hotspots
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The state government will use drones or unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) with advanced cameras to identify the illegal sand mining hotspots, following the Centre’s directives.

A state government official said using the drones would help keep a track on the sand mafia as well as calculate the sand used for infrastructure projects. “We had tried the drones on a pilot-basis for some districts and would replicate it now in other parts,” a senior state government official, working in the sand mining department, said.

It was only recently that the state, with its huge number of infrastructure projects, had put an order to use artificial sand to address the sand requirement in the state. “Such directives had been issued earlier as well. But, the present one has called for detailed guidelines to form teams that would involve both police and traffic police, which would be good to curtail any illegal activities,” the official said.

The state government said illegal sand mining was much lesser in Maharashtra as compared to the other states. But, cases of illegal sand dredging, especially along creeks, were on the rise.

In a first, states were also directed to quantify future demands for sand over the next five years, based on a market survey to compare demand and supply (factoring in illegal sand extraction). This needed to be done under the mining plan for each district.

The ministry of environment, forests and climate change stated the guidelines were based on various court orders. The Supreme Court in July 2019 pulled up the Centre for not being able to curtail illegal sand mining across Tamil Nadu, Punjab, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh.

A state official said along with physical surveys, the advent of advanced technology in the form of drones needed to be used by states to have a topographic overview and provide information accuracy to curb illegal sand mining.

In May 2019, the United Nations Environment Programme had declared India and China as the top two countries where illegal sand mining had become a major environment problem.

Extraction of sand from rivers, coastal marine areas, lakes, reservoirs, agricultural field, among others, lead to pollution, flooding, lowering of water aquifers, beach erosion, destruction of important ecological habitats and frequent droughts, an official said.

Title: Nashik MPCB to step up drive against single use plastic
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik division of Maharashtra Pollution Control Board ( MPCB ) has decided to step up its drive against single use plastic following instructions from state environment minister Aditya Thackeray.

A Nashik MPCB official said they would write to Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) and other local bodies in the district to help in stepping up the drive.

Thackeray held a video conference with all divisions of the agency on Tuesday and has directed all divisions to do more to ensure the ban on single use of plastic is fully implemented.

“Single use plastic has been banned by the state government since June 2018, but the ban is not being implemented effectively. The environment minister expressed concern over lack of effective implementation of the plastic ban,” an official from the MPCB said.

“The minister has directed the MPCB divisional offices for effective implementation of the plastic ban and has instructed to chalk out an action plan at divisional level for its proper implementation,” he added.

The official said that it has also been decided to take up a drive on any week day to collect banned single use plastic.

“We will involve all civic bodies in Nashik division for effective implementation of the ban on plastic,” he said,

Nashik division of the MPCB includes four districts – Nashik, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar. Last year in October, the NMC had conducted a drive to collect banned plastic in the city and it had received very good response. The civic body had collected 9,000 kg of banned plastics in the city in one day.

The civic body had also set up collection centres at 31 locations across six divisions of the municipal corporation — six each in Panchavati, Nashik Road and Cidco, five each in Nashik East and Satpur and three collection centres in Nashik West division.

Plastic bottles with capacity of holding less than 200 ml water, plastic water pouches, plastic bags, single use disposable items made up of thermocol or plastics like dish, spoon, cups, plates, glasses, fork, bowl, container, straw, were collected by the NMC.

Title: Amid nCoV fears, Chinese set examples of good citizenry
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Empty metro trains, deserted roads, closed marketplaces, and no rush at tourist destinations — this scenario is rare in China, especially during January and February when the country celebrates its New Year. However, things are different this year. The novel coronavirus (nCoV) has wreaked havoc in Wuhan, a Chinese province, claiming over 425 lives till February 4.

In view of the virus outbreak there, several countries including India have evacuated their citizens from China.

Many youths from Vidarbha studying in different universities there have also returned home. Some of them shared their experiences with TOI on Tuesday.

“People were enjoying New Year holidays in China when the coronavirus happened sometime after mid-December. We had planned to stay there till February 24. As the nCoV fear spread, on the insistence of our family members we decided to return. This was before the evacuation by government of India,” said Tanmay Bansod, who has been studying in China for the last four years.

Tanmay returned to Nagpur on January 31 with some Indian friends. They were thoroughly screened at Delhi airport and then allowed to go to their respective cities.

“Our university is in Hangzhou, which is far away from the virus epicentre. But, travel restrictions have been imposed there also. Those who want to go out of the university premises need to apply with valid reason. If the authorities are convinced, you get permission to go out for 2 hours. On return, one must undergo thermal screening,” he said.

The Chinese government has made provisions of thermal screening at several public places. Residents can go out for shopping or other purposes only once in two days. Masks and full-sleeved clothes have been made compulsory while going out. Moreover, you must come back home within 2 hours, he added.

“Though the restrictions have been of advisory nature, people are following them religiously. Their belief in local authorities is noteworthy. People help each other, make way for elderly and children, and strictly follow every alert issued,” Tanmay recalled.

“Restrictions imposed by the Chinese government on social media are often criticized, but the same have turned out to be a blessing in disguise as the curbs have restricted spread of fake news/rumours during the nCoV crisis,” said a China returned girl student, who was not willing to be named.

“I wonder how many wrong messages, fake news, rumours etc would have spread in India in such a situation. As all messages/posts on social media are screened in China, only right information reaches the users,” she said.

All these students are now worried as they are uncertain when they will be allowed to go back and resume their education. “Our sessions may get delayed, examinations may get cancelled and our stay in China might get prolonged. It’s good that we have reached home and feeling safe,” said one of the students.

Title: GST revenue jumps 12% this fiscal in Nashik division
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The Nashik divisional has registered 12.36 % rise in its revenue through goods and services tax ( GST ) during April-Jan of current financial year 2019-20, as compared to the corresponding period last year.

The division earned Rs 2,590 crore during this period of the current financial year, against Rs 2,305 crore during the corresponding period last financial year, said officials from central GST. Central GST had collected revenue of Rs 2,825 crore during last financial year (April-March).

Nashik division of CGST has served notices to 1,500 tax defaulters for defaulting tax payment, asking them to clear their tax dues at the earliest.

The Nashik divisional office of the Central GST have jurisdiction of five districts – Nashik, Ahmednagar, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar. The jurisdiction of the Nashik divisional office of the State GST department (erstwhile Sales Tax department) is also the same.

There are over 1.25 lakh businesses registered with GST in Nashik division. Of which, maximum (65,000) businesses are registered with the Nashik divisional office of the state GST, while 60,000 businesses are registered by the Nashik divisional office of the Central GST.

The new tax regime GST came into effect from July 1, 2017 replacing multiple indirect taxes and traders with turnover below Rs 20 lakh were exempted from GST, while those with annual business turnover up to Rs 1 crore eligible for composition scheme.

The GST council made several changes in the past. The exemption limit had been increased from Rs 20 lakh to Rs 40 lakh and the businesses with turnover above Rs 40 lakh are under the tax net only.

BOX: Cultural event on Feb 6

The office of commissioner of CGST, Nashik division, has organised cultural event on February 6. This is for the first time such event is being organised with an aim to relive stress of its staff and promote arts and cultural qualities of their staff. The staffs of CGST from entire Maharashtra, except Mumbai zone, are participating in the event.

Title: Gaffe in 2020-21 budget leaves VMC embarrassed
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: Budgets, which warrant highest care at the preparation level, are expected to be error-free accurate documents. However, that wasn’t the case with the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) budget document for the year 2020-21. An error in the document implies 12 times rise in professional tax collected by the civic body.

The civic body’s draft budget presented by the administrative wing as well as the one cleared by the standing committee, included professional tax. But instead of an annual collection, this tax was shown as ‘collected monthly’. The error went unnoticed and was also included in the budget cleared by the standing committee on Monday.

It came to light only after the budget cleared by the standing committee was printed and circulated among the media. “It was clearly a printing mistake as the VMC does not decide on the tax. It is decided by the government and VMC only collects it and includes it in the budget,” said an official.

Officials pointed out that the total collection of professional tax in the budget was expected to be Rs 48.5 crore. “This is the amount we expected to collect,” said an official.

The fact that the faux pas was only as printing mistake also becomes evident from the fact that in the last budget for 2019-20, VMC had expected to collect Rs 45 crore. tnn

Title: Panel rejects claim by Maradu flat owners
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

KOCHI: The Supreme Court-appointed committee to supervise the distribution of compensation has rejected the claims by Maradu apartment owners with multiple flats who sought Rs 25 lakh for each demolished dwelling.

Meanwhile, the committee noted that if the SC issues a directive that the owners are entitled to get interim compensation of Rs 25 lakh for each flat, the committee will revisit this order and direct the release of the eligible amount to all the owners.

Nine owners, who owned multiple flats in the buildings demolished at Maradu on January 11 and 12, approached the committee seeking interim compensation of Rs 25 lakh for each flat they owned. The committee has also approached the SC seeking clarification on this.

“The interim compensation is intended for rehabilitation. We (committee) think the said payment should be confined to Rs 25 lakh irrespective of the number of flats owned by a person. If the contention of the claimants is accepted, for the persons who own five flats, Rs 1.25 crore will have to be released for rehabilitation. We think, the same was not intended by the SC,” noted the committee.

The term of the three-member committee will expire on March 10. Meanwhile, the deadline set by the committee for owners to submit the documents sought in the proforma 3 expired on Tuesday. The owners had been asked to submit the proforma 3, along with the documents, for determining the balance amount, besides the compensation.

Title: DRI arrests Kochiite in gold smuggling case
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

KOCHI: The Mumbai unit of directorate of revenue intelligence ( DRI ) has arrested a Kochi resident for his alleged involvement in aiding and abetting an inter-state smuggling syndicate that was illegally importing gold in the guise of brass scraps via ports in Gujarat. The accused VE Siraj , a resident of Elamakkara , runs a cosmetic shop in Ernakulam Broadway.

DRI sources said the accused went into hiding after the agency busted the smuggling gang, including kingpin Nisar Aliyar of Perumbavoor , whom Siraj was aiding a year ago. DRI officials said the smuggling gang operated through various ports in Gujarat and smuggled gold worth more than Rs, 1,000 crore from the United Arab Emirates ( UAE ).

DRI nabbed him on Thursday from his residence after receiving a tip that he had reached Kochi. He is now being interrogated in Mumbai. DRI officials suspect that he had invested huge amounts in the illegal gold business.

“Mumbai unit arrested Aliyar, the kingpin in the case, last year. After this incident, Nisar left India and stayed in gulf countries. Recently, he returned to Kochi and DRI received a tip on his whereabouts. Officials were tracking him for a while and arrested him at his residence. After receiving the transit warrant from a court in Kochi, they took him to Mumbai. The officials are tracking his involvement in the scam,” said a source.

DRI said that Siraj was not directly involved in gold smuggling activities in Kerala, but he was connected to one Asif and Fazil from Perumbavoor, who were the main operatives of Aliyar. Though Aliyar was arrested, Asif and Fazil escaped with 90kg of gold before DRI could nab them. Siraj reportedly aided them and DRI is confirming how he might have helped them.

Investigation has revealed that the gang smuggled 4,522kg of gold worth Rs 1,473 crore from the UAE. They would melt the gold and transform them into rods and discs and later colour it to look like brass.

Title: Man returns from Singapore with flu, admitted to Jipmer
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Puducherry: A man with symptoms of flu and fever from Ariyankuppam on the outskirts of the town was admitted to an isolation ward in Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research ( Jipmer ) on Monday.

The man, aged more than 40, visited Singapore recently and had interacted with a delegation from Hong Kong during the business trip. He reached Puducherry two days ago with symptoms of flu and fever. With the coronavirus scare looming large, he preferred to approach Jipmer for treatment.

He was admitted in an isolation ward and doctors collected the swab samples of the man which would be sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune, on Tuesday to test for coronavirus infection.

“We will send his swab samples to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune today (Tuesday). We must follow standard operating procedures to collect swab samples from the patients and send them through designated people in designated vehicles. The samples will be sent by air to Pune. The test may take six to eight hours. NIV generally sends the results by email or conveys it over phone. We may get the results of the test by tomorrow (Wednesday),” said a Jipmer official.

The doctors treating the man said he was stable. “He’s not sick and not critically ill. The man will be soon transferred to a facility established by the district health authority. The government has taken a policy decision to treat patients testing positive for coronavirus at a state government facility and Jipmer will treat only critically ill patients,” said the official.

Presently, Jipmer has an isolation ward with facilities to treat five patients. “We will enhance the facility to treat more patients as and when the need arises,” said the official. NIV, Pune, is one of the institutes accredited in the country to test for coronavirus infection. Jipmer has not obtained accreditation to perform tests for coronavirus.

Three people from the Union territory – one each from Puducherry, Karaikal and Mahe, who returned after visiting China recently — are under home quarantine.

Title: 1.11L candidates to appear for SET
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: Around 1.11 lakh candidates will take the state eligibility test (SET) to be conducted by the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) on June 26.

The candidates appearing for SET can make changes to their applications till Thursday, the SPPU SET department coordinator BP Kapadnis said. TNN

Title: Maharashtra to recruit 800 teachers by March
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: By March-end, recruitment for as many as 800 teachíng posts for higher secondary classes in unaided private schools affiliated to the state government would be completed, education commissioner Vishal Solanki said.

The recruitment would be conducted through the Pavitra portal. The recruitment has been ongoing since the last 18 months, but the portal has technical glitches and court proceedings.

“The recruitment process has been going on in phases. There were some technical issues in the portal and some legal issues that were creating hurdles in the recruitment system. We are trying to find out some way to overcome these hurdles and conduct this recruitment,” Solanki said.

The recruitment is being done for teachers’ posts in schools affiliated to the local self-government and unaided private schools affiliated to the government based purely on merit.

“This exercise of candidates filling up preferences was over last month. The selected candidates’ list will soon be announced,” Solanki said.

Another 1,200 more vacancies reserved for ex-servicemen will also be conducted by March. A recruitment drive through interviews in private government recognised schools for 3,000 posts would also be conducted by the education department.

Solanki said there is a huge list of applicants and almost 10 candidates would be interviewed for one vacant seat so the competition to bag the post will be tough.

Title: Civic body alters bus project to curb financial losses
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to roll out lesser number of buses under its bus service project to reduce the losses after district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal voiced his concerns about it.

NMC officials said that instead of introducing 150 electric buses, the civic body would roll out 50 such buses, for which the Centre would provide subsidy. Initially NMC had decided to run 400 buses — 150 electric, 200 CNG and 50 diesel .

This change of plan is apparently to reduce the losses that the cash trapped civic body could entail by rolling out the project as planned earlier.
