NMC officials said that the civic body would have suffered losses of over Rs 55 crore annually by operating 400 buses. However, by rolling out 300 buses, the civic body’s annual losses would be reduced by at least Rs 20 crore.

The district guardian minister had recently cautioned NMC to roll out the project in a judicious manner so that there is not huge financial liability on it.

The bus service is to be operated on GCC (Gross Cutting Contract) for a period of 10 years. This includes purchase of new buses, maintenance of buses, employing drivers, purchasing fuel, etc. NMC will pay charges to private agencies on kilometer basis.

The union ministry of heavy industries & public enterprises has approved a grant of Rs 55 lakh each to 50 of total 150 electric buses. This amount is to be given to the agency for procuring the 50 electric buses. Hence, the per kilometre rates for these 50 electric buses will be Rs 60 per km and Rs 80 per km for remaining 100 electric buses.

“Our losses will reduce by Rs 20 crore if we reduce 100 electric buses and operate only 50. We have also urged the government to give grant to all 150 buses instead of 50 buses. But until we get government the approval, we have decided to roll out 50 electric buses only,” said NMC sources.

NMC’s standing committee chairman Uddhav Nimse said the bus service with start from April 1. The CNG buses will be available by March-end. Moreover, Maharashtra Natural Gas Ltd (MNGL) has also assured to provide CNG for the buses through tankers and its six CNG stations, said Nimse.

The municipal corporation also has plans to run the Integrated Transport Management System (ITMS) through a private IT firm in an attempt to make the bus service more effective.

This system will help NMC track locations of the buses through GPS system and also the revenue collected as ticket machines will be connected online. NMC is already in the process of finalising the IT firms for the project.

Title: Expel Hegde from BJP, demands Cong
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mangaluru: The Dakshina Kannada District Congress Committee (DCC) has strongly condemned former Union minister and BJP MP Anantkumar Hegde ’s alleged remarks on Mahatma Gandhi , that the freedom struggle led by him was a “drama”.

Addressing a press conference, DCC president and MLC K Harish Kumar said the BJP should immediately expel Hegde from the party.

“Let the BJP expel Anantkumar Hegde from the party and remove him from his office as MP. This is not the first time that Hegde has made derogatory statements and is showing arrogant behaviour. In the previous instances, Hegde has assaulted a doctor, stoked a controversy by making statements of changing the Constitution and called rationalists dogs. He also made a provocative statement to, “Cut the hands of those who touch Hindu women”. It is a tragedy that such a person has been given entry into the Parliament as an MP,” Kumar lamented.

There are hundreds of historical monuments and statues of Mahatma Gandhi across the nation. Further, we can see roads in the name of Gandhi all over India, Kumar said, and dared the BJP to condemn Gandhi openly by removing all his memorials, if the party does not want to take action against Anant Kumar Hegde. “All people together should boycott Hegde, who made derogatory remarks against Mahatma Gandhi,” Kumar said.

He also urged the police to book a suo motu case against Hegde. “Criticising a government in a democracy is a right of every citizen, but the BJP considers it an anti-national act. If so, isn’t this, Hegde’s statements against Mahatma Gandhi, anti-national?” he questioned.

What is Kateel’s stand on Yettinahole?

BJP MP Nalin Kumar Kateel was in the forefront fighting against the Yettinahole project. At present, he is the state president of BJP, which is in power at the Centre and state. Hence, let Kateel explain his stand on Yettinahole project now. Since Kateel is president of the ruling party, he has the power to give directions to chief minister B S Yediyurappa. Let him direct the CM to stop the project now, Kumar said.

Title: HC: Police need sensitization on rights of citizens
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kochi: Police need to be sensitized on the rights of citizens , including lawyers, who get involved in criminal cases, the high court said while quashing a case registered against a lawyer for trying to speak to an accused who was his client.

Justice P B Suresh Kumar considered a petition (Crl. M.C. No. 4749/2019) filed by advocate Prasanth K of Wayanad through advocate S Rajeev. He had challenged the case registered against him by Vadakara police based on the statement of a woman civil police officer escorting a woman accused in an NDPS case.

Offences alleged against the lawyer under IPC included wrongful restraint (Section 341), assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharging duty (Section 353), and assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty (Section 354). It was alleged that the lawyer tried to speak to the accused four times and finally shouted at the woman officer and pushed her.

Along with quashing the case, the court said, “Before parting with this judgment, I think it is my duty to observe that it is high time that the police need to be sensitized about the rights of citizens, including prisoners, and need to be trained to deal with the complainants, accused, witnesses, lawyers etc. in the peculiar social fabric of our country.”

Further, the court said it cannot agree with the conduct of the lawyer and the woman officer. “This court does not approve at all the conduct of the accused involved in this matter in chasing the prisoner. There are other more appropriate means in place for the purpose of conversing with the accused who seeks legal aid in a case. At the same time, I am unable to endorse the conduct of the police officer involved in this matter in refusing to permit the accused to converse with his client, the prisoner, for one or other reason and the conduct of the police officer who registered the case against the accused and later filed the final report in a case of this nature,” the judgment stated.

If the officer had behaved properly, leaving her ego behind, this incident could have been avoided, the high court said.

Title: Pune: One held on charge of suicide abetment
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A heated argument over parking space a fortnight ago is suspected to be the trigger behind an autorickshaw driver’s suicide.

The deceased, Sunil Ramchandra Bhargade (47) of Santoshnagar in Katraj, was found hanging from a neem tree near Jambhulwadi lake around 2pm on Monday, police said.

The Bharati Vidyapeeth police arrested an autorickshaw driver, Sachin Dattatray Abhangrao (30) of Dattanagar in Ambegaon , and booked his accomplice on Monday night on the charge of abetting Bhargade’s suicide.

The police have launched a manhunt for Abhangrao’s accomplice, who is also an autorickshaw driver.

Bhargade’s daughter lodged a complaint with the police stating that an autorickshaw driver and his friend threatened her father of dire consequences over a parking dispute at the Shaninagar chowk stand in Katraj a fortnight ago.

An officer said Abhangrao and his accomplice had claimed they would kill him and his son if Bhargade refused to remove his autorickshaw from the parking queue.

Bhargade had been visibly stressed since the incident, his family members vouched.

Title: First aid importance taught to Delhi Public School students
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Class II students of Delhi Public School were taught to give first aid to their respective doll/teddy and were made familiarised to the terms like antiseptic, gauze, bandage, band-aid and glucose. The students were taught to stay calm and act swiftly while giving first aid to the needful. They were given step by step demonstration of first aid to their toys on any cuts and wounds. The students were also educated about the importance of expiry dates.

Lawrentian wins an inter-school competition

Six students of St Lawrence High School participated in an inter-school Rangoli competition organised by the Symbiosis School. The students made Rangoli depicting their vision of ‘Saving the Environment’. Nikita Nishad of class IX bagged the first prize to bring laurel to the school. The institution also had its annual sports day for class I to III where class III students shared their views about sports and recited a few poems about the importance of sports.

MaRRS won by Global International

The students of Global International School bagged two honours at MaRRS Competitive Exam. Arna Jain won the first prize at the international level while Swaranjali Mohan stood third at the national level.

New Era stands second at Bhagvadgeeta recitation

Class VII student of New Era English School, Chinmay Garud, bagged the second position in the Bhagvadgeeta recitation competition organised by Sringeri Sharada Peetham, Karnataka under the Geeta Gyan Yagna Venture. All the 700 verses and 18 chapters of the Sanskrit scripture of the Geeta were to be memorised and recited in the presence of the dignitaries. Out of seven contestants in the finals, Garud was the only one to represent Maharashtra. The students of the school also made a model of the United Nations where the delegates of various countries like China, France, Russia, the UK, USA, Germany etc portrayed their environmental issues. The students discussed environmental impact of peacekeeping, global warming, air and water pollution, deforestation, change in climatic conditions, etc.

Vasant Panchami at The Nalanda Academy

Vasant Panchami was celebrated by students of The Nalanda Academy in a traditional way. All the kids were in yellow attire and a special assembly was conducted with Saraswati Vandana. The teamwork and co-operation made this celebration successful.

Fravashi bids farewell to the X batch of 2019-2020

Fravashi International Academy bid a warm farewell to its class X batch of 2019-2020 in a glorious function. The Master and Miss Fravashi contest was the highlight of this event. All boys and girls ramp walked as they flaunted their finest attires. Based on the confidence and presence of mind of the contestants, at the end of two tough rounds, Rajat Patil and Rucha Malpure won the coveted titles. The students were taken down memory lane by a presentation that made everyone quite emotional. They also pledged to uphold the values inculcated in them by the school in a solemn ceremony.

Title: Transport official warns parents of minors found driving vehicles without licence
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vellore: Action will be taken against parents of minor children spotted driving vehicles without driving licence , warned Tenkasi S Jawahar, principal secretary and transport commissioner, while participating in the regional level road safety meeting for officials of the composite Vellore district (Ranipet, Vellore and Tirupattur) and Tiruvannamalai district on Tuesday.

During analysis, compared to other factors, it was found that road accidents on arterial roads in towns and cities were because of minor school students riding two-wheelers without licence and flouting safety regulations, Jawahar said. Apart from taking action against the minors , appropriate punishment and fines would be imposed on their parents too, he said.

Addressing the media, Jawahar said, “According to reports from road transport and highways department, government of India, in 2016, Tamil Nadu topped the number of road accidents with more than 17,000 fatal accidents. Following joint preventive and enforcement measures adopted by police, state highways, traffic, school education and transport departments, fatal accidents decreased to 10,000 in 2019. In the composite Vellore district, there were 870 fatal road accidents in 2016, but it decreased to 375 in 2019. Our vision is to create an environment with zero fatal accidents by 2030.”

“During the meeting, we discussed ideas with SPs and DSPs of all four districts and other department officials on how to enforce the helmet rule for both riders and pillions who are the most vulnerable road users,” he said. Out of the 3 crore registered vehicle users in Tamil Nadu, 2.45 crore were found to be two-wheeler users, he said.

When asked about the key strategies to reduce fatal accidents, Jawahar said the main reasons for road accidents is unskilled drivers and bad roads. While bad roads could be repaired after holding discussion with the authorities concerned, we plan to give intensified training and awareness to unskilled drivers, he said.

Title: Five years on, VSPF yet to get share capital and corpus fund
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

VSPF was floated in 2015 as a JV for operations and maintenance of Sama indoor sports complex and Manjalpur ou... Read More

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) is yet to pay the share capital and its share of the corpus fund for the VMC Sports Promotion Foundation (VSPF). VMC has not been issued shares of the foundation that is a joint venture (JV) between the civic body and the Sports Authority of Gujarat (SAG).

VSPF was floated in 2015 as a JV for operations and maintenance of the Sama indoor sports complex as well as the Manjalpur outdoor sports complex. Sports complexes are amongst the prestigious projects taken up by the Vadodara civic body.

The VMC was to pay Rs 5 lakh towards shares of VSPF and another Rs 10 crore towards the corpus fund for the foundation. VSPF has been sending reminders regarding the amount to the VMC. The interest from the corpus fund is used for the upkeep of the two sports complexes. Sources said that SAG has paid its share of the corpus fund. Sources said that the auditors of VSPF have also pointed this out to the VSPF from time to time.

Sources said that the issue has been raised in board meetings of the VSPF too. VMC commissioners or other officials attending the meetings have also been apprised of the situation in the meetings itself. The issue was also raised in the board meeting last month.

VMC officials have promised to take up the issue with the elected wing and get a nod for disbursing the amount to VSPF. But the civic body’s fund crunch and the fact that the elected wing is not very happy with VSPF working style may be hurdles in the process.

Title: Chennai: Marina beach to have only 900 carts; Loop Road decision in 2 days
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Shops at the Marina beach (File Photo)

CHENNAI: It is official now. The Marina beach will have only 900 shops, and each of them will pay Rs 3,000 as annual licence fee and monthly rent of Rs 1,000 to Rs 1,500 to the corporation. In two days, authorities will finalise laying a concrete footpath along the Loop Road, off the Light House, in consultation with the CRZ officials.

A submission to this effect was made by the corporation to a division bench of Justices Vineet Kothari and R Suresh Kumar on Tuesday, in response to orders passed by the bench. While those with corporation-supplied carts with motor will pay Rs 1,500, carts without motor will pay Rs 1,000 a month, said additional advocate general S R Rajagopal. The plea was posted to February 6.

A total of 900 carts meant to be allotted to licensed vendors are being purchased at Rs 16.47 crore, Rajagopal said, adding publication inviting applications for allotment of carts and licence would be issued on Wednesday. Rent and licence fee details will be published in the application so that applicants are made aware of the conditions.

The issue pertains to a batch of pleas moved including one by Fishermen Care organisation seeking to enhance allowance provided to fishermen families during the fishing ban period. During the course of hearing, the court expanded the scope of the litigation and directed the corporation to regulate hawking in Marina and the Loop Road.

Title: Differently abled student bags national child award
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Puducherry: A differently-abled student from Puducherry has bagged the national child award (Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar) for 2020 for his exceptional achievements in academic and extra-curricular activities.

R Venkatasubramanian, a Class XI student of Kendriya Vidyalaya at Jipmer campus, received the award from President Ram Nath Kovind in a function at New Delhi.

Born with deformed left arm, Venkatasubramanian overcame his disability by channelising his energy into a wide range of fields, including abacus, karate, scouts and yoga.

He bagged the national gold medals in abacus for two consecutive years — 2014 and 2015 — and clinched a national silver medal in 2016.

“I solved the maximum number of problems (addition, subtraction, division and multiplication including numbers with two decimals) in the given three minutes in the two nationals bagging gold medals (2014 and 2015). I finished second in 2016 nationals,” said Venkatasubramanian.

His father C Ramamoorthy alias Vaithianathan is a driver in a private firm while his mother R Jayapradha is a homemaker.

A regular participant in the national integration youth camps, Venkatasubramanian overcame 75% disability to finish third in the state-level karate tournament in 2012-13. He has also received a certificate for Rajapuraskar as a scout in Bharat Scout and Guides held at Kendriya Vidyalaya, Ernakulam.

Taking a break from all his extra-curricular activities, Venkatasubramanian has now set two goals in his life – one to win a medal in Paralympics (international multi-sport event for the differently-abled) for the country in badminton and the other to join civil services and serve the country. Ramamoorthy and Jayapradha are confident that their only son will realise his dreams. Jose Mathew, Kendriya Vidyalaya (Jipmer) principal, said the strength of his student is to set realistic goals. “He is among several differently-abled people who prove that disability is a state of mind,” said Jose Mathew.

“I joined an academy to hone my badminton skills to successfully compete at the international level,” Venkatasubramanian said. He along with his mother called on lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi and sought her blessings on Monday after receiving the award from the President.

Title: Ahmedabad travel agency employee held for overcharging SoU visitors
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: The Kevadia police in Narmada district on Tuesday arrested employee of a travel agency for overcharging tourists for entry tickets to Statue of Unity (SoU). The accused had tampered with the tickets and charged more money from the Delhi-based tourists.

The police said that it is yet to arrest owner of the Ahmedabad-based Rao Travel Agency. “We have nabbed the computer operator Jay Hakani who used to issue tickets to the tourists. We are looking for owner of the agency as he too is the prime accused,” said A D Rathwa, police sub-inspector, Kevadiya.

The police said that it is investigating the case further to find out if the accused had overcharged other tourists too for SoU tickets. The racket surfaced on Sunday when Ehsaan Saiyad, who works as ticket coordinator at SoU, noticed anomalies in the entry fees rate on the tickets that the tourists produced.

Saiyad got 10 express tickets having Rs 1,260 written on them towards entry charges, whereas the actual entry fee is Rs 1,030 per person. The matter was reported to SoU officials who then filed a complaint with the police. The tourists told the police that they had booked the tickets from a Delhi-based travel agency that in turn had got the tickets from Rao Travel Agency.

The accused duped the tourists of Rs 2,300. This is second such incident within a year. In May 2019, a travel agency was busted for overcharging on SoU entry tickets. SoU officials have urged the visitors to directly book the tickets online without involving any agent.

Title: Chennai: After FOB, more CMRL cabs for metro commuters
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Edappadi K Palaniswami on Tuesday inaugurated an FoB on GST Road linking Alandur metro station

CHENNAI: After a foot overbridge (FoB) was opened on Tuesday giving commuters quick entry to Alandur metro station, Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) will add more cabs to its existing fleet to provide commuters with easy access to all metro stations. The FoB built at a cost of Rs 9.7crore on the busy GST Road, nearly five years after the station started operations, was inaugurated by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami.

A CMRL official said by April they will have about 256 share cabs. The 32 stations of phase-1 will get eight cabs each providing commuters a feeder service for first and last mile connectivity. The cabs will be linked to an existing app where commuters can select one of the pick-up locations given for each station and either pay online or through smart card. “The fleet will be ready in three months. The app-based service will replace other share taxis and share autos,” the official said.

At present, the share cab service is being operated at 16 stations with 32 cars. But commuters complain that the service is erratic and not enough cabs are available, particularly during peak hours.

The FoB has several facilities for an easy and safe access for commuters including four escalators, two elevators, LED lights, CCTV cameras and ramps. The facility links the city’s largest elevated transit hub at Alandur with the air-conditioned bus stop at Asarkhana and the upcoming inter-modal urban square under Kathipara grade separator.

S Bhuvaneshwari from Tambaram was one of the first metro commuters to use the facility soon after it was inaugurated through video conferencing. “It usually takes me 30 minutes to reach the station from Asarkhana bus stop which is on the opposite side of GST Road because I walk all the way upto Kathipara flyover and cross the road. Today, it took me just three minutes,” said Bhuvaneshwari, who takes metro at Alandur to go to her office at CMBT daily.

Title: Amid protests, AMU proctor quits
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

AGRA: The proctor of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Tuesday stepped down from his post and the varsity said it was mulling rescheduling the exams missed by protesting students in an apparent bid to break to deadlock between the administration and the protesters.

The varsity’s move to placate the frayed nerves met with mixed responses. A large group of protesting students was not impressed and said they will not settle with anything less than the scalps of the vice-chancellor (VC) and registrars who they hold responsible for the entry of security personnel into the campus.

AMU proctor Afifullah Khan did not specify reason for his resignation. He stepped down days after students launched an agitation demanding his resignation along with that of VC Tariq Mansoor and registrar Abdul Hamid after the December 15 violence in the campus which left several of them injured.

Prof Khan’s resignation was accepted by the vice chancellor, who appointed Professor Mohammad Wasim Ali of the law department as the new proctor.

After the violence on the night of December 15, thousands of students of various faculties have been on an agitation demanding resignation of top university officials, including the proctor, for the alleged police excesses in the campus. They also gave a miss to exams.

AMU’s coordination committee member Faizul Hassan, who is also the former students’ union president, said that though this move is “welcome”, but the students will not call off their stir till their other demands, including resignation of the VC and the registrar, are fulfilled.

Meanwhile, varsity spokesperson Rahat Abrar said, “The university is back to normal to some extent, and efforts are on to address other pending issues including quashing of the FIRs lodged against students of the varsity.”

He said, barring a few departments, classes were held in the university on Tuesday and the “examinations will be rescheduled soon”.

According to university officials, the proctor’s resignation has helped “build confidence among students and the administration is hopeful that the situation will normalise by next week”.

Title: AMU students booked for burning effigies of PM, HM and CM
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Students burnt effigies and raised slogans

AGRA: Twenty one students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) were booked by Aligarh police on Tuesday for allegedly burning effigies of Prime Minister Narendra Modi , home minister Amit Shah and UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath on the campus on Monday evening.

According to police, the group of students, six of whom have been identified, had also written slogans of ‘Hinduatva terror down down’, ‘Islamophobic Yogi’ on the effigies. They burnt the effigies and raised slogans on the campus.

Civil Lines circle officer Anil Samaniya said that the students have been booked under section 6 of UP Special Power Act 1932 and section 153 A (promoting enmity between different groups on ground of religion) of IPC at Civil Lines police station.

The identified students are Ammar Ahmad, Amirull Jaish, Nadeem Haidar, Ashif Hussain, Farhan, and Nihad PV.

Meanwhile, Aligarh police also issued notices to 153 people including women to sign a bond agreeing that they would be liable to face legal action if any untoward incident takes place outside Shahjamal Idgah where a large number of women have been on a sit-in for the past one week against the CAA and NRC.

According to police, men, who are providing logistic support to the protesting women, have also been issued notices.

Title: IIT-Madras technology to be showcased at Lucknow DefExpo
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Indian Institute of Technology Madras

CHENNAI: From multirole expendable UAVs to Ramjet projectile technology, researchers from Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IIT-M) will showcase next-gen defence technologies at the February 5-9 DefExpo 2020 in Lucknow. IIT-M, the knowledge partner of Tamil Nadu Defence Corridor, will be part of TIDCO (Tamil Nadu Industrial Development Corporation) pavilion in the expo.

Professor Lt Gen (retd) P R Shankar, department of aerospace engineering at IIT-M, said, “We are now on the verge of making a mark in the defence industry through technologies developed by our faculty and through our startups incubated in our research parks. We have come a long way since the last DefExpo held in Chennai.”

Multirole expendable UAVs that will encompass surveillance, logistics, NBC (nuclear, biological, chemical weapons) monitoring, and offensive roles, which is in the process of design and development, will be one of the technologies to be showcased at the expo. When the development of the UAV project is complete, it will build a substantial non-contact warfare capabilities into the armed forces; the researchers said.

A next-generation artillery combat command and control network, which is under development, will also be showcased. The network has been proposed to be based on Shakti process developed by IITM in a lightweight tablet configuration. It will be a precursor to secure net-centricity in the armed forces incorporating all new weapon systems. The ramjet projectile technology, under development, for incorporation in Artillery projectiles will also be showcased.

The institute will also sign two MoUs. One with Ordnance Factory Board for establishing a joint Centre of Excellence for Ammunition in emerging technologies in hypersonic/ supersonic ballistics. Another with Bharat Electronics Limited for establishing research and collaboration in the areas of ‘Propellants, Explosives and Related Technologies.

Title: Church reiterates stand on ‘Love Jihad’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

KOCHI: Despite clarification issued in Lok Sabha on non-existence of Love Jihad in Kerala on Tuesday, the Syro-Malabar Church has said that the circumstances under which they made the statement exists.

Answering a question by Benny Behanan MP, Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy had stated that “no such case of ‘Love Jihad’ has been reported by any of the central agencies”. He also said that “the term Love Jihad is not defined under the extant laws”.

In a statement, the Syro-Malabar Church said the public affairs commission discussed the report presented before the Lok Sabha. “The Synod has, at no point in time, made any statement or observation that will in any way threaten the longstanding friendship and understanding existing between the Christian and the Muslim communities. The Synod only demanded that the authorities concerned should probe the issue as this matter might adversely affect the families and the society at large. The circumstances under which the Synod made this statement still exists,” the statement said. The Church expressed its concern in the matter after carefully examining various reports furnished by the different dioceses across the state, it said.

The commission also observed that the stand of the Church has been misinterpreted by vested interests which could lead to serious consequences. Objecting to such moves, it alleged that it is being used in news channels and other media continually with the ulterior motive of endangering the communal harmony in Kerala. The statement requested members of the church as well as the civil society to be cautious and alert towards such intents.

“It is the earnest desire of the Syro-Malabar Church to maintain and preserve the communal harmony and brotherhood that prevails in our state,” the commission said, reminding the faithful to maintain extreme caution in this regard.

Title: Hospitals mark World Cancer Day with screenings, events
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The ‘Jumble Sale’, organized by Cochin Cancer Research Centre as part of World Cancer Day programme, raised Rs... Read More

Kochi: On Tuesday, various hospitals celebrated World Cancer Day by launching a screening programme or creating awareness about the disease. According to WHO, one in 10 Indians will develop cancer during their lifetime and one in 15 will die of the disease.

The district-level awareness programme started with Valanthakad PHC ’s programme at Maradu Sreedevi auditorium. They discussed preventive steps like ensuring daily exercise and ending unhealthy habits. There was also a one-act play named ‘Arbudam’, to convey a message: fight against the disease.

Lisie hospital conducted an awareness class on various types of cancer and their symptoms. It ended with a street play to create awareness among people. Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences (AIMS) inaugurated a specialized clinic for all breast-related ailments. “The unit offers the best healthcare package for multi-disciplinary consultation for female patients,” said Dr Beena KV, senior medical administrator at AIMS. Every year, AIMS treats over 500 cases of breast cancer.

On the other hand, DDRC SRL Diagnostic Services launched an innovative blood test named Agkura personal score to aid early detection of breast cancer in women. They have tied up with USA-based biotechnology company, OncoTAb, Inc, to provide these tests.

Meanwhile, Aster Medcity in association with NSS unit of department of polymer science and rubber technology at Cusat organized an awareness programme, for early detection of cancer. “In 20 years, major progress was made in cancer treatment. One-third cancer deaths can be avoided by detecting and treatment ,” said Dr Jem Kalathil, lead senior consultant (surgical oncology ) at Aster Medcity.

On the other hand, VPS Lakeshore hospital organized a cancer awareness session with people, in which they got to interact with specialists including Dr VP Gangadharan.

The participants will also be offered a free consultation with one of the oncologists at the hospital at later date .

‘Green jackfruit flour prevented leukopenia ’

Meanwhile, a study of 50 solid tumor patients over six chemo cycles in a private hospital showed that inclusion of green jackfruit flour as a dietary intervention prevented chemotherapy-induced leukopenia in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

Many patients having leukopenia needed expensive antibiotics and anti-fungal treatments. “The solid tumor patients were given 30g or three tablespoons of green jackfruit flour/day along with their regular food didn’t develop leukopenia in six cycles of chemotherapy. Since there was no leukopenia, there was no additional costs, dose reduction or rescheduling, which ultimately improved cure rates and 5-year survivals,” said Dr Thomas Varughese, oncologist and surgeon, Renai Medicity hospital.

Title: Robbers damage two police vans in 10km chase
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Caption

Vadodara: Robbers speeding away in a truck and chased by two police cars with beacon lights with blaring siren. This may seem like a scene from a crime thriller, but this was the scene on the national highway-48 between Jambuva and Kapurai chowkdi on Tuesday early morning.

Two PCR vans chased around a dozen robbers for nearly 10 km after catching them red-handed siphoning off betel nuts and dry fruits from a parked container truck.

According to Rupsinh Baria, in-charge of one of the PCR vans, he suspected something fishy on seeing a few men shifting bags from the container truck to another in the parking bay near Jambuva bridge. Seeing the PCR vans approaching from a distance, the robbers quickly got into their trucks. Baria, an assistant sub-inspector, asked his driver Dhanpalsinh Manusinh to stop the van right behind the truck.

However, the truck driver reversed the vehicle, crashed it into the PCR van and sped towards Ahmedabad. The police vehicle’s bonnet and headlights were damaged, yet the two cops chased them and informed police control room. On the way, some men from the truck pelted stones at the PCR van due to which the windshield got damaged.

Another PCR van joined the chase from Tarsali on getting the wireless message. The other PCR van’s driver Chetansinh Vikramsinh tried to overtake the truck on Kapurai bridge. But the truck driver shoved the car away by brushing his heavy vehicle on the driver’s side. The other police vehicle was also damaged badly due to the impact.

Cops followed the truck even as it turned towards Dabhoi at Kapurai chowkdi. But with broken headlights, the cops could not follow the truck much. After a distance, the two vehicles turned back towards Makarpura police station where they registered an offence of attempt to murder, assaulting to deter public servant from performing his duty and Damage to Public Property Act.

“We have got the truck’s registration number, but it turns out that it was fake. We are checking the footages of CCTV camera to find out more details about the truck,” said inspector R A Patel of Makarpura police station.

Title: Man, 65, gets 11 years in jail for sexually assaulting girl
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Police bring health clinics under scanner
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

KOCHI: A day after issuing notices to all hospitals in the city, the police team, which is investigating the incident in which the body of a preterm baby was found in a bucket in Perandoor Canal at Elamakkara , has brought health clinics under its jurisdiction under the scanner.

The decision was in the wake of reports that several clinics in the city are illegally helping to carry out abortion and the police suspect that the baby’s body could have been dumped after abortion in one of those clinics.

Though the police have sent a notice to all hospitals on Sunday invoking Section 91 of CrPC (summons to produce document or other thing) seeking details like whether any premature baby was delivered or aborted in any of the hospitals in the recent dates, not many hospitals have submitted the details till Monday night. “We are checking the clinics in the city too,” said an officer.

Meanwhile, top police sources said they have identified the parents of the baby and the hospital where it was delivered. They said that more details cannot be divulged now.

“The investigation is proceeding and we are yet to confirm why the body was abandoned in such a manner,” said a top police officer.

Title: 7 states to emulate antimicrobial resistance strategic action plan
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kerala Antimicrobial Resistance Strategic Action Plan (KARSAP) to combat the growing cases of antimicrobial immunity arising primarily from irrational use of medicines and excessive antibiotics used in livestock and poultry will be emulated by the seven states in the country.

Andhra Pradesh, Telengana , Karnataka , Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu , Goa and Puducherry have evinced interest in implementing the action plan to reduce the antibiotic use, said health minister K K Shailaja adding that the action plan has already attracted national attention. She was speaking at a workshop organised to provide training for the health officials from these seven states.

By 2021, the state is intended to become antibiotic literate. Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) is a serious public health threat. Major drivers of AMR include inappropriate use of antimicrobials in healthcare as well as in animal husbandry, especially those used for non-therapeutic purpose like growth promotion and in agriculture and fisheries. AMR cannot be completely eradicated however, collaborative and comprehensive action needs to be taken to reduce the prevalence and spread of antimicrobial resistance, said the minister.

To minimise the development of AMR and to maintain the effectiveness of existing antimicrobials, an integrated overarching “one health” approach is essential in addressing this complex and challenging issue. The KARSAP has been developed involving multiple sectors and it addresses a wide range of activities required to tackle AMR problem effectively, she said.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: We are not soft nationalists, we are hardcore nationalists
Content:
NEW DELHI: Chief minister

says

created Shaheen Bagh because it could not counter the good work done by the

government in the past five years. In a wide-ranging interview with

Subhendu Mukherjee

and

Alok KN Mishra,

a day before campaigning comes to an end, he offered to open a window for cooperating with the corporations by giving them funds for specific projects, recalled how the Anna movement was all about hardcore patriotism, expressed concern about the violence wracking university campuses, and reiterated his commitment to work for the people of Delhi.

In any election, there is a lot of rhetoric from all sides. But this time personal attacks and communal overtones reached unprecedented levels. You were called a terrorist more than once, even by a Union minister. Where do you think is it coming from?

Do you wish Shaheen Bagh had not happened?

Independent of this, Shaheen Bagh has emerged as a symbol of the anti-CAA movement. What would you like to say about it?

Except for fielding Manish Sisodia and Bhagwant Mann, you carried the burden of the entire campaigning for your party while BJP unleashed a phalanx of senior leaders in the past 15 days. Will this have any effect on the election outcome?

AAP’s manifesto has promised deshbhakti curriculum. What was the need for it?

Political observers feel you are taking a soft nationalist stand.

kattar rashtrabhakt

Is that the reason why you did not go to Shaheen Bagh, Jamia and JNU?

Do you empathize with the students because there is turmoil in all campuses.

So, whom do you blame for this?

How is Arvind Kejriwal of February 2015 and that of February 2020 different? What has five years of being chief minister taught you and how has it changed you?

dhurandhar

You spoke about patience. Do you think that the initial one or two years were spent in combat. It could have been utilised in a better way.

You spoke about sanitation. What is the reason behind Delhi being a dirty city? What do you plan to do about it?

How will you tackle this?

Municipal polls are far away. You have promised to focus on sanitation in a major way. But the performance of the municipal corporations, which say that they are starved of funds, does affect the quality of life in Delhi. What is the way out?

Is there a way to address the grievance of corporation on funds?

You have questioned BJP about the lack of a chief minister face. Amit Shah has said that every citizen of Delhi is BJP’s CM candidate.

Pollution is Delhi’s biggest problem and it affects the poor the most. You did odd-even and the pollution level has come down but it is still a major issue.

BJP leaders are promising smog towers for Delhi.

Congress appears to be absent from the election campaign in Delhi. There are rumours that Congress has worked out a tactical alliance with Aam Aadmi Party.

You talked about giving transport a push in the next five years but buses did not come to Delhi in as many numbers as expected.

The modes of para transit like autos, e-rickshaws and grameen sevas are known for breaking traffic laws. Efforts to regulate them trigger an outcry on grounds like they belong to economically backward section.

The issue of hanging of Nirbhaya convicts has turned political when it is actually a legal issue. How did this happen?

But Nirbhaya’s parents are blaming your government.

You have been urging people to vote for AAP irrespective of the parties they belong to. Are you disassociating elections from ideology? And what has been your feedback?

Does that mean scaling down of your national ambitions?

The Anna movement which led to AAP’s birth and your party forming the government had a larger message and a larger resonance, much beyond Delhi. What will happen to that if you confine yourself to local issues?

Does that mean you want to adopt a non-confrontational approach with the Centre?

How has your relationship with the lieutenant governor evolved?

How will the guarantee card that you launched a few days back work and what if midway progress is very slow and things do not turn out the way they should be. Will the response to criticism also be innovative?

Those who have left you — like Kapil Mishra and Kumar Vishwas — are bitter and indulge in personal attacks on you. They were close to you. How do you react to it?

Law and order is not under you but we have seen since Sheila Dikshit’s time that its implementation always has implications for the Delhi government. What is your assessment of Delhi Police?

What do you have to say about the man who fired at Shaheen Bagh and has turned out to be an AAP worker, according to the police?

Are the pictures fake?

Do you think EC has done enough to check hate speech in the elections?

How have been your meetings with the PM and home minister?

Your manifesto talks about developing the river front. Isn’t that what the Centre will be doing?

During Sheila Dikshit’s tenure, infrastructure got a big push. Do you think your government has done enough for infrastructure?

It is happening because BJP does not have anything to counter the work that has been done in Delhi. It has tried everything but failed to punch holes in our work. It came out with photographs of some of our schools but these turned out to be fake. It came up with some videos of mohalla clinics but these too turned out to be fake. It came up with the water issue but that too didn’t wash with people. They were left with nothing. They gathered all parties — JD(U), RJD and LJP and formed an alliance — but that did not work. Now they have fielded 200 MPs, 70 union ministers, 11 CMs without any results. They have no option left and are trying to polarize on the lines of Hindu-Muslim.It is BJP that’s deriving benefit from Shaheen Bagh. It is contesting the election on the issue of Shaheen Bagh only, nothing else. The road should be opened. Everyone wants that road to be opened. It is obstructing school buses and ambulances and causing a half-an-hour commute to stretch over three hours. Amit Shah is home minister and the most powerful man in this country. Nobody is going to believe that he cannot get a road opened. It can be opened within 10 minutes if he wishes. He does not want to get the road opened because he wants to keep the Shaheen Bagh issue alive. It is very sad that for one election, he has for one-and-a-half months put people to trouble. Shaheen Bagh has been created only and only by BJP for elections.Shaheen Bagh is an issue only because of the blocked road. Otherwise, it’s not a Delhi specific issue but a national one.We are a small Delhi-centric party and have a shortage of faces. Incidentally, this time all are contesting the election and are busy in their respective assembly constituencies. Manish, Sanjay Singh and Gopal Rai, besides me, have done many public meetings. We do not have many leaders of national stature. Our biggest strength is our people and our work. BJP does not have a counter to our work. They cannot explain what they did in the MCD in the past 15 years. People of Delhi gave me the responsibility for schools and we made the schools better. They gave them responsibility for sanitation and they turned Delhi into a garbage dump (kuda ghar). I want to ask BJP what they have done for a clean Delhi. If Shaheen Bagh ceases to exist as an issue today, they won’t know what to say in their election speeches.Gandhiji had said a student who comes out of school or college should have three qualities — he should be a good human being, be capable of earning for his family and should be a hardcore nationalist. We started the happiness curriculum for making them good human beings, entrepreneurship for pet bharne ke liye (earning a meal) and deshbhakti for making them hardcore nationalists.We are not soft nationalists, we are hardcore nationalists. We have come out of the Anna movement. Under the Anna movement, we put the Indian flag in the hands of every child and it became a matter of pride. We are(hardcore patriots).I do not have any role in that, I have my limitations. I am Delhi CM. I am responsible for education, health, power and water. In case the corporation faces a problem tomorrow, I would not poke my nose in that. It is a law and order problem related to CAA and NRC and I do not have any role in that. Amit Shah will have to tackle it.Violence and politics taking over colleges is not a good thing. We all send our children to study and make a career. Such violence causes a sense of insecurity among people about their children. All over the country, people are feeling insecure about where they should send their children and it is not about three or four universities.I blame the central government. We should keep party politics away from university campuses.I think we are more experienced and have got a little more patience now. When we were out of government, we used to wonder like any other common man why hospitals, roads, schools and water supply are in bad condition and do not improve. We used to feel it has been 70 years, and it must be very complex — that’s why they are unable to do it. All parties have tried but nothing happened.But the earth-shaking changes witnessed in Delhi (in the past five years) prove it can be done. They were all(bigwigs) but the intent was missing. Everyone was looking for personal benefits, and if a person is occupied with personal benefits all time, he will not think about the country and progress. We are not here for making money. We are honest and want to work. Barring the administrative problems due to the power tussle with the lieutenant governor and the Centre, things have moved very fast. Education, health, electricity and water sectors have witnessed big changes. It has ignited hope and now we have a vision for the next five years.The administrative structure had made us restless. After a Delhi high court order, all files were being routed to the LG. The HC almost said that the CM is only an adviser to the LG. How can that be in a democracy? All files were sent to the LG and he did not clear them due to political reasons. It caused restlessness because we had a huge mandate and we were unable to do anything. Ultimately, it is our accountability...people will question us. Subsequently, the SC judgment changed the scenario. It gave us more power.BJP in the municipal corporations does not have any intent to clean Delhi. It is not rocket science. The world has many well-known sanitation firms. If you float a global tender, many companies will come up and clean Delhi.We will do it and make the corporations do it. We will contest the civic elections and hope to win. It’s not rocket science. The most difficult part was education. Building construction, toilet cleaning and water supply were relatively easier. Motivating teachers and doctors was difficult. Now government doctors and teachers are being appreciated. This will also be done.There are many ways of doing things. We had a list of work to do with MCD before the civic elections — vacuum cleaning and painting of roads to make them look tidier. For Yamuna cleaning, we are in an advanced stage of addressing the issue of four major drains flowing into that river by cleaning them with STPs. A lot of work will be done before the corporation elections and a lot after that.We will give the corporations funds earmarked for specific projects — like we are giving you these funds for solid waste management only. Otherwise, they end up diverting funds.That is a political position. People have the right to know who the chief minister face will be, whom they are voting for. People elect a CM but BJP does not believe in democracy. If you make an illiterate person CM later, it will be like cheating people of Delhi. BJP should disclose their CM face. I want to debate with him.The silver lining is that pollution has come down, not gone up. In other cities, pollution is going up but we have brought it down by 25%. In 2015, the average AQI was 155 while it was 115 last year. The real problem manifests between October and February due to stubble burning and temperature inversion. Due to frequent power cuts, around 6 lakh generators were operational in 2015 in Delhi. The 24-hour power supply has led to the generators being switched off. Eastern and western peripheral expressways, increase of green cover with 1100 acres of additional land being used for afforestation and other factors have reduced pollution.In next five years we will take several steps, including tackling of dust pollution and greening of open areas. Transport will get a push which we hope will reduce the number of two-wheelers. As of now, no one knows the real sources of pollution because we do not have equipment to measure. Pollution changes every minute and varies from month to month. So, we have tied up with Washington University. From April 1, a lab for real-time source apportionment of pollution will be functional and on-the-spot decisions about tackling particular reasons for pollution can be taken.Smog towers are overrated. We had sent some people to China to study smog towers, but these have not been successful. If they are successful, we will install them.We do not have any understanding with any party. I believe Congress will get confined to 2% to 3% of vote share in this election. Various surveys are showing that they have been reduced to a vote share of 2% to 3%. People do not see any hope in Congress.The reason was that in 2017 we had executed the work order for new buses but someone went to HC and got a stay on purchase. It took us three years to get the stay vacated. It was vacated only six-seven months ago. It caused a delay. But buses have now started coming, and in four to five months I think we will have 4000 more.Delhi is facing an overall issue of traffic indiscipline and it involves all vehicles. It is related to enforcement. Enforcement agencies are not under us. If the enforcement agencies become a little stricter, the situation will improve. Hike in traffic fines has led to some improvement.Delhi government does not have any role in it. We do not have the police or judicial system under us. Our role is confined to forwarding the files received from MHA to prison and the ones received from prison to MHA.Nirbhaya’s parents are simple folk and are being misled.I am saying that for the first time a party has improved schools and hospitals. If you vote for other parties, they will go back to their earlier condition. So, in national interest and in the interest of your own children, vote for AAP.There is no such national ambition. People of Delhi voted for me for Delhi. They will vote for me for Delhi for the next five years. I will be in Delhi for the next five years. The party will decide whether it wants to contest elections at other places.Improving schools is a national issue, not confined to Delhi. All over the country, schools are in a bad condition. Roads and hospitals should be better. Twenty first century India will not be built by Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens. It will be built by better schools, colleges and hospitals and progress in our space programme. In the past five years, the capital has given the country a model of development. This model can build 21st century India.I was never confrontational. Whenever we were seen being confrontational, confrontation was imposed on us. Like LG was sitting over the CCTV camera file which was cleared after our dharna. We needed to get confrontational only to get work for people of Delhi done. After the Supreme Court judgment, we do not need to get confrontational anymore.He is an excellent person. I have high respect for him. We have very good relations. I think the Supreme Court judgement helped.I have given a five-year guarantee. I will be answerable if work is not done in five years.It feels bad but it is part of politics.Delhi Police is good. It can become the most efficient police force of the country provided those controlling it are good. They can control crime if they are given clear instructions and there is no interference.Delhi Police is being used as a political tool. As I told you, BJP has nothing to counter our work with. When nothing worked, they hurled abuses like terrorist, thug and anti-national at me. DelhiPolice is their last resort. Suddenly, before elections they have come up with some photos claiming that he is an AAP member. His family members have denied any links with AAP. The country is watching how Amit Shah is coming up with conspiracies at the last moment. The person must be punished, and if he turns out to be an AAP worker, give him double the punishment.I do not know. We do not know that person.I think they could have done much more. They could have stopped whatever is going on. They did take some steps but after the bans were lifted, they began all over again…lost any fear.After Narendra Modi became PM, I went to call on him. I told him he was the PM of the country and I the CM of the capital city. So, it is extremely important that both governments and both of us have extremely cordial relations. He appreciated that. The home minister has, however, not given me an appointment.It involves multiple agencies. I had advised them to create a special purpose vehicle for it like Delhi Metro. The first task is to clean the Yamuna and after that the river front will be developed. We will give the land we hold for the purpose.All infrastructure development under Sheila Dikshit took place during the Commonwealth Games. An amount of Rs 70,000 crore was pumped into the capital. In 15 years, 65 flyovers were constructed. Our government constructed 27 in five years. All such work fails to get any attention when people talk about our work in the areas of health, education, water and power which have been highlighted more.In Video: We are staunch nationalists: Arvind Kejriwal's exclusive to TOI

Title: Nandanam Junction: Nandanam signal to close for four-way traffic from today
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Following complaints about congestion, traffic at Nandanam junction will revert to the pattern followed during... Read More

CHENNAI: Motorists proceeding from Venkatanarayana Road to Anna Salai will once again have to take a circuitous route from Wednesday as the Chennai Traffic Police are bringing back the changes they made during metro rail construction. The move came after complaints poured into the traffic control room about congestion at Nandanam junction. The changes will be on a trial basis for a week.

Between 2012 and 2019, several changes were made on all approach roads to Nandanam junction due to metro rail construction. Vehicles from Venkatanarayana Road in T Nagar had to turn to South Boag Road and Pondy Bazaar before joining Anna Salai or take Burkit Road and Mooparappan Street before joining Anna Salai.

In July 2019, police reverted to the old arrangement, allowing four-way traffic at the junction, that existed before 2012. Almost after seven years, motorists could use the stretch again from all sides. Though Cmrl started metro rail services in May 2018, it handed over the stretch to traffic police to open it for regular traffic a couple of months later. In July 2019, vehicular movement on both sides was allowed from Cenotaph Road and Nandanam signal.

After the old changes were brought in, motorists began complaining of traffic snarls at the Nandanam junction and requested police to bring back the old arrangement. As police too were struggling to regulate traffic particularly during peak hours with the re-stored old traffic pattern, they decided to bring back the changes they made during the construc-tion of Nandanam metro station and tunnels.

Title: Farrukhabad hostage crisis: Mediator claims abductor was harassed by 2 cops, wanted them punished
Content:
Anupam Dubey was shot at and injured by Batham while trying to negotiate peace

AGRA: Four days after a murder convict was shot dead by police during an encounter to rescue 25 children, a man who tried to mediate during the 9-hour long stand-off claimed on Tuesday that the abductor wanted punishment for two policemen who “tortured him” in custody in a theft case and asked “sexual favour” from his wife in lieu of his release.When contacted, senior district police officials rejected the charges, but assured a probe into the allegation and into the role of the two policemen.The accused, Subhash Batham , was shot dead early on Friday while his wife died hours later on the way to hospital after being brutally attacked by locals in Farrukhabad ’s Kathariya village. Batham organised a birthday party for his daughter and then held 25 children who were his “guests” hostage on Thursday.On Tuesday, when TOI contacted Anupam Dubey alias Balloo , who was shot at and injured by Batham while trying to negotiate peace, said, “During my one-hour interaction with Batham, he accused two police constables of Farrukhabad of torturing him in custody. He also alleged that the policemen also asked sexual favours from his wife in lieu of his release in a theft case.”A contractual driver of UP roadways, Dubey was approached by Bhojpur MLA Nagendra Singh to talk to Batham during the stand-off.“Everyone present there heard Batham, but no one did anything. The entire drama was set up to attract administration’s attention in order to punish those two policemen,” said Dubey.When asked why he was shot by Batham, Anupam said, “I don’t think he wanted to shoot me.”Additional superintendent of police, Farrukhabad, Tribhuwan Singh said, “Batham planned this entire hostage situation for many months to extort money. He demanded Rs 1 crore for each child taken hostage. He constructed basement in his house several months ago and also gathered heavy explosive material to target policemen.”“We will look into the harassment allegation and question the policemen whose names have come up,” he added.In Video: Farrukhabad abduction drama: Kidnapper accused 2 cops of seeking sexual favours from his wife, says mediator
