A lot of work will be done before the corporation elections and a lot after that.We will give the corporations funds earmarked for specific projects — like we are giving you these funds for solid waste management only. Otherwise, they end up diverting funds.That is a political position. People have the right to know who the chief minister face will be, whom they are voting for. People elect a CM but BJP does not believe in democracy. If you make an illiterate person CM later, it will be like cheating people of Delhi. BJP should disclose their CM face. I want to debate with him.The silver lining is that pollution has come down, not gone up. In other cities, pollution is going up but we have brought it down by 25%. In 2015, the average AQI was 155 while it was 115 last year. The real problem manifests between October and February due to stubble burning and temperature inversion. Due to frequent power cuts, around 6 lakh generators were operational in 2015 in Delhi. The 24-hour power supply has led to the generators being switched off. Eastern and western peripheral expressways, increase of green cover with 1100 acres of additional land being used for afforestation and other factors have reduced pollution.In next five years we will take several steps, including tackling of dust pollution and greening of open areas. Transport will get a push which we hope will reduce the number of two-wheelers. As of now, no one knows the real sources of pollution because we do not have equipment to measure. Pollution changes every minute and varies from month to month. So, we have tied up with Washington University. From April 1, a lab for real-time source apportionment of pollution will be functional and on-the-spot decisions about tackling particular reasons for pollution can be taken.Smog towers are overrated. We had sent some people to China to study smog towers, but these have not been successful. If they are successful, we will install them.We do not have any understanding with any party. I believe Congress will get confined to 2% to 3% of vote share in this election. Various surveys are showing that they have been reduced to a vote share of 2% to 3%. People do not see any hope in Congress.The reason was that in 2017 we had executed the work order for new buses but someone went to HC and got a stay on purchase. It took us three years to get the stay vacated. It was vacated only six-seven months ago. It caused a delay. But buses have now started coming, and in four to five months I think we will have 4000 more.Delhi is facing an overall issue of traffic indiscipline and it involves all vehicles. It is related to enforcement. Enforcement agencies are not under us. If the enforcement agencies become a little stricter, the situation will improve. Hike in traffic fines has led to some improvement.Delhi government does not have any role in it. We do not have the police or judicial system under us. Our role is confined to forwarding the files received from MHA to prison and the ones received from prison to MHA.Nirbhaya’s parents are simple folk and are being misled.I am saying that for the first time a party has improved schools and hospitals. If you vote for other parties, they will go back to their earlier condition. So, in national interest and in the interest of your own children, vote for AAP.There is no such national ambition. People of Delhi voted for me for Delhi. They will vote for me for Delhi for the next five years. I will be in Delhi for the next five years. The party will decide whether it wants to contest elections at other places.Improving schools is a national issue, not confined to Delhi. All over the country, schools are in a bad condition. Roads and hospitals should be better. Twenty first century India will not be built by Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens. It will be built by better schools, colleges and hospitals and progress in our space programme. In the past five years, the capital has given the country a model of development. This model can build 21st century India.I was never confrontational. Whenever we were seen being confrontational, confrontation was imposed on us. Like LG was sitting over the CCTV camera file which was cleared after our dharna. We needed to get confrontational only to get work for people of Delhi done. After the Supreme Court judgment, we do not need to get confrontational anymore.He is an excellent person. I have high respect for him. We have very good relations. I think the Supreme Court judgement helped.I have given a five-year guarantee. I will be answerable if work is not done in five years.It feels bad but it is part of politics.Delhi Police is good. It can become the most efficient police force of the country provided those controlling it are good. They can control crime if they are given clear instructions and there is no interference.Delhi Police is being used as a political tool. As I told you, BJP has nothing to counter our work with. When nothing worked, they hurled abuses like terrorist, thug and anti-national at me. DelhiPolice is their last resort. Suddenly, before elections they have come up with some photos claiming that he is an AAP member. His family members have denied any links with AAP. The country is watching how Amit Shah is coming up with conspiracies at the last moment. The person must be punished, and if he turns out to be an AAP worker, give him double the punishment.I do not know. We do not know that person.I think they could have done much more. They could have stopped whatever is going on. They did take some steps but after the bans were lifted, they began all over again…lost any fear.After Narendra Modi became PM, I went to call on him. I told him he was the PM of the country and I the CM of the capital city. So, it is extremely important that both governments and both of us have extremely cordial relations. He appreciated that. The home minister has, however, not given me an appointment.It involves multiple agencies. I had advised them to create a special purpose vehicle for it like Delhi Metro. The first task is to clean the Yamuna and after that the river front will be developed. We will give the land we hold for the purpose.All infrastructure development under Sheila Dikshit took place during the Commonwealth Games. An amount of Rs 70,000 crore was pumped into the capital. In 15 years, 65 flyovers were constructed. Our government constructed 27 in five years. All such work fails to get any attention when people talk about our work in the areas of health, education, water and power which have been highlighted more.In Video: We are staunch nationalists: Arvind Kejriwal's exclusive to TOI

Title: Medaram Jatara: One crore devotees are expected for the biennial jatara at Medara
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Devotees from several states will gather for the four-day festival.

MEDARAM: Some one crore devotees are expected for the biennial jatara at Medara, which will commence on Wednesday. The four-day Sammakka-Saralamma jatara , also dubbed as Telangana’s Kumbh Mela , is Asia’s biggest tribal fair.

Millions of devotees from Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Tamil Nadu and Telangana have set up temporary tents in two kilometre radius of the tiny village of Medaram.

On Tuesday, tribal priests performed rituals for Pagididdaraju, the husband of Sammakka deity, at Punugondla village in Gangaram mandal of Mahabubad district . Priests trooped in from areas about 40km on foot.

On Wednesday evening, Kaka Saraiah, the hereditary priest will perform rituals for Saralamma at Kannepally village. Devotees offer jaggery to the deity during the ritual. The ritual is accompanied by traditional Koya dance.

Authorities have set up a 2km-long bathing ghat with a battery of taps. Some 8,900 temporary toilets have also been set up to ensure there is no open defecation during the festival. A temporary bus terminus has also been set up at Medaram, and the RTC is operating 4,200 buses from Telangana state. One of the highlights of the jatara will be plastic free celebrations.

The TSTDC has launched chopper service from Hyderabad to Medaram at cost of Rs 30 thousand for each passengers. For local pilgrims, a helicopter ride for sightseeing will be provided for Rs 3,000.

Meanwhile, governor Tamilsai Soundararajan and chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao are expected to visit the congregation on February 7. The Sammakka-Saralamma Tadwai mandal comes into Mulugu district, where authorities have announced a three-day holiday.

The South Central Railway will be operating 20 special trains during the festival. Most trains will run between Sirpur-Kagaznagar to Warangal and Secundrabad to Warangal.

Title: TNPSC scam: Key accused, four others held
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The CB-CID on Tuesday arrested police constable K Sithandi, one of the key accused in the 2017 Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) Group II-A examination scam, and four others who with his help secured top ranks and are now working in various government departments.

Police had already frozen the bank accounts of Sithandi, a 2008-batch head constable attached to Armed Reserve wing in Pudupet, and his wife. He had worked with a former chairman of TNPSC.

Police said Sithandi, believed to be involved in manipulating answer sheets in the 2017 Group II-A exam and 2019 Group IV exam, was arrested by a special CB-CID team from a relative’s farm in Sivaganga. Sithandi, who had got himself admitted to a hospital for treatment before going underground, will be interrogated in Chennai on Wednesday.

Sithandi and Chennai resident S Jayakumar, another of those involved in both scams, were found to have been hand in glove with a few agents and some government officials and helped several candidates crack the TNPSC exams and bag government jobs. They collected lakhs of rupees as commission.

Using his contacts, Sithandi helped four of his family members including his wife S Shanmugapriya and brother K Velmurugan clear the Group II-A and Group IV examinations. Police have arrested Velmurugan, an assistant in the Sivaganga District Registrar’s office in Karaikudi, while Shanmugapriya is absconding.

On Monday, the CB-CID also arrested MJ Deepak of Chennai, an employee of the finance department at the state secretariat, N Vinod Kumar, a commercial tax department employee in Vellore , Arun Balaji, a commercial tax department employee in Arcot , and S Devi, who works in the commercial tax department in Nagercoil . The first two paid Rs 8 lakh and Rs 9 lakh to jayakumar, while the other two paid Rs 13 lakh, a press release from the CB-CID said. The CB-CID had announced a reward for any person sharing information leading to the arrest of Jayakumar and circulated his photographs to the authorities at airports, major railway stations and other vital installations.

The TNPSC had banned 99 candidates for life after it was found that they, with help from agents and some government officials, manipulated the answer sheets in the September 1, 2019 Group IV exam using special pens with evaporating ink to shade the answers during exam. After the exam, middlemen and some TNPSC staff reshaded the answer scripts of 52 candidates and reinserted them in the answer sheet bundle on a moving vehicles. Of the 52 candidates, all of who appeared for the exam at the Rameswaram and Keelakarai centres in Ramanathapuram district , 39 ranked within the top 100.

Later, after several candidates alleged that similar malpractices were committed in the 2017 Group II-A exam, an investigation found that 42 candidates, who appeared for the exam at the Rameswaram centre that year, scored high marks by fraudulent means.

Title: CA inter results: Five city students in all-India Top 50
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vadodara: Five students from the city have bagged All India Rank (AIR) in the intermediate and foundation examinations of chartered accountancy conducted by the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI), whose results were declared on Tuesday.

Four students bagged AIR in intermediate (new) examination while one student bagged AIR in CA foundation exams. The examinations were held in November 2019.

Also, a total of 232 students have cleared their exams in integrated professional competency course (IPCC) and intermediate. A total of 478 students had appeared in group-1, group-2 and exams of both the groups of IPCC (old syllabus). Of these, 81 students have cleared the exams giving 16.95 % results.

Another 757 students had appeared for intermediate (new) exams in group-1, group-2 and exams of both the groups. Of these, 151 students cleared their exams giving 19.95 % results.

The Vadodara Branch of the Western India Chartered Accountants Students` Association of ICAI felicitated the toppers of both the examinations.

Ankush Chirimar, who bagged AIR 32 in CA foundation, topped the city by scoring 332 out of 400 marks. A first-year BCom student at MS University’s Faculty of Commerce, Ankush’s father Sanjay is a branch manager in a transport firm while mother Sunita is a homemaker. He wants to complete his bachelors studies along with CA.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Preventive actions to ensure safety of women
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Participants at a KravMaga self-defence workshop

CHENNAI: When news of the Hyderabad-based veterinary doctor’s rape and murder broke last year, a deeply disturbed S Sreeram took to social media to write about how the safety of women had to be addressed at various levels. The post served to bring together a group of like-minded people who felt it is necessary to take preventive action to ensure safety of women . The result is PENN, an initiative that will be launched on February 8 to curb crime against women.

“It will work at various levels. At an individual level, it will educate girls and women on preventive aspects, such as online safety, use of technology and self-defence,” says Sreeram, founder and chief instructor of KravMaga TN Chapter, who has been training women in self-defence since 2009.

At the community level, members of PENN will visit localities, apartment complexes, corporates, and commercial establishments to implement safety practices. “At the governance level, we will be working with various departments like transport, electricity, tourism, education and social welfare to ensure safety in public spaces,” says Sreeram.

Work will be done at the law enforcement level to reduce field level apathy, corruption and increase sensitivity to victims. “Our emphasis is to work on a proactive, 360-degree approach to the problem, including addressing the issue at the legal level to enable a speedy, time bound mechanism to deter perpetrator and thus prevent sexual crimes,” says V S Sridhar, corporate executive and managing trustee of PENN, who reached out to Sreeram after reading his post. “After the Nirbhaya incident, I got in touch with him to conduct self-defence classes for the female employees of the corporate I work for. And later, I felt that we need to take a proactive approach and focus on preventing crime rather than reacting and protesting after something happens.”

Other core members of PENN include V Anand, a technocrat who works on various causes for youth development; Sriram Sharma, director, and music composer; and Swarnalatha Mahesh, senior advocate with a focus on woman and child safety.

PENN’s initiatives will focus on prevention of crime. “It lays stress on situational awareness, understanding criminal psychology, de-escalation, online best practices and using technology for safety,” says Sreeram. “In my experience this knowledge is easily absorbed by women rather than physically demanding self-defence skills, which are the last resort.”

PENN will be launched by selected women achievers from various fields and also a senior police officer in charge of prevention of crimes against women and children. The launch will also feature the dance ballet ‘Velu Nachiyar’.

“It is the vehicle to bring in more girls to participate. It dramatises the martial valour of the first queen who fought the British and kept them at bay for 20 years in the 18th century,” says Sreeram. “PENN plans to train girls in Israeli KravMaga self-defence as part of the ballet, making it a Trojan horse to teach personal safety.”

He will also groom trainers who can extrapolate the knowledge to all vulnerable sections, especially the urban and rural poor. “I will also work to get the state police involved as I am their close-combat trainer since 2013,” says Sreeram.

Sridhar says they will start by conducting self-defence class in colleges and also for women who are more ‘vulnerable’, working late night shifts. “Sensitising men is also an integral part of the campaign. They will be trained how they can help women in distress instead of being a mute spectator,” he says.

Title: Vidyodaya team wins NIE quiz
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

From left: Sai Krishna S Prasad and Sachin Prasanth of Hari Sri Vidya Nidhi; A V Venkata Ram Shenoy and Akhil ... Read More

KOCHI: The Vidyodaya School, Thevakkal , team, comprising Navneeth M Kumar and Shraddha Rajeev, emerged the winner at the Inter-School Fundamental Quiz conducted by Times NIE and Empathy at JTpac, The Choice School, Tripunithura, on Tuesday. The team scored 60 points.

Empathy project principal investigator Dr Neeraj Raizada, who led the Empathy campaign — ‘Empowering People Against Hepatitis — declared the quiz open. The campaign was launched by the Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, with funding from Airports Authority of India. Raizada gave a presentation on hepatitis, its causes and prevention, on which many questions were based.

Chinmaya Vidyalaya, Kannamaly, team, comprising A V Venkata Ram Shenoy and Akhil Kannan, scored 55 points and became the first runner-up. Bhavan’s Vidya Mandir, Elamakkara, team, comprising Abhinav A Warrier and Rishan R Nair, became the second runner-up with 40 points.

Six teams made it to the final — Christopher Joseph and Neo Sebastian from Naipunnya Public School, Kochi , bagged the fourth position; Abhiram Lokanathan and Meera Anilkumar from Chinmaya Vidyalaya, Tripunithura, became fifth followed by Sachin Prasanth and Sai Krishna S Prasad from Hari Sri Vidya Nidhi School, Punkunnam, Thrissur.

Dr Raizada, Empathy project advocacy coordinator Deepthi Katyal and The Choice Schools educational administrator Vimala Jacob gave away prizes to the first six teams.

“The quiz was well organized and provided infotainment. It raised awareness on hepatitis, which is posing a grave threat, and underlined ways to prevent it,” said Navneeth M Kumar.

“This is the largest quiz I have attended. I was very thrilling,” said one of the participants.

Title: Delay in starting approval process by AICTE likely to affect engineering admissions
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: More than a two-month delay in starting approval process by All India Council for Technical Education ( AICTE ) for 2020-21 may affect the engineering admissions in the next academic year.

Usually, AICTE would start inviting applications in the first week of December for extension of approval, variation of intake, starting new courses and new technical institutions. But, so far the council did not release the approval process handbook due to a litigation. “Affiliation and approval is a long process that would take four to five months. Due to delay in starting the process, it may go beyond month of May and that it would affect the admission process,” principals of engineering colleges said.

“The technical council would give 45 days to 60 days to apply for approval process. Then it will take another two to three months to scrutinize the applications and give its approval. It would also make visits to new technical institutions and surprise visits to some of existing institutions,” said B Chidambararajan, principal of Valliammai Engineering College said.

“Though Anna University would send inspection teams to colleges before the approval process, they would issue extension of affiliation only after receiving approval letter from AICTE,” he said. After getting approval and affiliation, the colleges need submit the orders to directorate of technical education (DOTE) for starting admission process. So, all the process should be over before May to start engineering counselling in June.

S R R Senthil Kumar, principal of Sona College of Technology in Salem said without approval process handbook the colleges cannot apply for approval or affiliation for a new course.

“The technical council has permitted the universities to offer courses in eight emerging areas including AI, machine learning and data science, internet of things (IoT), cybersecurity. Many institutions wanted to start new BTech in artifiicial intelligence and data science. But, without knowing nomenclature of the course, the colleges will find it difficult to set up lab and hire faculty members,” he said.

When contacted, AICTE officials said the approval process handbook for would be released this week. “The Supreme Court has delivered the judgement. The council is now vetting the regulations,” officials said adding engineering admissions will not be delayed.

Title: Hyderabad youth drowns while taking holy dip
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

MEDARAM: Two devotees, including a youth from Hyderabad, died in Medaram late on Tuesday evening hours before the jatara commenced. The deceased were identified as 24-year-old Battu Vinay, a resident of Marredpally, and 22-year-old Tama Vinod from Dummugudem mandal in Bhadradri Kothagudem district .

Vinay, who had come to the jatara with his family drowned in the Jampanna Vagu while taking a holy dip. Devotees bathe in the Jampanna Vagu before offering prayers to the deities during Sammakka Saralamma Jatara. In Tama Vinod’s case, police said he suffered convulsions while on his way back from Jampanna Vagu. Police said he was epileptic. Vinod’s body was shifted to the government hospital in Mulugu while Vinay’s body was kept at the Medaram hospital. The latter had come for the Jatara along with his family. Police said that while the deaths were unfortunate, there was no security lapse.

Title: Accenture opens innovation hub, Nano Lab in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Global global professional services company, Accenture , which provides services and solutions in strategy, consulting, digital, technology and operations, on Tuesday opened its new innovation hub in Hyderabad spread over 3 lakh sq ft and a capacity to house 2,000 people.

The new innovation hub, which will enable clients to co-innovate with Accenture by ideating, rapidly prototyping and then scaling disruptive products and services for the digital economy, also houses Accenture’s first Nano Lab in the Asia-Pacific region that will offer clients a window into the latest breakthroughs in applied research from Accenture Labs worldwide, the company said. The Nano Lab will showcase uses for a range of advanced technologies including artificial intelligence, extended reality and security, and allows clients to connect with researchers located in Accenture Labs globally through immersive sessions and workshops.

The Hyderabad innovation hub, which is the latest addition to Accenture’s global innovation network, will also help its clients co-innovate and co-create solutions with over 2,000 Accenture professionals having expertise across multiple industries and advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence, security, extended reality, automation and blockchain.

“Our research shows that organisations are struggling to achieve their innovation goals, due to the lack of an enterprise-wide strategy for technology investments and adoption,” said Bhaskar Ghosh, group chief executive, Accenture Technology Services.

“Through our leading advanced technology capabilities, we help clients scale their technology investments and bridge the innovation achievement gap. Our Innovation Hub in Hyderabad has the pieces our clients require to accelerate value creation through enterprise-wide, game-changing innovation,” he explained.

The Hyderabad Innovation Hub will join others in Bengaluru, Recife and Sao Paulo in Brazil, Toronto, Shenzhen, Helsinki, Tokyo, Zurich, Perth, Singapore and 11 Innovation Hubs in the United States, including Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Detroit, Houston, New York, San Francisco, Seattle and Washington, DC.

Title: KSIE likely to bag tenders for plastic shredders’ supply
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala State Industrial Enterprises Limited ( KSIE ) is set to bag the tender for supply of plastic shredders , baling machines and dust removers to local bodies in the state after qualifying in the technical trial run of machines.

Clean Kerala company (CKC), which is learnt to have completed negotiation with KSIE, is likely to sign an agreement with KSIE this month. CKC was forced to go for new tenders for the supply of plastic shredders after LSG minister A C Moideen directed that supply contract which was earlier bagged by Ram Biologicals cannot be extended.

RTI documents show that Ram Biologicals was paid a total of Rs.11.15 crore between 2017-18 and 2019-20 for the supply of plastic shredding units in the state after the company got its supply contract extended three times. The 29th board meeting of CKC held in September 2019 decided that new tenders may be invited instead of extending Ram Biologicals’ contract. It was also decided that a trial run of machines may be conducted and assessed by a technical committee. Only the financial bids of those firms which complete the trial run successfully may be considered, the board decided.

In October 2019, Ram Biologicals, when asked to do a live demonstration of machinery, sent a communication to Clean Kerala Company saying that the supplier of its machinery is another company and that it shall be considered as demo of Ram Biologicals. The technical committee which assessed various parameters like production rate, vibration levels and noise noted in the report that the shredders supplied by KSIE met most specifications satisfactorily and that the company which supplied machinery for Ram Biologicals did not meet salient requirements.

In 2017, the contract for supply of plastic shredding units was given to Ram Biologicals for a period of six months. However the board gave extensions to the same firm thrice regardless of the higher price it had quoted in the beginning. RTI documents reveal that in the 21st board meeting held on September 9,2017, the principal secretary LSGD opined that the feedback on the performance of the machinery received from local bodies so far was good and he recommended continuing the contract for a further period of six months till the tender validity.

The 25th board meeting held in September 2018 again extended the contract and this time they reasoned that calling for fresh tenders would lead to price enhancement. The contract was renewed even while CKC kept receiving complaints from various local bodies regarding the functionality of machinery.

Title: SVNIT employees face salary issue again
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: There could not be worst start to the new year than this. Salaries of teachers and non-teaching staff of Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT) have been delayed and there is little possibility of they getting the payment before lapse of a week. About 200 teachers, 150 administrative staff, 250 daily wage staff and 300 research scholars are desperately waiting for payment for the past five days.

Institute officials said they did not receive grant for salaries from ministry of human resource development (MHRD). The grant is likely to come by February 10. Interestingly, the institute officials had announced in September that SVNIT’s annual grant has been increased to Rs125 crore from Rs80 crore. There are funds with the institute but they are reserved for specific purpose.

A group of employees in a representation to SVNIT director S R Gandhi on Tuesday demanded that their salaries be paid immediately. The staff were assured that their salaries will be paid at the earliest.

“There were problems in the past, but this time the grant is delayed due to some other issues. We are hopeful of receiving the grant soon,” Gandhi said.

After its annual grant was put on hold for two consecutive years from 2016 by the MHRD, the institute faced severe financial crisis and had to delay payment of salaries for a couple months in 2019. The institute, which has been struggling with financial issues since 2015, is showing signs of stability after replacement of a few top officials now. The institute could not submit audited accounts to MHRD for 2016-17 and 2017-18 because of financial irregularities and absence of bank reconciliation document. In the past, accounts without clearance by The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India were submitted and MHRD had even released grant. But with change in the rules, the grant of SVNIT has been put on hold this time.

Title: BMC budget 2020: Civic body to curb hiring, move FDs to bonds
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BMC

MUMBAI: With the outgo towards salaries of its one lakh-odd employees rising to half of its income, the BMC has placed curbs on hiring. It has also decided to boost its investment income by redeploying surplus funds parked in banks into government bonds and debentures.

Implementation of the seventh pay commission has increased the BMC’s wage burden by Rs 1,300 crore.

It has set a target to bring down its establishment cost by up to 44% in 2020-21.

As part of its cost-cutting measures, the corporation will fill vacancies by taking on apprentices for terms ranging from six months to three years. They will be hired for various departments such as gardens, litigation and accounts. The positions will include those of clerks, engineers and architects. The corporation will discontinue their services upon completion of their term and the apprentices will not have any claims on their job.

“The BMC will not replace retiring employees. Instead, we will hire apprentices who will work with the BMC temporarily. The municipal work experience will help them get jobs subsequently,” said Praveen Pardeshi, municipal commissioner. He further said up to 20% of the corporation’s staff requirements can be fulfiled by apprentices. Pointing out that hiring apprentices is a global practice, Pardeshi said Germany, with a population of seven to eight crore, has 20 lakh apprentices while India does not even have 10 lakh.

The decision to freeze recruitment will save Rs 250 crore. Under the amended Maharashtra Apprentices Act, apprentices are entitled to a monthly stipend of Rs 9,000. They are not entitled to benefits such as provident fund, which keeps employee costs down. Pardeshi said the BMC will revisit its decision to freeze hiring after the economy revives and its revenues improve.

To increase revenues, the BMC has revised its capitalized value policy with respect to pending redevelopment projects of civic land, lease renewal policy, regularizing unauthorized constructions, and granting of vacant land tenancies. These measures are expected to increase the BMC’s annual revenue by Rs 500 crore. The BMC's property tax collection till January 31 stood at Rs 2,878 crore—Rs 630 crore lower than last year. This was partly due to its earlier decision to scrap property tax for homes with a carpet area under 500 square feet.

Title: Mango traders predict low crop yield, high prices this season
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Mango traders in Visakhapatnam and Tuni wholesale markets have predicted a fall in mango yield this season.

The fall in yield has been attributed to untimely rains in late December and late January, which affected the mango crop during the flowering season. Sources in the horticulture department said the yield this year could be below average.

Assistant director of the horticulture department K Sailaja said, “The rainfall could affect flowering and yield this year.”

The latest spell of rain coincided with Rathasaptami towards the end of January. Farmers in the region, who expected a bumper yield this year due to a strong monsoon, now fear a fall in prices. Heavy rains in 2019 had revived mango orchards in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram districts, where the fruit is widely cultivated.

“To begin with, there was late flowering this season, partly because of a delayed monsoon, but now these rains have ensured massive flower fall in the orchard area. This will translate into a low yield as the flowering season has come to a close,” said P Latcha Reddy, a wholesale trader in both Tuni and Visakhapatnam markets.

Anji Reddy, another trader from the Gajuwaka market in Visakhapatnam, added, “Last year, the wholesale rates for the A-Grade variety of Banganapalli and Suvarnarekha, the two most popular varieties hovered between 170 and 220 a dozen. Now the rates are likely to shoot up, with crop lease holders likely to demand more from traders.”

As a majority of the lease holders of orchards are not wholesale traders, the price of the fruit is marked up by the time it reaches the consumer. In 2019, retail rates hovered around the 500 mark per dozen in Visakhapatnam city. This year, consumers are likely to pay more.

While mango orchards in Srikakulam district were destroyed by cyclones last season, the crop in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram districts withered due to a poor monsoon in 2018.

Farmers said the number of mango orchards in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram districts have come down owing to a dry spell between 2017 and 2019. A fall in temperature also affects flowering of the crop.

Title: Hyderabad Metro: JBS-MGBS Metro stretch to open on February 7
Content:
The JBS-MGBS stretch is part of the 14.78km JBS-Falaknuma Metro corridor. (File photo)

HYDERABAD: The Hyderabad Metro Rail Corridor-II ( green corridor ) between Jubilee Bus Station ( JBS ) and Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station ( MGBS ) will be inaugurated by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on February 7 at 4pm. The JBS-MGBS stretch is part of the 14.78km JBS-Falaknuma Metro corridor. The 11km stretch will provide better connectivity between Secunderabad and Hyderabad.The corridor covers nine stations, and the stretch would be covered in 16 minutes as against the 40 minute journey by road. However, sources said work on the stretch between MGBS and Falaknuma is yet to begin.Metro rail authorities received the green signal for the route after the Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety issued the mandatory safety certificate.“The inauguration of JBS-MGBS route will culminate the entire Metro phase-I project in Hyderabad. With this 11 kilometres, the total operational length of the Hyderabad Metro will be 69 kilometres,” Hyderabad Metro Rail managing director NVS Reddy said.The Hyderabad Metro project is the second largest Metro network in the country, next only to Delhi and the world’s largest public transport facility on public private partnership (PPP) mode.“It is also the world’s largest Metro in PPP mode. The project cost has gone up to Rs 21,000 crore so far,” Reddy added.

Title: Pune: Signals on Alandi Road to be functional in less than 15 days
Content:
Traffic signals located at four junctions between Bombay Engineering Group and Centre (Bombay Sappers) and Vi... Read More

PUNE: Traffic signals located at four junctions between Bombay Engineering Group and Centre (Bombay Sappers) and Vishrantwadi will be functional within the next 15 days. Regular commuters have pointed out that traffic signals at the Mental Hospital junction and others along the stretch haven’t been working for over a year.Installed under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM) a few years ago, the signals at four junctions along the stretch hadn’t been in working condition due to lack of maintenance. The Pune traffic police, which requested re-starting of the signals, went into a tizzy as the Pune Municipal Corporation denied having any signal poles along the stretch.R Vaishali, a resident of Tingrenagar, said, “The crossing here are dangerous for traffic, especially at night when there are vehicles travelling at high speed along the main road and the service roads. As the signal at Yerwada Jail Road junction has not been working for a while, vehicles turn left and right blindly. I have seen a couple of small accidents happening here.”Officers from the traffic department stated that due to the increasing traffic along Alandi Road, they wanted to start the signals along the stretch. “We wrote to PMC officials requesting them to start the existing signals. The PMC officials wrote back stating that they cannot do so as the civic body does not have any signal poles along the stretch. They said that they will have to first install signal poles at the junctions,” an officer explained.The officer further added that the traffic signals had been functioning until a few years ago. Confusion then prevailed among the traffic department and civic authorities over the matter. A traffic police officer said, “These signal posts are solar powered and do not need electricity supply. This is probably the reason that these signals may not be on PMC records. Also, it is suspected that the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) installed and operated the signals for the Bus Rapid Transit System (BRTS) and later discontinued its use.”Swapnil Pawar, a regular commuter along the stretch, said, “Most traffic signals along this stretch have been non-functional for over a year. The Mental Hospital junction that connects Alandi Road to Commerce Zone and Airport Link Road has been witnessing growing traffic and incessant congestion. Making the signal functional is of utmost importance.”However, PMC clarified that the signals had been installed as a part of JNNURM. “Traffic signals were installed at four junctions but they stopped functioning due to a lack of maintenance. Over the last two months, former Yerwada traffic police inspector Ramesh Sathe got some signals functioning. We have now identified the signals and a tender has been floated to revive the signals. The wiring controllers need to be changed. Work is expected to start in a few days and the signals will be functional around the middle of the month,” said Srinivas Kandul, head of PMCs electrical department.

Title: Close shave for 35 as MSRTC bus catches fire; cops clear traffic jam in 35 minutes
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation bus catches fire near Chandni Chowk on Monday evening.

PUNE: A semi-luxury Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation bus, plying from Thane to Swargate, caught fire at Bavdhan near Chandni Chowk on Monday evening.

The bus was completely gutted, but none of the 35 passengers on board was injured in the incident, Yamini Joshi, divisional controller, Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC), Pune division, said.

The incident, which occurred at 5.15pm during the peak evening hours, triggered a massive traffic jam on the Katraj-Dehu Road bypass. It took 35 minutes for the police to clear traffic from the area.

The smoke from the burning bus could be seen around 5-6km away, an official of the city fire brigade said.

“Some passengers spotted the smoke billowing from the rear side of the vehicle and raised an alarm. The driver showed presence of mind and asked the passengers to alight from the bus quickly,” Kothrud fire station officer Gajanan Patrudkar said.

Residents of the area called the fire brigade. Two fire tenders from Kothrud and Bavdhan fire stations rushed to the spot.

“We reached the spot and extinguished the flames within 15 minutes,” Patrudkar said. “The fire was so intense that the fibre seats, the base, and even the metal body of the bus were completely damaged,” he said.

The bus driver suspected that the fire might have been caused due to short-circuit in cables. “However, as the fire started from the tyre, we think it could have been caused owing to excessive braking or due to faulty brakes. The brake pads might have got overheated because of excessive braking, resulting in the fire,” the officer said.

“The bus, a semi-luxury Hirkani, was on way to Swargate from Thane. There were 35 passengers on board. The driver spotted the fire, which started from the rear side of the bus, and the passengers were evacuated immediately. Though investigations will have to be conducted, the fact that the fire started from the rear end of the vehicle suggests that it didn’t occur due to any electrical problem. It is likely the brake drum of the vehicle got heated due to excessive braking, triggering the fire,” Joshi, divisional controller, MSRTC, Pune division, said.

The Hinjewadi police said the bus caught fire during the peak evening hours, triggering a huge traffic jam. “We did not allow movement of vehicles as the fire brigade officials were busy dousing the fire. Once the flames were doused, vehicles were allowed to ply on two lanes, while another lane on the opposite side was thrown open. It took around 35 minutes to clear the traffic from the spot,” the officer said.

Title: HC grants bail to cancer patient held for anti-CAA stir
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmad Nabi

AGRA: Over 40 days after he was booked as prime accused for anti-CAA violence by Firozabad police and sent to jail, 52-year-old Ahmad Nabi , the second stage oral cancer patient, was granted bail by Allahabad high court on January 29. The copy of the order was made available on Tuesday afternoon.

Nabi’s defence counsel Preetam Yadav said, “Ahmad Nabi committed no offence; entire prosecution story is fake. He was neither part of protest march nor was he in any way involved in the march being carried out against CAA-NRC.”

According to the FIR, “Cancer patient Ahmad Nabi and 19-year-old Faraz Khan, nephew of woodshop owner whose shop was vandalised and set on fire by unruly group of men in front of heavy police force, were prime accused of leading violent anti-CAA protesters on December 20.”

Notably, it took local administration 15 days, two reminders from Firozabad district court and multiple reports in the media to admit Ahmad Nabi in S N Medical College, who had suffered multiple fractures in alleged action by police. After surgery, Nabi is still in S N Medical College, Agra under observation.

Speaking with TOI, Nabi’s family expressed happiness on the bail. “Now, we can take him for radiotherapy, which has been pending for more than a month,” said Vakil Nabi , younger brother of Ahmad. Ahmad Nabi owns crockery store in Hajipura area of Rasoolpur police jurisdiction, where violence was reported on December 20 afternoon.

Title: Nizamabad: Turmeric growers split over regional centre
Content:
Turmeric farmers are divided over the Centre’s decision to set up a regional extension centre in Nizamabad.

HYDERABAD: Turmeric farmers are divided over the Centre’s decision to set up a regional extension centre in Nizamabad .A majority of the farmers who entered the electoral fray in 2019 from Nizamabad said only a turmeric board will be the panacea for their problems. Some growers, who welcomed Union minister Piyush Goyal ’s announcement, however, wanted clarity on minimum support price (MSP) for their produce.Farmer Tirumal Reddy, who contested as an independent in last year’s polls, said they want more clarity on MSP. “What we need is clarity on MSP for our crop. Currently, we are getting Rs4,000-Rs 5,000 per quintal. We are demanding Rs15,000 MSP per quintal.”Growers, who are keen on a turmeric board, said having a separate board would ensure quality of the crop with better know-how and technical expertise.“We are actually confused over the latest proposal. We do not know what is a regional extension centre and how is it different from the existing one,” wondered a farmer.Anvesh Reddy, president of Kisan Congress cell, observed that the announcement was an attempt by the Centre to confuse farmers. “We accept nothing short of a turmeric board,” he said.Meanwhile, a few farmers under the aegis of Jagtial United Farmers’ Front have welcomed the decision and released a statement saying that the new centre would help them a great deal.

Title: BJP MLA’s move to give allowances to farmers ‘theatrics’, alleges Cong
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Jaipur: Congress chief whip Mahesh Joshi on Tuesday claimed that BJP MLA Biharilal’s suggestion to contribute assembly allowances and TA/DA of MLAs for days when the House remains adjourned to locust-hit farmers was nothing but theatrics. BJP state president Satish Poonia supported the suggestion of his party MLA from Nokha in Bikaner district. Biharilal suggested that the MLAs should contribute the amount to help locust affected farmers instead of using it for their personal benefits. Poonia said, “We do not want allowances when the House is not in session.”

The special session of the Rajasthan assembly was convened for two days on January 24 and 25 and adjourned till February 10 after passing a resolution against the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). Since the assembly was only adjourned, the MLAs were eligible for allowances and perks during this period.

In a letter to the chief minister Ashok Gehlot, speaker C P Joshi and opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria, Biharilal demanded that allowances of the MLAs for days the House remained adjourned should be used to help locust-hit farmers.The MLA said the government was paying only Rs 27,000 to farmers who had two hectares, which is not only insuffcient.

Joshi said the business of the House was finalised unanimously by the Business Advisory Committee(BAC) meeting in which opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria, his deputy Rajendra Rathore, senior MLA Kalicharan Saraf and Kiran Maheshwari were present. He said, “It is nothing but a drama of the BJP to be in the limelight.”

tnn

Title: Government to eco-restore 6 flood-hit districts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government is set to undertake a massive eco-restoration exercise to rejuvenate large swathes of land severely affected by flood, landslide and soil erosion in six districts.

The project will cover around 22,134 hectares worst affected by flooding, soil erosion and siltation in Idukki , Wayanad , Malappuram, Thrissur , Alappuzha and Kozhikode.

The project will be implemented at an estimated cost of Rs 57.03 crore. Further, around 707 hectares of landslide/landslip/land subsidence-affected areas would be revived through eco-friendly sustainable practices at an estimated cost of Rs 3.91 crore. Department of soil survey and soil conservation along with local self- government department will undertake the project within 2-3 years.

The government has accorded administrative sanction for implementing the project titled ‘eco-restoration of flood/landslide-affected areas in the state through soil and water conservation measures’.

As per the project document, the torrential rains and floods during August 2018 had damaged agricultural lands resulting in loss worth crores of rupees. The state was hit by around 1,000 landslides in Pathanamthitta, Idukki, Kottayam , Thrissur, Kozhikode, Wayanad and Kannur districts damaging large tracts of agricultural fields rendering cultivation impossible. The fertile top soil has been completely washed away from the upper reaches along with the flood water. Most of the rivers were flooded and overflowing with massive silt deposition.

The drainage course which was mostly blocked due to faulty land-use practices resulted in large-scale drainage meandering. The loss of fertile top soil has hit the agriculture sector badly with crop loss and fall in agricultural production, the document notes.

The main objective of the project is to prevent loss of fertile top soil, promoting scientific moisture conservation for facilitating safe disposal of excess water in a systematic manner. Thrust will be given to a watershed model of development of the affected areas. The drainage channels would be cleared to ensure free flow of water. Agro forestry, agrostology, planting of indigenous plant species would be taken up on a massive scale to promote revegetation and also to ensure proper soil binding.

The project document mentions establishment of green cover to reduce the carbon footprint and help in climate change mitigation. The sides of drainage courses would be reinforced with vegetative measures and geo-textiles for preventing drainage meandering. Revival of waterbodies/ponds would be taken up to improve water- holding capacity, preventing instances of flash floods and providing water for irrigation and domestic use.

The services of rural employment guarantee scheme workers would be utilised while executing low cost soil-based activities. The project would be implemented under the guidance of district soil conservation officer/assistant director of soil conservation of the district concerned.

Title: Pune: 50% dip in property registrations near proposed airport site
Content:
Officials of the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) remained tight-lipped on the project. ... Read More

PUNE: The property registration in the vicinity of the seven villages earmarked for acquiring land for the proposed Purandar international airport nosedived by a little over 50% last year compared to 2018 with investors and developers opting for a cautious “wait and watch policy”.A total of 87 documents were registered in the seven villages — Pargaon, Ekhatpur, Munjwadi, Kumbharvalan, Udachiwadi, Vanpuri and Khanavadi — in 2018 and the stamp duty collection was Rs48.65 lakh. In 2019, the number of registrations plunged to just 38 and the stamp duty collection was Rs23.34 lakh.Confirming the trend, sub-registrar of Saswad Rahul Khatpe said, “There has been a 56% dip in registration in 2019 as against 2018 in these seven villages.”Huge projects announced three years ago after Purandar was selected as the site for the new airport have hardly found any takers. The residents interested in the projects then are now waiting for the final take from the new government . A developer said the investors interested in projects about two years ago had recently told him to alert them only after there was some movement on the new airport project front.While the earlier BJP-led state government was pushing forth the project, there was tremendous opposition from the villagers. The new government, according to deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar , would take it forward through a “dialogue” with the villagers. He also talked about the connectivity to the facility by extending the Metro lines and the ring road. But the final gazette has not been issued by the government for the past three years.Against this backdrop, the investors are treading the cautious path. “We do not want a Chakan again in Purandar,” said a leading builder, keen to invest near the area but waiting for the final order from the new government.Same was the sentiment of another realtor, who had to withdraw after planning a project in Chakan. “We shall not make the same mistake twice,” he said.When the Purandar airport project was announced, many investors from the city and Mumbai had announced big projects in the area. In 2017, some investors owning land near the proposed airport site had started constructing farmhouses. “But there is hardly any activity now,” said a resident of one of the seven villages.Senior revenue department officials claimed that there was a status quo on measurement of land for the project as the final order was to be issued by the government. “There is no ban on land deals yet. That will fall in place only after the final notification,” said an official.Officials of the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) remained tight-lipped on the project. A few of them just said budgetary provisions were yet to be made for it.

Title: Ajit Pawar: Govt to decide on Purandar project site soon
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pune: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar said a decision on the future of the proposed greenfield international airport at Purandar would be taken soon.

Pawar told TOI over the phone, “As far as shifting the site of the proposed airport is concerned, I shall take a decision after reviewing the projects and talking to all the stakeholders. The meeting will happen soon, and I shall take a conscious decision.”

The deputy chief minister’s statement comes against the backdrop of Purandar’s Congress MLA Sanjay Jagtap demanding change in the site of the project, announced by former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis in October 2016.

The Pune guardian minister said, “The new airport project site had to be shifted from Chakan and Rajgurunagar to Purandar because of the landowners’ protests there. There have been protests against the project at Purandar, too.”

The deputy chief minister said, “A new airport for Pune is important because flyers face a lot of problems at the existing facility due to flight restrictions and runway closures since it is an Indian Air Force (IAF) base.”

After the recent meeting with the officials of the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA), Pawar had said no decision had been taken to change the site of the project.

Purandar’s Congress MLA Jagtap had then said, “We are a part of the government. The meeting on the Purandar project should happen soon. We have prepared some proposals regarding changing the site in Purandar. We are sure that the state government will accept our request. We are not against the proposed airport in Purandar but just want the present site to be changed as it is affecting seven villages.”

Aviation experts said a new airport for Pune was very essential and the state government needed to expedite the project. While all the approvals are in place, the notification on the actual land acquisition has been pending for almost a year. Officials of the Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) remained tight-lipped on the project. A few of them just said that budgetary provisions were yet to be made for the project.

Title: Experian opens IDC in city, plans to hire 2,500
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Global data, analytics and decisioning player Experian on Tuesday announced the setting up of its new India Development Centre (IDC) in Hyderabad.

Experian plans to grow the IDC, which is spread over 35,000 sq ft and currently houses 200 engineers, to 2500 employees by 2024. Experian employs around 17,200 people across 44 countries.

The new centre is part of Experian’s global network of development centres and will work closely with the Experian product teams globally.

It is another step in Experian’s vision of enabling consumers and businesses in taking prudent financial decisions with the help of technology, analytics and innovation. The IDC will allow Experian to build on its innovation agenda by tapping top talent available in India, the Ireland-based company said.

Commenting on the new centre, Alex Lintner, Group President of Consumer Information Services, Experian said, “Hyderabad has emerged as a major hub for technology and innovation apart from attracting top talent from across the country. Superior infrastructure, good quality of education and a rich talent pool combined with the ease of doing business makes it the ideal location for our India Development Centre. Experian has always believed in fostering a culture of continuous innovation and driving financial inclusion across the world to help consumers get easier access to credit.”

“We are excited to see Experian’s continued investment in India; and view this move as a clear testament to Experian’s commitment to grow the India operations through both organic and inorganic opportunities. Our continued growth in India over the past several years coupled with sustained investments such as these will propel India to play a significant role in Experian’s overall growth story for the years to come,” said Sathya Kalyanasundaram, country head and managing director, Experian India.

Title: Osmania University files plaint against land grabbers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Osmania University

SECUNDERABAD: The Osmania University (OU) officials lodged a police complaint against Tarnaka corporator Alakunta Saraswathi and her husband on Tuesday for attempting to encroach upon the university land recently.

According to officials, on the pretext of road widening near Manikeshwarnagar, some private individuals attempted to encroach upon university land. The university stalled all such excavation work through its internal security staff. Despite this, the corporator and her husband tried to go ahead with the work, forcing university officials to lodge a complaint.

“The corporator and her husband were trying to clear a vacant land to allegedly take up illegal construction work. We have booked them under section 448 for trespassing, 427 for damage of property and 506 for criminal intimidation of the IPC,” said Rajashekhar Reddy, OU inspector.

University authorities warned that stringent action would be initiated against any person indulging in unauthorized construction/encroachment of university lands and it would not hesitate to proceed legally.

The administration maintained that erecting new structures was “illegal” and would not be tolerated. “Any such structures being constructed would be razed and police cases will be filed against individuals,” stated a press release issued by the university.

Title: Quiet burial for capital area hyperloop project?
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vijayawada: Another project floated by the erstwhile TDP regime — the hyperloop transport system between Vijayawada and Amaravati — appears to have been quietly buried by the YSRC government. “The hyperloop project has not been discussed, not even once, by the government. It is no more a priority. It looks unlikely that the project will be revived,” a senior transport department official told TOI.

The TDP government had signed a high-profile memorandum of understanding with Hyperloop Transportation Technologies (HTT), an American transportation solutions company, in September 2017. As per the MoU, HTT was supposed to build the hyperloop system between Vijayawada and Amaravati in public-private partnership (PPP) mode. The project promised to cut travel time between the two towns to just 5 minutes (from 1 hour), using pressurised capsules that float on a frictionless magnetic cushion within tubes.

“HTT will analyse the surrounding cityscapes to create the best route between the two cities while identifying all pertinent stakeholders in the region. After conducting a six-month feasibility study, HTT will build the first hyperloop in India,” a press release issued by HTT had said at the time. It’s now unclear whether HTT had even started or completed the promised six-month feasibility study for the project’s roll-out.

While HTT is among a clutch of companies offering the technology around the world, the system has not been commissioned anywhere in the world yet.

Title: Post on woman IAS officer: 3 FIRs against Congress leader
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: Posting a message on social media about an unnamed woman IAS officer stationed in Ajmer has landed Congress leader and advocate Rajesh Tondon in a soup. Three women IAS officers from Ajmer have lodged three separate FIRs against Tondon along with a screenshot of the post. While two FIRs have been lodged in Civil Lines police station, one was filed in Kotwali police station. The FIRs stated that there are 51 women IAS officers posted in Rajasthan out of which five are in Ajmer.

The FIRs have been registered under IPC Sections 292, 293, 354, 501 209, Section 7 of Corruption Act and Section 67 of IT Act. Tandon, a former public prosecutor, had posted about an alleged obscene video clip involving a woman IAS officer of Ajmer on various social media groups and warned people to be cautious.

The post, which started doing rounds on social media, made people wonder which IAS officer Tondon was talking about. The IAS officers from Ajmer have stated that such posts were putting undue pressure on honest women officials. “All three FIRs will be investigated separately,” SP Kunwar Rashtradeep said.

The Rajasthan IAS Association and the Rajasthan Administrative Service Association have strongly condemned Tondon’s act and termed it deplorable and cowardly.

“Lady IAS officers have always been front runners and have significantly contributed to the service. The association also demands unequivocally that strictest action must be taken against this act of cowardice and malignity and any such act in future,” the IAS association said. Tandon, on the other hand, claimed that he had not shared any video clip and being an advocate he was only asking people to remain cautious. Earlier, Draupdi Devi, corporator and national president of the Koli community, Congress corporator Lalit Verma and several social groups staged protests against such posts on social media and demanded an investigation and action against such people.

Title: AP Capital News: Centre skirts Andhra Pradesh capital row, says it’s for state to decide
Content:
Union minister of state for home affairs Nityanand Rai

VIJAYAWADA: In a major relief for YS Jaganmohan Reddy government, the Centre on Tuesday distanced itself from the row over three capitals raging in Andhra Pradesh, saying that it was for a state to decide where it wants to build a capital.The Centre’s stand was stated by Union minister of state for home affairs Nityanand Rai in the Lok Sabha in a written reply to a question raised by TDP’s Jayadev Galla.The minister gave a single reply to five questions raised by Galla. The MP had asked the minister whether the government had taken note of the recent decision taken by CM Jaganmohan Reddy to set up three capitals, if so, the reaction of the government, the manner in which the move was likely to help the state and the people and whether the government would advise the state not to resort to such decisions which would not only vitiate the investment climate but would also be a great loss to thousands of farmers who gave their land for construction of the capital in Amaravati.Equally significant was the minister’s statement that public order and police were state subjects and the Centre had only limited role when TDP’s Kesineni Srinivas raised a question on the possibility of security forces being sent to the state to address law and order problem. Rai said: “Public order and police are state subjects as per Schedule VII of the Constitution and the state government is primarily responsible for maintenance of law and order and to take action against the culprits as per law.”The MP said that there were massive protests in the state against the proposal to shift the capital from Amaravati. He claimed that protesting women were subjected to brutality and wanted to know whether the state government had sent any request to the Centre for additional security forces or whether the central government had planned any intervention in the matter.Rai said that the Centre had not received any request from the state for additional forces to maintain law and order.In a related development, the AP CM on Tuesday met a group of farmers from four villages in Mangalagiri assembly constituency that form part of Amaravati region, even as the Amaravati Joint Action Committee took its fight to New Delhi where they met Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu urging him to intervene.

Title: Decision on integrated bus stand only after civic body polls
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aerial view of the congested central bus stand in Trichy

TRICHY: The location for the integrated bus terminus will be finalised only after the urban civic body election, the district administration and Trichy Corporation informed on Tuesday.

Collector S Sivarasu in the presence of corporation commissioner S Sivasubramanian said that the decision on the bus terminus cannot be taken in haste. “We need to take the opinion of the civic body’s council. Once the urban local body council is elected, we will conduct stakeholders meeting to hear public opinion to take a call on the location for the bus terminus,” the collector said.

While several locations were proposed since 1994, nothing had materialised. Panchapur, which was identified by the DMK government between 2006-2011, was almost ready for construction for the integrated bus terminus but the proposal was shelved after the government changed in the 2011 assembly election.

Corporation sources said that they have identified a few places which are on the city’s outskirts. However, the recent development is being viewed by residents as a ploy to shift the responsibility in establishing the integrated bus terminus.

It was revived by the AIADMK government in 2017 as the government proposed Kottapattu near Trichy airport as the site for the integrated bus terminus. However, it was also shelved since the location was close to the international airport and not feasible owing to frequent VVIP movement.

Residents have expressed disappointment as uncertainty persists in the conduct of urban local body election across the state. “Even when there was a group of elected councillors, there was no efforts to identify the appropriate location for the terminus. Waiting for the council is an indirect plan to snub the demand,” said Subash Chandran , a resident of Woraiyur .

Title: ‘30 countries to pitch in for Centre’s locust control plan’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Jaipur: A roadmap to control locusts would be prepared by the government of India by inviting 30 locust-affected countries to India. Parshottam Khodabhai Rupala, Union minister of state for agriculture and farmers’ welfare informed about this on Monday in the Rajya Sabha, while quoting the United Nation’s report, ‘Praising India and its states including Rajasthan and Gujarat for their efforts to control locusts.’ Kirori Lal Meena, Rajya Sabha MP from Rajasthan, expressed his concern over the locust attacks and urged for Centre’s intervention into the matter.

TOI spoke to Rupala on the locust attacks. “Meena ji expressed his concern on the locust attacks. I think the locust attack in various countries is been monitored on a world level and it is a big challenge for the farmers in the country especially in Rajasthan, Gujarat and Punjab. United Nations in its report stated that the swarms of locusts in Gujarat, Rajasthan and Punjab could have moved to Bangladesh if proper measures were not taken by the state governments in Rajasthan and Gujarat and also by the government of India.”

“UN has appreciated India, Rajasthan and Gujarat in its report. Now, we are planning to invite countries (nearly 30) to India including African countries, Afghanistan, Iran, Pakistan and others to discuss a roadmap for locust control. We are in touch with these countries and will ensure mutual coordination and expect mutual cooperation to ensure that we can avoid and fight locust attacks properly,” Rupala said.

Rajasthan revenue minister Harish Chaudhary on Monday written a letter to PM seeking to declare the cases of locust attack as a “national calamity”.

Title: Land acquisition, not court stay, stalled Anandbagh RUB
Content:
RUB under construction at Anandbagh.

SECUNDERABAD: It is not stay orders from the court but delay in acquisition of properties, shifting of electrical lines and water pipelines that has affected the completion of East Anandbagh road under bridge (RUB), which was expected to be ready by 2015. This has come to light in the response to an RTI query filed by a resident of Malkajgiri .The reply categorically states that no stay has been granted by the court on construction of the RUB at East Anandbagh, which has been pending for the last six years, and adds that all cases pertaining to RUB have been disposed.The revelation has left residents fuming. They rue how the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) has been dissuading them by attributing the delay to pending court cases. “When no stay has been granted by the court and all the cases have been disposed, why is the GHMC delaying completion of the RUB? We have been waiting for the RUB for close to six years and GHMC continues to delay it further,” said B Nagaraj, a resident of Malkajgiri who filed the RTI application with the GHMC and the roads and buildings (R&B) departments.The RUB project at East Anandbagh had commenced on May 30, 2014 and was taken up at a cost of Rs 27 crore. Over the last few years, Malkajgiri residents held protests and submitted multiple representations seeking completion of the RUB, but to no avail.“The leaders have a standard excuse, every time we ask about the status — lack of funds and unending litigation on land acquisition . These arguments only show lack of political will to tackle problems head on,” said PKR Krishnan, a resident of Malkajgiri. “Why did they start the work and close the gate and main road to the public without acquiring the land first? This shows absolute lack of sensitivity to woes commuters,” he added.The GHMC officials stated that the land acquisition has now been completed and that the RUB will be opened for public use this year. “We were facing issues in acquiring four properties near the RUB. However, recently we have acquired them and handed them over to the R&B department. There were also financial constraints due to which the work could not be taken up,” said T Dasharath, deputy commissioner in GHMC, Malkajgiri.

Title: Maharashtra: Ahead of summer, Khadakwasla starts second water release for crops
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PUNE: The state irrigation department has initiated second rotation of water release for crops ahead of the summer season.

Water will flow to farms in parts of Daund , Indapur, Shirur and Haveli .

The release, which commenced since the last three days, will continue for at least a month. About 2TMC water is expected to be discharged from four dams , which currently hold 21TMC (74%) water stock.

“The release was initiated after demands from the rural areas,” officials in the state irrigation department said.

The irrigation department had initiated earlier water discharge in December which ended last month after release of 2.17TMC water for crops. The water release, expected to continue till February, was stopped before the schedule time. While suspending the discharge ahead of the schedule the irrigation department said that it had decided to go ahead with the “demand-supply” approach wherein water from dams would flow out based on the demand instead of release on continuous basis.

A senior official from the department said that the water has again started flowing into the canal from dams since a sizeable number of fresh demands for water release were received in the last few weeks. Official added that the ongoing release was expected to continue till the second week of March.

“We had planned a collective release of 4TMC water for winter crops. The department will, most likely, stick to the quantum and no additional release is likely during the ongoing rotation,” the official added.

The water rotations for winter crops have been delayed this year by almost two months because of the extended monsoon. The first water release rotation started around mid-December, instead of mid-October. The second rotation, which commenced three days back, started ahead of summer.

Meanwhile, the irrigation department has clarified that the ongoing release of water for crops will not affect the city’s water quota. The city has been lifting 1350MLD water from dams. Irrigation department sources said that water stock in four dams were at a comfortable position this time as against last year when collective storage depleted to 14TMC in the first week of February. Currently, dams have almost 7TMC more water stock compared to last year.

Title: RTO to organize camps for old vehicles to be fitted with HSRPs
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: Regional Transport Office (RTO) will go to the doorsteps of people for fitting their old vehicles with high security number plates (HSRPs) in the Diamond City.

About 15 HSRP fitment camps will be held in different parts of the city from February 4 to cover maximum number of old vehicles moving without HSRPs. The camps will be held in Pal, Varachha, Mota Varachha, Katargam, Mora Bhagal, Mota Varachha and Kapodara.

Official sources said there is a backlog of more than four lakh vehicles in the city plying without HSRPs. The last deadline for fitment of HSRPs in the state expired in November 2019.

DK Chavda, regional transport officer, said, “We will be holding 15 camps in different parts of the city in February. We are going to the doorsteps of people to see that their old vehicles are fitted with HSRPs. We have been organizing HSRP camps every month since October 2019. Every month, we have been covering at least 15,000 old vehicles. This is first time that 15 camps will be held in a single month, where we plan to cover more than 30,000 vehicles.”

According to Chavda, on an average 1,000 vehicle owners are fined in the city in a month for driving their vehicles without HSRPs. RTO and police jointly collect fine amounting to more than Rs5 lakh per month.

RTO has asked residential societies, schools and colleges to avail of the benefit of doorstep service.

“We had not received good response from residential societies and educational institutions for HSRP fitment. However, we have decided to organize camps to facilitate vehicle owners,” Chavda added.

Title: Four years on, PMC’s theme-based tour service remains on paper
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

A PMPML official said around 11,400 people availed the Pune Darshan bus service in 2019. (Photo: PMC)

PUNE: The Thematic Pune Darshan, a special bus service plan of the civic body to boost tourism in the city, has failed to roll out though four years have passed since its approval.

The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ), in association with the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mandal Limited (PMPML), had planned to introduce special theme-based tours in the city in 2015. These tours included guided travel to Information Technology (IT) park, heritage buildings and gardens. The PMPML was supposed to buy 10 new air-conditioned (AC) buses for the purpose.

“The purpose of the Thematic Pune Darshan was to take the tourists to destinations bearing significance of the city’s history and identity. The project has failed to move forward as expected. The civic body should make sure that such tours are organized soon,” former mayor Prashant Jagtap said. He was also a member of the PMPML board that had approved the proposal in 2015.

PMPML traffic department head Anant Waghmare admitted to the delay in the implementation of the project.

“The thematic tour project is yet to take off. We have, however, started a tour for the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation areas on the lines of the Pune Darshan bus services. We are yet to see much response to the service,” he said.

At present, the PMPML runs AC and non-AC bus services as part of its Pune Darshan service for carrying visitors to several tourist sites. A joint venture by the PMC and PMPML, the service was availed of by around 11,400 tourists in 2019, an official in the transport utility said. The official added that the civic administration generated around Rs4.5 lakh per month through this service.

The municipal budget for 2020-21 had stated to spend funds on repairs and restoration of heritage structures in the city. Along with the conservation, the aim was to promote tourism.

Title: Pune: Repair work to hit water supply tomorrow
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Taps will run dry across the city as repairs would be carried out at pumping stations in Warje/SNDT, Wadgaon, New Holkar bridge and Cantonment on Thursday. The supply will resume with low pressure on Friday.

The repair work at Warje/SNDT pumping station will affect the water supply at Bhusari Colony, Shastrinagar, Bavdhan, Bhugaon Road, Sus Road, Baner, Balewadi, Pashan, Warje, Karvenagar, Erandwane, Sutardara, Dahanukar Colony, Gandhi Bhavan, Model Colony, Law College Road, Gokhalenagar, Bhosalenagar, Aundh, Bopodi and Khadki.

The work at Vadgaon pumping station will hit the supply at Sinhagad Road, Hingne, Vadgaon, Dhayari, Dhankawdi, Katraj, Anandnagar, Ambegaon Pathar and Santoshnagar. Peth areas, Dattawadi, Rajendranagar, Lokmanyanagar, Swargate, Parvati Darshan, Mukundnagar, Parvati village, Sahakarnagar, Bibvewadi and Taljai would be affected because of the work at Parvati pumping station.

The work at New Holkar Bridge pump would affect the water supply at Vidyanagar, Tingrenagar, Kalas, Dhanori, Lohegaon, Vishrantwadi, Vimannagar and Ahmednagar Road. The water supply at Cantonment, railway station, Koregaon Park and Tadiwala Road would also be hit.

Title: Examine lotteries for local polls: Rajasthan HC to government
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: Rajasthan High Court has directed the state government to examine the action of drawing of lotteries with respect to its desirability or necessity for panchayat reservation for the posts of ward panch, sarpanch, member panchayat samiti, member zila parishad and pradhan and has also directed to place the same before the court in relation to cases where the process of drawing of lotteries has been challenged.

Justice Arun Bhansali directed the reports to be placed in the court before proceeding further in the matter of drawing lotteries. Matter has now been listed for hearing on February 7.

Meanwhile, in its January 30 order the court directed that if the state proceeded with lotteries in pursuance of the order dated 24.01.2020, the same would remain subject to the final outcome of the present writ petitions and would not be given effect without prior permission of the court.

Title: Amit Shah: BJP Telangana unit to invite Amit Shah for CAA talk
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Union home minister Amit Shah

HYDERABAD: The BJP state unit has proposed to invite Union home minister Amit Shah to spread positive awareness on the National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). “Because of civic polls we are lagging a little behind the other states. But now, senior party leaders have asked us focus on spreading awareness at grassroot level,” said a senior leader who was at the meeting.

As part of the campaign, senior leaders were asked to cover at least 100 families each and conduct regular meetings with 5,000 people. Sources said the meeting with Shah is likely to happen after Delhi elections.

Title: Relief under I-T is confusing: Expert
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: Eminent tax consultant Mukesh Patel has said that the Finance Minister’s move to provide relief under income tax has confounded the economic analysts.
