Speaking at the budget analysis and impact on the economy organised by SGCCI and Gujarat Income Tax Bar Association on Tuesday, Patel said, “The FM has tried to reduce the slab with riders. But ultimately the individual tax payers are not seeing any relief from it. They would rather chose to be with the old tax slabs than going for the new ones.” He further said that the I-T benefits seemed more like illusions. “When people finally worked it out, they found the sops more like a mirage,” he said.

According to Patel, the abolition of DDT has created a lot of confusion. For the high networth individuals (HNIs), DDT is going to increase their tax burden, especially for those earning above Rs 50 lakh. It will also impact individual tax payers, he said. Patel lauded the efforts of the central government for implementing the e-assessment and faceless scrutiny.

“These are the best possible ways to eradicate corrupt practices going on in the department,” he asserted.

Title: Tide centre at IIM-V to play angel investor for start-ups
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The ministry of electronics and information technology (Meity) has sanctioned a Technological Incubation and Development of Entrepreneurs (Tide) Centre to the Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam. IIM-V is the fifth IIM in the country to get a TIDE Centre.

The centre will get a grant-in-aid of Rs 1.7 crore from Meity that will allow it to play the role of an angel investor for the technology startups. IIM-V will operate the centre as a Section 8 company with a mandate to nurture and support technology startup companies.

The five key thrust areas of the tech startups should be agriculture and water resources, health and nutrition, education and skill development, financial inclusion and smart cities and smart transportation.

Speaking to TOI, IIM-V director Professor M Chandrasekhar said the grant of Rs 1.7 crore can be invested in five technology startup companies. “Each company selected for incubation would get the financial support in the form of a soft loan for a maximum period of three years. The company will have to return at least half of the funds invested into the respective start-up at the end of three years. The remaining 50% funds can be converted into equity. The Section 8 company floated by the IIM-V to set up the centre has already got the approval of the IIM-V board,” said Prof Chandrasekhar.

Prof Chandrasekhar further added that the IIM-V incubating a particular start-up and having a representation on the company’s board will boost investor confidence. “IIM-V, being the host institute, will extend its full support to the start-ups at the centre, including mentoring, entrepreneurial training, providing market linkages, market research, expertise and facilities. It would help foster innovation at IIM-V, paving way for more indigenous products. The students of institutions will also get hands-on experience and can help the start-up in developing business models,” said Prof Chandrasekhar.

Prasad Dahapute, one of the IIM-V board members, will be the chairman of the Section 8 company, while the IIM-V director will be the chief executive officer. Chairman of entrepreneurship development cell and a faculty of the IIM-V, Mohammad Shameem Jawed will be the chief operational officer.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Private hospitals ordered to transfer suspected nCoV cases to govt hospitals
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The state health department issued strict orders to private and corporate hospitals to redirect any suspected case of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) to the three nodal hospitals ( Gandhi Hospital Fever Hospital and Chest Hospital ) only and not admit the patient in their hospitals.Three new suspected cases for the novel coronavirus were reported on Tuesday are currently at the Fever Hospital while one more suspected patient is at the Gandhi Hospital. “Of the total 51 suspected cases, 21 were found to be negative for nCoV while reports for four others are awaited. The remaining 26 are asymptomatic and under isolation,” said Vijay Kumar, nodal officer for coronavirus.The state government on Tuesday issued orders to district collectors to start coronavirus control rooms at the district levels and initiate control measures and efforts to raise awareness about the virus. The state government has issued advisories asking people to refrain from travelling to China and affected countries.In a video conference held by the central health ministry on Tuesday, it was decided that all suspected cases from Andhra Pradesh will be tested at the ICMR lab at Gandhi Medical College. A senior official from the state health department, said, “The centre has also directed the establishment of rapid response teams in all districts. These teams will act to control the accidental spread of situation any virus, like novel coronavirus or ebola.“Anyone with symptoms of coronavirus should be immediately sent to Gandhi Hospital or Fever Hospital,” the official added.In a bulletin issued on Tuesday, the state health department said, “In the backdrop of the coronavirus outbreak , the general public is advised to adhere to health advisories issued by the government. People who have arrived from affected countries should remain under strict home isolation for 28 days.”As the fear of coronavirus spreads, Vaada Foundation, an NGO, has written a letter to the traffic police to stop breathalyzer tests for drunken driving checks.

Title: Maharashtra: Tourists kick up a storm over heritage sites without toilets
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The trek route to Pratapgad fort lacks toilet facilities for the tourists. (File photo)

PUNE: Heritage sites across the state, including those in Lonavla and Mahabaleshwar, lack toilet facilities. Tourists have taken to the social media to talk about it and the poor hygiene where they are available.

A tourist, who recently visited Bhaja caves near Lonavla, was told there are no toilet facilities for the ASI staff or the tourists and they would have to go out in the open.

A post on a social media website said, “How do you expect tourists who want to visit the site trek for 5km and not be provided with these basic facilities?’’

“One cannot ignore them or their upkeep when the state is pushing for heritage tourism ,’’ an avid traveller said.

The trek to Pratapgad fort, located 24km from Mahabaleshwar, takes less than a hour, but there are no facilities for tourists along the route.

“The state government has not given any importance to basic needs while promoting tourism,’’ a local villager said. Social media handles have many complaints about other sites too.

Tourism minister Aditya Thackeray must look into these issues, another tweet says. An official from the state tourism department said they will take up the complaints in their forthcoming meeting.

The previous BJP government had declared the entire state open defecation free in both rural and urban areas. But tourists said most heritage sites promoted for tourism are deprived of the mandatory public toilet facility.

The state department has put the onus on the Archaeological Survey of India while those officials said the state government’s tourism and rural departments should have provided toilets. Local villagers at most heritage sites collect a small amount but do not provide proper facilities.

Last year, the government had approved a heritage tourism policy wherein historical forts not in the Archaeological Survey of India’s protected list will be promoted to boost the local economy.

“There are about 350 forts blessed with a beautiful landscape and have a history and tradition and can be used for tourism. We will ensure that toilet facilities are provided here,” a tourism department official told TOI.

In 2019-20, the state received a budget of Rs 188 crore to develop the infrastructure and add new tourist amenities.

Title: Help MSRTC get back dues, Bombay high court to Maharashtra transport department
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

An MSRTC bus

MUMBAI: Bombay high court on Tuesday directed the secretary, Transport Department, to take up the issue of recovering a huge amount of money owed by various departments of the state government to the beleaguered Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC).

The court heard a PIL by advocate Datta Mane, which said that MSRTC was suffering losses and one reason for that was concessions to around 25 categories such as disabled, freedom fighters, senior citizens, students, without reimbursement to it. Eight departments of the government are respondents from whom a substantial amount is due. In 2015 the amount due was Rs 3,000 crore.

A bench of Justices Satyaranjan Dharmadhikari and Riyaz Chagla noted that the “benevolent and welfare schemes” of MRSTC have resulted in it suffering losses year after year. Further, that it does not have adequate funds to upgrade and improve the services and compete with private bus operators who are plying on their routes.

The judges directed the transport secretary to “take up this issue with the other functionaries of the government and resolve it as expeditiously as possible.”

“Let all secretaries in the concerned departments cooperate with the department of transport in resolving the issue amicably,” the judges said in their order. They added that, “in the event a resolution is not possible or not attempted, this court will take a serious view and call upon the functionaries to explain as to why MSRTC is not allowed to function independently.”

The judges sought an action taken report on February 28. They told government pleader Priyabhushan Kakade to take instructions from the secretary and MSRTC general manager, and in case of non-cooperation from the departments, to take the matter up with the chief secretary .

Title: Govt to set up seven medical colleges, 1 cancer care hospital
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Amaravati: As part of its ongoing move to revamp public healthcare system in the state, the government has decided to upgrade all district hospitals into teaching hospitals to take the healthcare infrastructure closer to the people.

The government also plans to set up seven medical colleges, eight super-specialty hospitals, seven nursing colleges and one cancer care hospital in different regions of the state. For better management of medical colleges and nursing institutions, two more health universities would be created in addition to the existing NTR health university.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, who reviewed various health infrastructure projects proposed under the Naadu-Nedu programme with senior officials on Tuesday, said the failure of the previous government to improve the condition of government hospitals crippled healthcare system in the state. “It’s high time we take healthcare facilities in the state to the next level by revamping everything from primary health centres (PHCs) to district hospitals to medical colleges,” the CM said.

He also asked officials to ensure that all Lok Sabha constituencies in the state get at least one teaching hospital each.

“All teaching hospitals should focus on becoming self-reliant to provide the best of healthcare services to the poor. The poor should be able to access proper medical care close to their villages and towns. Sub-centres should be set up and affiliated to the teaching hospitals, which would work as referral centres,” the chief minister added, while urging officials to come up with innovative ideas to revamp the “age-old public healthcare system” in the state.

“Setting up of more medical colleges and super-specialty hospitals will also help us overcome the shortage of specialists in medical care. Ready the proposal to set up three health universities in three regions to manage the medical colleges better,” he said. Health department officials informed the CM that around nine district hospitals, where the existing infrastructure is good enough, would be upgraded into teaching hospitals in the coming months.

Jagan also directed officials to focus on getting more super-specialisation seats in medical colleges in the state. “Segregate the state into five zones to get more super-specialisation seats. Medical colleges should be segregated into these five zones — north-coastal, Godavari districts, Guntur-Krishna, Prakasam-Nellore-Chittoor and Rayalaseema districts — to get additional super-specialisation seats,” he said, and told officials to fill up all existing vacancies in medical and health department by May.

Title: Chathiram bus stand redevelopment work to be completed before Feb 2021
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Trichy: District collector S Sivarasu along with the senior officials from Trichy City Corporation on Tuesday reviewed the progress of the Chathiram bus stand redevelopment work. The bus shelter and a commercial complex were completely dismantled for the work at an estimated cost of Rs 17.34 crore using the Smart Cities Mission fund.

Classified as category D bus stand, 225 city buses including 135 private fleets had been using the bus stand. As the existing bus shelter was inadequate to manage the increasing number of passengers, the corporation proposed to redevelop the terminus in September 2018 and the bus shelter was closed in November 2019 for the work. “Almost 90% of the pile foundation work is done, and the basement will be completed before April 2020,” the district collector said. Out of the total 248 pile foundations, work for installing 218 piles is completed.

The corporation said that the remaining work will be completed before February 2021. “The basement area will be completely utilised for two-wheeler parking,” S Amuthavalli, city engineer, said. Pedestrian pathway, passenger waiting hall and food court are the amenities to be set up at the terminus. After the redevelopment, the bus stand can accommodate at least 30 buses at a time; earlier it was 20. Only the city and suburban buses will be permitted to operate from the bus stand. The mofussil buses to Thuraiyur, Perambalur and Ariyalur will continue to operate from outside the Chathiram bus stand.

Title: CAA Protest In Hyderabad: Anti-CAA protests continue in Old City
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Expressing solidarity with protesters in Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia students, Chatta Bazaar traders organised a 15-minute blackout protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, National Population Register ( NPR ) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) In Old City on Tuesday.

“ A black out protest was organised by printing press owners at Chatta Bazaar against CAA ,NPR and NRC. We are staying away from our business for 15 minutes by switching the lights off in solidarity with fellow protesters at Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia students,’’ a shopkeeper, Anas Ahmad told TOI.

Nizamia Tibbi College students also took out a peaceful march within the campus and demanded that central government take serious actions against those firing at protesters. In a symbolic gesture, students wore bandages on their eyes and hands, in solidarity with Jamia students who were injured in the attacks.

“Despite the pleas and protests , the government is ignoring the demands of the population. Incidents of assault and firing are taking place one after the other. But the government has failed to stop the troublemakers,’’ said Ibrahim, one of the students of Nizam Tibbi College.

Title: CPM to launch anti-CAA drive from March 16
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Communist Party of India (Marxist) will launch an anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act door-to-door campaign in the state from March 16.

CPM welcomed KCR’s decision to not support CAA . “KCR should pass a resolution that the state will not implement NPR,” party state secretary Tammineni Veerabhadram said. TNN

Title: Nagpur University faces NAAC inspection with over 50% vacant teacher posts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Even as Nagpur University faces National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) inspection in a couple of months, majority of its departments are struggling with massive shortage of faculty.

As per schedule, the NAAC visit was slated in December last year but NU had requested the council to defer it as it had failed to submit the status report. The NAAC had awarded A grade to the NU in 2014.

Reply to an RTI query by activist Abhay Kolarkar brought to fore that staggering 50% regular posts are vacant in 34 NU departments and same is the condition in its conducted colleges.

NU has appointed over 100 contributory teachers on a monthly pay of Rs25,000 in various departments. It has started this practice in the last couple of years following retirement of a large number of faculty and ban on recruitment by the state. Condition in majority of its over 500 affiliated colleges is even worse. Thankfully, NU enforced strict measures that led to closure of over 250 colleges which were operating without a single regular teacher and infrastructure in last 3 to 4 years.

NU officials admitted that efforts of its administration were insufficient for getting a good grade, as it is mandatory to have full-time teachers in departments and affiliated colleges. Even posts of registrar and pro-vice-chancellor haven’t been filled though incumbent Puran Meshram retired in 2018 and Pramod Yeole took up the charge of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University in Aurangabad over a year ago.

Ahead of assembly polls in October last year, BJP government had lifted ban on recruitment and allowed all universities to fill up teaching posts. NU was granted sanction to fill up 93 posts. However, it turned out to be a mere poll gimmick as the state failed to clear roster for reservation in the posts, dispatched by the varsity.

A couple of years back, even the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) had passed strictures on NU for meagre staff and not filling up several vacant posts. The situation is likely to worsen in coming days as employees are retiring every month, officials said. According to them, last recruitment took place in 2013, during the tenure of then VC Vilas Sapkal, when 72 posts were filled.

Among the sufferers is Laxminarayan Institute of Technology (LIT), which couldn’t apply for autonomy due to severe shortage of teaching and non-teaching staff.

Title: Lioness attacks, feeds on boy near Pipavav
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Rajkot: Early on Tuesday morning , five-year-old Kishore Devipujak suddenly woke up hearing some growling sound. His groggy eyes sparkled seeing two cute lion cubs in the farm in Uchhaiya, a coastal village of Amreli district. He started fondling and playing with the cubs, completely unaware that their mother was around.

Before the little boy could realize anything, the lioness pounced and savagely attacked him. So furious was the lioness that she even ate some of this body parts.

The incident happened sometime between 4am and 5am, 3km from Port Pipavav, a private port run by APM Terminal and 12 km away from Rajula town.

Kishore was sleeping in the open outside his hut in the farm, which is located along side a railway track that leads to the port. His parents work as farm labourers.

Forest officials, however, said that the lioness might have mistaken the boy to be some prey as she had killed a goat at the same place in the recent past.

“The lioness caught the boy by his neck and ran for nearly three km in a grassland opposite the port. His family members and others even chased her. The lioness was familiar with these people as she moved around in the same area,” Sandeep Kumar, deputy conservator of forest, Shetrunji division, told TOI.

“The lioness was very angry. The forest department team has found her location in a near-by grassland and a trap has been set to capture her,” Kumar said.

According to forest officials, the boy’s head and parts of legs were eaten by the lioness. Villagers said some lions were also seen moving around in this area in the morning.

Congress MLA from Rajula, Amrish Der, has demanded creating a new sanctuary for lions in this area. Talking to media after the incident, Der said, “The number of lions in this coastal area is increasing. A sanctuary will help avoid such incidents of man-animal conflict besides providing protection to lions.”

The expanding lion population outside the protected areas and close to human habitats is fast becoming a cause of concern.

On December 23 last year, a farm labourer from Madhya Pradesh, Kadu Bhilad, was dragged and killed by a lion in Jira village of Dhari taluka in Amreli. Bhilad had gone to answer nature’s call and the lion mistook him for a prey as he was covered in blanket.

In December 2018, a lion had ripped off a fisherman named Rama Chudasama on the sea coast near Mahuva.

Title: Hyderabad: Missing fish vendor found murdered
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Green zones with regulations may not figure in master plan 2040
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The proposed master plan for 2040 is likely to do away with green zones/strips and may only suggest areas that require conservation although majority of the areas marked as green strips in sanctioned master plan (SMP) were flooded in 2018.

The draft master plan 2031 had pitched planned development and green zones under proposed land use, which was one of the major reasons for protests. The identification of areas that require conservation to prevent flooding and retain natural flora is going to be the major challenge for town planners, given the stress on land development irrespective of need for zoning regulations.

While being forced to forsake the critical aspect of green zones in master plan for 2040, the town planning wing will have to disregard the findings of the report prepared following the flood in 2018 in the district.

As part of the flood report, spatial assessment was done to analyse how far the factors such as proximity to water body, existing drainage pattern and topography influenced the impact of flood throughout the district. Also the sink area percentage and the land use distribution were taken into account to arrive at inferences on the reason and intensity of the flood.

In the flood report, sink areas which are topographically low-lying areas were derived from digital elevation model (DEM) data available for the district. The flooded area in the sink area emphasised the need for building regulations for conservation of such areas, the report noted.

Distribution of sink areas to the total land area in each flooded local body was also marked as part of the report. In city corporation 24% sink area of the total land area recorded flooding.

Further, the study showed that a considerable percentage of built up area was flooded during 2018 and this pointed out the need to implement regulations for building constructions in riverside areas.

The land use distribution of flooded area within the city in 2018 shows that 50.82% built up area and 17.9% agricultural land were flooded.

Flooded areas when compared with SMP of the city showed that majority of the flooded areas fell within the green strip area, proposed for conservation, mostly along the water bodies like Karamana River , Killi River, Pattom canal , Ulloor canal and Amayizhanjan canal.

The draft master plan-2031 had mooted green zones; green areas associated with area earmarked for planned development. It was proposed that these green zones can act as drainage basins during rainy season and during summer season people can use it for recreational purposes or as spaces for morning walks. With local protests mounting against the master plan -2031, the state government was forced not to implement the plan.

Title: Notification for executive MBA today
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: IIM-Visakhapatnam is set to release the notification for admissions to their postgraduate programme for experienced professionals (PGPEx/executive MBA). About 30 professionals from diverse sectors enrolled in the first batch of the programme launched in 2019. The notification will be released on February 5 and last dat for applications submission is May 29.

Candidates must hold a bachelor’s degree (must have minimum 55% marks or equivalent). The degree obtained by the candidate must entail a minimum of three years of education after completing higher secondary schooling (10+2) or its equivalent. The applicant must have a minimum of three years of full-time work experience. Applicants will be short-listed based on their performance in CAT/GMAT/GATE/GRE/IIM-V Test (as chosen by the candidate), academic record, duration and quality of work experience. The shortlisted candidates will be called for a written test and interview. tnn

Title: Builder arrested for Rs 18cr GST evasion
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: The Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) arrested a real estate developer from the city on Tuesday on charges of evading GST payments to the tune of Rs 18 crore.

According to the DGGI, the officials had conducted searches at various locations in the city owned by Raj Mahal developers, a partnership realty firm engaged in the construction business in the city, in November 2019. The DGGI sleuths had received intelligence that the firm was indulging in large scale evasion of GST payments.

The officials had recovered many incriminating documents including dairies relating to their investments and the cash received from their clients in the sale of various projects in the city.

Further investigation revealed that the realtors had suppressed the sale value of shops by receiving major portion of sale proceeds in cash on which no GST was paid. Out of the two partners, the active partner Ramesh Kumar Gupta was confronted with the seized documents.

Gupta admitted to receiving Rs 135 crore cash payments on which more than Rs 16 crore of GST was not paid. In addition, he had also not paid GST of more than Rs 2.8 crore since April-2018 on the cheque components of the sale proceeds.

Title: 20 govt depts to be powered by solar plant in Bijnor
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bijnor: Work on installation of a 50-Kw solar power plant has begun at Vikas Bhavan building here. The building houses at least 20 government departments.

The district's largest solar plant, constructed at a cost of Rs 23 lakh, will be offering excess power to the electricity department.

According to officials, the solar power generation plant will be a boon for environment as it will curb use of diesel generators during powercuts at Vikas Bhavan. Besides, these generators emit smoke and cause air pollution.

SK Singh, project officer of New and Renewable Energy Development Agency (NEDA), said, “We had prepared a proposal last year and sent it to the authorities concerned. The budget was sanctioned two months ago and work on the installation of a 50-Kw solar plant has started.”

Singh added, “The plant will supply power to 20 departments here. However, we need a 75-Kw plant to meet the power demand. A proposal for a separate plant will also be prepared this year.

“In case the solar plant generates excess power, it will be go to the power corporation. Work is going on and it will bear fruit within one month,” the NEDA official said.

Title: Trader arrested for cheating diamond bizman of Rs 4 crore
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: Police arrested owner of a private limited company for cheating a diamond businessman of Rs4.09 crore from his house in the city on Tuesday. The businessman, who has offices in different parts of the world, had duped a city-based diamond businessman by making purchases of diamonds while being in Hong Kong.

Haresh Dholiya, a resident of Mota Varachha, was arrested for allegedly cheating Subhash Monpara, a diamantaire, and produced him before a court which remanded him in police custody for three days. The accused, a diamond businessman, did not make payment for diamond purchases that he made since January 2018. He had been purchasing diamonds from Monpara and others since 2014 but began to default of late on payment. “We received information that Dholiya was in the city and he was arrested. He spends most of his time in Hong Kong,” police said.

“The accused had allegedly duped many other diamond businessmen too in the city and Mumbai of about Rs38 crore. We registered complaint of Monpara as he was able to produce documents of the deals,” said a police officer of Kapodra police station.

Police investigation revealed that the accused used to visit city and Mumbai during exhibitions and selected diamonds for purchase. Later, he used to place orders from Hong Kong and received the supply there.

“When the accused visited the city initially, he purchased diamonds worth Rs36 lakh. He made payment too, but after a few years he began to default,” police said.

He informed police that he used to purchase products at high rate and sold them at lower rates which caused him massive losses.

Title: Almost half of anti-CAA protestors out on bail
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bijnor: Citing serious lapses in framing of charges against the accused, Bijnor courts have released 68 of the 155 accused jailed by police of involvement in “violent” protest against CAA (Citizen Amendment Act) on December 20. Meanwhile, three fresh arrests were made on Monday for the December 20 violence.

Punching holes in UP police’s version, the Bijnor judge said prosecution could neither produce any evidence showing who among the hundreds accused of the firing, had “opened fire in Nagina”, nor of the firearms used. The judge also said prosecution couldn’t furnish any record of shops damaged during the clashes.

“Keeping all facts and circumstances in mind, the accused are granted bail,” the court order, a copy of which is with TOI, read.

According to officials, the protests against CAA in the district spiraled and turned violent on December 20 in seven towns — Bijnor, Nahtaur, Najibabad, Jalalabad, Chandpur, Sherkot and Nagina — where protesters allegedly burnt vehicles, hurled stones at cops and damaged public property.

The two towns most affected in the violence were Bijnor and Nahtaur. Two protestors died of gunshot wounds, while a bystander was injured, in addition to injuries suffered by 31 cops across the district.

After the violence, 34 cases were registered, 3,900 unnamed protesters booked under serious sections of IPC, and 155 protesters arrested. Of these, three were jailed on Monday evening.

On being asked about the high number of released protesters, jail superintendent S P Singh said, “Around 155 protestors were lodged in Bijnor jail since December 20, of whom the 68 released on bail are from Nagina, Najibabad, Jalalabad, Nahtaur and Bijnor.”

Title: Import duty on coloured gemstone could lead to job losses: GJEPC
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: The Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) has urged union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to roll back the 0.5% import duty on the rough coloured gemstone to protect the domestic industry.

GJEPC has stated that the gemstone jewellery is 100% exported in the foreign countries and that the imposition of duty on rough gemstones may result in job losses in the sector.

The demand for gemstones has increased with changing consumer preference. Apparently, these colours are connected with the Gods of various caste and creeds. Hence, the demand for every type of gemstone emerges during different festivals.

If suppose a middle-class consumers are planning to buy diamond necklace, they could do it with the studding of the coloured gemstones in the ornaments, thereby reducing the cost by almost 30%.

Moreover, all gemstones are available at hardly 10% of the cost of a diamond and this is the reason why the consumers in India and abroad are attracted towards them. With diamond prices steadily becoming unaffordable due to lack of new mines and rapid depletion of existing ones, the gemstone demand has seen a compounded annual growth rate of 20-25% with the overall gemstone-based jewellery market in India pegged at over Rs 5,000 crore.

According to GJEPC data, the import of rough coloured gemstone between April-December decreased 35% at Rs 1,300 crore compared to Rs 2,000 crore during the same period in previous month.

Rajiv Jain, former chairman of Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) and managing director of Sambhav Gems Private Limited at Jaipur, a leading colour gems stone company told TOI, “This is first time that the import duty on rough coloured gemstone has been increased. The gemstone manufacturing is a cottage industry and the hike in the import duty will directly impact over 2 lakh workers.”

According to Jain, the coloured gemstone are imported from Africa, Brazil and South America. Many African countries producing rich gemstones including Tanzania have banned the export of gemstones weighing one gram or more to encourage local benefaction.

Pramod Kumar Agarwal, chairman of GJEPC said, “The import duty on rough coloured gemstones will disrupt the gemstone manufacturing centre in Jaipur. The annual import of coloured gemstone is $300 million and the export is pegged at $500 million. The government is going to earn less than Rs 15 crore in duty per annum.”

Title: BMC budget 2020: 5% hike in licence and birth certificate fees
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BMC has proposed a 5% hike in fees on trade and market vendor licences as well as birth certificates.

MUMBAI: The BMC , which is exploring “innovative” ways to boost its income without increasing the tax burden, has proposed a 5% hike in fees on trade and market vendor licences as well as birth certificates.

This would translate into an additional revenue of around Rs 120 crore. BMC has also proposed to extend the licence period to 10 years and collect the amount upfront in one instalment.

That apart, it is focusing on trying to recover 10% of Rs 15,000 crore property tax from defaulters that’s pending for years for various reasons, including court cases. It has also tenanted properties through which it expects to earn Rs 125 crore.

Currently, BMC’s trade and market vendor licences, for which it collects fees, need to be renewed every two years. Officials said these fees have not been raised for years and BMC now plans to “keep up with the rate of inflation”.

A pan shop spread over an area of four to 10 square metres, for instance, has to pay Rs 1,155 licence fee currently. This would rise by 5%, or an additional Rs 60 annually.

Other than water charges, BMC will also collect garbage collection and sewage charges.

Title: Supply of water to be disrupted in elevated areas
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Though KWA began pumping by Tuesday night, elevated areas in the city will receive water only by Wednesday noo... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A leak in the main transmission pipeline, bringing water from Aruvikkara to the city, has affected water supply in the capital for several hours on Tuesday.

Also, a major portion of the Aruvikkara–Kachani Road was damaged due to the leak in Kummi, around 1.5km from Aruvikkara.

The leak was reported in the 1,200mm transmission line, which connects the 72mld plant at Aruvikkara to the observatory tank, on Monday night.

However, before the Kerala water authority ( KWA ) began works, the water gushing out due to the leak had damaged a major portion of the road.

To prevent further damage, KWA initiated work by around 8.30am on Tuesday. A portion of road caved in and cracks had developed, forcing authorities to divert traffic in the area.

After restoration, KWA will hand over the stretch to the public works department (PWD) for rectification works.

KWA executive engineer (Aruvikkara) A Noushad said that the workers have identified the leak.

“The 12,00mm transmission line, made of cast iron, was laid in 1970s. However, the pipes are in good condition. The leak developed in a joint. We completed the works and started pumping by night,” said Noushad.

Though KWA began pumping by Tuesday night, elevated areas will receive water only by Wednesday noon.

Areas such as Vazhutacaud, Thycaud, Palayam, Statue, PMG, Bartonhill, Edapazhanji, Kannamoola, Kumarapuram, Pothujanam Lane , Vikas Bhavan, General Hospital, Pattoor, Vanchiyoor, Karikkakom, Sanghumukham and Veli were affected.

Many of the areas affected by the new pipe leak were the ones which faced water shortage during last weekend when KWA shut down the main pump at Aruvikkara as part of installing a standby pump.

Title: Man hangs self, cops suspect family feud
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A 35-year-old man hanged himself from a ceiling fan at his residence in Simhagiri Colony near Gajuwaka area on Tuesday. The deceased was identified as D Sunil Kumar of Rajahmundry Town in East Godavari district.

Police said that Sunil Kumar along with his family members (wife and two daughters) had come to Visakhapatnam city in search of livelihood a few years ago and he was working with a civil contractor at the Visakhapatnam Steel Plant.

Sunil Kumar’s wife has been working in Kuwait for the past one year and his two children stay with his in-laws in East Godavari.

Preliminary questioning revealed that Sunil Kumar had spent Monday night with his friends and cousins at Gajuwaka and his body was found hanging from the ceiling fan the next day. Police are yet to ascertain the reason for the suicide. Police suspecting familial disputes coupled with financial crisis might have driven Sunil Kumar to end his life. They have seized the deceased phone and will be examining the call data for clues.

A case has been registered under Section 174 of CrPC (suspicious death). Police handed over the body to the relatives of Sunil Kumar following the post-mortem.

Title: Murder accused from UP is constable in Uttarakhand
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

RUDRAPUR: A murder accused from Bareilly in Uttar Pradesh cleared the Uttarakhand Police recruitment test in 2001 and served the police force as a constable for nearly 20 years before his crime came to light about four months back when a court in Bareilly convicted him and awarded life sentence. Officials at the vigilance department said constable Mukesh Kumar has been suspended and action will be taken against him as per the law. A case under section 420 of IPC has been registered against Mukesh Kumar at Pantnagar police station in Udham Singh Nagar district.

Sources said Mukesh was involved in a murder case in Bareilly in 1997 and joined the Uttarakhand Police four years later in 2001 by giving false affidavit about his background. The matter surfaced when Mukesh was convicted by a court in Bareilly and was awarded life imprisonment. According to superintendent of police (city) Devendra Peencha, Mukesh is a native of Abhaypur in Bareilly and joined the Uttarakhand police in 2001.

“Four years after Mukesh committed the crime, he and his family shifted to Sehdora village in Kichha in Udham Singh Nagar district in 2001. He mentioned the Sehdora address in the application form for the post of constable, and this address was physically verified after he cleared the recruitment test,” said SP Peencha.

Constable Mukesh was posted in Almora district when he and five others were convicted by the Bareilly court last year, said Peencha adding that a resident of Bareilly informed senior police officials in Almora and the police headquarters in Uttarakhand that Mukesh had moved an appeal in a higher court.

"The informer alleged that Mukesh had used false affidavit to enter the state police force. An inquiry found that the declaration made by Mukesh in a self-attested affidavit while joining the police force stating that no inquiry or case under the law is pending against him was completely false. The report was forwarded to the Udham Singh Nagar district police seeking action against Mukesh. Following this, the senior clerk at the district's SSP office, Jodh Singh Tomqyal, filed a complaint against Mukesh at Pantnagar police station,” said Peencha. “A case under section 420 (forgery) of IPC has been registered at Pantnagar police station against Mukesh Kumar,” said SHO Ashok Kumar, adding “Mukesh applied for recruitment in the state police force in 2001, four years after committing the crime. The affidavit he provided was entered in his service book, which is a routine practice during recruitment, after his address was verified.”

Udham Singh Nagar SSP Barinderjit Singh said, “After the case was registered against the accused constable, we have sent the report to the vigilance department seeking departmental action against him.”

The SSP added that “appropriate action would be taken against those involved in verifying Mukesh Kumar's credentials prior to his recruitment in the police force.”

Title: Telangana high court to govt: Firm up rules for State Security Commission
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Driving home a stern message that the state should not deploy anymore delay tactics, the Telangana high court has directed the state government to formulate within one month from now the rules and regulations meant for the constitution and functioning of of the State Security Commission ( SSC ) and Police Complaints Authority ( PCA ) at the state and district levels.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy was hearing a contempt case filed against AP and Telangana states for not bringing in SSC and PCA mechanism that would provide independence to police and a mechanism for people to air grievances against police.

Telangana special counsel A Sanjeev Kumar told the court that they wrote a letter to the high court registry requesting the name or names of retired HC judges to head SSC and are awaiting a reply from the HC.

“This letter writing business is not sufficient. First formulate rules and regulations pertaining to SSC and PCAs and then expect this court to make recommendations,” the CJ said.

The state counsel said that he too had advised the authorities to first prepare the rules. “ Pull the officials up. Tell them that their inaction cannot be defended in the court”, the CJ advised the state counsel.

AP counsel claimed that it has already set up SSC and sought time to set up PCA. But the state counsel could not explain whether they framed any rules that govern the constitution and functioning of SSC & PCAs. The bench gave AP a month’s time to file a detailed affidavit on its rules and regulations.

Title: Iowa Democrats release some caucus results after long delay
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Iowa Democratic Party chairman Troy Price speaks about the delay in Iowa caucus results on Tuesday, February 4... Read More

DES MOINES, IOWA: Clouded by doubts on a chaotic day-after, the Iowa Democratic Party began releasing partial results of the state's first-in-the-nation presidential caucus on Tuesday.

Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders were ahead in the initial results released by the Iowa Democratic Party, with Elizabeth Warren, Joe Biden and Amy Klobuchar trailing behind in the tally of State Delegate Equivalents.

The data, made public for the first time nearly 24 hours after voting concluded, reflected the results of 62% of precincts in the state.

While campaigns were eager to spin the results to their advantage, there was little immediate indication that the incomplete results eased the confusion and concern that loomed over the opening contest of the Democrats 2020 presidential primary season.

It was unclear when Iowa's full results would be released.

During a private conference call with campaigns earlier in the day, state party chairman Troy Price declined to answer pointed questions about the specific timeline - even whether it would be a matter of days or weeks.

"We have been working day and night to make sure these results are accurate," Price said at a subsequent press conference.

The leading candidates pressed on in next-up New Hampshire, which votes in just seven days, as billionaire Democrat Michael Bloomberg sensed opportunity, vowing to double his already massive advertising campaign and expand his sprawling staff focused on a series of delegate-rich states voting next month.

The party's caucus crisis was an embarrassing twist after months of promoting the contest as a chance for Democrats to find some clarity in a jumbled field with no clear front-runner. Instead, after a buildup that featured seven rounds of debates, nearly $1 billion spent nationwide and a year of political jockeying, caucus day ended with no winner, no official results and many fresh questions about whether Iowa can retain its coveted "first" status.

Iowa marked the first contest in a primary season that will span all 50 states and several US territories, ending at the party's national convention in mid-July.

Campaigning in New Hampshire on Tuesday, Warren said she was "feeling good" about her performance in Iowa but questioned the state party's plans to release partial results.

"I just don't understand what that means, at least half of the data. I think they ought to get it together and release all the data," she said.

The Sanders' campaign told supporters that its internal monitoring showed him in the lead with nearly half the vote in. Sanders himself said late Monday, "Today marks the beginning of the end for Donald Trump."

Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, essentially declared an Iowa victory.

"So we don't know all the results, but we know by the time it's all said and done, Iowa, you have shocked the nation," he said before leaving Iowa. "By all indications, we are going on to New Hampshire victorious."

Biden said he was "feeling good" and predicted the results would be close.

The party told campaigns on Tuesday that the problem was a result of a "coding issue in the reporting system" that it said had since been fixed. It said it had verified the accuracy of the collected data and said the problem was not a result of "a hack or an intrusion."

A Biden campaign representative objected to the party's plan to release partial results before checking them against paper records, saying in the conference call that the plan didn't address "growing reports" about problems on caucus night, such as precinct captains unable to get through on the phone to report results.

"The stories and the problems are just multiplying so presumably you're going to have some way of addressing that and explaining to us as you release these partial results why you're comfortable," Biden campaign attorney Dana Remus said. "You need to have enough transparency that other people feel comfortable about it now and we're just not there right now."

Sanders adviser Jeff Weaver thanked party officials, and encouraged other campaigns not to undermine the party.

"Folks who are just trying to delay the return of this because of their relative positioning in the results last night, I think that's a bit disingenuous," Weaver said.

For the first time, the Iowa Democratic Party reported three sets of results: a tally of caucusgoers' initial candidate preference; vote totals from the "final alignment" after supporters of lower-ranking candidates were able to make a second choice, and the total number of State Delegate Equivalents each candidate received.

Early polling had suggested Sanders entered the night with a narrow lead, but any of the top four candidates _ Sanders, Biden, Warren and Buttigieg _ was positioned to score a victory. Senator Amy Klobuchar, who represents neighboring Minnesota, was also in the running, while outsider candidates including entrepreneur Andrew Yang, billionaire activist Tom Steyer and Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard lagged behind.

Sensing opportunity amid the chaos, Bloomberg's campaign announced plans to double its national television advertising spending, which has already exceeded $100 million , as it expands its paid staff to more than 2,000 people.

Bloomberg is looking to next month, having decided to bypass Iowa's contest and the three other states voting this month in favor of the delegate-rich states in March.

"After more than a year of this primary, the field is as unsettled as ever," Bloomberg spokeswoman Sabrina Singh said. "No one has made the sale or even come close to it. Meanwhile, Mike is taking the fight to Trump every day, doubling down on the national campaign strategy we've been running from the beginning."

Beyond 2020, the debacle invited fresh criticism about Iowa caucuses, a complicated set of political meetings staged in a state that is whiter and older than the Democratic Party. Many used the moment to question whether it was a quaint political tradition whose time had passed.

The party has tried to accommodate critics before, this year by promising to report three different data points about voters' preferences, presumably improving transparency. But the new system created new headaches.

"I think Iowa is a dumpster fire," said Dick Harpootlian, a South Carolina state senator and longtime Biden supporter, who served as an Iowa precinct captain for Biden on Monday.

Title: 2 booked in Haridwar for posting obscene photos of minors on FB
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Haridwar: Haridwar Police on Tuesday registered an FIR against two persons for posting objectionable photos of minors. The photos were uploaded from the account of a man named Akhil Rathore in Haridwar in June last year.

The IP address of the mobile from which they were uploaded was traced to another person in Haridwar. Police teams were sent to Ranigali, Bhopatwala in Haridwar but are yet to find the two accused.

Station house officer (SHO) city Praveen Singh Koshiyari told TOI, “Obscene pictures of men, women and minors were posted from the account of Facebook user Akhil Rathore in June last year. Facebook had shared this information with National Cyber Crime Reporting Portal (NCCRP) and NCCRP in turn forwarded a letter to Uttrakhand Police.”

He added, “Initial investigation revealed that the IP address of the mobile number was from Haridwar. The phone had been issued by a mobile company to a resident of Ranigali, Bhopatwala, Haridwar. We have registered a case against both the accused under relevant sections of Information Technology act and POCSO Act.”Circle officer of Haridwar Abhay Singh said that police are trying to find the accused and had asked locals to share any details they might have.

Title: Driving on Hyderabad roads or over craters on moon?
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A tweet about a two-wheeler rider being grievously injured, after his vehicle hit a pothole in Bachupally , caused a stir across social networking platforms, on Tuesday, with furious locals demanding that roads in the area be immediately repaired.The tweet was posted by the man’s daughter, Deepthi Duggirala. It read: “Yesterday [Monday] my father is another victim of roads of Bachupally. He fell into a pothole & hurt himself very badly. He came home bleeding. This isn't the 1st time I'm writing abt the NASTY roads Y the heck you don't fix them? @CommissionrGHMC @GHMCOnline @Director_EVDM @CEC_EVDM (sic)”Later, speaking to TOI, Duggirala reiterated the severity of the accident that took place near the road leading to SLG Hospital. She said her father hurt his chin and palm. “The bleeding would not stop...There is a pothole just before a curve. It’s very dangerous as it’s just before a slope,” she added.Her tweet prompted a host of reactions ranging from anger to memes.A tweet by Mahesh Goud (@indian66669296) said, “I think it is time for (Ivanka) Trump to visit Hyderabad again.”Prashant Mamidala, who carried out a ‘pothole plantation challenge’ where he and other residents planted saplings in potholes to raise awareness in the area, said, “Authorities seem to be least bothered about human life. We have made follow-up calls to officials to fill up the potholes, but in vain. Do the officials expect us to protest at each and every corner of the city to fix issues?”Vinay Vangala, an activist, said, “Better roads and sanitation are the basic needs of citizens. A lot of employees travel from this location to IT hubs. We have been following up the issue with the Nizampet Municipal Corporation.”Stating that after the recent incident, he had approached the municipal commissioner as well, Vangala said, “The commissioner responded positively and assured the road will be attended to on priority.”

Title: This Ayurvedic doctor fixes sore backs for free
Content:
Dr Pamulaparthy Rama Rao with patients at his daughter’s house

HYDERABAD: For over three decades now, Dr Pamulaparthy Rama Rao has been on this philanthropic mission — of treating people free of cost. And this, despite the fame that’s come his way, over the years. The thousands of people who throng his premises in Warangal and Hyderabad, continue to get free treatment from the Ayurvedic (MD) doctor, known for developing a disc management technique as a remedy for sciatica and cervical spondylitis.Every first week of the month Dr Rama Rao, who belongs to the family of former Prime Minister, P V Narasimha Rao, treats patients at his daughter's house in Bachupally. Hundreds of patients from Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam, Chittoor, Tamil Nadu make a beeline to see him. The scene at his hospital in Warangal is no different. Along with other patients, the crowds comprise actors, MLAs, ministers and NRIs from around the world.The 63-year-old former Ayurveda professor from Government Ayurvedic College in Warangal, said he has treated about three lakh patients so far. “My father and veteran journalist, Pamulaparthy Sadasiva Rao was the founder editor of Kakatiya Patrika in Warangal (from 1947 to 1955). He ran the paper with his cousin PV Narasimha Rao. It was my father who advised me to treat patients free of cost as the medical profession is a noble service,” said Dr Rama Rao. For seven years beginning 1987, he worked in tribal and naxal infested area of Charla in Bhadrachalam.The doctor’s popularity can be gauged from the fact that his appointments are full till May 27, 2020. “I can treat only 300 patients a day. I come to take rest in Hyderabad every month, but people have started thronging this place too,” he said.And patients admit that they undertake the long journey only for Dr Rama Rao.A Nandeedswari, a resident of Mangalagiri, said, “I have come all the way from Guntur district. I have been suffering with sciatica but with the disc massage and Ayurveda medication prescribed by the doctor I have been cured.” She added: “Dr Rama Rao is not only gifted but also benevolent. He doesn't accept any fee while we spend lakhs in private hospitals.”Speaking about his treatment method, Dr Rama Rao said that he takes to allopathy only for acute emergency cases. “For trauma accident cases, heart attacks, strokes, burns, snake bites and other acute emergencies allopathy is followed. But for chronic diseases, Ayurveda is better,” he said.

Title: Since Outbreak In China, Supply Of Components Has Stopped Affecting Production
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Agra: The outbreak of the deadly novel coronavirus (nCoV2019) in China has affected the footwear industry in Agra as supply of raw material from that country has stopped completely. Industry sources say raw material worth Rs 15 crore for manufacturing finished footwear is imported from different parts of China to Agra every month. Now, with the virus spreading fast, supply from China has dried up, affecting manufacturing here.

The virus is taking a toll in the economic front as well, shutting down businesses, curbing international travel and impacting production lines of major global businesses. In Agra, which is the largest footwear hub in India, the industry is adversely impacted as manufacturers imports several components such as laces, shoe lining, buckles, ornaments, insoles, outsoles, cellulose board, shank board, foam and packing material from China.

Every year, leather shoes worth over Rs 3,000 crore are exported to European countries from Agra. The US and several African countries are also important destinations for Agra footwear, say industry sources.

Talking to TOI, Puran Dawar, president of Agra Footwear Manufacturer and Exporters Chamber (AFMEC), said, “The spread of coronavirus has affected the shoe industry at a crucial time. January and February are peak months when manufacturing is done for exports during summer. Some of the shoe components are imported from China because these are not manufactured in India as it too expensive here.”

The footwear industry in Agra is renowned for leather products that it sells. Footwear alone accounts for 46% of the overall exports from leather industry. Agra has a share of 28% in the total footwear exports from the country and 65% of the domestic requirement.

Shoe exporter Gopal Gupta said, "We depend heavily on footwear components supplied from China. The factories in China remain closed for their traditional new year on January 25. Due to the outbreak of coronavirus, factories in that country have shut. Imports from China will remain affected even if the factories there start operating, as delivery of consignment would get delayed due customs and other security clearances. We are searching for alternatives. Footwear components can be imported from Italy or Spain but they cost more as compared to China.”

President of Agra Shoe Factories Federation, Gagandas Ramani, said, “Due to coronovirus outbreak, import of footwear component from China has completely stopped since January. This has affected manufacturing of finished footwear in micro units in Agra. Medium and large scale manufacturers maintain stock of components supplied from China. The footwear industry of Agra will suffer major losses if the situation does not normalise in the next one month.”

According to AFMEC sources, Agra has around 10,000 micro units, 30 medium scale units and around 15 large scale units. On an average, more than two lakh pair of shoes are manufactured in the city every day, and there are over 3.5 lakh people employed in the footwear industry in Agra.

Reputed global brands like Florsheim, Nunn Bush, Stacy Adams, Gabor, Clarks, Nike, Reebok, Ecco, Deichmann, Elefanten, St Michaels, Hasley, Salamander and Colehaan are manufactured under licence in India, especially in Agra. Besides, due to cheap labour, many global retail chains seeking quality products at competitive prices actively source footwear from Agra.

Meanwhile, UP tourism department has issued an alert to travel industries Agra and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), Agra circle, to immediately inform the health department about any visitors from China in the city.

Title: Centre allots five 2018 batch IPS officers to AP
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vijayawada: The Centre has allotted five Indian Police Service ( IPS ) officers of 2018 batch to Andhra Pradesh cadre. The state government on Tuesday issued a GO notifying the allotment of the new officers, all of whom have completed their training.

K V Maheswar Reddy and Kommi Pratap Sivakishore from AP, Shafqat Amna from Bihar, Suneel Sheoran from Delhi and Rahul Meena from Rajasthan have been given state cadre.

Maheswar Reddy is facing allegations of dowry harassment from his wife. A case was booked against him in October last year under sections 498A, 323, 506 of the IPC and SC/ST Act, following which the ministry of home affairs (MHA) put his appointment under suspension till further notice.

However, he moved the central administrative tribunal (CAT) challenging the MHA order, which stayed the suspension and cleared the way for his appointment.

Title: Court orders to book bank staff in Rs 38 lakh fraud
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bijnor: A chief judicial magistrate (CJM) court on Tuesday ordered Dhampur police to lodge a case against a bank manager, cashier and clerk for allegedly withdrawing Rs 38 lakh from a farmer’s account by forging his fake thumb impression on the withdrawal slip.

Filing a complaint at the CJM court against bank staff under section 156\3 of the Criminal Procedure Code, a farmer, Mathura Singh of Purana village said the government had acquired his land for constructing a National highway, in lieu of which he received Rs 38 lakh as compensation.

The misappropriation came into light on December 16 when Mathura Singh went to the bank at Dhampur to get entry of his bank passbook. He learnt that Rs 38 lakh were withdrawn from his account in different dates.

Title: Parking fee row: Traders take out 'baraat' of donkeys in protest
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Traders garlanded a pair of donkeys and took them around market

Agra: On the twenty second day of their indefinite strike, traders of Sanjay Place market took out a “baraat” (wedding procession) of donkeys named after mayor Naveen Jain as protest against Agra Municipal Corporation’s (AMC) levy of parking fee at the market. Amid sloganeering and performance by a musical band , traders garlanded a pair of donkeys and took them around the market.

Senior leaders of Pragatisheel Samajwadi Party (PSP), including Manisha Singh and Nitin Kohli, attended the protest to extend their party’s support to the traders’ cause. Kohli declared he would go on hunger strike in their support.

Since January 14, traders with shops at Sanjay Place have been sitting on an indefinite strike against AMC, for charging parking fee at 38 places in the market. They claimed it violates norms, as they had already paid a parking fee at the time of purchasing the property.

K N Agnihotri, secretary of the market association, said, “The AMC administration is trying to exploit traders by illegally charging parking fee. We’ve already paid for the parking space. To muzzle the voice of traders, a fake FIR has been registered. We’ll continue our fight against the parking mafia.”

The dispute over parking fee between Sanjay Place traders and AMC is sub-judice. Traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its verdict in the matter.

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Charging fee for parking on public place is a right of the civic body. The fee collected will be used for development and maintenance of sanitation and hygiene. In this regard, we have planned to constitute a monitoring committee of traders. The contractor has been directed not to charge parking fee from traders. Customer or visitors will not be charged separately at 38 spots, they will have to pay parking fees only once. To put a tab on traffic congestion and vehicle theft, the parking system at Sanjay Place is essential and will be continued.”

Title: Man demands 2L bribe, lands in ACB net
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Officials of anti-corruption bureau ( ACB ) on Tuesday arrested Manthri Murthy, a foreman at Visakhapatnam Steel Plant (VSP), for demanding and accepting a bribe of Rs 10,000 bribe from one Ruthala Yeshu.

Twenty-nine-year-old Yeshu, who works as salesman with a pharmacy at Kurmanapalem area, met Murthy through a common friend a few weeks ago. When Yeshu expressed his interest in working with VSP, Murthy claimed that his brother is a trade union leader at VSP and he can use his influence to get Yeshu a job at VSP.

The CBI officials said Yeshu alleged that Murthy demanded Rs 2 lakh for getting him the job and Rs 10,000 in advance. As Yeshu was not willing to pay the bribe, he approached CBI officials and lodged a complaint against Murthy. After verifying the facts, CBI officials laid a trap and arrested him when he was accepting the bribe money from Yeshu.

Title: Goods train derails near Ankleshwar, halts rail traffic
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

People stand in front of the derailed train engine

Surat: Three wagons of goods train got derailed near Ankleshwar, resulting in the disruption of the traffic between Ahmedabad and Mumbai on Tuesday evening. No casualty was reported in the incident.

Official sources said the accident occurred around 7pm between Ankleshwar and Bharuch railway stations. Three wagons of the goods train got uncoupled and were derailed.

According to the railway officials, the train had started from Surat and was heading towards Vadodara for loading of goods. The three wagons of the goods train got uncoupled below the Ankleshwar fly-over bridge, which is some 5km away from the Ankleshwar railway station.

The railway staff from Ankleshwar and Bharuch rushed to the spot for clearing the derailed wagons from the main Mumbai-Ahmedabad line.

Railway PRO of the Vadodara division, Khemraj Meena said, “The derailment was caused near Ankleshwar due to some technical reasons. The goods train was empty and was headed from Surat to Vadodara. Our teams of engineers and railway staff are working to clear the wagons from the main line.”

Meena added, “Due to the derailment, the railway traffic on the down line from Mumbai to Ahmedabad was disrupted. Over a dozen trains were running late by more than an hour due to the accident.”

According to Meena, the trains including Sayaji Nagri Express, Ranakpur Express, Rajdhani Express, August Kranti Express, Nizzamuddin Garib Rath, Bandra-Jaipur super fast train, Ahmedabad Passenger, Jamnagar-Surat passenger, Bhilad Express and two other Memu trains were running late due to the derailment.

Title: Centre dashes farmers’ hopes, no turmeric board for Nizamabad
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A full-fledged turmeric board , a long-pending demand of turmeric growers of Nizamabad and a promise which BJP had made in the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, won’t happen. Instead, Nizamabad will get a regional extension centre of Spices Board now. Telangana is the largest producer of turmeric in the country. Four erstwhile districts of Nizamabad, Karimnagar, Warangal and Adilabad account for 90% of production of turmeric in the state.

Announcing this in Delhi on Tuesday, Union commerce minister Piyush Goyal said the regional centre was being set up to take care of the needs of turmeric and chilli farmers. He said the regional centre would focus on exports of turmeric along with other spices and pulses. The existing divisional office in Nizamabad would be upgraded soon to serve as the regional centre.

BJP’s Dharmapuri Arvind , who in a sensational upset defeated CM K Chandrasekhar Rao ’s daughter Kalvakuntla Kavitha from Nizamabad in LS polls, had promised to get the turmeric board established in the town. Record nominations were also filed by turmeric growers from Nizamabad, drawing national attention on the issue.

Defending the move to set up the regional centre, Goyal said: “The turmeric board’s role is limited when compared to services that can be offered by the regional centre of Spices Board. A deputy director-level officer will head the centre.”Director (marketing), Spices Board, would monitor its activities.

The minister’s announcement, however, evoked a mixed response. Talking to TOI, turmeric grower Padigala Pravin, who filed a nomination as an independent in the 2019 Lok Sabha elections from Nizamabad, said the regional centre would be of no use. “It will not do any good. A regional centre is already functioning in Warangal. Only a separate turmeric board can help us get a good price,” he said. Pravin said turmeric growers should be paid a minimum support price of Rs 15,000 per quintal to cover their cultivation expenses.

Stating that the new extension centre would begin functioning soon, Goyal said it would not only focus on improving quality of turmeric but also help farmers get access to international markets. “The centre will also help the turmeric farmers get higher yield with better quality. We have given farmers more than what they have been asking for.”

In a separate directive to the secretary of Spices Board, the ministry of commerce said the regional centre will have to coordinate with the state government on production-related issues.

Curiously, Arvind said the Centre took the call after assessing the situation in the last six months. The Centre had realised that what turmeric farmers needed was a regional centre more than a board. “All separate boards for other commercial crops are not functioning as they were expected to. There is a need for a clusters’ system for spices,” he said.

The MP also said the Centre was ready to consider offering MSP for turmeric if the state government sends a proposal.

Joining the issue, Telangana State Planning Board vice-chairman B Vinod Kumar said they have been very clear on a separate turmeric board for Nizamabad. Vinod, who had written to Centre against shifting the regional centre at Warangal to Nizamabad, said: “Kavitha and the party are very clear that Centre should set up the turmeric board in Nizamabad only. She had voiced this when she was an MP. The latest move is further confusing the farmers.”

Title: Rape survivor accuses BJP MLA of shielding accused
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Woman steals newborn from LLRM Med College, FIR filed
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Meerut: A newborn boy was stolen allegedly by a woman in her forties from Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial (LLRM) Medical College on Monday. The family mistook the woman in question as hospital staff when she started helping them. She allegedly stole the baby by asking his father to dispose of a diaper. Within seconds the baby was gone. The man saw the woman running. He ran after her but could not catch her as she disappeared amid the rush.

The baby was stolen from outside the nursery. However, the CCTV cameras were not working near the spot. Hospital authorities are checking the other cameras in the vicinity to track the woman. An FIR has been filed in the matter.

“The patient, Sumaiya, was admitted to LLRM Medical College with complaints of labour pain. She had a caesarean section to deliver a baby boy on Monday afternoon. Her baby was kept in the nursery for observation for two hours. During this time, a woman in her forties struck up a conversation with Sumaiya’s husband, Aasif. She helped him as men are not allowed in the ward where his wife was admitted. Later, she accompanied him to the nursery when he went to take the baby. The woman then volunteered to change the baby’s diaper and asked Aasif to throw away the used one in the dustbin. According to our inquiry, it has been found that in the few seconds that he turned to throw the waste in the bin, the woman fled with the baby. He even tried to follow her but failed,” said Dr Rachna Chaudhary, chief medical superintendent, LLRM Medical College.

Police were informed in the matter and an FIR has been filed against an unknown woman.

There were no CCTV cameras outside the nursery and the others in the surrounding area were not functioning. As a result, the woman could not be captured in any of the CCTV camera recordings. “We are checking videos of more CCTV cameras, which were functional during the time to trace the woman in question,” said Chaudhary.

Title: Upgrade AU college of engg: Vijayasai in RS
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: YSRC Rajya Sabha MP V Vijayasai Reddy, through a special mention in Rajya Sabha on Tuesday, urged the Union government to upgrade the Andhra University College of Engineering (AUCE) to that of Indian Institute of Engineering, Science and Technology (IIEST) as per the recommendations of Anandakrishnan Committee.

“Unfortunately, the report has never been implemented and no proposal has been mooted to upgrade AUCE to the level of an IIEST. It has been nearly 14 years since the report was submitted by the committee,” said Vijayasai Reddy.

Vijayasai Reddy, while citing details of the committee, in order to give an impetus to higher education, the government had constituted the Anandakrishnan committee to identify institutions for upgradation to the level of institutes of national importance. “These ungraded institutions were to be called IIEST. The committee submitted its report and recommended that five institutions be upgraded to the level of IIEST. One such institution identified was AUCE. I request the government to introduce and pass a Bill to upgrade the AUCE to IIEST as done in the case of the Bengal Engineering College in 2014 and Institute of Technology, BHU in 2012,” he said. tnn

Title: 5-year-old joins cubs to play, gets mauled by lioness in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The hutment where the boy lived.

RAJKOT: Early on Tuesday morning , five-year-old Kishore Devipujak suddenly woke up hearing some growling sound. His groggy eyes sparkled seeing two cute lion cubs in the farm in Uchhaiya, a coastal village of Amreli district. He started fondling and playing with the cubs, completely unaware that their mother was around.

Before the little boy could realize anything, the lioness pounced and savagely attacked him. So furious was the lioness that she even ate some of this body parts.

The incident happened sometime between 4am and 5am, 3km from Port Pipavav, a private port run by APM Terminal and 12 km away from Rajula town.

Kishore was sleeping in the open outside his hut in the farm, which is located along side a railway track that leads to the port. His parents work as farm labourers.

Forest officials, however, said that the lioness might have mistaken the boy to be some prey as she had killed a goat at the same place in the recent past.

“The lioness caught the boy by his neck and ran for nearly three km in a grassland opposite the port. His family members and others even chased her. The lioness was familiar with these people as she moved around in the same area,” Sandeep Kumar, deputy conservator of forest, Shetrunji division, told TOI.

“The lioness was very angry. The forest department team has found her location in a near-by grassland and a trap has been set to capture her,” Kumar said.

According to forest officials, the boy’s head and parts of legs were eaten by the lioness. Villagers said some lions were also seen moving around in this area in the morning.

Congress MLA from Rajula, Amrish Der, has demanded creating a new sanctuary for lions in this area. Talking to media after the incident, Der said, “The number of lions in this coastal area is increasing. A sanctuary will help avoid such incidents of man-animal conflict besides providing protection to lions.”

The expanding lion population outside the protected areas and close to human habitats is fast becoming a cause of concern.

On December 23 last year, a farm labourer from Madhya Pradesh, Kadu Bhilad, was dragged and killed by a lion in Jira village of Dhari taluka in Amreli. Bhilad had gone to answer nature’s call and the lion mistook him for a prey as he was covered in blanket.

In December 2018, a lion had ripped off a fisherman named Rama Chudasama on the sea coast near Mahuva.

Title: Advocacy group objects to PPP model for medical colleges
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vijayawada: The Visakhapatnam-based Praja Arogya Vedika (PAV), a healthcare advocacy group affiliated to the Jan Swasthya Abhiyan, a nationwide network of 21 organizations promoting a people’s health movement, on Tuesday urged Union health minister Harsh Vardhan to reject Niti Aayog’s scheme to link new and existing private medical colleges with functional districts. It also objected the setting up of medical colleges through PPP model.

PAV general secretary T Kameswara Rao, in his letter to the minister, said the PPP (public-private partnership) model would eventually lead to increased cost of healthcare by way of imposing user charges for all services rendered in government hospitals. “This suggestion given by the Niti Aayog will reduce the government’s social obligation of being a healthcare provider to its citizens and will pave way for privatization, where the only motto will be profit and which in turn will be a burden on the vast majority of ailing public in the country,” Rao said in the letter.

Once privatization is done, there will be entry of multinational and monopoly capital into healthcare sector, as a result of which the already-widened gap between the poor and rich will further widen, which will further deteriorate the situation of common man suffering due to severe inflation and price hikes, he said.

“The move is contrary to those followed in some developed countries like Britain where healthcare sector is fully funded by the government and the outcomes of the same are also experienced by the people and are hailed around the globe. This proposal also goes against the commitment of universal health coverage charter signed by India,” Rao wrote, and requested the minister not to accept the proposal.

Title: Compensation for land acquisition: Arbitration process to restart on Thursday
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: After a long gap, the district administration will now restart the arbitration process pertaining to the land acquired for the widening of the Mukkola-Karode national highway stretch.

The Kazhakottam-Karode national highway action council had earlier announced an indefinite strike from March 15 over the delay in the arbitration process.

In the arbitration process, district collector, who is the arbitrator, will hear concerns of land owners who had approached high court alleging that the compensation for their land was low. The arbitration will be held at collectorate on Thursday.

As per the letter received by Jameela Prakasham, former MLA and patron of Kazhakkoottam-Karode national highway action council, the petitions of land owners in Kottukal, Kanjiramkulam, Thirupuram, Chenkal and Karode villages will be heard at the collectorate from Thursday.

Action council chairman V Sudhakaran said that the district administration agreed to hear the petitions after a gap of over a year. “This happened only after we repeatedly complained about the issue,” he said.

The decision for arbitration was taken after the land owners approached the court against district administration which arbitrarily fixed compensation.

After convening a district-level purchase committee meeting, which ended without forming a consensus on compensation between the then district collector K N Sathish and the land owners, the district administration had announced compensation package in 2014. After land owners challenged this in court, the high court had appointed collector as arbitrator.

During his term, former collector S Venkitesapathi heared 165 petitions and announced a 15 % hike. His successor, K Vasuki, heard 185 petitions and announced a hike of 50%. However, NHAI challenged it in court.

After NHAI approached court challenging the hike announced in the arbitration, the district administration had put the process on hold, though there was no stay on it, Sudhakaran said.

‘The district administration has to hear 1,850 complaints. It had heard only 350 petitions in the past six years. We have demanded them to settle the remaining petitions in six months,” said Sudhakaran.
