Title: Two labourers killed after earth-mover machine falls into gorge
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Uttarkashi: Two labourers were killed on Tuesday after the earth mover machine they were operating fell into a deep gorge in Arakot region of Uttarkashi district. Both the victims died on spot. Revenue police has sent the bodies for postmortem examination.

The deceased have been identified as 30-year-old Sanju Verma, a resident of Haripur, Chakrata; and 28-year-old Ujjwal Thapa, a Nepali citizen. According to TOI sources, the two labourers were engaged in the on-going Arakot-Thunara-Damti motor road construction work on Tuesday evening, when the earth mover machine fell into a nearly 300-metre-deep gorge.

Soon after the accident, revenue police and local villagers reached the spot and pulled out the bodies of the deceased labourers.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer, told TOI, “While doing road cutting work, the earth mover machine skidded into deep gorge, killing both the operators on the spot.”

Title: Self-finance colleges yet to give info for setting up exam centres
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

AGRA: The 2019-20 annual examinations at Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University are scheduled to start on March 2. But so far, the varsity administration has not been able to determine the examination centres. The managements of self-financed colleges are not providing details on 21 parameters sought by the university administration. After getting details, university officials will conduct physical verification for determination of the examination centres.

There are 996 colleges affiliated to Agra University . Out of these, 39 are government-aided colleges and 17 are colleges owned by the state government. More than five lakh students are enrolled at these colleges.

According to university officials, around 300 colleges will be made examination centres. All the 56 government-aided and colleges owned by the state government will be compulsorily made examination centres.

To shortlist examination centres out of the self-financed colleges, the university administration had sought details on 21 parameters, including number of classrooms, availability of furniture, CCTV cameras and voice recorders. So far, only 70 colleges have provided details to the university administration.

University’s public relations officer GS Sharma said, “The process for determination of the examination centres has been initiated and will be completed by end of February. Around 70 self-financed colleges have provided details on required parameters. A reminder has been sent to the remaining colleges. Examination centres will be determined after inspection of the shortlisted colleges.”

Title: Goa: ‘New bill will penalise landlords who don’t give cops tenant information’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Stating that 85% of rapes and murders in the state are committed by migrants, chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday said the government would introduce a tenant verification bill in assembly that would contain provisions to penalise landlords who rent accommodation to migrants without due verification.

The chief minister told the House that Monday’s double murder case in Fatorda — which involved a Karnataka native killing a casual labourer and a ragpicker over alcohol — was cracked within 12 hours of the incident being reported. He said the accused neither had a labour card nor was his tenant verification done.

“If the accused had moved out of state by bus or some other route, the case would have remained unsolved forever as there was no information about him with the state authorities,” Sawant said. “Migrants are staying in Goa without tenant verification.”

Sawant also urged all legislators to support the drive to check how many landlords have conducted tenant verification. “If there is any person renting his premises without tenant verification, bring it to the notice of the government,” Sawant told them.

Reiterating that a law would be enforced to act against people who do not inform the police after renting out their premises, the chief minister insisted that a record of all migrants be maintained at police stations. He said contractors who employ migrants for construction work or any other activity must conduct police verification and obtain labour cards for them.

Title: Coronavirus to hit diamond export to China by 20%
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: Outbreak of novel coronavirus in China is all set to take sheen out of the world’s largest diamond cutting and polishing centre in Surat. Industry experts said polished diamond exports to China, Hong Kong and Vietnam have been hit hard and that the decrease could range between 18 and 20% in the coming months.

Industry sources said Hong Kong, China and Vietnam are the biggest market for polished diamond exports for India. Out of the total exports of polished diamonds from India, about 40% valued at $6 billion are exported to Far East countries.

Majority of diamond offices owned by Gujarati diamantaires are non-operational in Hong Kong as the government has sealed the borders with China due to the outbreak of deadly virus.

According to figures available from Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC), gross exports of gems and jewellery to Hong Kong were down by 8.45% at $7.4 billion between April-December 2019 compared to $8 billion during the same period in previous year.

On the other hand, overall exports of polished diamonds between April and December 2019 have decreased by 18% at $14.66 billion compared to $17.86 billion during the same period in the previous year.

Vipul Shah, chief executive officer and managing director of Asian Star Company Limited, told TOI, “China and other countries in Far East are the second largest market for polished diamond exports from India and that the impact of virus on diamond exports will be around 20%. Our sales office in Hong Kong is operational, but we are not getting any customers as the borders have been sealed. We are monitoring the situation and may take a call to shut down the office in a day or two.”

Hitesh Patel, managing director of Dharmanandan Diamonds, said, “Diamond industry is facing problems in Hong Kong and China since a long time. First came the US-China trade war and it was followed by anti-government protests in Hong Kong. Now, it is novel coronavirus. We have called back our staff from Hong Kong office as there is no business. The novel coronavirus is going to hit the diamond industry hard.”

Title: Five babus arrested as ACB holds surprise raids across AP
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Officials of anti-corruption bureau ( ACB ) on Tuesday carried out surprise raids across the state and nabbed five officials from various departments in four districts of Andhra Pradesh for amassing assets dispproportinate to his known source of income.

ACB officials arrested an executive engineer with the tribal welfare department and ITDA-Parvathipuram, Vizianagaram district, T Mohan Rao (57) for having properties worth over Rs 15 crore. ACB sleuths, led Srikakulam ACB DSP, BVS Ramana Murthy, raided Rao’s and his relatives’ houses across north Andhra Pradesh, including Vizianagaram and Visakhapatnam.

In another raid , ACB officials uncovered illegal assets (movable and immovable properties) worth over Rs 1.75 crore belonging to field assistant (staff assistant) of primary agriculture cooperative society, Tamaram, Makavarapalem in Visakhapatnam district, S Govindu (Govindam). The total worth of all the property will be over Rs 12 crore as per the market rate.

Sakhe Satyam, revenue divisional officer and personal assistant to special collector, Srisailam Project, Kurnool district, also landed in the ACB net after he was found with illegal assets over Rs 1 crore, including immovable properties in Telangana.

In East Godavari district, two officials, superintending engineer of Kakinada Municipal Corporation, Gandham Venkata Pallam Raju, and Kakinada CEO for employment and training, L Raghu Babu, were arrested by ACB officials for amassing illegal assets worth over Rs 5 crore, respectively.

Title: Hyderabad: Man shoots wife’s uncle, held
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Peeved over marital problems, a cement factory worker shot his wife’s uncle at Israjpalli in Jagtiyal district on Monday night. Hours later, he was nabbed. Jagityal police said the victim, who suffered bullet injuries, is out of danger.

P Srinivas, 35, a cement factory supervisor in Madhya Pradesh and native of Govindaram village in Jagityal district, married Gitika and they have two children.

“Due to marital discord, his wife went to her native place with the children a few months ago,” Jagityal SP Sindhu Sharma said.

On Monday night, he along with a friend went to her native place and asked her to return home, resulting in a verbal spat.

On hearing the ruckus , Gitika’s uncle B Raji Reddy’s who stays nearby, came to the house, SP said. As he tried to intervene, Srinivas pulled out a firearm from his pocket and fired at him. On Tuesday, Srinivas, surrendered and was taken into custody.

Title: YSRC seeks spl central package for Uddhanam
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Union minister for health and family welfare Harsh Vardhan on Tuesday told Parliament that there was no provision of pension for dialysis patients with below poverty line status under Pradhan Mantri National Dialysis Programme (PMNDP).

He said the AP government had informed the Centre that it was paying monthly pension of Rs 10,000 to BPL dialysis patients.

Responding to a query in Rajya Sabha, the minister said that under PMNDP, dialysis services are provided at district hospitals for management of chronic kidney diseases free of cost to BPL patients. The programme was running at 35 dialysis centres across 13 districts in AP, he said.

YSRC’s Vijayasai Reddy told the minister Uddhanam has a large number of people with chronic kidney disease . He said chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy has decided to set up a research centre and 200-bed super specialty hospital in the area. He requested the Centre to sanction a special package for Uddhanam and build a super specialty hospital at Palasa. He said only 15,000 kidneys are available every year in the country whereas kidney transplantation patients number around 2 lakh. tnn

Title: Supreme Court adjourns case on Muslim quota
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Supreme Court

HYDERABAD: Former Congress minister Mohammed Ali Shabbir said Supreme Court on Tuesday adjourned the hearing on 4% reservations for Muslims in the Telugu states. Shabbir is one of the petitioners with Telangana and AP governments.

Senior counsel Rajeev Dhavan represented the case on behalf of Telangana BC department and sought a week’s time to which the court agreed. Senior advocates, Salman Khurshid and Shakeel Ahmed , represented Shabbir. “We are confident justice will be done to Muslims in the SC in terms of continuing reservations,” Shabbir said.TNN

Title: Surat: Cop jumps into Tapi to save ragpickers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Traffic constable RR Rabari with Rita Rathod and her niece Jayshree

SURAT: A traffic police constable of city police rescued a 30-year-old woman and her 10-year-old niece from drowning in Tapi from weir-cum-causeway built over the river on Tuesday. The constable, who was in uniform, immediately jumped into the river and rescued the two ragpickers.

Constable R R Rabari, lifesaver of Rita Rathod and her niece Jayshree, was commended by police commissioner R B Brahmbhatt for his courageous act and awarded Rs1,000 cash prize. He was also given a letter of appreciation by Brahmbhatt in his office. City police will recommend Rabari for Jivan Raksha Padak awarded by the Government of India.

Rabari spotted a crowd at 9am when returning home in Singanpore after night shift from city traffic police head office in Athwalines. He was crossing the river from the causeway but stopped.

“I noticed that the girl was coming out of water frequently but the woman was taking time to come out. I knew they must have gulped a lot of water by now and hence jumped to rescue them. I did not wait for a team of fire department to arrive,” Rabari told TOI.

Rabari didn’t even wait to remove his wallet before jumping into the waters. He first rescued the girl and then the woman. “The woman had already gulped lot of water and hence I pressed her back and chest after which she began to puke. She was safe after that. The girl was normal,” said Rabari, a native of Khakhrathad village near Than in Surendranagar district.

The girl was picking plastic waste from the causeway’s sloppy side when she slipped into the waters because of algae. In an attempt to rescue her, Rita threw one end of a cloth to Jayshree and tried to pull her out. Meanwhile, Rita too lost balance and fell into the waters. They both started drowning when Rabari arrived there as a saviour.

Rabari is in police for the past six years and was trained at PTS Vadodara.

Read this story in Bengali

Title: Second leopard attack in a fortnight in Rikhnikhal block of Kotdwar
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR: The nearly decomposed body of a 90-year-old woman was found near Gajarijal-Balachaur village of Rikhnikhal block in Kotdwar on Tuesday.

Villagers alleged that she was killed by a leopard. Savitri Devi (90) was missing from home sinced January 26. Searching for her, villagers recently stumbled upon her scarf in nearby bushes and then found her body. The forest department said that they are yet to get the details of the woman’s post-mortem report and cannot yet confirm if the woman was killed by a leopard or not.

On January 25, a man in Kotdwar was killed by a leopard near Angani village of Rikhnikhal block. However, divisional forest officer (DFO) Laxman Singh Rawat had then refused to acknowledge there was a leopard problem in the area and blamed the accident on the man’s negligence, saying he had ventured out in the dark despite warnings. Villagers have now made a fresh demand to declare the big cat a man-eater. “The leopard has turned a man-eater now, we want it killed or tranquilised and sent to a zoo,” said Pushpa Devi, pradhan of Dhikolia gram Panchayat of Rikhnikhal block.

Title: Posted in Siachen, Army jawan from Uttarakhand dies
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: Army jawan Ramesh Bahuguna, who had fallen sick while on duty at the Siachen sector, died in Chandigarh hospital on Monday night.

Bahuguna, a Mahar regiment jawan, was a native of Sabli village in Chamba region of the Tehri district. The 38-year-old jawan is survived by his wife and two children who live in Rishikesh . He had joined the Indian Army in 2002.

Deceased’s brother Dinesh Dutt Bahuguna told TOI that extreme weather conditions in Siachen took a toll on his brother’s health. The cremation would take place at Purnanand Ghat in Rishikesh on Wednesday. Bahuguna was brought to a Chandigarh hospital after he complained of health issues on January 31. The Siachen sector in Jammu and Kashmir is considered to be the toughest postings of the Army because of the inhospitable terrain and the high altitude. Bahuguna was posted at Siachen last year.

Title: Agra: Man slits wife’s throat, booked for dowry death
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

AGRA: A newly married woman was allegedly murdered by her husband in Firozabad district for “chatting on mobile phone”.

Identified as Aashima (22), the victim was married to Asif (24) of Noornagar under Ramgarh police jurisdiction. According to police, around 12:30 am, Aashima was killed with a sharp weapon . After the incident, the accused along with his mother reached police station from where the accused, who tried to kill himself too, was referred to S N Medical College.

Based on the written complaint of the victim’s brother Hanish Khan, police booked Asif, his brother Waris, father Ikrar and mother Rabia in a case of dowry death .

However, Ramgarh station house officer Shyam Singh said, “The accused claimed that his wife was continuously busy on phone and engaged in chatting. Infuriated with his wife’s act, Arif slit her throat.”

Though the victim’s family claimed that two days back, Arif had come to their house to take Ashima back, but the victim refused, as he was demanding a motor-bike.

Arif, labour working in local factory got married to Ashima just two months ago.

Title: Auctioning of mining leases difficult as govt has only 20% surface right:CM
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Panaji: In a tacit admission regarding the difficulty in restarting mining , chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Tuesday his government wants to restart the industry but it isn’t possible since over 70% of surface rights lie with private owners and lease holders, while the government only holds 20%.

Sawant was responding to several members of the House who demanded an answer from him as to when exactly the industry would restart, and why were leases not being auctioned when the state was facing a financial crunch.

His own party colleague, Panaji MLA Atanasio Monserrate, demanded a categorical answer — “Tell me, when will mining restart? Are people being taken for a ride?” he asked. Another BJP legislator, Clafacio Dias of Cuncolim, said that people in the mining belt are suffering and asked for it to be restarted at the earliest. Tivim MLA Nilkanth Halarnkar too questioned the government about resumption of mining.

Congress MLAs Luizinho Faleiro and Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco, and MGP’s Ramkrishna Dhavalikar also grilled the CM, to which Sawant said he is “very clear” that his government wants to restart mining.

“I want to start legal mining,” he said. “I know what problems people are facing due to the stoppage of mining, but there are a lot of hurdles.”

Talking about the steps taken for the resumption of mining, he said that 22 e-auctions of 16.8 MMT of ore extracted have already been held. “Of this, 13.54 MMT has been sold, and revenue earned amounts to Rs 130 crore,” he said.

The review petition filed for restarting mining, Sawant said, is expected to be heard by the Supreme Court soon. Besides, he said, an interlocutory application is before the apex court for allowing handling of dumps based on the recommendations of central empowered committee. He further said that the government has taken a positive stand before the SC with regards to transportation of royalty-paid ore by mining companies. The SC has allowed the petition for transportation of royalty-paid ore.

Title: World Cancer Day marked by awareness events
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Coimbatore: City hospitals that specialize in cancer treatment commemorated the World Cancer Day on Tuesday by organizing innovative awareness campaigns.

This year's theme for the day was ‘I am and I will’, acknowledging everyone’s capacity to act in the face of cancer.

Sri Ramakrishna Institute of Oncology and Research launched cancer awareness umbrellas. The QR code on them leads to a website providing information on various type of cancer. The hospital also inaugurated a month-long free prostate screening programme.

At the PSG Institute of Oncology and its nursing college, IIIrd year nursing students displayed posters, videos, PowerPoint presentations and pamphlets to create awareness on oral cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, colon cancer, blood cancer and lung cancer. They explained about the causes, risk factors, signs and symptoms, diagnostic evaluation, management and prevention.

Gem Hospital inaugurated ‘Care for Life’ along with the Rotary Club of Coimbatore to provide free treatment for patients from low-income families with gastrointestinal cancer. Founder of Sankara Eye Care Institutions Dr R V Ramani was the chief guest. The initiative intends to pool fund to treat early stage gastrointestinal cancers, which can be cured.

Title: 10-year-old raped, thrashed, nearly buried alive in Rajasthan
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

JAIPUR: A 10-year-old girl is battling for life at Churu district hospital after she was brutally raped and beaten by an unemployed youth living in her neighbourhood late on Monday night.After beating her up with stones on her head, the accused tried to bury her alive in an abandoned house.The girl studying in Class 3 is in the hospital in a serious condition. She has injury marks on her head and neck. The girl had left her house at around 9.30pm to buy chocolates from a shop in her locality. When she did not return, her family launched a search.At around 10.30 pm, they found her in a serious condition at an abandoned house in the area in an unconscious state. She was bleeding from her head.Police immediately began to investigate the case and arrested a 21-year-old living near her house. “When the girl had gone to buy chocolates, the accused lured the minor to an abandoned house and raped her,” said Vishnu Dutt, station house officer, Rajgarh police station, Churu.

Title: Coronavirus in Agra: Agra footwear industry stares at losses due to coronavirus
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

AGRA: The outbreak of the deadly novel coronavirus (nCoV2019) in China has affected the footwear industry in Agra as supply of raw material from that country has stopped completely. Industry sources say raw material worth Rs 15 crore for manufacturing finished footwear is imported from different parts of China to Agra every month. Now, with the virus spreading fast, supply from China has dried up, affecting manufacturing here.The virus is taking a toll in the economic front as well, shutting down businesses, curbing international travel and impacting production lines of major global businesses. In Agra, which is the largest footwear hub in India, the industry is adversely impacted as manufacturers imports several components such as laces, shoe lining, buckles, ornaments, insoles, outsoles, cellulose board, shank board, foam and packing material from China.Every year, leather shoes worth over Rs 3,000 crore are exported to European countries from Agra. The US and several African countries are also important destinations for Agra footwear, say industry sources.Talking to TOI, Puran Dawar, president of Agra Footwear Manufacturer and Exporters Chamber (AFMEC), said, “The spread of coronavirus has affected the shoe industry at a crucial time. January and February are peak months when manufacturing is done for exports during summer. Some of the shoe components are imported from China because these are not manufactured in India as it too expensive here.”The footwear industry in Agra is renowned for leather products that it sells. Footwear alone accounts for 46% of the overall exports from leather industry. Agra has a share of 28% in the total footwear exports from the country and 65% of the domestic requirement.Shoe exporter Gopal Gupta said, "We depend heavily on footwear components supplied from China. The factories in China remain closed for their traditional new year on January 25. Due to the outbreak of coronavirus, factories in that country have shut. Imports from China will remain affected even if the factories there start operating, as delivery of consignment would get delayed due customs and other security clearances. We are searching for alternatives. Footwear components can be imported from Italy or Spain but they cost more as compared to China.”President of Agra Shoe Factories Federation , Gagandas Ramani, said, “Due to coronovirus outbreak, import of footwear component from China has completely stopped since January. This has affected manufacturing of finished footwear in micro units in Agra. Medium and large scale manufacturers maintain stock of components supplied from China. The footwear industry of Agra will suffer major losses if the situation does not normalise in the next one month.”According to AFMEC sources, Agra has around 10,000 micro units, 30 medium scale units and around 15 large scale units. On an average, more than two lakh pair of shoes are manufactured in the city every day, and there are over 3.5 lakh people employed in the footwear industry in Agra.Reputed global brands like Florsheim, Nunn Bush, Stacy Adams, Gabor, Clarks, Nike, Reebok , Ecco, Deichmann, Elefanten, St Michaels, Hasley, Salamander and Colehaan are manufactured under licence in India, especially in Agra. Besides, due to cheap labour, many global retail chains seeking quality products at competitive prices actively source footwear from Agra.Meanwhile, UP tourism department has issued an alert to travel industries Agra and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), Agra circle, to immediately inform the health department about any visitors from China in the city.

Title: Nainital ropeway gets stuck midway, tourists rescued
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The ropeway in the lake townwas stuck mid-way for almost two hours on Tuesday evening. According to eyewitnesses, nine tourists were headed to the Snow View point when around 4pm, the trolley carrying them got stuck. Officials, however, said that the tourists were rescued within minutes and they returned to their hotels. The officials added that the ropeway had a technical glitch, which disturbed its functioning, but it was cleared later. The Nainital ropeway is a major tourist attraction, which is used by tourists to go to the Snow View point for Himalaya Darshan.

Title: Mango farmers expect bumper crop this year
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Surat: Love mangoes, then rejoice. Mango farmers of south Gujarat are hopeful of a good harvest this season. The cold atmosphere after Diwali has ensured there was no additional vegetative growth, which in turn pushed heavy flowering in the plants.

For the past two years, the region has been witnessing only 50 per cent production and mango farmers want to reap at least 80 per cent harvest this season.

South Gujarat region is called Gujarat’s ‘Mango Bowl’, especially in the districts of Valsad and Navsari, where the famous Hafoos mangoes grow in abundance. Inclement weather played spoiled sport for the region in the last two years, disappointing not only the farmers with massive dip in production, but also mango lovers with less fruits in the market.

Yield of Hafoos mangoes came down drastically in that period due to flowers drying up before maturity and falling off owing to diseases, rued some farmers.

Some of the farmers replaced Hafoos with Kesar mangoes and others took to Nilgiri farming.

“This year, the onset has been very good. Soon after Diwali, winter set in which resulted in no new vegetative growth on the plants. The plants already have single and heavy flowering which will, hopefully, firm up as fruits by March,” said Dinesh Padaliya, assistant director of horticulture, Navsari.

Padaliya further said that with mercury remaining between 12 and 18°C at present, the climate is very conducive for good fruit. More so, this year there is single heavy flowering, unlike past years. This is good as then it eliminates chances of mucus setting on trees and getting a bumper crop, he added.

A progressive mango farmer from Gandeva village in Navsari district whose orchard is home to 1,500 trees, said, “Flowering has taken place a little late, but it is very good. With nights cold and warmer daytime temperatures, I feel it will help in a good output and can even go up to 80 per cent.”

Title: Nine juveniles escape from Mehsana observation home
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Palanpur: In a daring escape , nine juveniles escaped from the zonal observation home in Mehsana on Tuesday morning after locking the guard and another employee.

According to an offence lodged with the B-division police station, the juveniles thrashed the guard when they were called for breakfast.

They locked the guard and another employee in the toilet and later broke open the iron grill to escape.

There were only nine juveniles in the observation home. The boys were from Surat, Ahmedabad, Maharashtra and Silvassa. Police sources said that four were detained for loot while two had attempt to murder cases lodged against them.

Observation home superintendent, Amit Limachia, said the juveniles were lodged here for the past six to seven months.

Title: Minister urged to lift export ban on KP onions
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Speaking on the ban on KP onions in the Rajya Sabha, commercial tax minister Piyush Goyal on Tuesday said the Centre would study the possibility of lifting export ban on KP onions.

KP onions are cultivated over 5,000 acres in and around Kadapa and Prakasam districts. The variety is grown for export to Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore.

YSRC national general secretary V Vijayasai Reddy said that the ban on onion export has affected farmers and urged the Centre to lift the ban on export of KP onions. tnn

Title: BMC aims to elevate Mumbai on happiness index
Content:
Bruhanmumbai municipal corporation

MUMBAI: In a controversial move, the cash-strapped BMC’s Budget 2020-21 has proposed to regularize misuse of non-habitable areas inside commercial and residential buildings.In several buildings, people illegally use flower beds, lofts and car decks by amalgamating these areas into their flats or offices. Now, the civic administration plans to provide conditional floor space index (FSI) to regularize this misuse by charging a fee— 15% of the ready reckoner value of the unauthorized use. It hopes to raise Rs 600 crore with this initiative.Experts said this regularization must be in accordance with new building rules. “Else, they would violate permissible FSI, which will be both illegal and undesirable,” said former municipal commissioner Subodh Kumar. He further said the BMC will not be able to implement it unless relevant sections of the MRTP Act are modified.Justifying the proposal, municipal commissioner Praveen Pardeshi said, “Occupants have made changes to their premises without any permission. The BMC cannot go home to home to check such unauthorized use of space. So, we are providing an option of regularization.”Housing activist Chandrashekhar Prabhu said Development Control Rules 2034 already provide for 35% extra (fungible) FSI for all existing built areas. “If illegal spaces which have been built over and above that available free of FSI are sought to be regularized, then it can raise legal issues,” he said.Architect Manoj Daisaria described it as a “good move”.“It will not only regularize unauthorized extensions but avoid unnecessary litigation by payment of a premium. This is reasonable.”The civic administration said under the 1991-2012 DCR, areas such as flower beds, car decks and lofts were free of FSI.But people in residential and commercial establishments illegally use them as habitable spaces without seeking any permission.

Title: Nallamala Forest Fire: Parts of Nallamalla forest catch fire
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nearly 50 acres of forest land between Vatavarlapally and Dhomalapenta range of Nallamalla was burnt down in a fire on Tuesday afternoon. According to forest officials, the incident occurred at around 2 pm and it took them almost four hours to put out the fire.

“We suspect that tourists may have thrown flammable material onto dry grass, causing the fire. No animals were harmed. We rushed to the spot and extinguished the fire,” said M Joji, divisional forest officer, Nagar Kurnool .

Title: Rail officials await announcement of SCoR commencement date
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: While the Union ministry of railways is yet to make an announcement on the commencement date of the South Coast Railway ( SCoR ) zone, railway officials here anticipate an official statement soon.

While creation of the zone was officially announced in February 2019, there has been no further progress till date. Nor has the new railway zone found mention in the Union Budget.

A senior railway official said, “Though bifurcation was announced earlier, the AP Reorganisation Act came into effect on June 2, 2014. Similarly, the date of commencement of the SCoR will be announced later.”

Official sources in the railways said a demand for retaining the residual portion of Waltair division in the new zone may have delayed the announcement and allocations in the Budget, adding that some sections have been insisting the Centre include Waltair in the newly-created zone.

Title: Take pivotal role in tackling pollution, says governor
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Tirupati: Indian Council for Agricultural Research (ICAR) DG Trilochan Mohapatra, who is also the secretary of department of agricultural research and education (DARE), has called upon veterinary graduates to help the Prime Minister achieve the goal of doubling farm income by 2022.

Delivering his address at the ninth convocation of Sri Venkateswara Veterinary University (SVVU) here on Tuesday, he spoke on making farming remunerative by linking it with veterinary, fishery and horticulture and by turning every farmer into an entrepreneur. “The required business skills have to be imparted in farmers. Agriculture has to be viewed in that perspective and this narrative has to be brought into farming and allied sectors”, he pointed out. Mohapatra also added that it requires market linkage, productivity enhancement, diversification into allied areas, food processing and value addition.

While the country has succeeded in hiking milk production by touching 176 million tonnes and growing at an unparalleled 6% rate, he maintained that the per capita milk availability has also exceeded the level recommended by World Health Organisation (WHO). Similarly, the poultry and fisheries sectors grew phenomenally to reach impressive figures, fetching over 7 billion USD through export. Crediting cattle rearers for production, he appreciated the scientific fraternity for bringing modern vaccines at affordable rates and introducing induced breeding programmes, slashing the cost of animal feed, all of which went into enhancing productivity.

Governor and chancellor Biswa Bhusan Harichandan called upon the graduates to take up a pivotal role in tackling air, water and industrial pollution, but also in reaching out to animals desperately waiting for medical intervention in the countryside. He spoke on the evil effects of pesticides and the need to promote greener alternatives. He later presented gold medals and awards to meritorious students .

In his annual report, vice-chancellor Y Hari Babu listed down the developmental activities taken up in the year such as new buildings under construction, farmer training programmes, health centre and so on.

Title: Tatabad man detained for bank loan fraud
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Coimbatore: A 43-year-old man was detained on Tuesday for cheating an elderly woman of Rs 50 lakh by promising to get education loan for her grandson.

Police identified him as K Dhanraj of Tatabad near Sivananda Colony in the city. “The incident happened in 2017. Sixty-year-old C Rajammal of Nagammapudur near Annur was trying to get education loan from a nationalised bank for her grandson. Dhanraj, who was Rajammal’s tenant, told her that he was working in a nationalised bank and would help her get loan by pledging property. On September 22, 2017, Dhanraj told her to come to a private bank branch at RS Puram with property documents. He got her signatures on some papers and told her that Rs 50 lakh would be credited to her account within a week,” a police officer said.

Rajammal contacted Dhanraj after she failed to get the money. “She came to know that he had obtained Rs 50 lakh loan against her property. He had transferred the amount to the account of his accomplice Jesintha Mary. Dhanraj threatened Rajammal with dire consequences when she demanded the money,” the officer added.

The Annur police registered a case against the Dhanraj and Jesintha Mary under sections of 467, 468, 471, 420 and 506 (i) of Indian Penal Code on January 13, 2019. After police failed to arrest the man even after a year, Rajammal decided to approach the Madras high court. It prompted superintendent of police Sujit Kumar to form a special team led by sub-inspector Arun to nab Dhanraj. The team detained him on Tuesday and handed him over to the Annur police.

Title: Gas leak: Experts cap valve manually
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Rajahmundry: Two RCMT teams finally managed to check the gas leak at the PFH Oil and Gas Pvt Ltd-owned oil well in Uppidi village on Tuesday morning by manually closing the gate valve. The gas leak had begun on February 2.

According to ONGC authorities, emergency team used water umbrella overnight at the site of gas leak to cool the wellhead where the natural gas was escaping at a force of 100 kg /cm2. The water umbrella allowed the RCMT team approach the well and by 10:47 am the well was closed and capped successfully.

The ONGC had closed the oil well in 2007 had handed it over to the Union government in 2016-17 and it is was leased out by PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited, Kolkata, a year ago.

Title: Charminar vulnerable to air pollution: Prahlad Singh Patel tells Lok Sabha
Content:
File photo of Charminar in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Iconic Charminar , which is synonymous with Hyderabad, is vulnerable to air pollution. This was stated by Union minister for culture and tourism, Prahlad Singh Patel in Lok Sabha on Monday as he listed 11 other monuments facing a similar threat.The minister revealed that NOx (oxides of nitrogen) and relative humidity were damaging the Charminar. The area around the 439-year-old structure has high levels of suspended particulate matter as well as high sound levels.Track the pollution level in your cityOther monuments in the country facing a similar threat are the Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Hoshang Shah’s tomb and Mandu, Agra fort, Akbar's tomb at Agra, Bibi ka Maqbara at Aurangabad, Shore Temple at Mamallapuram and the Dwarkadhish temple at Dwarka among others.Charminar was built in 1581 AD by Mohammed Quli Qutb Shahi, the fifth sultan of the Qutub Shahi dynasty, to commemorate the end of a deadly plague that had hit the city then.Archaeological Survey of India superintending archaeologist Dr Milan Kumar Chouley told TOI, “The lime plaster is deteriorating due to pollution. Lime reacts with chemicals in atmosphere and loses its binding property. The last time a chunk of the monument fell and we crushed it, it turned powder. The oxide of nitrogen pollution will have a similar effect as acid rain due to which the surface of the monument is affected.”He added that in the 1800s, the Nizam had re-plastered the entire Charminar because of a similar problem. “Lime normally has a life of 800 years, but when exposed to nature and chemicals, it can lose it property and become weak, which is what is happening to Charminar,” he said.The ASI official said that given Charminar’s location and setting, it is difficult to reduce the pollution levels around it. “But larger measures similar to those taken for the Taj Mahal can be taken up. When Taj Mahal’s marble was turning black, larger pollution prevention measures were taken. We need similar measures for the whole area here,” said Chouley. “The sound levels have come down after vehicular movement has been regularised.”P Anuradha Reddy, convener of INTACH Hyderabad, told TOI, “Besides pollution, the central government should also look at other issues concerning the Charminar, like encroachments, insufficient funding, maintenance, preservation measures and security.”

Title: Central team inspects airport
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Coimbatore: A central government team has arrived to inspect coronavirus prevention and detection systems in place in the district. Three senior officials landed in the city on Tuesday and a fourth official is expected to arrive on Wednesday.

The team consisting of regional director of ministry of health and family welfare Dr Roshini Arthur, Tushar Nala and Monica Matlani inspected the airport and 108 ambulance arrangements in the district. “

In the airport, they checked our handing over of self declaration forms for international arrivals, hand sanitizers in immigration desks, flights announcing passengers with flu symptoms to get checked,” said Dr Ramesh, deputy director of public health.TNN

Title: Decision to cancel board exam a relief, but could have come earlier: Teachers
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Trichy: Though the state government’s decision to cancel the board examinations it announced for class V and VIII gave a sense of relief for city school teachers, they say the decision could have come earlier rather than at the eleventh hour. With only a month left for the scheduled date of board examination, teachers were engaged in preparatory work apart from training the students for it.

Trichy district chief education officer S Santhi had a meeting on Saturday with teachers on conducting the board examination. A detailed discussion on teachers going to other schools for invigilation and evaluation of answer scripts took place. However, suddenly the examination has been cancelled.

“We don’t regret the preparation for board examination but the preparatory work on conducting the examination had much of our time wasted which could have been avoided had the announcement come a bit early,” said the principal of a government aided school. Most schools say they were prepared for the board exam and were even confident of making the students pass. But when asked about the reason for opposing the exam, a city school teacher said the very idea of board exam was contentious.

There would not have been any issue if the state government had announced a common question paper across the state for class V and VIII. But the very idea of board exam will instil fear in tender minds in class V as they will have to go to other schools and write the exam in front of unknown invigilators. They may not be able to perform even if they know the answers, said the teacher. We suspected that the board exam for class V and VIII was a move to victimise teachers, said Arockiaraj, district secretary, Tamil Nadu Primary Teachers Federation (TNPTF).

“Initially the government said that board examination for class V and VIII was for namesake and there was nothing to worry. Later a government statement said the real idea of board exam for class V and VIII was to test the teachers and not children,” he said. There are many primary schools in the state operating with two teachers. Preparing children for the board examination was very difficult with such less teachers, he said.

Title: Kochi woman’s 4 co-flyers from West Bengal test negative for coronavirus
Content:
Patients and staff of Infectious Diseases and Beliaghata General Hospital put on masks to ward off coronavirus... Read More

KOLKATA: Swab samples of the Kochi woman’s four co-flyers from West Bengal tested negative for novel coronavirus . While three were admitted to the isolation ward at the Infectious Diseases & Beliaghata General Hospital (IB&BG) — the state’s nodal hospital for coronavirus — another person from north Bengal was under home isolation. The three have been discharged from the hospital on Tuesday evening.“Till date we have given eight samples, out of which six, including the latest four, have tested negative. The results of two other samples are awaited,” said Ajay Chakraborty, director health services.Four more suspects turned up at ID&BG hospital on Tuesday, including one from Bhubaneswar. While three of them have been admitted to the hospital, the fourth person from Midnapore went back home. Swab samples of two undergoing treatment at the hospital have already been sent to NICED in Kolkata.“Three patients, the Kochi woman’s co-flyers, have been discharged on Tuesday. Currently, three other patients have been kept under observation,” said Ashish Manna, medical superintendent and vice principal, ID&GB Hospital.The three, who have been released from the hospital on Tuesday, had flown to the city on January 23 from Kunming with the Kochi woman, a medical student, the first to have tested positive for the virus in India.While swab samples of the three were tested in NICED, the sample of the suspect from north Bengal was sent to NIV Pune. Doctors, however, advised them home isolation for a few more days.A suspect from Odisha, who is currently in the isolation ward of the hospital, also travelled in the same flight. Another suspect from Hooghly, who came to the hospital on his own on Monday night, had returned from China a few weeks ago. A sailor, who reached the city in a vessel from Kochi on Tuesday, was brought to the ID Hospital after he was detected with fever with breathing distress.According to sources in the health department, a research scholar from Midnapore, who works in China, had returned to the city a few weeks ago. He turned up at ID Hospital voluntarily, where the emergency doctors found no immediate symptoms. But when the man insisted that his samples be tested, he was told that he had to be in the isolation ward to undergo the procedure. But he refused and returned to his home town.“We already have 25 isolation beds in two separate wards. We can increase beds, if the health department asks us to do so,” said Anima Haldar, principal ID&BG Hospital.

Title: Cash-strapped govt cut Rs 7,700 crore to 74 depts over past 3 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Panaji: Lack of funds and over estimation during the budget process left government departments facing a Rs 7,733.3 crore shortfall in their budgetary allocations for the last three years. Data released by chief minister Pramod Sawant indicates that the electricity department lost the largest quantum of allocation among all the other departments every year.

A total of Rs 1,136.8 crore could not be utilised by the power department because “estimates prepared were not materialised fully during the year, as some of the expenditure was deferred for next financial year”.

The information, provided to Saligao MLA Jayesh Salgaonkar, states that of the Rs 30,184.4 crore allocated to government departments in budget documents, over 20% of the budgetary allocation was not sanctioned due to “rationalisation of expenditure” a phrase used by the finance department when it runs short of funds.

It also clearly mentions that delay in financial approvals, austerity measures and non-execution of sanctioned works led departments to forego the funds.

TOI had reported on February 3 that the state faces a liquidity crisis and had quoted a government bureaucrat who said that “just 75% of the budget is spent. We are able to spend only 75% of the allocations”.

The power department missed out on Rs 478 crore, Rs 337.6 crore and Rs 290.5 crore in 2016-17, 2017-18 and 2018-19 respectively. Data for 2019-20 has not been compiled since the financial year is still on.

For the health department, “economic measures” and rejection of bills by the accounts departments led to Rs 550 crore being unutilised. The department also surrendered funds that were sanctioned to pay salaries for new recruits as the recruitment process was stalled.

At a time when local self-governing bodies have been crying for funds, the department of municipal administration and panchayats found themselves denied of Rs 851.3 crore and Rs 279.2 crore over the last three financial years. Documents tabled in the assembly attribute the reason to “economy measures”.

Several departments could not utilise the funds allocated to them as not enough beneficiaries came forward to avail of schemes. The departments of sports, industries, handicrafts, vigilance and many others found no takers for sanctioned funds.

Title: Child rights panel trains teachers to detect & prevent exam stress in students
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhopal: In an attempt to reduce exam stress and rate of exam-related suicides, the Madhya Pradesh Commission for Protection of Child Rights — in collaboration with the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights — on Monday organised a ‘Pareeksha Parv’ at the Regional Institute of Education. In the programme, counsellors and experts trained the teachers to detect signs of stress among children and help them deal with it in a healthy way.

Master trainers, who undergo training in Bhopal, will pass on the tips to school teachers of their own districts to implement the programme at the grassroots level. District Institute of Education and Training (DIET) principals of all districts, block-level officers and principal of Jabalpur CTC institute were present at the event.

Psychologist Dr. Vinay Mishra asked the teachers, “Do you, as a teacher, recognize students with symptoms of stress during examination? What do you do to boost the morale of students before an exam? Do you know how to treat depressed students and what not to do?” He explained to them what they can do to keep children away from stress. Counsellors Bhavana Sharma and Ankush Verma were also a part of the event.

The programme’s main objective was to mentally prepare the teachers so that they could identify and help the stressed students.

The programme was inaugurated by the chairman of NCPCR, Priyank Kanungo.

“The idea is to celebrate exams instead of fearing them. Students need to be told that marks — good, bad, average — are not the end of life and that there are several opportunities that they will get in life. The suicide rate due to exam stress and scoring low marks is increasing in the state, as well as the country. So it is important to counsel parents not to put unnecessary burden on students,” he said.

Member of MPCPCR, Brajesh Chouhan, said that this program has been designed keeping in view the incidents of suicide during examinations in children in the past years.

“It is important that teachers understand that unnecessary pressure will only stress children out and lead them to take drastic steps. Along with students, parents also need counselling,” said Chouhan.

Dr Mishra advised teachers and parents to refrain from using words like ‘loser’, ‘dumb’, etc and not discourage the students if they are not academically strong.

“Telling children that they will not succeed in life or will not be able to do anything worthwhile will only harm their self-image and they may go into depression. Just exam and studies don’t necessarily build pressure, the attitude of the teachers and parents towards students is a major factor. It is important to tell them that stress can actually make them do better as they will work harder and strive to do better,” he explained.

The three counsellors together talked about ten steps to make exams a success. These included self-confidence, small goals, moving forward, diet management, sound sleep, memory tricks, revision, managing emotions, yoga exercises and sports, resource management and stress management.

The counsellors also prepared a questionnaire for both parents and teachers so that they can understand how to treat a child.

Title: Now, Bharathidasan University pushes for bicycle use among its faculty too
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Around 300 odd such unused bicycles had been abandoned and getting rusted in the university

TRICHY: After BDU cycle, a free bicycle lending service on the main campus of Bharathidasan University at Palakalaiperur, became a hit among students , the university administration is keen on making the faculty members use the facility. There are two bicycle docking stations set up on the campus with 78 bicycles, and the university is planning to add around 100 more bicycles to the fleet in a week for the faculty members to use it.

These bicycles were abandoned by outgoing students after use during their stay in the university. Around 300 odd such unused bicycles had been abandoned and getting rusted in the university. The university administration has refurbished them and offered it to the university staff and students to use it on the campus free of cost.

We wanted to make use of the ‘scrap’ in an eco-friendly manner and bring down the number of motor-vehicles on the campus, said BDU registrar G Gopinath while speaking to TOI. “We are glad that students are effectively making use of it. But it has not picked up well among faculty members. One reason is that students take them to hostels and not return them to the docking stations. We have now decided to induct more bicycles as 100 of them are ready after refurbishing, so that more people could make use of the bicycles,” he said.

Cycling isn’t a status symbol if we see it from sociological perspective of a university teacher. That is largely the reason why most teachers could not make use of it, said Yenda Srinivasa Rao , head, history department, BDU.

As the in-charge of BDU cycle program, Rao has been trying to change the mindset and promote the habit of cycling through his ‘weekend cycling group.’ Residing within the campus, a 30-member group has been taking part in the weekly cycle expedition with Srinivasa Rao. The idea is to make more teachers make use of it, he said. There are two docking station on the campus, one near the entrance and another one near the library. As the university spreads across 700 acres, bicycle facility provides a non-motorised and eco-friendly option for people to commute on the campus.

Title: Mom moves HC to abort pregnancy of disabled girl
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: The dean of government Sivaganga Medical College has been directed by the Madras high court to constitute a committee of medical experts and submit a report with regard to the pregnancy termination of a 23-year-old disabled woman who was sexually assaulted in Sivaganga district.

In her petition, the woman’s mother, residing in Sivaganga district, stated that she has two daughters. While her elder daughter is married and living with her husband, she is residing at her house with her 23-year-old differently abled younger daughter.

On January 23, her elder daughter came to her house and noticed some abnormality in he sister’s body. When she took her younger daughter to the Sivaganga government hospital for a check-up the next day, the doctors after examining her informed that her daughter was 12 weeks pregnant.

On inquiry, she learnt that a person named Kasi, who was their neighbour had allegedly sexually assaulted her daughter. The woman said she used to go out to take the goats for grazing and return home in the evening. She stated that Kasi had taken advantage of the situation and sexually assaulted her daughter when she was alone at the house.

Based on a complaint, police had registered a case, and arrested Kasi and remanded him in judicial custody.

Since her daughter was not in a condition to deliver a child, she moved the high court Madurai bench seeking for a direction to terminate the pregnancy.

When the petition was heard on Tuesday, justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana gave the direction to the dean.

The court adjourned the case to a further date.

Title: Village secretariat inspected
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Tirupati: Collector Narayana Bharath Gupta paid a surprise visit to village secretariat at Velkur in Chittoor on Tuesday. He interacted with beneficiaries about the distribution of pension at doorsteps.

“The state government has introduced the distribution of social security pension at doorstep. We have been monitoring the programme.”

“A re-verification procedure is going on for the distribution of pensions to eligible beneficiaries,” said the collector Narayana Bharath Gupta. tnn

Title: Missing files a matter of concern, must hold babus responsible: CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Goa CM Pramod Sawant

PORVORIM: Chief Minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday said that files going missing was a matter of concern, and that probes should be conducted and officials concerned held accountable. He was responding to an accusation by former deputy CM Vijai Sardesai that the agriculture minister may be responsible for two files pertaining to community farming going missing from the department.

On November 3, 2019, TOI published a frontpage lead report on how files pertaining to the investment promotion board went missing from the chief minister’s office.

“Files from any department should not be lost,” CM said. “It is important to track the inward and outward movement of files. Those who are in charge should be held accountable.”

Sardesai said that around 13,408 hectares of land was lying fallow in the state.

“If the government wanted to make use of this land, the only alternative was community farming, he said.

“This government may be allergic to me, but they should not be allergic to the scheme,” said Sardesai, a former agriculture minister. He said he doesn’t suspect officials of the agriculture department involved in the files going missing, but pointed a finger at the agriculture minister.

Pointing to agriculture minister Chandrakant Kavalekar, Sardesai said, “I think on your instruction, the file has disappeared.” Kavalekar admitted that the files were missing, and said the ‘disappearing act’ happened when the former agriculture minister was sacked.

“I am not going to benefit in any way by taking the file,” Kavalekar said. “As soon as the former agriculture minister left, the file went missing. Where it went or where it got stuck is a mystery. We tried to trace the files and now we have also taken steps to recreate the files.”

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: Aerobridge assigned for China passengers
Content:
Passengers wearing masks arrive at Chennai airport

CHENNAI: An exclusive aerobridge will be linked to flights that carry passengers from China and seven other countries affected by novel coronavirus. All passengers will be screened in an isolated area before they are sent home for the 28-day mandatory quarantine. Those who show flu-like symptoms such as cold, fever or respiratory distress will be taken to the nearest tertiary care centre for quarantine.Meanwhile, police said a 45-year-old man was admitted to Kilpauk Medical College and Hospital with symptoms of coronavirus late on Tuesday. He had travelled to China between January 14 and January 22. He was referred to the hospital after he complained of cold and fever to doctors at Tambaram PHC.Earlier in the day, health minister C Vijayabaskar said there were no confirmed cases of novel coronavirus in the state. “We know we won’t be able to stop people from travelling to the country, but we are doing all we can to stop the virus from spreading. There is no positive case in the state so far,” he said at a press conference. “We advise people not to travel to affected country or state,” he said.In the last two days, the number of passengers coming into India from China has come down, he said. In the last 24 hours, 75 passengers from China landed in the state taking the total number to 1,125, he said. “Since the virus is imported, we quarantine those from affected countries. The incubation period for the virus is two weeks, but we quarantine passengers for at least twice as long so that we are sure they don’t have the virus. This will prevent its spread to people with no travel history,” he said. The names, contact details and addresses of passengers have been shared with the home department as a ‘preventive measure’, he said.On Tuesday, four samples of a family of Chinese passengers quarantined in a government hospital in Coimbatore sent to NIV in Pune tested negative. Eight Chinese citizens admitted to Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital who tested negative were discharged. Five other samples sent to King Institute of Preventive Medicine in Guindy also tested negative and results of three samples are pending, he said. If tests are positive, patients will be moved to quarantine wards of the nearest government hospital by ‘108’ ambulances, he said. The health department has set aside nearly 288 beds across state-run facilities. Health inspectors and nurses visit the houses of people who are on home quarantine to lift samples and screen them every day. Staff from ‘108’ also make calls to ensure they get necessary information.Information about the virus has been shared with civic bodies, education and police departments. “Civic bodies have been asked to disinfect public places, police have been asked to alert their personnel so that they can use protective gear and prevent reuse of disposables in breathalysers. Education department will promote hand hygiene,” he said.

Title: Plea to give funds to two HSS schools
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has ordered notice to the central and state governments on a plea which urged the central government to release funds for the two Harijan Sevak Sangh (HSS) schools functioning in the state.

In his petition, S Muthuselvam, a law student from Madurai, stated that the HSS was founded by Mahatma Gandhi in 1932 with an objective to eradicate the prevalence of untouchability and for the upliftment of scheduled caste and downtrodden people. He stated that he came across a news item published in ‘The Times of India’ dated October 5, 2019 which mentioned that the Union social justice and empowerment ministry has not released funds for HSS for the past three financial years. There are two HSS schools in the state- N M R Subbaraman memorial residential primary school in Madurai, established in 1979 and a residential middle school at Thirukoilur in Villupuram district (presently Kallakurichi district), established in 1993.

He stated that an RTI information revealed that funds were not released for these schools since 2016-17. Since funds were not released to these schools, they are functioning with great difficulty. He added that if funds are not released these schools may shut down.

Since Right to Education (RTE) is a fundamental right guaranteed under the Constitution, the ministry is duty-bound to release funds every year for the effective functioning of these schools. Though he sent a representation to the authorities concerned, no steps were taken so far. Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to release funds for both these schools. TNN

Title: 2 men arrested for throwing stones at private bus
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police arrested two men on Tuesday for throwing stones at a private bus on Avinashi Road.

The arrested people were identified as Venkatesh, 21 and Hari Pranesh, 21, both hailing from Kangeyam in Tirupur district. “Both of them are engineering graduates engaged in garment exports. Pranesh was planning to visit Mumbai for business and came to Coimbatore city along with his friend Venkatesh on Monday evening to catch a flight. Both of them consumed liquor in a bar before heading towards the airport on a motorcycle. When they were crossing the LIC traffic signal on Avinashi Road, they threw stones at a bus and fled from the place,” a police officer said.

The rear glass of the bus was damaged and the driver alerted police.

The Race Course police registered a case against the duo and arrested them on Tuesday evening. They were remanded in judicial custody and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Presidency University’s vice-chancellor returns after leaving campus
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Presidency University

KOLKATA: Presidency University ’s vice-chancellor Anuradha Lohia left the campus early on Tuesday morning after being confined to her chamber for over 16 hours by agitating students .

Though Lohia returned to office by 11.30am, she didn’t leave the campus till last reports came in. Students, though, said the VC was not under gherao.

A senior official of the varsity said the students did not stop Lohia when she was leaving. She was back in her office by 11.30am and attended meetings till late in the evening.

Boarders of Eden Hindu Hostel , along with other students of the varsity, started protesting against the delay in completion of the three blocks of hostel, despite assurances by authorities concerned. On Monday afternoon, the VC along with other officials, got stuck on the campus as the students had gheraoed her office.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Pregnant woman found with throat slit, hubby held
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A 23-year-old pregnant woman was found dead with her throat slit in unexplained circumstances at her house near Musiri. Police arrested her 33-year-old husband in this connection. The deceased, K Jeevitha, a native of Pullambadi, had got married to S Kamalkanth, an engineering graduate, on June 6.

Kamalnath was employed in Kuala Lumpur till his marriage, but after that he did not return for work and instead idled at home. This led to frequent sparring between the couple especially in the last few months. Police said neighbours saw Kamalkanth coming out of his house with blood oozing out of his hands on Tuesday morning. Subsequently, he was rushed to Musiri government hospital for treatment. By then, Jeevitha was found dead on her bed inside their house with her throat slit. She was pregnant for three months.

Musiri police arrived at the spot and conducted an inquiry. Based on statements from neighbours, police took Kamalkanth to the police station from the hospital and interrogated him. Preliminary investigations revealed that it was a quarrel between the couple over Kamalnath taking up a job in Kuala Lumpur that ended in the murder. Police said he is being further interrogated.

Title: Meghalaya banana farmers get training in value-addition
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A five-day entrepreneurship training programme focussing on cultivation, production and marketing of value-added products from green unripe and ripe bananas for wealth generation from waste and doubling the farmers’ income was organized for a group of farmers and entrepreneurs from Meghalaya by the National Research Centre for Banana ( NRCB ), Trichy on Tuesday.

Fifteen farmers and entrepreneurs took part in the hands-on training programme on ‘Value addition and Marketing of banana’. The participants were educated on the importance of getting licence from the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) for food safety measures.

In her presidential address, Dr S Uma, director of NRCB appreciated the trainees for evincing keen interest in selecting banana value addition as their business option for their development, as banana is an important commercial crop for the livelihood of north-eastern states.

Course coordinators V Kumar, K N Shiva, and P Suresh Kumar, said the entrepreneurs learnt a new skills in cultivation, value addition and marketing of more than 30 different value-added products such as banana fig, jam, RTS fruit juice, sweet chutney from ripened fruits; chips, sauce, flour, baby food, health drink, soup mix and bakery products from unripe fruits; pickle (thokku) from flowers and candy from central core stem and fibre from pseudostem sheath.

Fairborn Gathphoh, business development officer, Meghalaya Basin Development Authority [MBDA], Shillong, Meghalaya thanked the centre for hosting the programme for the benefit of the farming community, entrepreneurs and officials of Meghalaya.

Title: Rice smuggling comes down as authorities flex muscle
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

250 vehicles seized by the district supply office (DSO) last year, have not been released to the owners

COIMBATORE: Gone are the days when authorities would release the vehicles, used for smuggling rice distributed to the poor under public distribution system (PDS), after levying a small fine.

Taking a firm stand to curtail rice smuggling to neighbouring Kerala, as many as 250 such vehicles seized by the district supply office (DSO) last year, have not been released to the owners.

“We followed the directions of collector K Rajamani and decided not to release the vehicles. As it turns out, PDS rice smuggling has come down by 40%,” said a district administration official.

The smugglers mostly used lorries and two-wheelers. “Earlier, they would pay a penalty and get back the seized vehicles to go on with their business. Now that the vehicles are not released, some of them have stopped smuggling,” the official told TOI.

The smugglers source rice from Madurai and Tirupur. “As there about 40 routes connecting Coimbatore with Palakkad, rice is smuggled through the city,” he added.

The office of DSO is keeping 678 vehicles seized for smuggling rice over the years. It has sought permission from the Tamil Nadu civil supplies department to auction 170 of them.

Last month alone, DSO officials had seized three vehicles and recovered 16,835 kilograms of rice from smugglers.

Title: Row over Cong leader’s remarks on RSS, Bhagwat
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhopal: Congress and BJP were embroiled in a war of words after the ruling party’s minister Govind Singh on Tuesday attacked the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), the BJP’s ideological parent.

On Tuesday, minister for cooperatives Govind Singh targeted the RSS and its chief Mohan Bhagwat .

Speaking to reporters, Govind Singh, who is one of the senior-most cabinet ministers in the Kamal Nath government, said that RSS is not a non-political organization like it claims. He claimed RSS works like a political party and Dr Mohan Bhagwat “should remove his mask” and take charge of the BJP.

“RSS wants to push the country into the fire of communalism while BJP functions like Hitler’s dictatorship,” Govind Singh said.

“For 50 years, RSS has been saying that it is not a political organization. But when Mohan Bhagwat can decide on the chief minister and appointment of Governor, then it is clear that RSS is a political party.”

The minister also alleged that RSS offices have become lavish after the BJP has come to power. “I want to ask Sangh leaders that after BJP formed government, how did RSS get so much money to have air-conditioned offices,” Govind Singh said. “And camps are being held everywhere. RSS needs to explain.”

Responding to Govind Singh’s remarks, the BJP on Tuesday said that RSS is a non-political organisation and that Congress leaders are making controversial statements on the RSS to make the party high command happy.

“Congress leaders have no status to speak on RSS and Sarsanghchalak ji (Mohan Bhagwat). Sangh is dedicated in the work of nation-building, society and individual. RSS is not a political organisation. In what capacity, Congress leaders are making comments on the organisation?” said BJP MLA Vishwas Sarang.

A day earlier, senior Congress leader Manak Agrawal had also hit out at the RSS chief saying, “Wherever RSS chief goes, he instigates communal riots. The state administration and police should be alert.”

The BJP said Congress leaders were raking up controversies to create headlines. “The Congress leaders are making statements against RSS chief to please their party high command and remain in the headlines,” said Sarang.

Title: Coronavirus in Coimbatore: Public areas lack soap for handwashing
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: At a time when medical experts are recommending frequent hand washing with soap and water to reduce risk of infection from the deadly coronavirus (2019-nCoV), most of the public spaces including bus stands, railway stations, public toilets and government-run educational institutions here lack soaps.“Hand washing is one of the important things that need to be followed to prevent the spread of bacteria and virus. But hardly anyone pays attention to it. Even teachers who educate students about the importance of washing hands, lack proper awareness about it. That’s why most of the government schools don’t have soaps at hand wash stations,” said MA Aparna, trustee of Arc Foundation, which is promoting hand washing among school students.“School authorities say that they do not provide soap to students as they play with it and might injure themselves during the play. But, they are children. It is the teachers, who should explain about the importance of hand washing and inculcate discipline,” Aparna told TOI.The school education department had directed government schools to spend 10% of the school grant to maintain cleanliness and hygiene. The initiative is a part of the Swachh Bharat mission.Senior specialist in Tamil Nadu Urban Sanitation Support Programme (TNUSSP) Niladri Chakraborty said that only sophisticated places like airports, shopping malls and restaurants have soap dispensers at wash areas. “Other public places lack soaps. It is mainly due to two reasons – lack of awareness and additional expenses,” he said.Explaining the need to bring in a behavioural change, the official said that public would start washing hands out of habit if they have access to soap and water at all the places. “But making it a habit is a tough task.”Most of the public toilets do not have separate hand washing stations, said D Jayakandhan of Clean Toilet. “Bacteria can spread from one place to another by mere touch,” he said.The situation is same in educational institutions, Jayakandhan said. “Hand washing techniques are being taught to students in over 70% of schools. But it could not be made a habit due to lack of sustainability and negligence,” he added.Officials of the school education department said that they conducted several sessions to teach hand washing technique to students and also displayed the steps on the walls of washing stations to create awareness.Pointing out that 10% of the school grant would be used to maintain hygiene, an official said that school managements have been purchasing soaps using the fund.

Title: HC seeks status report on enumeration of waterbodies
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the district collectors of four southern districts to submit a status report with regard to the enumeration of waterbodies and digitalization of the records. The court also sought a report with regard to the prevention of release of drainage water inside Vaigai river stretch.

When a batch of petitions regarding the restoration of waterbodies in southern districts were taken up for hearing on Monday, a senior counsel who was appointed as amicus curiae by the court, after an inspection on January 25, submitted that drainage water from bathrooms and toilets on the northern banks of Vaigai river in Madurai was let out into the river, thereby polluting it.

R Murali, standing counsel of Madurai Corporation submitted that the government had accepted the recommendations of the corporation to develop the sewage system on the northern banks of the river under the Smart City Mission. He further submitted that it would bring a permanent solution to this problem.

Taking cognizance of the submissions, a division bench of justices T Raja and B Pugalendhi questioned if similar steps are taken by other districts administrations to prevent pollution in the river. Hence, the judges directed the revenue divisional officers of Theni, Dindigul, Sivaganga, Ramanathapuram districts to carryout inspections to take remedial steps to prevent the flow of drainage water inside Vaigai river from Theni to Ramanathapuram districts. The judges further observed that while taking such remedial measures, the officials should also ensure that no other waterbodies are subjected to pollution with drainage water. The judges sought a report in this regard on February 11.

The judges also observed that the special government pleader V R Shanmuganathan brought to their notice that the Vaigai river was heavily contaminated following the release of drainage water from Panthalkudi channel. The standing counsel of the corporation informed the court that works have commenced for installation of modular sewage plant in Panthalkudi channel to prevent the flow of drainage water into the river. The judges observed that the amicus curiae told them about the status report filed by Madurai district collector where chief secretary had given several instructions including to digitize the entire records of waterbodies after removal of encroachments. The judges cited that he also requested the court to call for a report from the district administrations in this regard. Taking cognizance of the reports submitted by Madurai, Sivaganga and Theni collectors, the judges directed the collectors of Ramanathapuram, Dindigul, Virudhunagar and Tirunelveli districts to file a status report on February 11.

Title: Kolkata Rain: Chill persists, Met predicts Friday rain
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

While the mercury is likely to rise on Wednesday owing to an approaching cyclonic circulation that could lead ... Read More

KOLKATA: The Met office said there were yet no signs of winter bowing out of Kolkata, which experienced yet another chilly day in February , with the minimum temperature touching 12.3 degrees Celsius on Tuesday.

Not often had Kolkata experienced sub-15 degree temperature in February, said Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC) director G K Das. “It doesn’t happen very often but winter is not over till February 15. This season, we have had frequent western disturbances that led to rain , paving the way for the chilly northwesterly to blow in. This has kept the temperature low for a considerable period,” he said.

While the mercury is likely to rise on Wednesday owing to an approaching cyclonic circulation that could lead to rain on Friday , the minimum temperature is predicted to slide once the system blew away by Saturday. “With the moisture sucked out by rain, the northwesterly will return, bringing the chill back. This has been the pattern this season and it will continue till at least early next week,” said Das.

A cyclonic circulation over Madhya Pradesh is set to form and lead to rain across south Bengal on Friday. It could trigger moderate rain in the western districts of Bengal but the intensity in Kolkata is not clear. “We expect thundershowers similar to pre-monsoon spells. But the system is yet to form and so, it’s too early to predict the impact on the city weather. But showers are likely on Friday,” added Das.

Since 2013, last month was the wettest January in Kolkata, which received 42.5 mm rain. The previous two Januaries saw zero rainfall. In 2012, Kolkata received 94.4mm rainfall, highest for the month in the past one decade. The following year, the count was 12.2 mm but after that, it was never more than 3.2mm in January. “It was unexpected as this has been a very cold and severe winter across north and east India. Cloud cover and rain tend to pull the temperature up but we had short spells of shower repeatedly in January. So, the periods of high temperature were short,” said a weather scientist.

Title: Uzhavar Sandhai: Where traders have a field day
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

On Monday, 20 traders from Ooty were not allowed inside the market by the agriculture officer in charge of Uzh... Read More
