All is not well with Uzhavar Sandhai (farmers’ market) at RS Puram in the city.

Instead of farmers from the district, some traders and vegetable sellers from other districts get space in the market using benami ID cards.

Though the agriculture marketing department has begun taking some measures to rein in on traders and farmers from other districts, it is time for the state government to revamp farmers’ markets.

On Monday, 20 traders from Ooty were not allowed inside the market by the agriculture officer in charge of Uzhavar Sandhai, Kannan. A woman trader lost Rs 10,000 worth of business. However, the traders accuse officials of accepting bribery to set up stalls on the pavements outside Uzhavar Sandhai. Collector K Rajamani refused to support them for the simple reason that all 20 of them were traders and not farmers.

Farmers at R S Puram Uzhavar Sandhai concur with the collector. “The Nilgiris farmers who were thrown out on Monday, are not farmers but traders,” said P Thanamani, a farmer from Alandurai, who sells tomatoes. “They buy vegetables from Mettupalayam market and sell it here. They even live in the city and we have seen agents from Mettupalayam come and deliver vegetables to them,” he said. “Some of their ID cards are not even theirs but of their parents, aunt’s, uncles’ and even a benami,” a farmer from Annur said.

But why and how are these ‘traders’ from the Nilgiris are allowed inside Uzhavar Sandhai.

TOI on Tuesday found at least six shops run by people “who don’t farm” but belong to “self-help groups”. “We work for the farmers’ cooperative or self-help group, bring vegetables from their godown, sell it and hand over the revenue earned. In the month end, we get a salary. So, it is still farmers selling it but through employed people like us,” said JD Joseph, a seller from Annur. The agriculture officer in the market also admits that 15 of the 170 shops are allotted to self-help groups.

A few of the remaining farmers too admit that sometimes when their farm vegetables sell out and the next cycle is too young to harvest, they do buy vegetables from neighbouring farms and sell them at the market, which amounts to trading. The market also limits vegetables that can be sold by self-help groups and some farmers. “We genuine farmers have no such restrictions,” Balakrishnan, a farmer from Karamadai who cultivates almost six different crops, said.

Bribery too used to take place in the market, farmers said. “These benami card holders used to pay bribes, some offered bribes to bring more vegetables than they can and even for daily shop allotment. But it doesn’t happen anymore,” a farmer said.

To start filtering traders, the Uzhavar Sandhai last year issued new updated cards. “The cards were issued after verifying our agriculture land ownership or lease documents and verifying the vegetables that we grow,” a farmer from Karamadai, Kannan Rangarajan , said. Though many of the Nilgiris traders did not manage to get new identity cards, they were trading inside till last week.

The district collector said he has ordered the newly appointed deputy director of agricultural marketing service to do an audit of all the four Uzhavar Sandhai in the district and submit a report in a fortnight.

“Once I get the report, I will come up with ways to clean up the system entirely. But preference will always be given to farmers from the district,” he said.

State secretary of Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam P Kandasamy said many traders have begun entering Uzhavar Sandhai in the past few years.

“Soon farmers began staying away. This will improve only if the agriculture officer in charge knows the situation in farmers lands and is pro-farmer. It is they who have to ensure farmers are given preference over traders,” he said.

Title: No effective hygiene practice in place in schools, public places
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Trichy: Frequent washing of hands is said to be a basic protective measure against the spread of novel coronavirus (nCoV). But a random check has revealed that city schools are yet to take it seriously. Same is the case with other places of mass gathering, be it bus stands or railway stations in the city.

Going by the nature of nCoV, the possibility of the disease spread is high in crowded places. But the authorities concerned are yet to wake up to the reality, which demands effective steps to create awareness on the disease. The only relief is the fact that there have not been any positive cases of nCoV reported in the state so far.

Washing hands using alcohol-based hand sanitizers or soaps is found to be effective in curbing nCoV, but only a very few government schools in the city have hand wash in lavatories. The practice is equally poor among other schools. The state government too is yet to issue any specific directive to schools on taking preventive measures .

“The habit of washing hands using water has been encouraged among students, but unavailability of soaps or other hand wash is a matter of concern,” said an employee of a government school. Children are taught to wash their hands, while coming out of lavatories or playground. But on most occasion, they do it with just water, which may not be effective against nCoV,” said the staff.

A teacher from a middle school having more than 300 children in Manapparai said that non-availability of water in lavatories too is a discouraging fact. Another school teacher said that they ask students to wash their hands, but not many are using soaps that are kept in the toilets. There is a need for further inculcate such habits that indeed lack in government schools. Meanwhile, lack of facilities for safe hand wash continues at the Central bus stand in Trichy. Urinals for men near Thanjavur bus bay lacks basic infrastructure including a washbasin and a dedicated tap for the users to wash their hands. People often spend some money to purchase bottled water for cleaning their hands. Soap is still an ‘expensive’ facility as water itself remains a luxury in the bus stands.

Title: Death of girl: Ex-MLA seeks judge’s intervention
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

MADURAI: Former Dindigul MLA K Balabarathi has petitioned district Mahila court judge seeking intervention in a case pertaining to the sexual assault and death of a nine-year-old girl, near Vedasandur in Dindigul district .

Submitting the petition, Balabarathi alleged that real culprits are still at large, stating that they would take the issue to court to get the victim justice. The petition was handed over to judge S Purushothaman on Monday in the presence of members from AIDWA.

The girl died after falling from a tractor driven by a 16-year-old boy in a village near Koombur near Vedasandur on Sunday. Postmortem examination conducted on Monday revealed that she was sexually abused before she died. Koombur police registered a case under sections of Pocso against the minor boy and against Umasekar, owner of the tractor, for allowing minor to drive tractor. While the family members of the victim staged a protest on Monday claiming that minor boy was implicated to save real culprits, members of AIDWA too staged a protest.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Indian carriers suspend flights to Hong Kong
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Indian carriers have now cancelled all their flights to China in wake of the coronavirus epidemic. Air India Delhi-Hong Kong, the only remaining flight by an Indian carrier between the two countries, is being suspended from February 8 to March 28, 2020.

On Tuesday, AI tweeted it is “suspending its operations to Hong Kong in view of the coronavirus situation after flying AI-314 on Feb 7 from Delhi to Hong Kong and AI-315 from Hong Kong to Delhi on Feb 8.” With this announcement, all flights by Indian carriers to China will be suspended after Friday. AI had earlier suspended its six-times-weekly Mumbai-Delhi-Shanghai flight from January 31. The frequency of Air India’s daily Delhi-Hong Kong was reduced to thrice-weekly from January 31 and has now been suspended till March 28. IndiGo, the only other Indian carrier that flies to China, has suspended all its three daily flights to the country — Delhi-Chengdu, Bengaluru-Hong Kong and Kolkata-Guangzhou.

Among Chinese carriers, Shandong Airlines and Air China have suspended their flights to India.

In a statement, Cathay Pacific said: “As of now, all Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon flights out of India are operating as per schedule. From India, we operate 49 direct flights to Hong Kong per week. Cathay Pacific flies out of four (places) — Delhi, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Chennai. Cathay Dragon flies out of Bangalore and Kolkata.”

Title: Pune farmer on organ donation bike yatra spanning 17,500 km
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pramod Mahajan

MADURAI: Pramod Mahajan, a 68-year-old farmer from Sangli village near Pune, is on his second pan-India ride on his bike to create awareness on the importance of organ donation . The father of four who had donated one of his kidneys to an ex-serviceman, a total stranger, 19 years ago says he is committed to removing inhibitions from the minds of prospective donors.

During his first Bharat Organ Yatra in 2018, he covered 12,800 kms across 19 States in 100 days. “This time he is on Bharat Organ Yatra 2.0 that started from Pune on January 18. He will be covering 17,500 km in 25 states over 132 days,” said Rajesh Shetty, the president of ReBirth Foundation, an NGO spreading awareness on organ donation which is funding a major part of the yatra. The local riding clubs in all the 94 cities where he is visiting makes arrangement in hospitals and educational institutions for him to create awareness. Starting from Pune, he rode through Goa, Karnataka and Kerala before reaching Madurai through Thiruvananthapuram and Tirunelveli.

In Madurai, he was received by Freedom Riders Club. Mahajan, who is conversant only in Marathi and Hindi, addressed patients, parents and hospital staff at a private children’s hospital in the city where K Rajnesh Kumar of Freedom Riders helped him with the translation. He told the gathering that people have to overcome the fear and inhibitions that he also had before donating a kidney at the age of 49 years. “I am hale and hearty, still working in the fields and also riding a bike across the country at this age,” he said and pointed out the vast difference between availability of donors and recipients.

The rider said there are 10,000 people waiting for organs for every donor, resulting in deaths of 500 people a day due to want of organs. He claimed that 1.05 lakh people were declared brain dead in India in 2017 and that there were only 817 organ donations that year. On Tuesday he set off from Madurai to Coimbatore as part of his yatra which he intends to complete on May 28.

Title: Dindigul farmers urged to take up millet cultivation
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Dindigul: About 55,057 hectares in Dindigul is under millet cultivation which is more than the average millet cultivation area of 51,500 in the district, and farmers should explore the cultivation of these healthy varieties more, said district collector M Vijayalakshmi.

Speaking at a seminar on millet cultivation here on Tuesday, Vijayalakshmi said that millets were predominantly used in the traditional foods of Tamil Nadu in the past. But, in accordance with the changing food habits and industrial development, people moved away from these healthy foods. As a result, children and youth are affected by nutrition deficiencies. In order to revive millet cultivation, late chief minister J Jayalalithaa introduced schemes to promote cultivation under the National Food Security Scheme. Due to this, the sale of millets such as pearl millet, sorghum and ragi, had increased in recent times.

The government was taking many steps to encourage the cultivation of millets among farmers. They are being given a subsidy of Rs 6,000 for purchasing quality seeds, vermicompost and cultivation. When farmers use certified seeds they get a good yield.

A subsidy of Rs 30 is also given for purchasing seeds. Farmers should get the quality of their soil tested and use manure accordingly to enhance the fertility of the soil. When natural fertilizers are used it could go a long way in maintaining and sustaining the nature of the soil and they could also reap good harvests, she said and urged the farmers to use natural fertilizers, instead of chemical ones.

Title: Times Half Marathon: Kolkata to make a dash for clean air on Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Around 3,000 people from across the country are expected to converge on Red Road, where the event will be held... Read More

KOLKATA: The city is set to put on its running shoes as the inaugural edition of Times Half Marathon is flagged off around 6am on Sunday .

Track the pollution level in your city

Around 3,000 people from across the country are expected to converge on Red Road , where the event will be held around grand and famous landmarks of Kolkata.

With an aim to promote the importance of keeping the environment clean, participants can register in any of the three categories—Fun Run (3km), Timed Run (10km) and Apollo Gleneagles Run (21km). To run for a “breath of fresh air” seems apt as Kolkata only recently recorded an air quality index (AQI) of 343, which falls in the ‘very poor’ category, at the Fort William automated air monitoring station in Maidan, the city’s green lungs.

Among some of the prominent runners who will be part of the event are entrepreneur Sudhir Ahuja, fitness expert Anwar Wahhab, functional and rehabilitation of sports athlete Sumana Dutta, entrepreneur Gagan Sachdev, fitness enthusiast Abhishek Lodha, Kolkata airport’s general manager (ATC) R S Lahauria, fitness enthusiasts Swati Poddar and Monalisa De and marathoners Vernon Morais, Bharat Bagla and Harsha Banthia. Also present will be Rana Dasgupta, CEO of Apollo Gleneagles Hospitals, Amit Das, director (HR) and CHRO, Bennett Coleman & Co Ltd (Times Group), golfer Indrajit Bhalotia and actors Prasenjit Chatterjee and Ritabhari and actor-cum-MP Nusrat Jahan.

“Running is not just about physical endurance or fitness. It is a combination of physical, mental, emotional and spiritual wellbeing, which helps you become stronger and focused. I applaud every single participant, who are running, to create awareness about cleaner air for better and sustainable environment. All the participants need to support each other not to just reach the finishing line at this marathon, but also to continue this journey to save the environment,” said Das.

Monalisa De, who owns two cafes in Kolkata, plans to be at Maidan early on Sunday. “I have participated in multiple marathons over the past few years. I was awarded a silver medal for being a podium finisher in a marathon in 2018. Given the opportunity, I will give my best to make every event reach its zenith.”

Title: Thanjavur ready for Big Temple consecration
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The Brihadeeswarar Temple in Thanjavur is all set for the mega consecration ceremony on Wednesday

THANJAVUR: The Brihadeeswarar Temple (Big Temple) in Thanjavur is all set for the mega consecration ceremony on Wednesday, which is taking place after a gap of 23 years. The ceremony rituals will be conducted in both Tamil and Sanskrit, as the court has ordered to hold rituals and pujas in accordance with the agama principles and Tamil should be given due place by chanting Thirumurai. As per the court order, a team of Odhuvars will recite Thevaram, Thiruvasagam, Thirumurai and other hymns in Tamil during the consecration.

Tight security is in place with drone surveillance and over 5,500 police personnel pressed into service to maintain law and order and provide security to devotees. The event is being organised in coordination with multiple government departments including Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE), PWD, health department, police, tourism department, Thanjavur municipal corporation among others.

Commissioner of municipal administration K Baskaran visited the temple and examined drinking water, rest room, and other basic amenities provided by the municipal corporation. In view of the ceremony, food has been arranged at the Raja Raja Samaya Sanga marriage hall near the temple. He also examined the quality of food prepared at the mahal.

To avoid a repeat of the fire during the consecration in 1997 which claimed about 50 lives, fire and rescue services has been pressed into service to avert any such incidents, authorities said.

“Bursting of firecrackers has been banned during the ceremony. This was the reason for the fire that caught on the thatched pandal in 1997. This year, metal sheets have been used to erect pandal,” authorities said.

Apart from special trains, Southern Railway has opened two additional counters at the main entry booking office and one at the rear entry booking office have been opened.

Title: Court relief for Mumbai resident in dowry case
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court recently quashed and set aside an FIR registered against a woman from Mumbai who was booked by the Ahmednagar police along with other accused in a case involving dowry demand to the tune of Rs 10 lakh.

The 31-year-old woman had approached high court through lawyer DR Jaybhar seeking to quash and set aside the FIR registered against her based on a complaint lodged by her sister-in-law (25).

The complainant had alleged that her husband and other in-laws, including the petitioner, had sought Rs 10 lakh from her for repaying a loan amount. When she expressed her inability to pay the money, the in-laws would beat her and had driven her out of home in May 2017.

The FIR was lodged on November 16, 2018, on basis of which offences punishable under sections 34, 498-A, 323, 504, 506 of the Indian Penal Code were registered in Ahmednagar’s Kotwali police station.

While allowing the Mumbai resident’s criminal application, the bench observed: “On perusal of the FIR it is seen that the allegations against the applicant are vague and general in nature. No specific act is attributed to the applicant. An omnibus statement is that all the accused started demanding Rs 10 lakh for repayment of loan on failure of which she was subjected to ill-treatment. The applicant is the married sister of the husband of respondent no.2 (the complainant), a resident of Kedgaon in Ahmednagar district. The applicant is not the resident of Ahmednagar i.e. matrimonial place of the complainant. Even as per the chargesheet she is a resident of Mumbai.”

Title: West Bengal: IS operative throws shoe at lawyer during hearing
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mohammad Masiuddin

KOLKATA: Suspected jailed Islamic State operative Mohammad Masiuddin alias Musa — who was earlier questioned by FBI for his alleged links with the Islamic State (IS) — threw his shoe at a lawyer in the Bankshall court where his hearing was scheduled on Monday afternoon. The shoe hit the lawyer Soumyajit Chakraborty, who reportedly received injuries.

“Musa became violent in the open court. Before throwing the shoe, Musa began shouting. He also passed some objectionable remarks about the legal procedure,” said NIA ’s special public prosecutor Tamal Mukherjee.

Police said Musa, a resident of Birbhum’s Labhpur, tried to assault the lawyer once he entered the court room. “His behaviour is troublesome and hampers work at the court. We have requested the judge to ensure the safety of everyone in court,” said a lawyer.

The incident happened exactly a month after Musa had attacked the head warder of Presidency Jail and a little more than two years after he had slashed the throat of an Alipore Central jail’s warden.

The NIA sleuths, probing the case, want the trial be conducted through video conferencing as Musa has hinted that he would commit suicide. Earlier, the STF of Kolkata Police had recommended video-conference trial for him, along with American Centre attack mastermind Aftab Ansari.

Cops spoke to the legal cell and lawyers about how to beef up security at the court. Meanwhile, the security personnel at the central lock-up are taking no chance even after putting him in solitary confinement.

“He is being monitored every minute. The guards have been briefed accordingly,” sources said.

Title: 13 of two fake note gangs arrested by Task Force
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Hyderabad Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar displayed fake currency notes siezed from a gang of 9 men held in t... Read More

HYDERABAD: Task Force sleuths on Tuesday arrested 13 members of two fake currency circulation gangs from the city and seized Rs 17.7 lakh worth fake currency from their possession. Police also arrested a wanted fake currency circulation gang member from West Bengal.

In the first case, South Zone Task Force arrested BV Shiva Sandeep, Md Akbar Pasha, Mohammed Moin, Mohammed Raziuddin, a milk vendor from Hussainialam. They were arrested from a house in Asifnagar. Police seized Rs 8.5 lakh worth of fake currency in Rs 500 and Rs 2,000 denominations.

The gang members confessed that they had been scanning original currency notes and printing fake currency. “The accused had procured a colour printer, scanner and screen printing machine. They were circulating fake currency in the market at a 1:2 ratio,” Hyderabad commissioner Anjani Kumar said.

In another case, acting on specific information about some people circulating fake currency at Jagdeesh Market, North Zone Task Force laid a trap and caught three suspects in possession of fake currency on Tuesday. Based on the information given by them, police conducted a raid in Sangareddy and arrested six others.

The arretsed were identified as — Ishaq Bin Saleh, B Gowtham, Mohd Sohail Ali, Md Ghousiuddin, Abrar Khan, Syed Kashif Bahadur. Three juveniles were also arrested. Police seized Rs 9.27 lakh worth of fake currency in Rs 200, Rs 100 and Rs 500 denominations. “The accused have been circulating the fake currency in Sangareddy, Sadashivpet, Zaheerabad and Hyderabad at a 1:3 ratio,” police said.

South Zone sleuths have also arrested an inter-state fake currency supplier from West Bengal, Ameen Ul Rahman, who is wanted in eight cases registered in Hyderabad and Visakhapatnam since 2014.

Title: Doc forces husband to watch porn; he finds her sex video online
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bengaluru: A 32-year-old doctor who forced her techie-husband to watch porn with her and enact whatever they saw landed in trouble after he saw an online video of her having sex with another man and walked out on her.

The woman has now knocked on the doors of Parihar family counselling centre in the police commissioner’s office to save her marriage.

The woman, 32, from Kolkata and the man, 33, from Uttar Pradesh, met on a matrimonial portal, tied the knot in 2018 and began living in east Bengaluru.

She’d told him before marriage that she had a relationship with a man in the past but had later separated. All was well between the couple though she always forced her husband to watch porn videos and enact the scenes with her. He was not used to watching such videos but did so to fulfil her desire.

However, he was in for the shock of his life when he saw a video of her in a compromising position with a man on her mobile phone. She claimed he was her former boyfriend who used to blackmail her with the old video and she had saved it in case she needed to produce it in future. Though the husband was unhappy, he consoled her and asked her to move on.

However, in the third week of January, he found a porn video online featuring his wife and another man. When he confronted her, she confessed to having had many relationships before marriage but didn’t know how the video was available online.

Hurt, the man left her and began living separately. She later approached Parihar and alleged her husband was not living with her on her in-laws’ advice and was not taking care of her.

BS Saraswathi, senior counsellor at the centre, summoned him and brought the couple face to face. The man revealed his wife was addicted to watching porn videos and also forced him to do so. Also, he said he’d separated from her as he was upset that she hid details about her past.

“The man wants a divorce but the woman wants to save her marriage by forgetting whatever happened in the past. We are counselling the couple,” Saraswathi said.

———

Box: More such cases reported

Parihar counsellors said there’s an increase in cases of porn and social media addiction leading to marital disputes. Rani Shetty, coordinator of the centre, said recently they got a case of a man assaulting his wife to enact porn scenes he had seen online. “We had to inform police and later had to counsel the couple as they wanted to save their marriage. He would watch porn for two hours at least every day. His wife was pregnant but he forced her to do things that were unpalatable to her. She approached us and we eventually sent him to Nimhans to get treated for addiction,” Rani said.

Title: 65 gardens to get 4L plants via Miyawaki
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mumbai: The BMC has reduced its garden department budget to Rs 226 crore for the coming financial year from Rs 277 crore currently. Besides, it will give special emphasis to the municipal commissioner’s favourate subject—creation of urban forests through the Japanese Miyawaki method of tree plantation.

The BMC intends to plant four lakh plants through the Miyawaki method in the coming financial year in 65 municipal gardens.

Meanwhile, civic officials confessed in the budget book the BMC had granted permission to cut 25,000 trees over the past five years.

The BMC maintains more than 1,000 gardens and grounds in the city and requires Rs 100 crore annually for their maintenance. The remaining budgetary provision will be used to develop gardens and grounds and to plant trees. While explaining the cut in the department’s budget, an official said the BMC has decided to not construct boundary walls around parks to reduce development costs. Congress corporator Asif Zakari said, “By reducing funds for the department, the BMC is indicating it wants to give out the spaces to private entities.” — Vijay V Singh

Title: Seven more IAS officers given posts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Two days after the major reshuffle of IAS officers, the government has given posting to seven more on Tuesday. According to a government order (GO), Benhur Mahesh Dutt Ekka has been posted as additional director of Dr MCRHRD Institute while Ahmad Nadeem posted as secretary of minority welfare department.

Syed Ali Murtaza Rizvi was posted as officer on special duty at Telangana Bhavan, New Delhi and GS Panda Das has been made secretary of SC commission. Chief electoral officer Rajat Kumar, who has been posted as principal secretary of irrigation department, was given additional duties of relief and rehabilitation, land acquisition. Aisha Masrat Khanam, who was transferred from Vikarabad two days ago, was posted as deputy secretary of Panchayat Raj department while Ch Shivalinghaiahhas been posted as deputy secretary in agriculture department.

Title: Karnataka: Vegetable vendor’s daughter is VTU gold medallist
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Lalitha says her parents’ hard work inspired her to burn the midnight oil

BENGALURU: When Lalitha R walks up the stage to receive gold medals for securing highest marks in aeronautical engineering during the Visvesvaraya Technological University convocation on Saturday, her story of grit and dedication will inspire many. Lalitha, the daughter of a vegetable vendor-couple in Hiriyur of Chitradurga, will receive two medals at the event.

The student of East West College of Engineering (EWCE), Yelahanka comes from a very humble background. Her father has studied till class 1 and mother till class 5 and together they run a vegetable shop in the town. “They leave home at 4.30am every day to buy vegetables from farmers. The shop opens at 6am and they are there till 10pm. Seeing them work this hard motivates me to toil as much. After college, I get to studies by 5pm. I take a break later and then study at a stretch from 10pm to 3am,” said Lalitha.

Lalitha, 22, completed SSLC from Vagdevi School, Hiriyur with 94% and PU from SRS College, Chitradurga with 87%. After clearing CET (with a 20,000 rank), she joined EWCE under CET quota, for a fee of Rs 18,000 per annum. “I am a first-generation graduate in my family. So, I thought something like aeronautical engineering would be special for my parents. And it turned out to be new, exciting and interesting,” she added.

The small-town girl, who came to Bengaluru for the first time in 2015, took some time getting used to life in a metro. After getting selected at a National Skill Development programme, she is now interning with an aerospace company and hopes to get placed with the same firm.

The college waived Lalitha’s final year hostel fee. “We recognised her potential in academics and decided to waive the last year’s fee. We also gave her a separate room so that she could focus on studies. The credit also goes to the department, which is a relatively new branch, with lots of young faculty, who motivated her,” said Santosh Kumar G, principal, EWCE.

An elated Rajendra said he wanted to give his daughters the opportunity to study, something he missed out on. “First, I wanted my brother’s children to do well. But, they didn’t. I then started focusing on my kids. Lalitha has been a topper since childhood. Today, other vendors in my market are celebrating as if she is their daughter,” Rajendra told TOI from Hiriyur on Tuesday. Lalitha is a familiar face in the market as she often goes to the shop when she is visiting her hometown. Her two younger sisters are pursuing diploma in fashion designing and civil engineering.

“I want to do my MS in aerospace engineering and have applied for GATE. The biggest lesson life has taught me is that only hard work will take you somewhere,” said the youngster.

Title: Karnataka: Miner appointed to wildlife board; greens call it conflict of interest
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BENGALURU: The recent appointment of a mining company owner to the Karnataka State Wildlife Board has led to a controversy with questions being raised in wildlife circles about the conflict of interest involved.

The person in question is Dinesh Singhi, owner of Bharat Mines and Minerals, Ballari. A copy of the government notification dated January 18, 2020, accessed by TOI, shows Dinesh and three others were appointed non-government members of the board.

The three other fresh appointees are Naveen JS, Alok Vishwanath and Chethana B. They replaced four existing members and have been described as conservation experts, ecologists and environmentalists. The order issued by the department of forest, ecology and environment bears the signature of Gayathri L, undersecretary to the government.

“This is a clear case of conflict of interest as the person happens to be a mining company owner. The wildlife board reviews applications of developmental projects such as mining, highways and dams in or around tiger reserves, wildlife sanctuaries, national parks and other protected areas,” said an environmental activist on condition of anonymity.

Another activist involved in wildlife conservation said the appointment is a matter of concern at a time when a mining company is lobbying to denotify Kappatagudda Wildlife Sanctuary in North Karnataka.

Appointments to the state wildlife board have been controversial in the past too. In 2017, appointment of a mini-hydel firm owner, who was facing cases of forest offences, to the board had raised eyebrows. Environmentalists allege controversies arise due to political appointees.

Interestingly, the state wildlife board is chaired by the chief minister himself and has about 10 expert members, besides officials from forest and other departments.

While the CM’s office said it will look into the matter, repeated efforts to reach forest minister CC Patil, who is also vice-chairman of the board, went in vain. His personal staff are yet to get back on the issue.

Principal chief conservator of forests (wildlife) did not respond to calls and messages. A senior manager with Bharat Mines and Minerals also didn’t revert.

Title: MBA students delay entrepreneurship: want experience, pay off loans
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Due to the rising cost of education in premier management schools, the number of students opting out of placements to begin their own venture/pursue their passion has decreased over the years. For, the priority of a large majority is to land lucrative jobs to clear loans.

At Indian Institute of Management-Bangalore (IIMB), where final placements are due to begin on February 10, only two of a class of 440 students in the flagship MBA programme have opted out of placements this season. This is in contrast to around 16 students who had done so in 2011, when the batch size was 348. Only one student didn’t sit for placements in 2019, five in 2018 and 10 in 2017. In both 2016 and 2015, the number stood at five.

“Barring a handful, most students prefer to sit for placements and bag a high-paying job as soon as their studies are over. This is perhaps because most of them have the obligation to pay EMIs for student loans they would have taken. At the same time, those students who have a flair for entrepreneurship get to work with startups as a large number of them hire from the campus. The requirement for a well-paid job and the opportunity to work with startups make students sit for placements,” said Sapna Agarwal, head, career development services, IIMB.

Sapna said many students may get into entrepreneurship a few years after they graduate. However, the placement office does not keep a track of alumni activities. The current fee for the flagship MBA programme is Rs 21 lakh and will be increased to Rs 23 lakh in the next academic year as reported by TOI earlier.

Pursuing passion later

IIM-Kozhikode, which recently completed its final placements, had 3-4 students opting out of placements. “The number of students opting out of placements on our campus has always been below 10. But we see a large majority of students sitting for placements, thanks to the huge education loans they take. Many of them pursue their passion, entrepreneurship, after a few years of graduation,” said Shovan Chowdhury, chairperson, placements, IIM-Kozhikode.

Title: Court defers verdict on Abdul Karim Tunda to February 18
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

File photo of Lashkar-e-Taiba terror suspect Abdul Karim Tunda

HYDERABAD: The judgement against Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) terror suspect Abdul Karim Tunda in 1998 Saleem Junaid module, which was scheduled to be given on Tuesday, was deferred to February 18 by the Nampally court on Tuesday. Earlier, the court had fixed Tuesday for the judgement against Tunda, who is presently lodged in Ghaziabad jail. He is expected to be brought to Hyderabad on February 18.

SIT officials had arrested Tunda in October 2013, a few months after he was nabbed by central security agencies near the Indo-Nepal border. Tunda is accused of training youngsters to carry out terror activities in India. One of these youngsters was Pakistani national Saleem Junaid, who was nabbed in Hyderabad when he and few other members of the module were planning to carry out a terror strike during Ganesh festival in 1998.

Title: Kolkata: With beacon, ID card, ‘IB officer’ dupes job-seeker
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ochira Yadav has fitted her vehicle with a beacon and an IB board

KOLKATA: A 47-year-old woman was known to her neighbours as an “influential person with contacts in Delhi”. Everyone in her locality at Purbalok near Jadavpur stadium thought she was an Intelligence Bureau officer until cops from the East Jadavpur police station hauled her away on Monday for impersonating as a senior government officer and duping at least one job-seeker.

Ochira Yadav, who had faked her designation to near perfection by fitting her SUV with a blue beacon and a ‘Govt of India, Intelligence Bureau’ board on it, reportedly has a PhD from a top Delhi university. Her husband was a Customs officer and her father had retired as a senior forest official in Assam, police said, adding she shifted to her current address from Kasba in 2017. She spent years in Guwahati and Tinsukia in Assam.

According to joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma, they arrested Yadav after Satyabratu Basu Roy, a 23-year-old resident of Bansdroni, lodged a complaint at the East Jadavpur police station that Yadav promised him a government job in exchange for Rs 5 lakh. “She allegedly posed as a senior police officer. She travelled in an Innova Cresta, to which she had fitted a blue beacon and a plate, with ‘Govt Of India’, ‘Intelligence Bureau’ written on it. She even flashed a fake IB card,” he said. Suspicious over such an offer, when Basu Roy tried to carry out Yadav’s background check, he was allegedly threatened with dire consequences. Police claimed even after her arrest, the woman refused to admit to her fault. “She appears firm in her stand but we have to find out how many others were duped and who were involved,” police said.

Basu Roy’s complaint coincided with a recent alert from the state Intelligence Bureau. Around 10 days ago, when Yadav’s vehicle was stopped at check naka, the cops pulled her up for using the fake IB board on her vehicle and using a forged IB card. But at that time, she pleaded innocence and apparently promised the cops that she would remove all the official boards. She was let off but the IB alerted Kolkata Police about her activities, said a Lalbazar source.

“We have arrested the accused under sections sections 170, 171, 419, 420 and 506 of IPC and forwarded her to court. Yadav lived alone and struggled to make ends meet. She apparently bought the SUV soon after settling in Kolkata and it is registered in her name. The flat is also registered in her name. Her husband, Subodh Chandra Chowdhury, was a Customs officer,” an officer said.

Title: Habitat, climate limit range of Shola Sky Island birds
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Black-and-orange flycatchers are insectivorous birds

BENGALURU: Black-and-orange flycatchers , weighing about 10 grams each, are endemic to Shola Sky Islands , the highest reaches of Western Ghats. Their adaptation to climatic features specific to some parts of the Ghats have severely limited their range .

VV Robin, an evolutionary ecologist who has been studying birds on the sky islands of Western Ghats, said these bird species could be considered relict endemics. “The terminology refers to those species which may’ve in the past had a great range but reduced thereafter owing to climatic and geographical changes,” he explained.

Robin, who is also an assistant professor of biology in Indian Institute of Science Education and Research, Tirupati, was speaking at an international symposium on India’s biodiversity at the Indian Institute of Science on Monday.

“While birds are impacted across landscapes, a few species are isolated when compared to others. The common notion is that birds can fly, so it shouldn’t be a problem for them to spread across landscapes. But this is not so, specifically for these insectivorous birds. The Shola habitat does not permit a high diversity of species. But they do have a high proportion of endemism, which means the species are unique to a particular geographical location,” said Robin.

One of the most important barriers in the southern Western Ghats for the bird species is Palaghat gap (a low mountain pass between Coimbatore in Tamil Nadu and Palakkad in Kerala) as it is one of the deepest valleys in the region. Robin and his students’ study, which also looked into genetic data from the bird endemic to Shola Sky Islands, found the fragmentation of landscapes had severe impact on the species apart from their flying range.

“When we tested it on one bird species, we found the contemporary gene flow had reduced across human-modified landscapes,” Robin said. Their group studied bird songs and found that dialects of birds are different on different sky islands and even across deforested landscapes.

Title: Karnataka: Cop dies in accident, family donates eyes
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 44-year-old head constable who tried in vain to get his wife’s night blindness cured in will light up the lives of two visually impaired people after his death. The cop’s family donated his eyes after he was killed in a freak accident on Monday night.

The eyes of Bhaktharam SY, a resident of Saptagiri Layout, Vidyaranyapura, and head constable attached to Nandini Layout police station, were harvested by Dr Rajkumar Eye Bank of Narayana Nethralaya.

Bhaktharam was riding back home on his scooter when he met with the accident at Pipeline Road Junction near Goraguntepalya around 8.45pm. According to Yeshwantpur traffic police, a speeding truck coming from the Hebbal side on Outer Ring Road tried to overtake a car from the right, but the driver lost control and hit the median built of cement bricks.

The impact sent four bricks flinging into the air: three of them hit Bhaktharam riding on the opposite lane and the fourth landed on a car behind him.

“His right hand, leg and ribs were fractured and he collapsed on the road. Passersby rushed an unconscious Bhaktharam in uniform to a nearby private hospital where he succumbed to injuries by10pm,” traffic police said. “We have arrested truck driver Hari Prasad, 31, a resident of Turuvekere, Tumakuru district,” an investigating officer said.

Police handed over Bhaktaram’s body to his family on Tuesday morning. His last rites were conducted at Hebbal crematorium.

“Bhaktharam’s wife Sumangala suffers from night blindness. But no treatment could cure her and even transplantation was ruled out. As the family knew about the problems faced by the visually impaired, they decided to donate Bhaktharam’s eyes,” said Shashikumar N, DCP (north). The couple has two kids.

Bengaluru police commissioner Bhaskar Rao tweeted: “Extremely inspirational act in hour of tragedy.”

Title: Bengaluru: Bidar incident will scar kids for life, says parents
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The protesters — mostly teachers, parents and social activists — participated in a candlelight vigil at Mysore... Read More

BENGALURU: Some 300 persons staged a demonstration in the city on Tuesday criticising police for repeatedly grilling the students of Bidar’s Shaheen Primary and High School for staging a play over the Citizenship Amendment Act .

The protesters — mostly teachers, parents and social activists — participated in a candlelight vigil at Mysore Bank Circle. Slamming police for charging a teacher and parent of a nine-year-old student with sedition for staging the play, the protesters asked: “How can cops repeatedly interrogate students inside the school? Why has everyone turned a blind eye to what they (police) are doing?”

Dwiji Guru, a parent and food-tech expert who participated in the demonstration, told TOI: “The arrested parent is a widow; her child is being taken care of by a neighbour. Slapping sedition charges and arresting them just like that is a clear example of the government trying to instil fear among students and parents and telling them to never question the authorities. It is horrifying and an inhumane act.”

Athiya Firdose, a homemaker, said police machinery is being used to scare schoolchildren. “Several things are happening in the country, but why is the government hell-bent on questioning kids and arresting parents,” she asked.

Recounting another incident in Mangaluru where students of a school run by a Hindu activist enacted the Babri Masjid demolition, another demonstrator Vinay Raj said: “If no action was taken against the school authorities in Mangaluru, why are kids and parents of the Bidar institution being harassed?”

Title: Hyderabad: Hospital managing director kills self, cites harassment in suicide note
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 30-year-old managing director of a private hospital in LB Nagar committed suicide by hanging on the health facility premises on Tuesday morning due to alleged harassment by the hospital building owner and his associates.

The victim was identified as Ajay Kumar, a resident of BN Reddy and managing director of Sri Vaishnavi Hospitals at Omkar Nagar, LB Nagar. Ajya Kumar founded the hospital in 2014 and started functioning out of a multi-storied building owned by Karunakar Reddy.

After a financial dispute, building owner Karunakar Reddy allegedly harassed Ajay Kumar to vacate the building and even filed a case in court with the help of his associates — relative, Kondal Reddy, former Turkayamjal sarpanch Shiva Kumar, Saraswathi Nagar colony president Megha Reddy.

The victim’s family alleged that Kondal Reddy had earlier snapped power to the hospital and threw nurses out at midnight. Megha Reddy allegedly warned office staff and told them to leave the premises, the family added.

On Tuesday, the victim went to his office around 9am. Later, when the staff knocked on the door of his office chambers, he did not respond. When they broke open the door, they found him hanging.

“The victim was allegedly vexed by their harassment, which was also affecting his reputation for the past few months. Due to this, he took the extreme step,” LB Nagar inspector V Ashok Reddy said.

Police found a message, written in Telugu in his notebook, stating that he took the extreme step after harassment from the four. A case of abetment of suicide was filed against the four persons and the body was shifted to hospital for an autopsy. No arrests were effected so far in the case.

Title: Farmers’ market gives this BE graduate a lifeline
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

At the R S Puram Uzhavar Sandhai, along the line where a majority of Karamadai farmers have set up shops, is a tall young man sporting a T-shirt and jeans, standing in front of a shop that has three varieties of bananas. Kannan Rangarajan’s shop in the market, though relatively new, is well-known for his fresh, ripe bananas. Not many people know that a little over a year back, Rangarajan, was considering giving up farming altogether due to cut throat middle men and agents. The 32-year-old says introduction into Uzhavar Sandhai (farmer’s market) changed his life.

A little more than two years back, Rangarajan, a BE graduate, was working in Dubai as a site engineer earning Rs 3 lakh a month. However, an accident at his workplace brought his career crashing down and Rangarajan was left recuperating in his home with three to four bulged discs in his back. “They said even if I go back, I can’t even climb a flight of 10 stairs,” he said. After a few months of mulling over career options, he decided to join his parents in farming their 8 acres of land spread across Sirumugai, Moolayur and Ammanpudur.

However, the first time he took his bananas to the Mettupalayam vegetable market, he was shocked to find agents offering him just Rs 2.50 for a bunch of bananas. “I was ready to give up farming or sell it in front of my house myself,” said Rangarajan. That was when a member of his father’s farming cooperative suggested he take his vegetables to one of the uzhavar sandhais and sell it himself. “Here, after all my expenses, including my own travel to town daily, my transport costs of Rs 2 per kg of vegetables, I make a profit of Rs 1,000 per day, or Rs 30,000 to Rs 35,000 a month on an average,” he said. “This is the only way agriculture becomes sustainable,” he added.

There are several farmers like Rangarajan who believe that the Uzhavar Sandhai is a critical factor that has made agriculture sustainable. “In uzhavar sandhai, we get Rs 5 more per kg of produce than in the market daily. In fact, we would get Rs 7 more, if we had free buses from Karamadai, which we don’t. But still Rs 5 per kg or per bunch of greens, means we earn more than Rs 300 to Rs 400 per day than what a middle-man would give us,” S Balasubramaniam, who owns 23 acres of land at Thimampalayam Pudur, said.

Title: Bengaluru: Rowdy makes daughter, 3, drink whisky, stabs wife
Content:
A video grab shows Kumaresh cajoling his daughter into drinking whisky, promising to take her out on a bike ri... Read More

BENGALURU: A rowdy-sheeter allegedly stabbed his 24-year-old wife in the nose with a screwdriver after she raised a complaint with the women’s helpline of city police saying he forcefully made their three-year-old daughter drink alcohol.The video of the rowdy-sheeter, Kumaresh alias Mavatti, an accused in a murder case, making the child drink alcohol has gone viral. Police are yet to arrest the accused.According to police sources, the woman fell in love with Kumaresh and married him against her elders’ wishes four years ago. She wasn’t aware that her husband was a rowdy-sheeter.“When the woman was four months pregnant, she came to know the truth when police arrested Kumaresh in a murder case. The woman returned to her parents. After giving birth to a girl, she began working as a domestic help. Out on bail, Kumaresh asked the woman to hand over his daughter to him, but she refused. In January, he came to her residence, assaulted her and took the child away,” the sources said.When the woman was searching for her daughter, Kumaresh sent to her a video showing his daughter drinking whisky with him. The woman rushed to Parihar family counselling centre in the police commissioner’s office. The counsellors sought police help and tracked the child to Kumaresh’s sister’s house, but he had fled the place.The woman shifted to Byadarahalli, Magadi Road with her daughter. A few days ago, Kumaresh barged into her house and assaulted her with a screwdriver.Bindya Yohannan, counsellor at the centre, said the woman has fled the city, fearing her husband.The viral video shows Kumaresh cajoling his daughter into drinking whisky, promising to take her out on a bike ride.In Video: Karnataka: Man makes 3-year-old daughter drink alcohol, sends video to wife

Title: Coronavirus in Tamilnadu: As ‘remedies’ for novel coronavirus emerge, officials call for caution
Content:
Representative image

A 14-year-old boy walked into the Tirupur collectorate on Monday to meet the collector, claiming that he has found a herbal cure for novel coronavirus (nCoV). Displaying a bottle with a dark green liquid, he said the concoction was made from 11 herbs. The Class IX boy attributed his herbal knowledge to his grandmother and insisted that his concoction could be sent for lab tests to ascertain its efficacy. The officials received a petition by him in this regard and sent him off.On Tuesday, the boy visited the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital demanding to meet the dean. He was given a liberal dose of advice and sent away by the hospital authorities. If the boy was innocent enough to approach health authorities with such a claim, there may be others who are not so naïve coming up with similar claims.An alternative medicine practitioner from Chennai made a similar claim that he has a cure for nCoV. The man said the herbal extract he has formulated would cure all sorts of viral infections and would be effective in treating multi-organ failure caused by nCoV.Quite similar to claims made by several people during the outbreak of infections right from chikungunya to dengue in the past, this time too dozens have sprung up offering ready remedies for nCoV. Social media has been abuzz with people claiming to be practitioners of alternative medicine offering solutions ranging from garlic rasam to thulasi syrup. There were customised yoga sessions for nCoV too.Health officials have warned that in general it was not safe to try any unproven methods of treatment for any viral infection. “People should understand that none of these treatments has actually been proven to be effective simply because we don’t have even one case in our state to test,” said deputy director of public health G Ramesh Kumar.Health minister C Vijayabaskar said, “We don't have much information about the virus yet. Scientists, agencies such as WHO are working to find more information. We don't have a vaccine yet. We don’t have a list of standard drugs. So, it is better not to go with anything that is unscientific as of now.”He also said there is no official information about preventive medicines in AYUSH.

Title: Model of fighter jet bidding to join IAF on display
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

F-21 fighter jet, which will be made in India if the US company wins a contract

Lucknow: Visitors to the Defence Expo will be able to experience the working of an aircraft competing to join the Indian Air Force.

A model and simulation set-up of the F-21 fighter jet, which is specifically configured for the IAF, is on display for visitors at the expo. A product from US defence major Lockheed Martin, it will be manufactured locally under the Centre’s ‘Make in India’ initiative if chosen by the IAF for its fleet. The US defence firm will build the plane in collaboration with Tata Advanced Systems.

All major fighter aircraft manufacturers including Sukhoi and MiG from Russia, Boeing from US, Eurofighter consortium from Europe and Saab from Sweden are competing to supply 114 jets to the IAF.

IAF had invited requests for information early last year for the project, which is under the defence ministry’s ‘strategic partnership’ model.

The deal, valued at Rs 1.5 lakh crore, is expected to be the biggest ever in terms of the number of aircraft and the amount of money involved. IAF is carrying out trials of all the participants to select the multi-role combat aircraft.

The process is expected to be completed over the next few months.

India needs to fulfil the shortage of fighter planes in the IAF, which is looking to replace the MiG-21, MiG-23 and MiG-27 with more advanced jets.

Lockheed Martin had unveiled the F-21 jet at Aero India in 2019 last year.

Meanwhile, vice-president and chief executive of Lockheed Martin India William (Bill) Blair said that the company aims to identify additional strategic partners including MSMEs and startups during the expo.

Title: 27-year-old youth arrested for murdering drunkard father in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Anna Nagar police apprehended an autorickshaw driver for murdering his father after finding his troublesome behavior too much to handle.

The police nabbed K Vinoth, 27, for killing M Kallanai, 60, of Vinayagar Nagar 8th Street, Gomathipuram. He allegedly crushed his father to death with a boulder following a fight with him. An alcoholic, Kallanai beat up his wife regularly after getting drunk and was staying alone until a few weeks ago.

He came to live with his wife following intervention from relatives recently. Police said that a quarrel broke out between Kallanai and his wife on Monday night in which he not noly beat her, but removed her sari in public view.

Learning about the incident, Vinoth questioned his father’s action and began beating him up. In a fit of rage, he took a boulder and smashed his head, killing him on the spot.

Title: RTE recognition certificate for schools may soon come online
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The education department is planning to shift online the application process for recognition certificate for schools , which is mandatory under the Right To Education (RTE) Act. The RTE recognition is valid for three years after which it has to be renewed by getting it endorsed by the local primary education department. The current block of recognition, 2019-22, has been put on hold by the education department till a final decision is taken on the online portal.

This part came to the fore after it was revealed that over 2,000 schools have not renewed their RTE recognition certificate . Chintaman Vanjari, education officer (primary), said, “The entire process has been put on hold for sometime. The state government is in the process of shifting the entire application and approval process online and that is the reason we are holding back. I will wait till March to see if something concrete happens. Otherwise, we will revert to the offline process.”

Vanjari added that since he took charge, in June 2018, just over 1,600 schools have got RTE recognition certificate. “We are monitoring schools closely regarding RTE recognition as that certificate is needed for them to claim reimbursements and get other permissions,” said Vanjari.

Education activists say the bigger question is how RTE admissions can happen if these schools are illegal. Shahid Sharif, an activist, said, “Only 20 schools have got the RTE recognition renewed in the 2019-22 block. The rule says that schools which do not have RTE recognition are technically illegal. Now, the education department is going ahead with admissions under RTE quota, but how can admissions be done in schools which are technically illegal?”

Though free admissions under RTE is a topic which attracts maximum attention, the Act actually covers a wide range of factors concerning schools. Infrastructure of a school is a major factor for getting RTE certificate and it gets renewed in fixed blocks of three years (the current one is 2019-22) after a ground level inspection by the education department.

Title: Bird flu: Govt seals OUAT poultry farm
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state government on Tuesday sealed the poultry farm of the Odisha University of Agriculture and Technology ( OUAT ) in view of the flu outbreak there.

Ratnakar Rout, director of the animal husbandry department, said, “Poultry production in the farm will be restricted for one year. The farm premises will be disinfected every 15 days to ensure that the area is infection-free,” he added.

The farm was sealed after culling of the birds and burying of carcasses in the presence of a specialised team from the Centre, which is currently in the city to monitor the situation. The move comes after Bhopal-based National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) confirmed the H5N1 — the avian influenza virus — in the samples of dead birds from the poultry farm at the College of Veterinary Science and Animal Husbandry under the OUAT on January 27.

Following the flu outbreak, all poultry birds from shops, business establishments and houses within one km radius of the infected area were culled. “The restriction on selling of chicken and eggs in the infected area is for one month. This apart, consuming chicken and eggs after cooking and boiling them has been declared safe in other parts of the state,” Rout said.

Rout added that the area within 10 km radius of the epicentre – OUAT farm – was under surveillance. “We collected samples from 76 villages in and around Bhubaneswar to ensure that there is no occurrence of H5N1 virus in birds. The reports are negative so there is nothing to worry about,” Rout said. A medical team from the state government also conducted health checks on people, who are residing in the infected area and had complained of cold and cough.

Title: Hyderabad an incubator for firms engaged in war on cancer
Content:
The city now has around 50 startups working in the field of cancer research or developing products related to ... Read More

HYDERABAD: The city now has around 50 startups working in the field of cancer research or developing products related to cancer. Right from focussing on basics like platforms to connect specialists and patients to sophisticated research like developing biosimilar drugs for exorbitantly priced ones, these startups are doing research at par with the world community. Many of the researchers and scientists have in fact returned after having careers in different countries to launch the start-ups here.“Considering the alarming statistics of cancer cases in India and the urgency needed to tackle the disease, the solutions developed by these startups have immense potential to provide technologically advanced and affordable methods for early detection and treatment of cancer. These startups need support from clinical organisations and regulators,” said Rohini Pimple, director - Lifesciences RICH.Sapien Biosciences, is one such startup biobank managed professionally to use ‘medical waste’ for healthcare innovation. “The biospecimens collected as well as associated digitized data is used for establishing advanced cell and molecular research platforms. We work with diagnostic companies to enable them to validate their tests using our samples and detailed treatment and survival data collated by us,” said Jugnu Jain, co-founder and chief executive officer of the startup.Reagene Biosciences founded by Dr Uday Saxena and Subhramanayam Vangala is one of the handful of firms (in India) working in the cutting edge 3D bioprinting of human cells technology which is used to recreate human organs. “90 per cent of the drugs fail in clinic trials. The primary reason is that the drugs are developed using animal models. We are trying to create human-like tools using human cells, like taking cells from a lung cancer patients to mimic a human lung. Human-like tools will better predict how a drug will behave in human being,” said Dr Uday.Another start-up is now ready to go for preclinical trials for biosimilars to cancer drugs, ‘Keytruda’ and ‘Herceptin’, that it has developed. “Since these drugs are extremely costly (Rs 2.5 lakh per injection) and 6-7 doses are required for treatment, we are working on developing biosimilar drugs which are affordable,” said Dr Sudharshan, founder of Oncosimis Biotech Pvt Limited.

Title: DPS-East to appeal again to run classes 1-8
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: On Tuesday, a day after the district primary education officer (DPEO) rejected the application of Delhi Public School ( DPS ) East to operate Classes 1-8, the school considered filing an appeal before the director of primary education, the Government of Gujarat. The DPEO, in a letter issued to the school on Monday, denied permission to operate the classes from the same premises (Hirapur, Ahmedabad) under the same name. The letter said that the school management could not furnish the requisite documents including the building-use permission, the certificate from a structural engineer, and the no-objection certificate from neighbouring schools.

“The application to the DPEO has been deemed unacceptable for now. A period of 30 days has clearly been given to appeal again and submit necessary documents online to complete the application,” said Unmesh Dixit, OSD, DPS-East. “The students’ academic interests being paramount, the school is taking necessary steps to not only protect students’ welfare but also the welfare of the academic staff.”

M N Patel, DPEO-Ahmedabad, said: “We have denied permission to the school because it did not have necessary documents and permissions. According to legal provisions, the school has a 30-day window to appeal.”

The school’s affiliation with the CBSE was cancelled on November 30, 2019, after it was found that the school had forged an NOC obtained from the state education department. Following the development, the management of DPS-East had re-applied for permission with the DPEO on January 16.

Well-placed sources revealed that the school management has also initiated the procedure for obtaining its affiliation with the CBSE. A source privy to the developments said that the school has all documents in place except the BU permission which the management is hopeful of getting soon.

“Once their appeal is submitted, an appropriate decision will be taken,” said Mahesh Joshi, the director of technical education, the Government of Gujarat.

Parents, however, have raised concerns over the school resuming operations from the next academic year. Bhaskar Patel, president, Gujarat State School Management Association, said that according to Bombay Primary Education Act, 1947, a school management can approach the director of primary education in the form of an appeal. And if that too is rejected, the management can approach courts. “Even if they produce all the documents in 30 days, the time limit for applying for a new school or additional classes is over,” he said. “The usual time limit for applying to start or close a school is six months. I do not think that the school management will be able to begin classes by April this year.”

Title: Samples lifted from shops selling cooking oil in loose
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: A team of food safety officials lifted samples from oil stores selling loose cooking oil varieties in East Veli Streets and adjoining areas on Tuesday. Officials said that appropriate action against the owners will be taken based on the outcome of the results.

The 16-member team of officials, led by designated officer for food safety for Madurai district Dr S Somasundaram took around 40 samples from 20 stores. This is in addition to around 50 samples lifted last week. Officials said that so far, they have covered only a couple of wards in the city. Lifting of samples will take place throughout the 100 wards and subsequently the whole of Madurai district would be covered. Officials said that at least 500 samples will be taken to test the quality of oil sold to the public.

Being the gateway for southern districts, huge quantity of oils is being sent through Madurai after repacking in the city. There are hundreds of oil stores selling loose oil in Madurai alone posing difficulty to officials in ensuring that right quality is sold to the customers.

Somasundaram said that good quality of gingelly oil cannot be sold for anything less than Rs 400 per kg, but it is available starting from Rs 220 in the market.

Similarly, groundnut oil is being sold from Rs 150. “How can oil be sold at such a lower price? So, we have a suspicion on the quality of the oil and decided to check it by testing it in the lab,” he said.

Somasundaram said that selling oil in loose is banned by Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) due to rampant adulteration.

The traders have been repeatedly warned to stop selling in loose for the past few months. While a few have started selling in packets, some have come forward to put a sticker on the vessels mentioning the name of the oil.

Title: To Russia, with love: Bengali translations fly off shelves
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata’s love story with Russian literature continued at the 44th edition of the International Kolkata Book Fair . Bolstering the image of Russia, the theme country at the fair this year, the Publishers and Booksellers Guild, along with the Russian Consulate, made elaborate arrangements to get the most popular Russian classics translated into Bengali. Understandably, the Russia pavilion, where the books have been displayed, has been drawing huge crowds, as book lovers flipped through titles, like ‘Shishu Kahini’ by Leo Tolstoy, ‘Alta Jaba’ by Sergei Aksakov, ‘Byanger Visvadarshan’ and Maxim Gorky’s ‘Ma’ and ‘Choruichhana’. Childhood nostalgia, coupled with the sheer appeal of the books, saw them flying off the shelves in no time. Students also took home engineering and medicine books. Even Russian readers has ostensibly developed interest in Bengali literature as poet Subodh Sarkar said his book had been translated into Russian.

Bringing AJC Bose to people

Bose Institute, a repository of all contents that Acharya Jagadish Chandra Bose wrote, has brought special editions and volumes of the scientist’s books, scientific essays, letters and memoirs capturing the pioneering science movement of the time. The idea, said an official, was to bring Bose to people. “Apart from his pioneering contributions to the fields of radio and microwave optics and to plant studies, did you know that he was also one of the first writers of science fiction in Bengali? He is almost an unknown planet and we want to present him holistically to the city. Hence this effort,” the official at the stall said.

Promoting wildlife

Books on wildlife have always been a favourite among readers here, and multiple new titles were unveiled at the fair, “forests of Bengal” being one of the most popular themes. Nature, Environ and Wildlife Society, which works for the welfare of forests and wildlife, also brings out a magazine, Environ. Given its unusual coverage of tigers, wild dogs and grizzly bears in the country, the magazine seemed an instant hit. Honey, mats, Dudheshwar rice and sonamug dal, all sourced from the Sunderbans, were also stocked at the stall.

Senior Citizens’ Day

Celebrating Senior Citizens’ Day, the Publishers and Booksellers Guild invited residents of old age homes in the city for a tour of the fair. Some of the visitors had physical incapacitation and had to be assisted while moving from stall to stall. The physical fatigue notwithstanding, they enjoyed themselves at the fair and returned home with books gifted by the Guild.

Title: Govt draws up plans for 24x7 water supply in state
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: To ensure round-the-clock water supply to every household, the Water Corporation of Odisha (Watco) here has come up with short-term, mid-term and long-term plans.

According to the short-term plan, which will be implemented within a year, the Watco has proposed to install water meters in every household and will set up a meter testing lab while a cell to address the issues of non-revenue water (water lost during supply and due to pilferage) will also be set up in the city.

It is also proposed to establish a centralised customer care centre with interactive voice response system for redressing urban water supply grievances. The districts will be divided and named district metered areas for concept planning, an official source said.

The Watco has planned to procure mobile water quality testing laboratories for continuous monitoring of water at taps of consumers. “We have also decided to initiate a customer tap sampling programme as part of which samples will be collected for quality monitoring,” Watco managing director Chitta Ranjan Jena said.

He said a GIS-based water supply asset database will also be created for management purposes.

Similarly, as part of the mid-term plan, which will be implemented within two years, the Watco has proposed to set up a state-of-the-art institution for capacity building of the engineers and officials. The institution will also support research programmes in the field.

A water supply central control and command centre will also be established for effective monitoring of works, incident response and maintenance of water supply system 24x7, another official of the corporation said.

The mid-term plan will also address the issues of non-payment of dues as part of which an innovative system will be adopted. It is proposed to restrict water supply by the use of specialised valves instead of disconnection of the defaulting consumers.

In the mid-term proposal, a water safety plan will be prepared and implemented while another emergency and risk management plan will be put in place to prevent water-related disasters for effective incident management.

As part of the long-term plan, which will be implemented within five years, policy framework and guidelines will be prepared for water conservation and groundwater usage. A framework for enforcement measures will also be developed for the purpose, an official said.

“Odisha is one of the states where water scarcity is not yet a problem, but there is a need to conserve and manage the available water. I am hopeful that the plans of the administration will yield good results,” social worker Alok Kar said.

Title: JEE racket arrests
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: Cops from the Cossipore police station have arrested Ujjal Suman, who impersonated as JEE candidate Mohammad Sibghatullah and wrote the entrance test for him. Sibghatullah has also been arrested, based on a complaint lodged by Subrata Sarkar, principal of North Calcutta Polytechnic College .

“During security scrutiny, invigilators caught the fake candidate, who was found carrying some forged documents,” said police, adding that while Sibghatullah was from Jharkhand, Sumar was from Patna in Bihar. tnn

Title: Mahatma Gandhi’s model of trusteeship is relevant even today, says Nobel laureate
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Prof Michael Spence

AHMEDABAD: The concept of trusteeship, primarily the one propagated by Mahatma Gandhi , can work as antidote to potential deviations from public interest, said Prof Michael Spence, noted economist and 2001 Nobel laureate . He was speaking at the inaugural session of the day-long symposium on ‘Trusteeship and the Future of Capitalism’ at IIM, Ahmedabad (IIM-A).

“In representative democracies, and in other forms of government, interest groups matter, and they differ in their power to influence and organize. The result is potential deviation from what we might call the public interest in the formulation and implementation of policy,” said Prof Spence. “The antidote: the thing that is supposed to limit these deviations, is public service or trusteeship.”

The Mahatma had suggested trusteeship as a concept where a certain part of an individual’s wealth was held in trust for the greater good of society.

“By and large this system worked pretty well, when applied. But its application has been narrower than it should be and certainly than Gandhi envisioned in a more expansive social version of it... It used to be part of the concept of public service. These days, with a few exceptions, I don’t think most politicians think of themselves as trustees. Nor do leaders in business,” said Prof Spence.

Title: Female elephant found dead in Erode forest
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

ERODE: A female elephant aged around 22 was found dead in the Kadambur forest range in Erode district on Tuesday. Forest officials said the elephant suffered from intestinal infection.

After being alerted by tribals of Makkampalayam village, forest officials and veterinarians reached the spot. The autopsy was performed on the spot and later the carcass was buried in the forest.

“The elephant had been suffering from intestinal worms and stopped eating. Subsequently, its health condition deteriorated and it died,” a forest official said.

“Elephants usually have round worms in their intestines. But, when the number of worms increase, it may become fatal as elephants stop consuming food,” one of the veterinarians who performed the autopsy said.

Title: Boy, 17, injured in neck after attack by classmate
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A plus two student was admitted to the Tenkasi government hospital on Tuesday with neck and hand injuries after he was attacked by a classmate. The victim had close to 12 stitches on his neck but is said to be out of danger. and the attacker was nabbed by the police.

The incident which happened on the way to Government Anna Boys higher secondary school at Veerakeralampudur was the fallout of a clash on Monday between the two boys, both 17-year-olds. According to the police, the victim hailed from Veeranam and the attacker from Veerakeralampudur.

Police said a teacher had asked the victim on Monday evening to inform the other student to meet him over academic reasons. The other boy was offended as the boy called out his name aloud in front of other students and picked a quarrel with him. Tension prevailed as the boys clashed and the teachers made the victim go home first and made the other boy wait for some time to avoid a clash outside the campus. On Tuesday morning, the victim got down from the bus at Veerakeralampudur and was walking to the school. Suddenly, the other boy surfaced and picked a quarrel with the victim. Quite unexpectedly, he attacked him with a sharp blade used to sharpen pencils.

The boy suffered cuts on his neck and left hand, seeing which the locals rushed him to the hospital. Meanwhile police in plain clothes picked up the attacker for questioning. Tenkasi district SP G Suguna Singh told TOI that the neck injury was accidental and that the attacker did not intend to cause any life threatening injury to the victim. “He tried to scratch the boy on his hand using the blade,” the SP said.

Singh added that an FIR was not registered in this connection as there is a Supreme Court direction that a case should be registered against a minor only if they he committed an offence that could attract a minimum punishment of seven years imprisonment – like an attempt to murder. A community service registry (CSR) was registered so that the incident does not become a bad trendsetter, the SP said. The SP said that the attacker will be produced before the juvenile justice board in Tirunelveli , which in turn will decide on the further course of action.

Title: Final plan of Puri corridor likely by 1st week of April
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The final architectural plan of the ambitious heritage corridor project around the Puri Jagannath Temple is expected to be ready by April first week with focus on the Kalinga style of architecture.

Eminent personalities like Puri King Gajapati Dibyasingha Deb, noted sculptor Raghunath Mohapatra, retired bureaucrat and researcher Subash Pani and servitors suggested necessary changes in the draft plan as Bengaluru-based Bhumiputra Architecture Firm made presentation on the draft plan at a meeting here.

Briefing reporters after the meeting, Mohapatra said there is a need to focus more on Kalinga architecture while preparing the final plan of the mega project.

State works secretary and Jagannath Temple chief administrator Krishan Kumar said there will be more consultation with people associated with the Jagannath culture before preparing the final plan.

Some of the key issues discussed in the meeting include streamlining the traffic movement in the streets/localities surrounding the shrine, developing the Ratha Khala where chariots of the deities are made, developing the ritual paths from the shrine to other religious places and developing facilities like advanced queue management system, cloakrooms, toilets, brief resting facility en route and provision for washing feet, said Kumar.

On Mohapatra’s concern over lack of Kalinga architecture in the draft plan, the works secretary said, “We have emphasized on Kalinga architecture in the draft plan. Since the plan is on the consultation stage, we have requested Mohapatra to guide the architecture team to ensure that Kalinga architecture is reflected in the final plan.”

Major suggestions made by the Puri King include special arrangement for Sankirtan and to perform other rituals within the heritage corridor.
