Similarly, the state government and temple administration have also planned to develop facilities through which over 5,000 people can partake of Mahaprasad at a time.

“The corridor is being planned keeping in mind the Jagannath culture and tradition of Shrikshetra (Puri). Steps are being taken to popularise the culture across the globe,” said the Puri King, who chaired the meeting.

The state government plans to spend around Rs 800 crore for development of the heritage corridor around the 12th century shrine and it is one of the top priority of the state government at present. The project is targeted to be completed in two years.

Title: Street vendors to be streamlined at 4 spots
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

About 1,680 street vendors have been identified at all the four places for the project

MADURAI: Madurai corporation has obtained sanction for streamlining street vendors at four places – Town Hall Road, East Chithirai Street, Thalavai Street and Thiruparankundram Road - under National Urban Livelihood Mission by providing them similar-looking space-saving street furniture. The corporation will get a fund of Rs 5.41 crore soon to execute the project.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said streamlining the vendors will help them operate without affecting traffic or pedestrian movement at the proposed places. There will be similar-looking stalls which suit the needs of various vendors like eateries and those selling vegetables or flowers. Other than Madurai corporation, only Greater Chennai corporation has received the fund in Tamil Nadu and the latter is planning to introduce a similar project on Marina beach. Works for the construction of stalls will start once the allotted fund is received, corporation officials said.

About 1,680 street vendors have been identified at all the four places for the project. They include 437 vendors on Town Hall Road, 390 at East Chithirai Street, 354 in Thalavai Street and 499 on Thiruparankundram Road.

They have been categorized under three divisions — fast food under one, flower sellers under another and vegetables, fruits, puja items, footwears and other things under the third category. Among the 1,680 street vendors there are 305 selling flowers and 314 selling fast food while the rest comes under the third category, officials said.

Assistant city health officer B Vinodh Raja told TOI that street vendors will be given stalls at the same place where they have been operating for long. They would be allowed to operate in such a way that others on the road are not affected. Already, all the street vendors in the city have been enumerated and are being issued identity cards.

The process started a few years ago and the street vendors have undergone various training programmes where they were told about their rights and responsibility. The identification of four locations and beneficiaries was carried out a few months ago. Officials said a minimum charge will be collected from the street vendors once the project is implemented.

However, other modalities like whether it would be collected every day or monthly are being worked out.

Title: Obscene messages: Airtel to face trial as Madras HC refuses to quash case
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: In a setback to telecom major Bharti Airtel , the Madras high court has refused to quash a criminal proceeding initiated against the company by a customer for failing to stop obscene text messages being sent to his mobile.

Dismissing the plea moved by Airtel, Justice P Velmurugan directed the chief judicial magistrate in Egmore to conduct the trial proceedings in accordance with law and complete it within four months.

The issue pertains to a police complaint lodged by advocate V S Suresh in 2011 against Airtel and its former chief executive officer Rajiv Rajagopal for failing to stop obscene messages sent to his mobile.

Based on the complaint, the cybercrime cell of CCB registered an FIR under Sections 292, 292A (distribution of obscene contents) and 294 IPC and Sections 3, 4 and 6 of Indecent Representation of Women (Prohibition) Act and Sections 2, 3 and 6 of the Young Persons (Harmful Publications) Act.

After investigation, the CCB police filed a chargesheet in 2013. Taking cognizance of the chargesheet, the magistrate ordered summons to the accused. Aggrieved, the petitioners filed the present petitions seeking to quash the criminal proceeding.

Counsel for the petitioner submitted that the company is only a service provider and it has no role in sending such messages as it has no occasion to see the messages transferred from one customer to another.

Therefore, the petitioners are not liable to be held for the alleged offence, he said. He further submitted that the messages said to have been received by Suresh were also not obscene as defined under the IPC and therefore, the petitioner has nothing to do with the messages received by Suresh.

Refusing to concur, the judge, referring to the statement recorded by police, said it shows prima facie evidence and also the advocate made a complaint before the petitioners, for which they have not taken any action.

Whether the petitioners are liable, or they have any direction or not, all those matters are to be decided after trial and not at this stage. Therefore, the court does not find any valid reason to interfere in the criminal proceeding, the judge said while dismissing the plea.

Title: Sterlite panel summons actor Rajinikanth on February 25
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Rajinikanth had visited injured Sterlite protesters after the police firing incident on May 22, 2018

MADURAI: Actor Rajinikanth has been summoned for an inquiry by the one-member retired Justice Aruna Jagadeesan Commission that is probing the anti-Sterlite protest and the police firing on May 22, 2018, that claimed 14 lives. The actor has been asked to appear before the commission during the 19th sitting of the inquiry in Tuticorin at 10am on February 25.

“On the directions of the (Aruna Jagadeesan) commission we summoned actor Rajinikanth from Tuticorin by post on Tuesday. It has been sent to his Poes Garden residence in Chennai. We expect it to be delivered in a day or two and are awaiting acknowledgement for the same,” a source in the commission told TOI.

The reason cited for summoning the actor is quoting his comment to journalists in Tuticorin on May 30, 2018, after his visit to the violence-hit southern coastal city that ‘intrusion of anti-social elements’ was the reason for the mob turning violent and eventually ended with the police resorting to firing at them.

Pointing out that the actor had also stated that he knows those behind the instigation and that he will reveal it at the right place, the source said that on these grounds Rajinikanth has been asked to appear and reveal those vital details.

Sources in the commission also said that Naam Tamilar Katchi (NTK) coordinator Seeman and advocates-cum-activists S Vanchinathan and A Viyanarasu were among the many who had given written submissions before the commission to summon Rajinikanth for an inquiry.

It may be recalled that the commission’s counsel Vadivel Murugan told Tuticorin reporters on January 25 – after the 18th sitting inquiry – that Rajinikanth would be summoned if needed.

Title: Former Godhra MLA denied bail
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: A city sessions court denied anticipatory bail to former Godhra MLA Haresh Bhatt and a builder named Sunny Patel, in connection with a complaint filed with Vasna police against them for an alleged illegal sale of land.

A lawyer, Kanti Pandit, lodged an FIR accusing Bhatt and others of cheating, forgery and criminal conspiracy. Pandit, the chairman of Manjushree (Vasna) Owners’ Association, accused Bhatt of selling the piece of land to Patel for Rs 1.55 crore though they are not members of the association.

Additional sessions judge P M Unadkat denied pre-arrest bail to Bhatt and Patel with the observation that economic offences are on the rise. Granting anticipatory bail to them would send a wrong signal to society. The legal protection against possible arrest would also cause issues with the process of custodial interrogation, the court said.

Title: Coronavirus Chennai: Washing hands is essential, but where is the soap for it?
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The messages stand out on posters at airports, hospitals and public places and blare out of health department press conferences – “washing hands with soap and running water can prevent transmission of novel coronavirus”.Toilets in general ward at the premier Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital, where eight Chinese passengers were kept in isolation, did not have soap for patients, though they had hand sanitizers at several places. The situation is the same in all government hospitals and offices. On Monday, health minister C Vijayabaskar said the health department has asked the education department to ensure school and college students practice hand hygiene and promote the practice at their homes.Most city schools – private or public – do not provide soaps and running water in the toilets. “My daughter doesn’t use the washroom in school or consume water because there is no soap. She carries a hand sanitizer but the school does not permit her to use it as the teacher feels the scent from it distracts other students,” said Radhika R, a parent. Many eateries, public offices, bus stops and railway stations don’t stock up soap solutions in restrooms.Infectious disease experts say hand hygiene practices are a concern across the globe. “We are probably among the worse,” said P Kuganantham, former city health officer. “We should use this opportunity to change it. If we make hand hygiene a practice now, we will be able to prevent many ailments,” he said.

Title: 16 police teams launch search for murderer on the loose in Salem
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: In separate incidents, an unidentified man has killed two men sleeping on the roadside in the city in the past two days.

Deputy commissioner (crime and traffic) of city police S Senthil said on both occasions, the man used boulders to smash his victims’ head. “But the reason for his actions is yet to be ascertained.” He said 16 special police teams are searching for the accused.

On Tuesday morning, A Angamuthu, 85, of Sadagoban Street of Ponnammapet, was found dead in front of a commercial complex near old bus stand with his head smashed with boulder, a police officer attached with the Salem town police station said. The victim was working in a fruit shop and used to sleep outside the shop.

When police checked CCTV footage from nearby shops, they found the accused throwing a boulder on Angamuthu’s head. “We were shocked as the accused had killed a 39-year-old alms seeker at Kasakaranur on Sunday night. He was caught on camera throwing a boulder on the unidentified victim’s head,” the police officer said.

“We will intensify patrolling in the night as the killings happened between 11.30pm and 3am,” the deputy commissioner said, adding, “We don’t know the motive. He could have some mental illness.”

Police have registered two separate cases.

Title: Private school adopts ward no. 64, to work with sanitary workers of corporation
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: SSVM School of Excellence at Uppilipalayam on Monday adopted ward 64 of the city corporation to keep it clean and tidy.

“The purpose of adopting the ward is to make the surrounding area cleaner and to appreciate, motivate and support the sanitary workers for the work that they carry out. It is only the corporation workers who carry out the work and our job is to stand with them and make them feel motivated,” trustee of SSVM institutions S Mohandoss said.

“We are planning to conduct periodical review meetings with corporation officials and workers. Issues pertaining to sanitation will be discussed and necessary actions will be taken to rectify them,” he added.

By involving students in the activity, we could turn them into responsible citizens who would keep society in mind while doing an activity, he said. The school has started a Swachh Bharat Club.

Apart from providing safety gears for sanitary workers and push carts, the school has come forward to provide breakfast to workers on regular basis. It has also agreed to send volunteers to educate the public about source segregation of wastes, said R Raveendran, a Swachh Bharat ambassador.

“By doing so, we are not just creating awareness among the public, but also educating the students about solid waste management,” he said, adding that sanitary workers had been facing an issue or other while they do it on their own. The school has also come forward to carry out two mass cleaning activities per week based on the suggestions given by the public, he added.

About a couple of months ago, CRI pumps had adopted ward 28 at Saravanampatty and had distributed safety gears to the sanitary workers and conducted medical camps for them, he said, adding that another educational institution had shown willingness to adopt another ward.

Chief Swachh Bharat ambassador Shanthi Priya Powroji and founder and managing trustee of SSVM Institutions Manimekalai Mohan participated in the inaugural function.

Title: Mushroom cultivators in U’khand await govt push for market to grow
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Dehradun: Lack of infrastructure, skills and markets is hindering mushroom cultivation in Uttarakhand, claim mushroom cultivators in the Himalayan state, adding that despite the inherent potential that the edible fungi has, the state hardly has shops that sell mushroom seeds (spawns) and there are very few laboratories either which produce spawns.

Social entrepreneur Divya Rawat, who is also hailed as the ‘mushroom lady’ of the state, for motivating and training many people to take up mushroom cultivation, told TOI, “The state has no shops that sell spawns and many of those engaged in mushroom cultivation in the state do not have technical knowledge. Also, the farmers don’t have markets to sell their produce.”

Notably, there are two types of mushrooms cultivators in the state — seasonal producers (small units) and all-season producers (controlled units). According to government data, there are 25 controlled units in the state and around 225 small ones. The regions which lead in mushroom cultivation are Haridwar, Dehradun, Pauri and Tehri as per government data.

According to Sanjay Kamal, chief mushroom development officer of Uttarakhand, the Himalayan state is the sixth largest mushroom producer state in the country and production here can be increased if alternatives of wheat chaff like mungretha, chingura and mandua chaffs are made available.

HNB Garhwal Central University’s professor RP Bhatt said, “There are over 65 species of edible wild mushrooms that grow in Uttarakhand which could be used commercially but no authority is working to expand this market. Our scholars are researching on the possibilities of cultivating wild mushrooms as these are expensive.”

Meanwhile, Subodh Uniyal, state agriculture and horticulture minister, when queried on what is being done to expand the mushroom market in the state, told TOI, “The government provides 50% subsidy on spawns and fertilisers. We also provide free training to mushroom cultivators in different parts of the state. Under the ‘Integrated Horticulture Project’, the state government will set up a Centre of Excellence for Mushroom where research will be done on increasing the quality and quantity of our mushroom produce. We will start the facility as soon as the World Bank approves the fund for it. Our department’s main objective is to double farmers' income in the state.”

Title: nCoV: 50 under home quarantine in Madurai
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A total of 50 people who had travelled from China to India are under home quarantine for novel coronavirus (nCoV) for at least 28 days in the district.“We have asked them to avoid going to public places having a lot of crowd such as shopping malls at all cost. We’re following up with visits and calls every day on the status of their health,” said Dr P Priya Raj, district deputy director of health services. She also emphasized that the 50 people, who are being monitored, are only ‘passengers’ and that no one is showing any symptoms of illness.Health officials are also creating awareness among public, especially in schools, both about nCoV and practicing regular washing of hands and cough hygiene.Assistant city health officer of Madurai Corporation Dr S Vinodh Raja said that hoardings have been erected at urban primary health centres to create awareness. “Visitors to hospitals are made to clean their hands using hand sanitizer while leaving the hospitals. An advisory has been sent to all hospitals, theatres and malls to erect standees insisting people to wash hands for at least 15 times a day,” he said.Meanwhile, in Tuticorin, district collector Sandeep Nanduri told reporters that all measures are in place to prevent spread of nCoV. “We have a special unit for screening sailors, especially those from China, at our sea ports in case anyone has any symptoms of the illness. Four people from the district, who had travelled from China, are being closely monitored by the health officials. There is no need to panic as so far there has been no sign of anyone suffering from nCoV in the district,” he said. The collector also said that the Tuticorin Government Medical College Hospital has set up special nCoV isolation ward fully equipped to handle nCoV cases.

Title: Gujarat: Officials move to set up Bapu experience for US President Donald Trump
Content:
US President Donald Trump. (Photo: AFP)

GANDHINAGAR: On Tuesday, Gujarat government officials visited the Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram to explore an itinerary that can be suggested to US President Donald Trump ’s team in case his visit — with Prime Minister Narendra Modi — is confirmed. Sources in the general administration department were tight-lipped. But it is expected that PM Modi will personally escort Trump through the ashram and the recently inaugurated Charkha museum within the ashram campus.The year 2020 marks 90 years of Gandhiji’s famous Dandi March that began from the ashram on March 12, 1930. Almost three decades later, in 1963, Gandhiji’s march had inspired Dr Martin Luther King Jr to lead the famous non-violent civil resistance in the US. King had organized ‘March over Washington’ as part of his campaign.King had visited the ashram on March 1, 1959, with his wife Coretta Scott King. They spent a day at the ashram. King also visited a few places on the Dandi route that year. King’s close associate, James Farmer Jr, visited the Ashram in August 1980 as part of the US consulate delegation. Farmer had led the Congress for Racial Equality. A staunch devotee of Gandhiji’s non-violent strategies, Farmer planned the historic Freedom Rides, which led to interstate travel desegregation. He was introduced to Gandhiji’s Satyagraha while at Howard University in 1941. In February 2009, King’s son Martin Luther King III visited the ashram as well as Gujarat Vidyapith to commemorate the 50th anniversary of his father’s visit.“As of now, there is no official communication from the state or the central government about Trump’s visit,” said a senior Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram official. A senior government official added, “Indian diplomats have suggested that the US president wears traditional Indian dress during his visit to the ashram, as Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau did.”

Title: Changes in train services for maintenance
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: The Madurai railway division has announced the following changes in train services due to track maintenance and other safety related works.

Train no. 56624 Madurai – Palani passenger will be fully cancelled from February 12 to 29. Instead a passenger special will run on those days from Madurai at 6.30am and reach Palani at 10am with the scheduled stoppages of the regular train.

Train nos. 56769/56770 Palakkad – Tiruchendur – Palakkad passengers are cancelled between Sattur and Tirunelveli on February 10, 11, 14, 15, 17, 18, 21, 22, 24 and 25. They will be cancelled between Madurai and Tirunelveli on February 12, 16, 19 and 23.

Train nos. 56734/56735 Sengottai – Madurai – Sengottai passengers are cancelled between Virudhunagar and Madurai from February 10 to 25 (except Thursdays).

Train nos. 56319/56320 Nagercoil – Coimbatore – Nagercoil passengers are cancelled between Thiruparankundram and Dindigul from February 5 to 25 (except 6, 11, 13 and 20) and between Sattur and Dindigul on February 11.

Train nos. 56721/56722 Madurai – Rameswaram – Madurai passengers are cancelled between Paramakudi and Rameswaram from February 13 to 29 (except Sundays).

Train nos. 56829/56830 Tiruchchirappalli – Rameswaram – Tiruchchirappalli passenger are cancelled between Manamadurai and Rameswaram from February 13 to 29 (except Sundays).

Train nos. 56822/56821 Tirunelveli – Mayiladuthurai – Tirunelveli passengers will be cancelled between Dindigul and Trichy on February 7, 10, 12, 14, 17, 19, 21, 24, 26 and 28 and March 2 and 4.

Train no. 56320 Coimbatore – Nagercoil passenger will run 50 minutes late in Madurai division area from February 15 to 24, except Thursdays. Train no. 56826 Tirunelveli – Erode passenger will run 115 minutes late in Madurai division from February 12 to 29, except Sundays.

Train no. 56822 Dindigul – Mayiladuthurai passenger will run 50 minutes late in Madurai division on February 13, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25, 27 and 29. Train no. 56769 Palakkad – Tiruchendur passenger will be handed over to Palakkad division late by 120 minutes on February 12, 16, 19 and 23.

Title: Ganja worth Rs 40L seized in Ganjam dist
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Berhampur: Over 1,900 quintals of ganja worth around Rs 40 lakh were seized from Dengaosta under Digapahandi police station limits in Ganjam district on Monday night . The driver of the pick-up van in which the narcotic substance was being illegally transported, was arrested on Tuesday.

He was identified as Biswaranjan Biswal of Puruna Sasan under Balianta police station limits in Khurda district, said sub-divisional police officer (Chikiti) S N Murmu. He was the only person in the vehicle during the raids, he added.

The ganja was being illegally transported from Mohana in Gajapati district to Puri, when police seized the contraband during night patrolling, said the SDPO. The contraband was packed in 60 gunny bags with each weighing around 30 kg. “We are probing to zero-in on the main accused,” he said.

This was the second major seizure of ganja after January 4, 2020. On that day, around 800 kg of ganja was seized near Dasanapalli Chhaka under Aska police station limits.

Title: Utkal starts process to fill up 118 posts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The premier Utkal University started the online application process to fill up 118 vacant posts of assistant professors, associate professors and professors on Tuesday. March 4 is the last date to file online applications. Printed copy of the application should reach the university by 5 pm of March 11.

The university has been facing an acute shortage of guides for research scholars in the last five years with 44% of faculty posts, mostly at the senior level, lying vacant. Vacancies have also affected teaching.

Altogether 30 professors, 42 associate professors and 46 assistant professors will be recruited for different departments. The institution has 119 vacant posts against 257 sanctioned teacher posts. One director-level post will be filled up later, said Dayanidhi Nayak, the registrar. In June, the ministry of human resources development cautioned that it will revoke Rs 100 crore grant given to Utkal University under Rashtriya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan scheme unless it recruits teachers against more than 100 vacant posts.

Title: ‘Mobile armour will thwart Pulwama repeat’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

LUCKNOW: The Indian defence forces may get a powerful ‘armour’ to protect their personnel from any Pulwama-type terror attacks in the future.

This would be made possible with the introduction of indigenous armoured protected fighting vehicle that can provide side blast protection against 50kg of TNT explosives. A prototype of the vehicle, named ‘Kalyani M4’ and currently in trial stage, will be on display at the Defence Expo in Vrindavan Yojana .

The need for such vehicles for the defence personnel was felt after a suicide bomber blew up a convoy of Central Paramilitary Reserve Force (CRPF) in Pulwama of Jammu and Kashmir in February 2019, killing 40 soldiers, said Baba Kalyani, the chairman of Bharat Forge Limited — the maker of this unique and indigenous vehicle in the country. Addressing a press conference in Lucknow on the eve of Defence Expo, Kalyani said their focus is now on manufacturing lighter products to facilitate easy movement of troops. Keeping this goal in mind, Bharat Forge is producing various lighter products, including a super light artillery gun, he added.

Hailing the upcoming defence corridor in Uttar Pradesh , Baba Kalyani stressed on increased participation of private sector defence manufacturing companies in the project. Bharat Forge has signed an MoU with UP government for setting up an ammunition factory in the state under the defence corridor project. The company has also scouted some locations in Jhansi to set up the factory.

Col(retd) Rajinder Singh Bhatia , CEO of Bharat Forge, said one of the greatest challenges in combating terror is ensuring the safety of the security personnel and ‘Kalyani M4’ would be of immense importance in such situations

Title: Man gets 10 years jail for abetting wife’s suicide
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The mahila court in Tuticorin on Tuesday awarded 10 years jail to a 34-year-old conductor of the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) after he was found guilty of abetting the suicide of his wife. The incident took place in the victim Gomathi’s house in Tuticorin in June 2014.

Special public prosecutor (SPP) of the mahila court V Subashini said Gomathi had got married to her maternal uncle’s son Murugan in May 2010 and the couple was residing in the house gifted to them by her mother in Rajiv Gandhi Nagar.

“Murugan repeatedly harassed Gomathi mentally, saying she is not beautiful,” the SPP said and added that the couple frequently quarrelled over these. “On June 24, 2014, Murugan left the home in the morning, saying that she should end her life before he returns or else he will kill her. The woman took the extreme step by dousing hersel.”

Title: Nithyananda Case: Gujarat high court moved for CBI probe in Nithyananda ashram case
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nithyananda

AHMEDABAD: The father of the two girls allegedly missing from the Nithyananda ashram , on Tuesday approached the Gujarat high court seeking transfer of investigation into his complaints to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI). The complainant’s main contention was that the central agency would be better placed to investigate and coordinate with Interpol because the prime accused Nithyananda and his two daughters are not in India. Local cops would find it difficult to investigate his complaints.

The complainant express dissatisfaction with the investigation, which has culminated in a chargesheet, by Ahmedabad rural police. He claimed that the investigation was not carried out in a neutral manner. It is by handing the probe over to CBI that lacunae in the local police’s investigation can be filled.

The complainant also demanded further investigation because the evidence gathered by police with regard to illegal confinement of children and the missing girls was not enough, the petition said.

The HC may take up this petition later this week.

On January 17, Vivekanandnagar police filed a chargesheet against the two ashram administrators, Harini Chelappan alias Pranpriya and Riddhi Ravikiran alias Priatatva, and showed Nithyananda as an absconder. Police have had Interpol issue a blue-corner notice against Nithyananda and have obtained an arrest warrant from a local court.

The two administrators, who are behind bars since the registration of the FIR in November, have been accused of illegally confining children, abusing them and putting them to labour.

Title: Kagaz king: Amid NRC jitters, AMC’s records genie to retire
Content: Ahmedabad: Over the past three decades, Jayanti Chanduji Thakore, 60, has been the genie at the civic body’s central birth and death registrar’s office in Danapith. Thakore manages to extract the exact register from millions of musty and dust-laden records stacked at the office since 1932.But now this lone oracle of the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), an office assistant, is retiring in February leaving this highly shortstaffed department of 10-odd personnel shaken and overwhelmed.The reason is that over the past nine weeks, people from across the city have begun to rush for their and their parents’ birth verification. People want to have the documents ready before officers verifying birth and death records for the National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the 2021 census come knocking at their doors.This department is staffed to solve 20-odd queries a day; queries have risen to 115 to 140 a day since mid-December.“People often break down when they don’t find their records in our digital archives, fearing that they won’t be able to make it into the NRC,” said a senior clerk at the office. “Seeing them in pain has been disheartening for us over the past few weeks. In such cases, Jayantikaka comforts and reassures the families by pulling out the right register. No one can pull off a miracle like he does.”Thakore explains the complexity of municipal record-keeping. “Ward boundaries have changed with each election delimitation,” Thakore said. For instance, prior to 1953, registers for Dariapur and Madhupura were one. Then in the 1960s, they were separated. Later, a new ward — Kazipur Dariapur — came into existence. Many of the records dating between 1932 and 1979 stacked together are in tatters. Small chunks of paper pieces lie strewn on the department’s floor as they are repeatedly brought out for verification.“If you tell me the year and the month of your birth, I can get the relevant ward file,” Thakore said. He gives the example of Gheekanta area, where records are scattered across Kalupur-3, Khadia, and Shahpur wards. Then there are supplementary records which are extensions of registers in which incomplete birth or death details were amended.“For births that have taken place before 1973, we look up ward records. For births that have occurred after this year, we look up hospital records even before referring to details in ward registers,” Thakore said. He is now worried for the poor who cannot pay the minimal charges for re-registering or hiring lawyers for court procedures. A senior officer at the registrar’s office explained that panchayat records of newly inducted areas such as Vastrapur, Jodhpur, Bodakdev, Mithakali, and Sola have made many mistakes in surnames and father’s names. “A birth and death record cannot go wrong and that is the pressure we deal with in each verification query,” Thakore said.

Title: Odia film director under cop scanner
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Famous Ollywood director Dilip Panda has landed in trouble after a CCTV footage featuring his alleged unruly conduct in a restaurant in Kharavel Nagar here on Sunday went viral on social media on Tuesday. The restaurant owner, Sitanshu Mishra, lodged a complaint against Panda in Kharavel Nagar police station on Tuesday.

While police are verifying the charges and examining the CCTV footage, Mishra demanded an appropriate legal action against Panda. Mishra alleged that Panda along with three others arrived at his restaurant after it had shut around 10.30 pm.

“Dilip Panda entered my restaurant in an inebriated state. He ordered food. My staff politely said the restaurant is closed as it was 10.30 pm. Panda flew into a rage and started threatening my staff by brandishing a knife. Panda also thrashed my staff,” Mishra told media persons.

Mishra’s cook, Maheswar Mohanty alleged that the Ollywood director heckled him and threatened him of dire consequences if he did not prepare food for him. “He shouted at me and picked up a knife from our hotel. He threatened to stab me. They left the restaurant after creating nuisance for several minutes,” Mohanty said.

Panda dismissed the allegations. “I was not drunk. I am a regular visitor to the restaurant. On Sunday night (around 10.30 pm), I and three of my friends visited the restaurant and asked for food. The hotel staff asked whether we would have chicken biryani. In view of bird flu, I requested him to serve some other dish,” Panda said. The director alleged that the restaurant staff misbehaved with him. The staff hurled abuses at me and asked me to leave the hotel. “I picked up the hotel’s knife to help the cook chop onions and not to stab him,” said Panda.

Title: A year after killing, two brothers booked for murder
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

BAREILLY: A year after the suspicious death of a man, police have filed an FIR under sections of murder against two brothers , after the viscera report confirmed the victim had been poisoned.

Rajendra Prakash Bhargava, a resident of Izzatnagar in Bareilly , went missing on February 25. Two days later, his dead body was recovered from a guava orchard. The reason of his death couldn’t be ascertained in the autopsy, and the viscera were sent for lab test.

Police have booked Santram and his brother Ayodhya Prasad in this case but none of them is arrested so far.

Bhargava was a clerk in the district administration’s cane department. He went missing after leaving for office on February 25. On February 27, his body was recovered but since there were no injury marks on the body, prima facie it appeared he had died of some illness. However, his family alleged he was murdered by Santram and his brother over a property dispute so the body was sent for autopsy.

After the autopsy failed to confirm exact cause of death, viscera samples were sent to the forensic lab in Lucknow, whose report was received by police recently, after which FIR was registered on the complaint of victim’s daughter Anu Bhargava .

According to sources, both brothers booked by police are land mafiosi and share good rapport with influential politicians of Bareilly. Many complaints against them are pending because of their political influence, and officials refrain from taking any step against them.

Izzatnagar SHO A K Verma told TOI, “We’ve filed an FIR against two persons under IPC sections 302 (murder), 328 (causing hurt by poisoning) and 120B (criminal conspiracy). We have started investigating this case and the accused have been informed about the complaint against them. None of them will be arrested at this moment, because we are trying to identify if the victim was poisoned by them or by someone else. Action will be taken as per law.”

Title: Schools struggle to keep proper hygiene
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: In the wake of the spread of the deadly novel coronavirus (nCoV) across the world, the health department and district administration are emphasising on washing hands with soap as one of the major modes of infection control and prevention. Among the primary target audience are school students who are given hand wash lessons.

But effectively bringing it to practice to tackle spread of the disease in city schools have to go a long way. Speaking to TOI, Madurai district chief education officer R Swaminathan said that adequate steps are taken to keep schools clean though there were still no particular instructions in relation to nCoV.

Under Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan scheme, funds are allocated as school maintenance grant to maintain toilets clean and keep the campus hygienic. “It includes providing soaps and facilities for hand washing,” he said. A government school teacher claimed that they used 10% of the grant to maintain toilets clean and ensure that students have adequate soap and water to wash their hands.

“We try our best but cannot force every last child to follow,” added the teacher. Several government, aided and corporation schools admitted that despite the funds provided they would run short of soaps, hand wash solutions and even cleaning solutions for toilets. “Either teachers are forced to spend money from their pockets or sometimes sponsors step in to provide such supplies,” said the headmaster of a corporation school.

Principal of a private school in Anna Nagar admits that “it is highly impractical to provide soaps through the year because of the large population. It is already a struggle to provide adequate water through the year in the toilets.”

Title: IIT-Madras to showcase cutting edge defence tech
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Lucknow: Breakthroughs in Ramjet projectile technology, the science which drives BrahMos missile system, will be showcased by a team from Indian Institute of Technology-Madras (IIT-Madras) at DefExpo-2020 which kicks off in the city on Wednesday.

“We are on the verge of a breakthrough in Ramjet technology for incorporation in artillery projectiles. If all goes well, we will be able to double the range of attack. This will make a substantial difference in India’s combat capabilities,” professor of practice Lt Gen (retd) PR Shankar from the department of aerospace engineering, IIT-Madras, told TOI.

He has also served as director general of Indian Artillery. Defence sources said IIT-Madras is likely to unveil a potentially revolutionary concept of 155mm Ramjet-powered pseudo-missile shell that can hit targets more than 70-80km away.

Sharing details of the technology, Lt Gen Shankar said, “Most engines convert chemical power into motion. Power is generated when chemical mixture of oxygen and fuel is compressed and ignited. Power generated on combustion propels motion. Normal fuels have significant amount of oxygen while the remaining part is igniting agent.” Adding that the ratio of oxygen and igniting agents is related to the range of an aircraft or jet, he said: “Whenever oxygen content in the fuel is reduced or increased, the range goes up or down. Ramjet is about carrying fuel rich propellants devoid of oxygen to use atmospheric oxygen to burn fuel.”

He said in defence sector, Ramjet-powered artillery was of cutting-edge technology. “What makes our effort significant is that it is made in India. The breakthrough can cut India’s expenditure on imported Ramjet missiles by up to one-fifth,” he said.

IIT-Madras will also showcase indigenous multi-role expendable UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles) and next generation fire control network which will ensure that all guns and missiles in an area work in synergy to produce a force multiplicative effort.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal dares BJP to reveal CM candidate
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Challenging BJP to declare its chief ministerial candidate, AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday said that people want to know whom they are voting for before polls are held on February 8.Kejriwal, who is ready for an on-camera debate with BJP’s CM face, said if the saffron party doesn’t announce its chief ministerial candidate by Wednesday afternoon, then he will return to make an announcement.Since BJP and Congress have already released their election manifestos, Kejriwal feels there is a need for an extensive debate on the key initiatives by different parties. “What if BJP makes an uneducated and unworthy candidate the chief minister (after coming to power)?” he asked.“In a democracy, it is important to have a detailed debate and discussion on the key initiatives addressed by different parties in their manifestos. People should be able to ask questions and give opinions on the key poll promises. I would like BJP to declare its chief ministerial candidate and I will challenge him to a debate with me,” Kejriwal said after unveiling AAP’s manifesto at the party’s headquarters.In the past, BJP had gone to polls with a CM face, but avoided it this time. Congress has also not announced a chief ministerial candidate. Because of this, AAP has been trying to take a political high ground. AAP has been questioning the absence of BJP’s CM face on multiple platforms and asking the saffron party, “Kejriwal versus who?”Underlining the importance of a CM candidate, Kejriwal asked how would people vote for a party if they didn’t know who would be leading it. “Amit Shah said that he will decide the CM face after BJP is voted to power. But the real power to decide the CM lies in the hands of the people. Shah cannot claim this right as per the Constitution,” Kejriwal said, adding that every vote for AAP will go to him, but every vote for BJP will be wasted.BJP slammed Kejriwal for his remarks and said that in a democracy people vote for MLAs, who elect the chief minister. “AAP is a one-man show, but BJP is a party of millions of workers. This election has turned into one between an anarchist and the nationalist people of Delhi who want a government that works for five years for their welfare and not just a few months before elections,” said Delhi BJP functionary Praveen Shankar Kapoor.East Delhi BJP MP Gautam Gambhir at a rally on Monday had said, “AAP says Kejriwal vs who? I want to say it is Kejriwal vs the truth.”

Title: Will fix broken roads in four months, says Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday said that Aam Aadmi Party was determined to work for the welfare of Delhi. Addressing an election rally in Narela , which is a part of North Delhi constituency, Kejriwal promised to fix all roads there within four months of being re-elected as the chief minister.He also vowed to ensure round-the-clock supply of water in the area. “Aam Aadmi Party has worked relentlessly to make Delhi a better city and we promise to make it even better for all of you... during the last five years, we improved the quality of schools...in the next five, we pledge to make the capital cleaner,” Kejriwal said.Targeting the BJP-served municipal corporations, the CM said that Delhi had become “very dirty” and promised to clean it up so that “everyone leads a comfortable life. We are concerned about you and your needs...We will make sure that by the next elections, Yamuna is so clean that you don’t have to go all the way to Ganga for a holy dip. I will take all the people of Narela to take a dip there”.The CM claimed that if BJP won the elections, it would end all welfare schemes started by the Aam Aadmi Party government. “BJP functionaries have been saying that they will stop everything that’s given for free to the citizens. If you want that to happen, you should vote for them...Else, vote for us. We have worked towards improving education, power, health and transport, offered free bus rides to women... the list is endless. And, we pledge to continue working like that in the next five years,” Kejriwal said.“Till the time I am with you, I promise that all your needs will be taken care of by your son, like they have been in the last five years. We will change the face of this place and make it more liveable,” he added.“I want that the people who support BJP and Congress should also see the work that AAP has done in the last five years and vote for our party this time. I am not asking for votes for my selfish reasons. I want everyone to vote for progress,” he said. “I have worked for the welfare of every citizen, keeping aside which party you supported in the previous polls...but, this time, everyone should side with a party that will help you progress.”Kejriwal concluded his speech by saying that the citizens of Delhi had created a special kind of bond with him and now they should vote for AAP again, so that they could take forward their relationship.As the CM left for his next stop — Bhajanpura — men, women and even children danced to the tunes of the party’s anthem, “Lage Raho Kejriwal”.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Work of five years, legacy and nationalism in 3-way clash
Content:
Kapil Mishra

NEW DELHI: BJP’s Kapil Mishra, formerly of AAP, is not new to controversies, but his recent provocative comments on Shaheen Bagh protests have added further spice to a triangular contest in the North Delhi constituency of Model Town. Mishra is pitted against sitting AAP MLA Akhilesh Pati Tripathi, who is aiming for a hat-trick of wins here, and Akanksha Ola of Congress.The constituency has a diverse mix of electors: while Model Town and Kamla Nagar are primarily inhabited by trader and business communities, Gulabi Bagh and Rana Pratap Bagh are home to lower middle class residents and slum dwellers.Tripathi bagged 38,492 votes in his win in 2013. In 2015, he did even better, garnering 52.4% of vote share at 54,628. He sought to strike a chord before the elections. “I have worked a lot in the last five years. People here have accepted me like a family member and I am committed to fulfilling the vision of CM Arvind Kejriwal,” he said.Calling himself a “100% work MLA”, Tripathi said while other states were in turmoil, Delhi’s economy was faring well because of the work done by AAP government. “This government has worked for the youth, providing scholarships and free coaching to them; for women, by installing CCTV cameras and giving them free bus rides; and for the elderly, by increasing their pensions and launching the free pilgrimage scheme,” he added.Promising a tough fight to Tripathi is Ola, who is the daughter of three-time Congress MLA Kanwar Karan Singh, who, incidentally, was at the receiving end in the 2015 polls.“My father is my identity and I am his shadow. I have been working with him since I was 21 years old and people know me well. He accompanies me for my padyatras and door-to-door campaigning,” she said, adding “the good work done by my father under Sheila Dikshit is remembered by all.”Ola alleged that five major infrastructure projects started by her father had come unstuck during Tripathi’s tenure. “Roads, sewer lines and parks have not been maintained,” she claimed.In a similar vein, BJP’s Mishra said that the government machinery had “completely collapsed”. He said: “This government has done nothing but blame the Centre, corporations and neighbouring states.” Calling for a “new vision”, Mishra said he would work towards improving the basics in the area, which, according to him, were ignored by AAP government.In a clear bid to polarise voters, Mishra had recently compared the February 8 elections with an India-Pakistan match. He had claimed that the protests at Shaheen Bagh against the citizenship law were Pakistan sponsored. Tripathi attacked Mishra by stating that “his statements prove that he has lost his mental balance”.BJP’s move to field Mishra, an MLA from Karawal Nagar, has been questioned by rivals and locals alike. Jaspreet Singh, a shopkeeper in Kamla Nagar, said: “We haven’t seen him in our area. He is not from here.”Ola agreed. “I can’t comment on why BJP gave him a ticket in Model Town. Perhaps, he didn’t do any work in Karawal Nagar. People who can’t ask for votes on the basis of their work will talk of India-Pakistan or Hindu-Pakistan,” she said.Mishra countered: “The public will respond to these questions. I was born in Gupta Colony and studied in DU. Those who have no work of their own can rake up these issue to get votes.”

Title: District-level sports meet held for disabled people
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: A district-level sports meet organized by the Sports Development Authority of Tamil Nadu (SDAT) was held for differently-abled people at Dr MGR Sports Stadium, Race Course in Madurai on Monday.

The meet which kicked off at 8 am saw enthusiastic participation by people with disabilities in Madurai and surrounding areas. Around 25 sports events were held under different categories which was inclusive of people with various disabilities.

The day-long meet included both team events like volleyball, throw ball, kabaddi and individual athletic events like track events, long jump and shot put. Over 500 participants took part in the event of which around 250 of them were women. TNN

Title: Chennai to get Rs 462 crore to clean up air, check flooding
Content:
File photo of stranded residents being evacuated by boats

CHENNAI: Four Tamil Nadu cities – Chennai, Coimbatore, Madurai and Trichy – with more than one million population each have been allocated Rs 556 crore for cleaning up their air and handling solid waste management.The 15th Finance Commission ’s recommendation, which has been accepted by the Centre, is for the next financial year. In all, Rs 5,344 crore has been allocated to local bodies in the state for 2020-21. Out of that, Rs 1,737 crore is for urban local bodies. Chennai will receive the maximum assistance of Rs 362 crore.The commission has also separately allocated Rs 100 crore to Chennai to prevent flooding in the city. “A targeted allocation of Rs 500 crore has been made in 2020-21 from the National Disaster Mitigation Fund (NDMF) to enable cities with a population of more than 5 million to prepare integrated solutions for flood management in view of the regular incidence of flooding, leading to heavy loss. Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata will get Rs 100 crore each in the coming financial year,” said the interim report of the commission presented in Parliament on Saturday.The commission has provided grants to all three tiers of panchayats in rural local bodies and also to cantonment boards in urban local bodies.“While 50% of grants to rural local bodies are untied, the remaining 50% will be tied as grants for sanitation and water supply which are identified national priorities. For rural local bodies, no conditions have been prescribed for getting the grants in 2020-21. However, from 2021-22 onwards, the entry level condition for rural local bodies getting these grants is timely submission of audited accounts,” said the report.For the first time, the finance commission has differentiated cities into million-plus cities and those with less than one million population.Larger cities have a tendency to grow faster. Grants are provided to 50 million-plus cities on agglomeration basis with special emphasis on meeting challenges of poor air quality, ground water depletion and sanitation. “For non-million-plus towns, 50% of the funds are untied and the remaining 50% is tied, with an equal share for drinking water and sanitation,” the report said.The commission has not recommended any conditions for urban local bodies in 2020-21, but has recommended two entry-level conditions in the subsequent years. Apart from timely submission of audited reports, the urban bodies will have to increase their own revenue.The commission has recommended that states make allotment of grants on the basis of population to the cantonment boards within their territories. The report has identified two cantonment boards in Tamil Nadu — St Thomas Mount in Chennai and Wellington in The Nilgiris district which have a total population of 63,257 people.

Title: Teachers, students hail scrapping of board exams
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The school education minister’s announcement scrapping board exams for Class V and VIII on Tuesday saw teachers and students from several schools in Madurai celebrate their relief by distributing sweets.

Teachers, students, parents and activists alike welcomed the government’s decision. Minister for school education K A Sengottaiyan in a circular has said that the department has withdrawn the order passed last year to conduct board exams for Class 5 and 8 from this academic year. “The decision has definitely removed the mental pressure of students. Education is not something to be forced upon students, but rather a natural process in which everyone deserves a chance. We have always seen many achievers who may have done poorly in academics,” said a government primary school teacher.

The SFI celebrated the announcement by distributing sweets. “These board exams would have increased the number of dropouts and many young children would have been forced into child labour. Similarly, it would have also forced girl children into marriage at an early age. Though it was promised that students would not fail, mental pressure would have been there in families,” said Vel Deva, SFI district secretary.

On the other hand, the Private Schools Correspondents Confederation (PSCC), an association of private schools affiliated to the state board, pointed out that such random and arbitrary announcements cause immense harm to the children’s education system. “In future, any decisions taken by the department of school education should be done in consultation with the stake holders and any changes should be announced at least a year before its implementation,” said Senthilnathan M, president, PSCC.

Teachers and educationists said that if such board exams were a test of quality of teachers in government schools, then teachers need to be appraised with a different system rather than just experience.

Title: Bullet train a ‘white elephant’: Uddhav Thackeray
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Uddhav Thackeray

GANDHINAGAR: The Gujarat government reacted sharply to remarks by Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray about the bullet train project, terming Thackeray ’s comments as `negative’ and `unfortunate’. In an interview, Thackeray called the bullet train project a white elephant , saying a decision on it would be taken after he was convinced it would boost the industrial development of Maharashtra.

“Who will benefit from the bullet train? How will trade and industry in Maharashtra get a boost because of it? If it is useful, convince me and then let’s go before people and decide what to do,” Thackeray said in the interview. He added, “We have to see what is urgent and not take up something because we are getting a loan at zero interest or low interest. We acquire farmers’ land for no reason and then look after these white elephants. This is not right.”

Deputy CM Nitin Patel, who is also the government spokesperson, in Gandhinagar said, “The Maharashtra CM’s remarks on investment in the bullet train are unfortunate. Uddhav Thackeray needs to understand the project and its benefits for the country. The project will not only help thousands of commuters who travel between the two states, but it will also bring more investment and jobs to both states.” Patel added that instead of spreading negativity about the project, Uddhav Thackeray should correct his statement.

Referring to the bullet train project, which has faced opposition from farmers and tribals whose land is to be acquired, Thackeray said there should be a comprehensive discussion on its viability. Of the 508.17km bullet train corridor, 155.76km will be in Maharashtra, 348.04km in Gujarat and 4.3km in Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

Title: BMC may relocate dairies located in five Bareilly wards
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Around 800 small and big dairies are currently operating within the city

BAREILLY: The municipal corporation is planning to shift dairies that are operational in five wards under Bareilly Municipal Corporation ( BMC ) to some other location, considering the cattle menace and civic problems being faced by residents.

Around 800 small and big dairies are currently operated within the city. The civic body is planning to shift dairies from five city wards — Azam Nagar, Rampur Garden, Siklapur, Gandhi Udyan and Naumehla. According to BMC, these wards are worst affected with clogging of drains and pits, frequent waterlogging and garbage due to the dairies.

Sanjeev Pradhan, environmental engineer, BMC, said, “BMC is considering shifting dairies in five wards — 9 (Naumehla), 20 (Azam Nagar), 32 (Gandhi Udyan), 57 (Rampur Garden) and 64 (Siklapur) — which were identified on the basis of the seriousness of civic issues faced by residents and commuters. We are yet to identify the alternative place for shifting these dairies, but most likely, they will be relocated to some place in the city outskirts.”

Locals and commuters alleged cattle waste from the dairies is discharged directly into local drains or disposed along roads, making it difficult for both group of people. Shubham Singh, a resident of Rampur Garden, said, “Cow dung is discharged into our drains, clogging them, causing waterlogging after even mild showers.”

Biharipur resident Aabid Husain said, “With dairies operating in city limits and residential areas, there is a cattle menace on roads, which often brings traffic to halt, when cattle strays in groups on prominent city roads. They also injure people sometimes.”

According to BMC, there are around 800 small and big dairies, including illegal ones, functional across the city, including areas such as Sanjay Nagar , Joginavada, Biharipur, Choupla, Baankhana, Civil Lines, Subhash Nagar, Madinath, Swale Nagar, Gulab Nagar , Premnagar, Cantonment, etc.

Title: Village nurses get trained to diagnose cancer early
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Madurai: Highlighting the importance of early diagnosis in treatment and prevention of breast and female genital cancers, a workshop was held at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) for village health nurses (VHNs) from across the district.

During the workshop held as part of ‘World Cancer Day’, the nurses were sensitised about breast and female genital cancers like cervical and ovarian cancer, which are easily preventable if diagnosed in the early stages. Doctors from the Department of Surgical Oncology at the GRH addressed nearly 200 participants, including VHNs and tutors from the school of nursing at GRH, on breast cancer, female genital cancers and myths surrounding cancers in women.

“Cancers in women can be cured completely if diagnosed early. Awareness is required at the grassroot level which is why we conducted this workshop for VHNs. We trained them to look for symptoms of cancers in women, on how to conduct a breast examination and other techniques that help in early diagnosis,” said Dr M Ramesh, Head of the Department of Surgical Oncology at GRH.

The participants were asked to watch out for some of the common symptoms of female genital cancers and breast cancer like an unusual white discharge or bleeding in the vagina, unexplained lower back pain and heaviness of the abdomen, and painless lumps in the breast.

The GRH performs around 1,000 oncology-related surgeries per year while close to 3000 patients undergo medical treatment for cancers in a year.

Title: Trichy: Idol wing seizes idols in Pudukottai, 4 held
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The idol wing CID team recovered five panchaloha idols and an altar and arrested four smugglers from Keeranur in Pudukottai district on Tuesday. The seized goods is worth around Rs 20 crore in the black market.

The arrested have been identified as Vellaisamy, Aravind, Kumar and Mathiazhagan. Search is on for four more people in connection with the smuggling bid.

Speaking to TOI, idol wing CID ASP R Rajaram said they had laid out a trap for the smugglers. “We received information that Mathiazhagan is in possession of a Vinayagar idol and was attempting to sell it for Rs 3.5 crore. The idol wing CID team reached his place in Keeranur in the early hours of Tuesday and nabbed him,” he said.

The team then went to Vellaisamy’s place and recovered idols of temple deities Somaskandar Sivan, Sivakami Amman, Parvathy Ammanm Manikavasagar and an altar.

“During investigation, it came to light that the arrested were attempting to sell the idols for Rs 20 crore. We are in search of four more accused in this case,” said Rajaram.

A case has been booked under five sections of the Antiquities and Art Treasures Act, 1972. The idol wing is trying to ascertain the temples that these idols belong to.

Title: In times of climate change, schools chant ‘cli-fi’ mantra
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CHENNAI: Cli-Fi or ‘ climate fiction ’ are books presenting the real science behind climate change to readers. Interestingly, several schools in the city are slowly incorporating them into their curriculum , teaching students current climate effects and what the future may hold if they do not protect it.

“Children enjoy reading novels and when they read novels on these subjects, they pay more attention to climate change and work on it,” said Srinivasa Raghavan, principal of Bala Vidya Mandir.

Novels like ‘The Great Derangement: Climate Change and the Unthinkable’ by Amitav Ghosh, ‘The Year of the Flood’ by Margaret Atwood, graphic novel Snowpiercer, which talks about the last remaining members of humanity travelling on a train after the earth succumbs to treacherously low temperatures, are among those that have made it to middle and high school classes in institutions like Vael’s, Arsha Vidya Mandir and some others.

“After reading the novel, we also watched the movie ‘Snowpiercer’ and discussed the challenges we’ll face if we ignore the current climate crisis,” said Ankita T, a Class VIII student of Vael’s Billabong and a big fan of climate activist Greta Thunberg. “For next week, our teacher has asked us to read Greta’s latest book ‘No One Is Too Small to Make a Difference’, so that we learn and improvise on her ideas of global warming and climate change.”

Srinivasa Raghavan explained that reading such novels inculcates a better understanding of climate change apart from the routine tree planting or cleanliness drives. “It makes children imagine and think about the ‘what-ifs’. This is an important genre and we see our children make sustainable choices in their daily lives,” he said.

The cli-fi classes are held at least twice a week for Classes V to X. Every week, children are prescribed a climate fiction novel by teachers, which they bring to class, read and discuss with their peers. After reading, they are given a project work. The initiative was begun recently and schools are happy with the response.

At the Hindu Primary School, students were asked to create a model of how the earth would look if it was filled with garbage and there was no water, based on the children’s books they were asked to read. “They came up with interesting ideas and conclusions, showing barren and abandoned lands, with no life forms,” said S Raja, the school principal.

The students, however, are not marked for these classes and projects, as teachers fear they would otherwise lose interest. “More than imposing, we want to gradually inculcate reading habits and make them aware of their surroundings, their planet, though it’s mandatory to read one cli-fi book a week,” he said. He pointed out that many children have stopped wasting water, whether leaving the taps open in toilets or watercoolers, and he also finds them picking up waste from roads and disposing it in bins.

However, most schools still do not discuss climate change, as teachers say it’s outside their subject area.

“But it’s not the answer. We need to discuss, especially with the younger generation,” said Arun Krishnamurthy, founder, Environmentalist Foundation of India. He said many times schools do not take up such innovative methods because of parents’ pressure. “Parents only want their children to score marks, and because of this schools are unable to go a step forward and help children learn. We need an overall change in attitude — right from, parents, teachers and even school managements. They need to know that climate change is real,” he said.

Title: UK doctors learn unique surgical techniques from Melghat
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Indian doctors are known world over for providing optimum health care despite problems like dearth of surgical devices, shortage of medicines and geographical challenges. Hundreds of doctors from England got first-hand experience of the skill sets of Indian doctors between January 30 and February 1, when Dr Madan Kapre and his team performed 115 major surgeries in Chikhaldara , in the foothills of Melghat .

Conducting an international thyroid surgical workshop in Chikhaldara is an annual exercise for Nagpur-based Head and Neck Foundation, Indian Society of Thyroid Surgeons, and Rotary Nagpur South for the last 27 years. This year’s workshop was special as, for the first time, it was live webcast to three locations, one of them being St Mery’s Hospital of Imperial Healthcare College in London.

“We perform all surgeries here for free. From last 19 years, it has also become an academic event. Doctors across the country participate in this surgical workshop and learn thyroid surgery techniques,” said Dr Madan Kapre, who has been leading the initiative for last two decades.

Prof Neil Tolley, from the department of thyroid surgery, Imperial College, attended this workshop as international faculty some three years ago. He was impressed with the way complicated surgeries are conducted in limited resources here, and still top-class results are achieved. He decided to live telecast the surgeries in his college.

“Several ENT, endocrine and surgical oncologists had gathered specially to witness the Chikhaldara magic in London. Prof Tolley was coordinating with Dr Abhishek Vaidya from our team in this live two-way transmission,” Dr Kapre added.

UK doctors were especially impressed to see the technique of cervical epidural anaesthesia, where thyroidectomy is performed while the patient is still awake. This was demonstrated by Dr Vidula Kapre. Dr Madan Kapre demonstrated his unique technique of thyroid surgery. Prof Devendra Mahore, Dr Neeti Kapre and Dr Rajendra Deshmukh ensured smooth running of the operation theatre.

Dr Tulsidas Bhilavekar took responsibility of all post-operative and follow-up care of the patients. Pathology team under the guidance of Prof Sadhana Mahore, anaesthetists Dr Shubha Deshmukh and Dr Pratibha Deshmukh contributed towards the peri-operative management of patients. Eklavya Ekal Vidyalay teachers identified and motivated tribal people to take advantage of this project funded mainly by the state forest department.

Title: Every voter in Delhi is like a chief ministerial candidate for us: Amit Shah
Content:
Amit Shah

NEW DELHI: Blaming AAP for creating a riot-like situation in the capital, where hundreds protested against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens and buses were burnt, Union home minister Amit Shah on Tuesday said that the party couldn’t control the situation or keep the capital safe.“Narendra Modiji brought CAA to provide citizenship to our brothers and sisters who were persecuted in the neighbouring countries, but Kejriwal says BJP cares about Pakistanis. Are these Hindus and Sikhs who are coming back Pakistanis? You (Kejriwal) can consider them whatever you want, but they have the same rights here as you and I,” said Shah.Alleging that AAP provoked the minorities and Muslims by telling them that their citizenship would go away, Shah said, “No one will lose their citizenship as CAA aims to grant citizenship. They (AAP) caused riots in Delhi. Didn’t everyone see that? For two days, Delhi was burning. Buses, cars and bikes were all burning. Delhi was in a crossfire. Will Delhi remain safe if these people return to power? No, they are not capable of keeping Delhi safe. Only Modiji can keep Delhi and the country safe.”Speaking at a jan sabha in Delhi Cantonment constituency in the evening, Shah hit back at chief minister Arvind Kejriwal stating that BJP didn’t need to rely on a single “chief ministerial face”. “Do you all want to know who the chief ministerial candidates are? Every voter in Delhi is like a chief ministerial candidate for us. We don’t need to rely on just one face,” he added.Shah was speaking in favour of BJP candidate Manish Singh, a former Armyman. He was accompanied on stage by MP Meenakshi Lekhi.Describing Kejriwal as a roadblock in the development of Delhi, Shah said the CM was stopping the filing of the chargesheet in the “tukde tukde” gang case and he was likely to cause problems even in the Sharjeel Imam case.“This roadblock can be removed if you have us (BJP) in power in the capital. It will be like a briefcase with three digits to open a lock. You have put Modiji in two of the three locks, but the briefcase of development will not open if you put Kejriwal in the third slot,” said Shah.The minister said on February 8, it won’t be an election between different parties, but different ideologies. “On one hand, there is a nationalist party who entered the homes of our enemies. One the other, Kejriwal and Rahul Gandhi are shamelessly supporting Shaheen Bagh for vote-bank politics. We are not afraid of their vote bank,” added Shah.

Title: Budget could revive long-term demand, no short-term relief likely
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: Disappointed with no clear booster measures to revive the slowing economy in the Union Budget, industry experts said that while the budget may help improve long-term demand, there is little short-term relief likely.

Hiranand Saviani, CFO, Astral Polytechnik Ltd along with Sanjay Shah, CEO, Prudent Corporate Advisory Services Ltd, Piruz Khambatta, CMD, Rasna Pvt Ltd and Nitin Parekh, CFO, Zydus Cadila Healthcare Ltd, were present at a panel discussion, ‘Unboxing Budget 2020’, organised by HDFC Bank Spectrum in association with The Times of India, in Ahmedabad on Tuesday. The panel discussion was moderated by Sunil Parekh, senior industry advisor and founding curator of AGS, an initiative of the World Economic Forum.

“The budget doesn’t meet short-term demands in terms of increasing consumption. The industry had expected solid steps to boost consumption. One way of doing this was reducing goods and services tax (GST) rates to make products available at a lower cost to boost consumption, which in turn would have encouraged industry and investment,” said Nitin Parekh. “What has been done in the name of economic development will certainly have fruits, but in the time to come,” he further added.

Shah said, “The NBFC crisis is one big reason for slowing demand. If the NBFC issue was addressed, it would have helped boost consumption.”

Khambatta felt that measures taken in the agriculture sector would certainly benefit FMCG growth.

Title: Tharu women learn about poultry to raise their income
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BAREILLY: Central Avian Research Institute ( CARI ) in Bareilly has launched a project for socio-economic uplift of women hailing from the tribal Thuru community by teaching them about rearing poultry. Six Tharu villages of Lakhimpur district have been chosen for the project under the tribal sub-plan of Indian Council for Agriculture Research .

The project is aimed at making women self-reliant. Scientists at CARI have provided chicks and grain to the Tharu women and educated them about scientific ways of rearing the birds. The chicks provided to these women are a cross of native chicken and improved chicken. The project has been introduced at Bela Persua village, Dhakhaini village, Shastripurwa village in Nighasan block and at Persiya village, Saunaha village and Poya village in Palia block of Lakhimpur Kheri district.

Sanjeev Kumar, principal scientist, avian genetics and breeding division, CARI, told TOI, “We first conducted an awareness camp at these villages and found that only a few families had hens, which were left to eat whatever they got. In the second phase, we distributed four- to-five-week-old chicks to women and gave supplements to the beneficiaries so that it would last for four weeks. We told people that it is necessary to give at least 25% supplement to chicks for better productivity. We created awareness among them on scientific ways of rearing chicks and how it can help them in earning more money. We will check the body weight of chicks after a few weeks to see if they are being reared in the right way or not.”

Sandeep Saran, principal scientist, agri-business incubation centre, CARI said, “The agri-business incubation centre will introduce the technology to these beneficiaries for their economic gain. We will encourage them to become entrepreneurs and produce more eggs and chicks by developing low-cost hatcheries.”

Other scientists who are part of this project are Chandradev, principal scientist of the feed processing division, and Divya, principal scientist of the nutrition division.

Laxman Rana, head of Persiya village, said, “Our village is situated on the outskirts of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve and most of the families living here come from poor backgrounds. As CARI has provided a good variety of chicks and explained about methods of rearing poultry, we are hopeful that it will be profitable for tribal women.”

Ganga Devi, one of the beneficiaries and a resident of Persiya village, said, “We are family of five with three small children. We were entirely dependent on farming on a small plot of land but we believe that if we expand poultry farming, we can generate more income.”

Title: Charminar Corrosion: Experts blame acidic gas for Charminar corrosion
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

File photo of Charminar in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: With Charminar being named among monuments that are most vulnerable to air pollution by the Centre, experts said that acidic gas was primarily responsible for corrosion of the monument.

While cautioning against alarm, Milan Kumar Chauley, superintending archaeologist, ASI, Hyderabad, said, “Lime is essentially calcium, which turns brittle when it reacts to water and pollutants. While lime mortar can last up to 800-1,000 years, its strength diminishes with exposure to nature.”

In Charminar’s case, Chauley said, “The impact of pollutants can be seen on the stucco work and outer layers of the monument where lime has been used exclusively. The lime plaster has peeled off at several places and stucco work has fallen due to pollutants and natural elements.” The main structure itself remains intact, he said. Incidentally, a chunk of lime mortar from the South west minaret fell last year.

Air pollution expert, Sagar Dhara, said acidic gas, such as sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide, can cause a lot of corrosive on monuments. “If lime is part of the structure, the gas oxidises it, causing blackening and deterioration.” He said that monuments, water bodies, vegetation and even humans’ mucous membrane can get damaged because of oxidisation.

Stating that vehicular pollution remains the primary source of acidic gas in the city, he said burning of garbage and pollutants released from power plants are other major sources. Last year, NOx (oxides of nitrogen) levels near Charminar were the highest in May at 47.8 ug/m3, as per data available with Telangana State Pollution Control Board. Though well within the range of around 80 ug/m3 considered satisfactory in India, Dhara says the figure is high and would be considered so by international standards. “Acidic gas can travel far with the wind, corroding everything on the way,” he said.

The Charminar area saw high levels of particulate matter above 10 microns (PM10) last year. The figures touched 155 ug/m3, higher than 100 ug/m3, which is considered a satisfactory standard. This type of pollutant also comes from industrial and transport sources.

Simplifying the effect of pollutants on heritage structures, conservation architect, SP Anchuri said, “Buildings breathe because they are porous in nature. The superstructure is corroded when pollutants distress monuments. They also decrease the strength of bonding material, leading to cracks.”

Speaking about what can be done to protect our heritage, Anchuri said, “Periodic simulations must be carried out to check the impact of pollutants. Traffic limitations around monuments are necessary and the use of different fuels or non-motorised vehicles may minimize the effect of pollutants that can travel vast distances.”

Title: Tantrik tricks five women into marriage, 'forces two of them into flesh trade'; probe ordered
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

BAREILLY: A 47-year-old man, a ‘ tantrik ’ (an occultist) hailing from Shahjahanpur , allegedly tricked five women into marriage in different cities and “forced two of them into prostitution”. When one of his wives came to know about his marriage with the other four women, she allegedly committed suicide in Kanpur.

After the tantrik’s first wife, 32, a resident of Mainpuri district, and the third wife from Nigohi lodged a complaint with deputy inspector general of police ( Bareilly range) Rajesh Pandey , the DIG ordered Shahjahanpur senior superintendent of police (SSP) Shivasimpi Channappa to probe the matter and take appropriate action. “It’s a sensitive matter. I have ordered the SSP to take strict action in accordance with the law,” said the DIG.

The accused, who is at large, has been booked under sections 498 (enticing or taking away or detaining with a criminal intent a married woman), 376 (punishment for rape), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt) and section 495 (marrying someone without disclosing the fact of his second marriage) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) at the Nigohi police station. The two women were sent for a medical examination on Tuesday.

Tantrik’s first wife told TOI, “We got married in 2005 and we have a 10-year-old son. Only a year after the birth of our son, my husband forced me to leave his house and married another woman. Left with no option, I took shelter at my parents' house and lodged a police complaint against my husband.

"However, a few months ago, I came to know about my husband’s third marriage in Nigohi. When I met his wife, she told me that he forced her into prostitution. When we further investigated, we were shocked to learn that he married two more women in Kanpur and one of them (the fourth wife) had committed suicide.”

“After knowing the truth, I contacted other wives of my husband and an FIR was lodged at the Nigohi police station, but police didn’t take any action. Meanwhile, our husband was repeatedly threatening us of serious consequences, forcing us to withdraw the case. This is the reason why we met the DIG in Bareilly. We believe police will arrest my husband and take appropriate action against him,” she added.

Nigohi police station SHO Indrajeet Bhadauria told TOI, “The accused is a tantrik, and doesn’t stay at one place. He is absconding, but we will arrest him soon.”

Title: Cancer in India: 1 in 10 Indians to get cancer in lifetime
