Content: NEW DELHI: One in 10 Indian will develop cancer during their life-time and one in 15 Indians will die of cancer, says the World Cancer Report released by World Health Organisation (WHO) which has pointed out “socio-economic inequalities” as a major cause for the rapidly increasing burden of the disease in the country.Lower socio-economic status is associated with oral and cervical cancer while urbanization, improvement in education and increasing disposable income with higher overall socio-economic status are associated with an increasing risk of breast and colo-rectal cancer cases besides such lifestyle-related types.India had an estimated 1.16 million new cancer cases and around 7.84 lakh cancer deaths in 2018. The six most common cancer types are breast, oral, cervical, lung, stomach, and colo-rectal cancer. Together, these accounted for almost half (49%) of all new cancer cases.The report shows over 90% of patients with oral cancer have lower socio-economic status in India because non-awareness about harms of tobacco use is common among these people. Similarly, cervical cancer disproportionately affects women with lower socio-economic status, who have limited access to public health services for prevention and early detection. India accounts for about one fifth of the global burden of cervical cancer, despite decreasing incidence in several regions of the country.On the contrary, incidence of colo-rectal and breast cancer is increasing in the most developed states in India and in urban population.Experts say improvement in socio-economic status and urbanisation have led to sedentary lifestyle, more stress, less of breast-feeding, poor eating habits and higher prevalence of overweight and obesity – all of which are risk factors for breast cancer, colo-rectal cancer, uterine cancer and ovarian cancer.The report also shows households with high socio-economic status spend less on cereals, millets and vegetables and more on beverages, processed foods, dairy products, meat, eggs and fish.IT suggests “highly focused and tailored public health interventions” to target different socio-economic groups to reduce disparities in cancer prevention.The UN agency warned that if current trends continue, the world will see a 60% increase in cancer cases over the next two decades with the biggest increase (an estimated 81%) in new cases in low and middle-income countries, where survival rates are currently the lowest.WHO pointed specifically at low socio-economic status, consumption of tobacco products and poor child and maternal health along with limited health resources for combating infectious diseases as reasons for the rapidly increasing cancer burden. It also stressed on the need for health services to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer.“This is a wake-up call to all of us to tackle the unacceptable inequalities between cancer services in rich and poor countries,” said Ren Minghui, WHO assistant director-general for universal health coverage. “If people have access to primary care and referral systems, cancer can be detected early, treated effectively and cured. Cancer should not be a death sentence for anyone, anywhere.”

Title: Sarabhai or CAA? Speculation over cancelled convocation at NID
Content: AHMEDABAD: Four days before it was to host its 40th convocation, on February 7, the prestigious National Institute of Design (NID) cancelled the event citing ‘unforeseen circumstances’. Miffed students and many faculty members see two possible reasons for the unexpected move: inviting well-known danseuse Mallika Sarabhai — a critic of Prime Minister Narendra Modi — as the chief guest; or the fear that the occasion would be used to show solidarity with anti-CAA protesters. At Cept University , a leading planning and architecture institute in Ahmedabad, students had sported black armbands while receiving degrees at the convocation on January 28.Several NID students had participated in the anti-CAA stir in Ahmedabad in December at various venues. Sarabhai was part of some of those events.A graduating student from Bihar, who did not wish to be named, said that students have heard rumours that the event was cancelled because Sarabhai had been invited. “But I personally believe that the authorities did not want a repeat of Cept convocation episode,” the student said. “That could be a big mistake; it could trigger impromptu protests.”The student said that a large number of students are coming to the campus because they did not get the message in time or could not cancel tickets. “This has irked them all,” he said. “While all students are not part of the anti-CAA movement, the cancellation has showed how the institute’s authorities are bending over backwards to ensure that it remains immune to protests.”The authorities informed students about the cancellation of the convocation on Sunday. Tarun Deep Girdhar, the student activity chairperson, mailed the students on Sunday afternoon invoking the ‘unforeseen circumstances.’More than the cancellation of the big event of their lifetime, the abrupt manner of scrapping has angered the students. In all, 318 students were to graduate at the ceremony.In 2016, Sarabhai had criticized the PM for not condoling the death of her mother, Mrinalini Sarabhai, a Padma Vibhushan awardee. Sarabhai wrote a post on Facebook stating: “My dear Prime Minister. You hate my politics and I hate yours. That has nothing to do with what Mrinalini Sarabhai did to promote the culture of this country, to the world over sixty years.”Sarabhai has been a vocal critic of Modi since he became the chief minister of Gujarat in 2001. She had filed a PIL in the high court against the Modi-led state administration over the 2002 riots and had organized protests against the BJP government.The state police had filed a case against Sarabhai for illegal trafficking of Indians to the US, allegedly taking people there as members of her dancing troupe. However, the courts had given a clean chit to her.Praveen Nahar, the NID director, could not be reached for comment. Sarabhai too could not be contacted despite repeated attempts.A few faculty members told TOI that the move was sudden and few knew about it before Monday. “Once, the chief guest was changed because the original invitee could not attend,” said a faculty member. “However, the event was not cancelled.” Accompanied by parents, students come to their alma mater — NID campuses in Gandhinagar and Bengaluru — for their big day, said the faculty member.Students plan to approach the authorities on Wednesday for clarifications. A faculty member said, “In the worst case scenario, the students may get degrees by post.”

Title: Elevated road: Jaipur Development Authority set for property owners’ rehabilitate
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The 2.3-km Jhotwara elevated road will ease traffic in one of the most congested areas of the city and provide... Read More

JAIPUR: To expedite construction of Jhotwara elevated road project, the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) will soon initiate the long-pending process to rehabilitate affected property owners.

During an inspection on Tuesday, the Jaipur Development Commissioner (JDC) directed the officials to remove the structures which are hampering construction work. The civic body will shift Fauji Kacchi Basti from the construction site to Anand Lok I constructed under the basic services to urban poor scheme.

According to an official, 17 slabs and 15 piling works are scheduled to be carried out this month. Thirty girders till Ambabari will be installed.

“A review meeting of the project will be held in every 15 days to resolve the issues and expedite the work,” said the official.

Sources in JDA said that 604 structures will be demolished for construction of elevated road. The JDA has proposed to rehabilitate affected shop owners of Jhotwara on the government land situated in Jhotwara Industrial area. The JDA has decided to relocate them to Niwaru Road and Kalwar Road. The 2.3-km Jhotwara elevated road will ease traffic in one of the most congested areas of the city and provide relief to over 6 lakh residents. However, the continuous delay is mounting the problem of the residents as they face long traffic jams daily.

An official source at JDA said, “The foundation stone of the project was laid on July 2 and deadline set for December 2020. Looking at the progress of the project, it looks nearly impossible to meet the deadline. The project is expected to be delayed by a year.”

In 2016-2017 Budget, the BJP government had announced the construction of elevated road to give relief to commuters travelling in Phalna’s Jhotwara region. The project is crucial as the narrow flyover has become a major bottleneck. As no land is available on either side, the JDA is left with no option but to construct an elevated road.

Title: Press lotus button to free Delhi from anarchy: PM Modi
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday said that February 8 was not a “chhutti” (holiday), but a day to send those who engaged in anti-national politics on leave (rashtra-virodhi rajneeti karne walon ki chhutti karne ka din).

Addressing a rally in Dwarka, Modi urged people to press the lotus button on Saturday to make “Delhi safe”, free it from “anarchy and violence” and turn it into a “21st century word-class capital”.

Taking a dig at AAP, Modi said BJP didn’t believe in working only before polls. “Some begin working just six months before the elections. We start at the beginning itself... Haven’t you seen how fast we are moving (after the 2019 general election victory)?”

In a nearly hour-long speech, Modi mounted an attack on the “ruthless AAP government” for obstructing central schemes meant for the poor, while drawing up a long list of projects that were executed by the Centre and others that were in the pipeline. “No matter what political differences you have, how can anyone even think about obstructing schemes meant for the vulnerable? What vikrit maansikta must they have to do this? Here’s a ruthless government that doesn’t worry about your lives,” he said.

Modi asked if a Delhi resident fell ill outside the city, would AAP move a mohalla clinic there to treat that person.

Modi also blamed Delhi government for delaying work on Metro’s Phase IV.

He said Delhi needed a government that empowered the nation and “stands by our brave soldiers” and not ones “who weaken us and give an opportunity through their statements to our enemies to target us”. Seeking support on issues of “national interest”, such as CAA and Article 370 abrogation in J&K, the PM said: “For selfish motives and appeasement, they (opposition) are instigating people. These people can weep for terrorists of Batla House. They can raise questions over our security forces, but can’t develop Delhi”. He added: “Delhi can’t be developed by vote-bank politics, of hate and wrong intentions.”

The PM said that the next decade would belong to India and its progress would depend on the decisions taken now. He projected the elections as a fight between decisive and obstructive sides, adding that Delhi needed a government that gave it “direction” and not excuses.

Modi credited the Centre with regularising 1,700-odd colonies and promised that a separate board would be set up for their holistic development. He said the Centre had developed modern infrastructure in form of peripheral expressways and Delhi-Meerut Expressway, apart from setting several projects in motion like rapid railways, metro expansion, and so on.

In an indirect swipe at AAP, the PM said: “They use indecent words for police while we honour 33,000 martyrs by setting up a memorial. We are working on creating a one-nation-one-ration-card to help Delhi’s poor. Yaha ration card banwane ko lekar kaisi kaisi samasya thi, I don’t even want to talk about them.”

He claimed that the Centre had transferred over Rs 10,000 crore to people of Delhi through various schemes.

Title: Samples of 3 with China connect taken for coronavirus test
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

BAREILLY: The health department on Tuesday evening collected samples of three people who are suspected to have contracted novel coronavirus (nCoV-2019). Two suspected patients are from Bareilly and one from Pilibhit . The samples will be sent to a laboratory in Lucknow.Of the two suspected cases whose samples have been taken in Bareilly, one person is a city-based industrialist who returned from China on January 12. Officials said another person, who is a native of a village under Sheeshgarh police station in Bareilly district, is a farmer in New Zealand and returned to India on January 17. His flight had a changeover in China. Similarly, a 55-year-old woman from Pilibhit’s Puranpur had travelled to Canada but she had to switch her flight in China.According to officials, the state government had provided a list of 47 persons to the health department in Bareilly who had returned from China in the last one month. When rapid response team constituted to deal with novel coronavirus contacted these 47 persons, it found that a few people were out of station while two persons were suffering from fever and cough.Additional chief medical officer, Bareilly, Dr Ranjan Gautam, said, “According to the guidelines of World Health Organization and health ministry, we have collected samples of two persons who travelled to China and had fever. Both claimed that they are fine but samples have been collected as a precautionary measure. They have been asked to stay at home in quarantine and not to venture out.”Both persons were called to the district hospital in Bareilly for collection of samples in the laboratory here. The samples that have been collected of suspected cases are nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs and sputum as per the provisions of WHO. It will be sent to Lucknow on Wednesday through official vehicle.Additional director (health), Bareilly division , Dr Rakesh Dubey, said, “The samples were collected as these two persons had fever after they arrived from China. The test report is awaited to know if they are infected with the virus or not.” He added, “There is nothing to panic about because all fever cases are not of coronavirus.”Chief medical officer, Pilibhit, Dr Seema Agarwal, said, “We have collected sample of a person as she stayed at an airport in China for changeover of flight and she has cough since January 26.”Meanwhile, experts said people can reduce the risk of coronavirus by cleaning their hands with soap and water or alcohol-based hand rub and should cover their nose and mouth when coughing and sneezing with a tissue. They should also not reuse handkerchiefs or tissues. People should avoid close contact with anyone with a cold or having flu-like symptoms. There should be no unprotected contact with live wild or farm animals and people should thoroughly cook meat and egg.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: First suspected coronavirus case in Ahmedabad
Content:
A 28-year-old woman from the Ambli area became the first suspected case of coronavirus in Ahmedabad on Tuesday... Read More

AHMEDABAD/GANDHINAGAR: A 28-year-old woman from the Ambli area became the first suspected case of coronavirus in Ahmedabad on Tuesday. The woman has been quarantined at an isolation ward in Asarwa Civil Hospital, after being referred from a private hospital on SG Road on Tuesday evening.The state government sent seven samples of suspected coronavirus patients to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune for testing. Four have returned negative, while the results of three are awaited.On the woman quarantined at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital, a senior hospital official said, “We are yet to gather details on the case. The woman has shown symptoms associated with coronavirus and was thus screened by the private hospital. She was immediately sent to Civil Hospital. Her biological samples have been collected and sent to the NIV in Pune.” The official added, “Her condition is stable, and she is under observation.”Asarwa Civil Hospital in the city is the nodal centre for coronavirus and a ward has been earmarked for quarantine. City health officials said they will get details on the woman’s travel history, and if needed, advise her relatives to undergo check-ups.“There is no positive case of coronavirus in Gujarat. Those with suspected coronavirus are under observation. We are taking all preventive measures. We are going to start holding video conferences with community leaders in the state to create greater awareness,” principal secretary, health, Jayanti Ravi said.State health commissioner Jai Prakash Shivhare said, “Till Tuesday evening, after screening 769 passengers who had returned from China, Singapore, Thailand and other coronavirus-affected countries, we sent seven samples to NIV to test for coronavirus infection. Four have returned negative and the results of three are pending,” he said. Shivhare added that the samples of the woman admitted to the Asarwa Civil Hospital had also been sent to the NIV.Emphasizing that there is no need for people to panic, Shivhare said all passengers arriving in the state from China and other countries are being screened. “Through data-sharing with the government of India, we are also screening passengers arriving in Gujarat from other countries via Mumbai, Delhi and other cities in India,” he said. Shivhare added that directions from the Union government on coronavirus are being followed on a daily basis through video-conferencing.As of Tuesday evening, India had recorded three confirmed cases of coronavirus, all from Kerala.

Title: Manoj Tiwari promises pucca houses to all
Content:
DIFFERENT STROKES: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari joined a group of children at a jhuggi in Delhi Cantonment for... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari was in for a surprise on Wednesday when he saw that not more than 300 people had gathered to attend the rally scheduled in Delhi Cantonment He, however, promised to shift them all to pucca houses in two years if his party was voted to office.Addressing the gathering there, Tiwari claimed that his party would solve all the problems faced by the local residents.“BJP, in the past five years, made sure that the garbage was cleaned up regularly in the area. Our workers also ensured availability of mobile toilets for the convenience of everyone,” he said.“Delhi chief minister says that every place in the city has electricity and water supply. Someone should just go and tell him that some places are still devoid of these two basic necessities,” he added.Tiwari then spoke about “Jahan jhuggi, wahin makaan” scheme, promising all the slum dwellers pucca houses close to their shanties.“All your worries will end if all of you have a two-room flat with access to electricity, gas connection and water at all times. Won’t these things make all of you happy? AAP government was elected from here last time but the face of this place has not changed a bit,” he claimed.“This is Army land. We will give you the houses but that will happen in the next two years. Please do not expect us to deliver on this promise immediately after being elected,” he added.He concluded the speech by singing his song, ‘Rinkiya ke papa’ and immediately went on to play cricket with the kids there. Seeing the bad state of the willow the kids were playing with, he asked his team to gift two bats to the children there.

Title: HC lifts stay on Shiv Enclave housing scheme
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Jaipur: A day before lottery for the Shiv Enclave Housing Scheme was to be drawn, the Rajasthan High Court lifted the stay on the scheme. A revenue court had earlier stayed the scheme saying that the title of the land was not clear.

The high court on Tuesday, however, gave the decision in JDA’s favour. The scheme is among the most popular ones in recent times, as JDA received 47,000 applications for it. The lottery will be drawn on Wednesday. tnn

Title: KMC shortlists architects, surveyors for building plan nod
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Sources in the Kolkata Municipal Corporation buildings department said civic authorities will officially recog... Read More

KOLKATA: If you have a three-cottah plot and want to build a house on an area not exceeding 500 square metres, get hold of an architect or a licensed building surveyor (LBS) who will be empowered to sanction plans for the building under a special civic scheme.

Sources in the Kolkata Municipal Corporation buildings department said civic authorities will officially recognize the credibility of a section of architects or LBSs who have never been booked for flouting rules.

Initially, the department bosses have decided to select 20 architects and 20 LBSs who will be empowered to sanction building plans under a special KMC plan. This will offer relief to land owners and a section of real estate developers from unnecessary hassles.

After series of discussions, the buildings department’s top brass will go through records of architects and LBSs empanelled with the civic body. “We have chosen the architects and LBSs based on their performance. They were evaluated based on whether they had ever faltered in ensuring a completion certificate for their clients in the last three years,” said a KMC building department official.

Once names of these 40 architects and LBS are notified, land owners or promoters want to avail a special KMC plan where instead of depending on the KMC building department, an architect or LBS could approve sanction of building plans in 30 days, could get hold of anyone of them and apply for sanction of their building plans.

A KMC official said the credibility of an architect or LBS depended on getting a completion certificate (CC) of an under-construction building from the buildings department to ensure that flat or land owners were entitled to all civic amenities like water supply, drainage connections provided by the KMC borough offices. “We often get flooded with complaints that without taking a CC, a promoter sells the flats, leaving flat owners in the lurch. Without a valid CC, we can’t offer water or drainage connections to a building,” an official said.

Title: Jaipur: Turbulence on ground over greenfield airport project
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

A file photo of Jaipur airport in Sanganer area. The greenfield airport project has been proposed near Shivdas... Read More

JAIPUR: Improper planning of the greenfield airport project by Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) has left many farmers near Shivdaspura area in the lurch.

Nearly two years ago, JDA had planned to acquire 2,094 hectares in 20 villages for the airport. Following the announcement, JDA had imposed a ban on land conversion and issuing of lease deeds in Shivdaspura. This has inconvenienced thousands of land owners who are not able to utilise their own land.

Former zila parishad member Ashok Mehta said, “The project is far from reality as there is no formal permission from the Airports Authority of India (AAI). The owners of the land in these villages cannot utilise their own land for other purposes.”

Farmers said in the city’s master plan 2025, these villages have been earmarked as a special area. The land use of these villages will be decided on the directions of the state government.

Ajay Singh, a land owner said, “After the change in regime, we submitted a memorandum to CM Ashok Gehlot but nothing has been done till date. For the past many years, the district lease committee (DLC) rates of the area have not increased. Farmers alleged that in Lok Sabha, civil aviation minister had replied that no airport was proposed in Shivdaspura. Still, the land was kept reserved.”

In 2018, the developers and locals had also submitted a memorandum to the Urban Housing and Development (UDH) department to regularise their land as the new airport still remained on papers. However, the developers were stumped after advocate general (AG) and committee constituted by the then UDH minister Shrichand Kriplani recommended state government not to regularise the reserve land.

“As per Section 54 (B) of Jaipur Development Authority Act, 1982 , there is a provision that land reserved for any project cannot be regularised even if it is not acquired. This was recommended by the AG and the committee constituted by the minister. The committee also mentioned that high court has banned regularisation of such land,” said an official.

Title: Devotees protest after BMC seals marriage hall of Banke Bihari temple for not paying taxs
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Bareilly: Committee members of Banke Bihari temple in Rajendra Nagar staged a dharna on Tuesday, after the tax department of Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) sealed the rear portion of the temple’s complex, a portion of which is used for commercial activities. The tax arrears of the complex amount to around Rs 60 lakh.

According to information from BMC officials, as soon as the team reached the spot and sealed the area, which is leased out for hosting weddings, scores of temple committee members gathered and staged a dharna near the premises.

Vipin Kuldeep, the zonal officer of BMC’s tax department, told TOI, “There is a space at the rear of Banke Bihari temple that is leased to wedding parties. Although spiritual places such as temples and mosques are exempted from paying tax, if a portion is used for commercial purposes, it becomes taxable. The wedding hall has tax arrears of around Rs 60 lakh for several years. Therefore, tax department sealed the place on Tuesday.”

Around 400 people, including temple committee members and devotees, gathered at the temple premises and sat on dharna against BMC’s move. Agitators also alleged the BMC team had misbehaved with people opposing the move.

The zonal officer retorted, “Protesters tried to create a ruckus, raised slogans against BMC for sealing the property and were demanding we remove the seal. Legal action was initiated after we were given directions by senior corporation officials for the same.”

Speaking to TOI, Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “The civic body has intensified its action against tax defaulters in the city, and have been regularly cracking down on those who have tax arrears. The space at the rear of the temple is being used for commercial activities, and has tax dues pending for several years. Though the seal has been temporarily removed, the concerned people have been directed to clear the dues at the earliest. If they fail to pay up, action will be taken.”

Title: History-sheeter carrying bounty of Rs 25,000 held in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative Image

BAREILLY: Bareilly police has arrested a history-sheeter wanted in nine cases of robbery and carrying a bounty of Rs 25,000 from Satyprakash Park in Quila area here on Tuesday afternoon.

Babua Majeed was arrested by inspector Manoj Kumar and his team, who also seized a country-made pistol and two bullets from him.

Babua was booked under the Arms Act.

Babua caught limelight after committing nine robberies in 2019, and police have been searching for him since then.

On Tuesday afternoon, police received a tip-off that Babua is in the city and planning a robbery. Police are questioning Babua for his involvement in other robbery cases reported in Bareilly recently.

Inspector Manoj Kumar said, “Babua operates many gangs. We are questioning him to identify his accomplices.”

Title: JMC to buy waste from ragpickers, give them ID cards
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: JMC has started its Material Recovery Facility (MRF) at Mathuradaspura landfill site where the waste collected by ragpickers will be recycled.

Under the project, uniforms and identity cards are being given to the ragpickers. Around 200 of them have already started working with the centre.

At the centres, JMC will purchase the waste collected by the ragpickers, who won’t have to travel to the city for the purpose.

Another MRF centre will soon be established at Sewapura landfill site.

Executive project engineer Banne Singh said the project has been designed keeping in mind the contribution of ragpickers in recycling and plastic waste disposal. “Right now these ragpickers are collecting plastic which can be sold to the dealers at higher rates. They usually collect plastic items which are big in size or heavy. They do not collect glass bottles, shoe soles or tyres. At the MRF centres, all kinds of dry waste will be accepted and ragpickers will be paid on the spot. This will also save time spent in travelling to the city and rule out middlemen,” said Banne Singh.

The MRF centres will be run by NGO Sarthak. This is the same NGO that has done similar work in Indore which ranked No. 1 in the country in Swachhta Survekshan 2020.

The MRF centres will have bailing machines, fatka machines and shredding machines that will minimize the size of the waste. “The bailing machines will compress the waste material in a sheet. Fatka machines will pack the waste in one packet and shredding machines will shred the plastic into small pieces. The plastic shreds can be utilised in cement sector. Machines have been purchased and they will start functioning soon. They will make our work easier,” Banne Singh added.

Moreover, medical camps will be organised for ragpickers to protect them from any diseases caused due to working with garbage.

Title: Garbage on MNIT campus catches fire
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Jaipur: Fire tenders rushed to Malaviya National Institute of Technology ( MNIT ) after receiving information of fire inside its campus on Tuesday morning. The incident occurred around 6.30am when a pile of garbage in the campus caught fire.

Around five fire tenders rushed to the spot and after around one-and-a-half hours of struggle, they were able to control the fire. The cause of fire is not yet known but some MNIT staffers claimed that it was caused due to accumulation of piles of garbage in the campus. Nandlal Kumawat, head of the non-teaching staff at MNIT said that for years, garbage is not being disposed of properly, and is being dumped inside the campus.

“Due to years of accumulation, the rear end of the campus looks like a landfill site. The place where garbage caught fire is situated near the non-teaching staff quarters. This would have been dangerous for us but the institute is not paying attention to it. There are 5,000 students studying at MNIT and last year, many students were found positive for dengue. Authorities should start focusing on the issue,” said Nandlal.

The authorities at MNIT, however, said that the cause of fire is not yet known.

Title: CA Foundation exam results declared
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) declared results for CA Foundation exam on Monday and as per the latest information provided by some local coaching institutes, the Nagpur chapter of ICAI has at least nine students in the top 50 list.

Since no official merit list is declared, the top three spots keep changing as per information coming in from local coaching institutes. Though TOI on Tuesday wrote about Tanvi Agrawal (AIR 25), who still continues to hold on to the top position in the Nagpur chapter, there are changes to the number two and three slots. Saachi Jaipuriya (AIR 30) and Akshat Agrawal (AIR 38) now join Tanvi to make the top three.

Speaking to TOI, Jaipuriya said “I was consistent at my studies and revised all the concepts on a regular basis. I tried my best to not get distracted while studying. I practiced the habit of not checking my phone and tried to stay away from social media.” Akshat Agrawal said “Time management is an essential factor that helped me prepare for my exams. Besides, I kept revising the notes on a regular basis and solved the mock test papers from the official cite. ICI Module helped me in preparation for the exams. Accounts and economics were a bit difficult whereas subjects like maths and law were easy to solve.” Saachi and Akshat’s guide from VPA institute, CA Vipul Vora said, “Question papers were above average but students with conceptual clarity could easily crack the examination.”

The next Chartered AccountantsFoundation Course exam will be held in the month of May. Candidates are advised to check dates depending on the format (new or old syllabus) they are appearing for.

Title: Second rally in two days, PM Modi focuses on national issues
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: “Desh badla, ab Dilli badlo” — so goes BJP’s election pitch. With the party going to polls without naming a chief ministerial face, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in the second of his election rallies on Tuesday, sought to strike a chord with the public on national issues.

The two rallies on successive days were also aimed at energising the party cadre. The Dwarka event was targeted at 20 assembly constituencies of West and South West Delhi. All the 20 candidates held lotus-shaped placards in their hands as they shared the stage with the PM. Local MPs Ramesh Bidhuri and Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma were also present.

Verma, having served a 48-hour ban for a provocative speech, raked up Pakistan yet again and attacked chief minister Arvind Kejriwal. “It is being alleged that we are making this election communal. I want to ask why the CM gave salaries to imams and assistants of mosques. He is reading Hanuman Chalisa now, but he wore a skull cap for five years... With defeat imminent, he (Kejriwal) is now remembering Hanuman Chalisa,” he said.

He added: “For five years, he kept saying LG and PM were not allowing him to work. Has Pakistan allowed him to work in the last six months?”

Bidhuri said he wanted to respond to Kejriwal’s question on who the CM face of BJP would be. “BJP has thousands of CM faces, but Kejriwal should ask why he has not made a single new school or college,” he said.

Chants of “Bharat Mata Ki Jai”, “Jai Shri Ram” and “Modi” rang in the air even as the different speakers took turns to woo voters. Speaking immediately after the PM arrived, BJP national president JP Nadda attacked AAP for not fulfilling its promises. “This is such a unique election where our competitors are using unadulterated lies in their campaigns. They failed on all their promises and have now found a new way of campaigning. Instead of carrying out jan sabhas where people can ask them questions, they are taking out roadshows,” he said.

Considering Dwarka’s proximity to Haryana border, Dushyant Chautala, deputy CM of the neighbouring state, was also present.

Title: Ambulance staff threaten strike over pay delay
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan Ambulance Karamchari Union has threatened to call a strike claiming they had not received their salaries for the past two months. The firm operating government ambulances in the state, however, denied the allegation claiming that they have credited the salaries on Tuesday.

Virendra Singh, ambulance employee union leader, said, 6,000 employees have not received salaries for the past two months.

However, GVK-EMRI claimed that they credited the salaries on Tuesday.

Title: ‘Reintroduce bill for proper utilisation of SC/ST resources’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

JAIPUR: Civil society groups have asked CM Ashok Gehlot to reintroduce the Rajasthan Scheduled Castes Sub-plan and Tribal Sub-plan Bill 2013 for ensuring proper planning, allocation and utilisation of financial resources meant for the SC and ST groups in the state.

Social activist Aruna Roy’s SR Abhiyan held a workshop here presenting a revised draft of the bill. The groups have demanded that announcement of the bill be made in the state budget.

The bill was introduced by Gehlot in 2013 but before it could be tabled his government, lost the polls the same year.

Nesar Ahmed of Budget Analysis and Research Centre Trust (BARCT) said after the central government and the state stopped the plan and non-plan classification of the budget, it resulted into inffective implementation of SC and TSP schemes.

“It has also become difficult to track schemes and one has to rely on the nodal department reporting made by the department concerned on the implementation of the schemes. The Act will make it mandatory for all the departments to spend budgetary allocation according to the norms and also ensures proper monitoring mechanism as suggested in the draft bill,” said Ahmed.

Underlining the importance of the Act, Ahmed said the state cannot achieve Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) until the vulnerable groups like SCs and STs are mainstreamed.

Dalit activist Bhanwar Meghwanshi said in the light of changes in the budget, it has become apparent for them to bring a law. “We will start a state-wide campaign to press for our demands to bring an effective law. In the absence of the law, the budgetary allocation for SC and TSP is losing its relevance and impact. Soon our delegation will meet Gehlot to remind him of the bill introduced by him in 2013,” said Meghwanshi.

Mukesh Goswami of SR Abhiyan informed that similar act are present in four states and government should introduced it as soon as possible.

Title: Car tow row: Insurance company refuses to pay for damage, police blame owner
Content:
Representative image

TimesView There are penalties laid down in the rule book for cars that have been parked illegally; damaging them while trying to tow them away is not part of those rules. Towing van staff should be careful while going about their job.

KOLKATA: Facing a repair estimate of Rs 80,000 for his damaged sedan, Baruipur film-maker Sanchayan Chakraborty on Tuesday shuttled between the repair workshop off EM Bypass and the Bidhannagar police headquarters, seeking reimbursement. Chakraborty’s insurance company has, prima facie, made it clear that he will not be reimbursed as the vehicle was damaged while being towed away by police from a no-parking zone. Chakraborty has urged them to reconsider their decision.Chakraborty, in his complaint to the police on Monday, said he had parked the car behind Bidyut Bhavan in Salt Lake’s DJ Block around 4.15pm and gone to the book fair. Around 7.45pm, when Chakraborty and his friend, Palash Haq, returned, they found the car was missing. They were informed by the Karunamoyee police outpost that the sedan had been towed away by cops. They found the car on the road in CJ Block, but its front portion was severely damaged.TOI sought an estimate from an expert who said, it would cost Rs 70,000-Rs 80,000 to repair the damage . “The front bumper, hood, grill, moulding, radiator, condenser and bumper beam need to be replaced. These will cost approximately Rs 80,000,” the expert said.Chakraborty alleged that when he went to the Bidhannagar East police station to lodge a complaint, an officer told him to pass it off as an accident. “I was told that if I lodged an accident complaint, I would be provided with an accident report, which, in turn, will allow me to claim compensation for damages. I refused,” he said. A senior officer said police will investigate if they receive a formal complaint.Cops, till now, have refused to shoulder any responsibility for the damage. “According to the Motor Vehicles Act, if any car is parked unattended in the no-parking zone, obstructing traffic, cops are authorized to tow it away. However, at times, the car may suffer damage during towing. Something similar might have happened in this case, but it was, after all, the car owner’s fault as he had parked in a no-parking zone,” an officer said.Negligent towing of vehicles is not uncommon in the city where people find designated parking spaces in prime areas, such as those around the book fair full on days like a holiday. Apart from damage to the vehicles, absence of a system to alert owners of the vehicles being towed away by the police compounds the matter further, an officer said.

Title: Goa News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Panaji: The foreigner who was placed in GMC’s isolation ward last week for suspected coronavirus infection, was discharged on Tuesday after she tested negative for the virus. The test reports for the other suspected case, an Indian man who was quarantined here last week, are still awaited. TNN

Title: Indian assault rifle giving stiff competition to latest Russian AK
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Even as the AK-203, the latest version of the dreaded Kalashnikov rifle, will be made in India in collaboration with the Russians, a comparable fully indigenous rifle has also been developed, and is already in use. The Indian weapon will be on display at the Defence Expo in Lucknow starting February 5. Known as the Trichy Assault Rifle ( TAR ), after Ordnance Factory Tiruchirapally (OFT), where it is made, the Indian rifle claims to be at par in terms of functionality with the Kalashnikov.

Information gathered by TOI says the AK-203 has an added feature of Picatiny rails, which can be used to fix reflexer or laser designator. Sources say the rails can be put in TAR too, and are basically add-ons. The TAR, which is made of solid metal, is also fundamentally said to be sturdier than the AK-203, which is made of sheet metal. Lately, there has been a shift to solid body in rifles in other countries too, said sources.

The AK-203 will be made at Ordnance Factory Korwa in Uttar Pradesh’s Amethi district by Indo Russian Rifle Private Limited (IRRPL), for the Indian army. The IRRPL, which is a joint venture between Russia’s Kalashnikov Concern and the Ordnance Factory Board (OFB), has a mandate to make over 7 lakh rifles. The agreement is an outcome of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to Russia last year.

Now as an inter-government deal has been struck between Russia and India, the Army would be going ahead with the Kalashnikovs. TAR, on the other hand, is being pushed for the paramilitary forces, which are already buying it. The deal gives a major boost Russia’s Kalashnikov Concern for entering the Indian market. OFB sees the TAR as the means to regain its trust, which it lost over the Insas rifle. OFB, which had drawn flak over its plan to corporatize the set up as a revamp move, is hoping to continue with orders from the paramilitary, with even the AK-203 being manufactured parallelly.

The production is to start in a year, as OFT has already begun making the TAR. This year, the factory has an order for nearly 40,000 pieces from the central paramilitary forces coming under the ministry of home affairs (MHA). CRPF is the major buyer.

A comparative analysis using data accessed by TOI shows that TAR, AK-47, and AK-203 have the same rate of fire at 600 rounds a minute, and muzzle velocity of 700 to 715m/s. All the three rifles can hit up to an effective range of over 350 meters.

The range depends on the length of the barrel and calibre of ammunition. The three guns have a barrel length of 415mm and use ammunition of 7.62x39 mm calibre. The ammunition will be made at the Ordnance Factory Warangaon, near Bhusawal, and will also be used for the AK-203 after it is inducted in the Army.

The range also meets the Army’s specifications for the assault rifle it needs, said sources. Even the picatiny rails that are in the AK-203, are being put in TAR on the basis of orders, a source said.

TAR was also offered to the Army initially, which had reverted with demand for a few corrections, said sources requesting anonymity. In the meantime, the gun was accepted by the paramilitary forces. TAR is now set to replace the Bulgarian AK-47 made by Arsenal Joint Stock Company, from where the paramilitary has been mainly sourcing its rifles.

Over 15,000 rounds were fired to test the TAR’s life cycle and over 2,400 for reliability, said sources. The trials were carried out at the CRPF Academy in Gurgaon after which a final approval was given. With more orders in sight, the ordnance factory is planning to increase production capacity at Tiruchirapally.

After the Army rejected the 5.56 Insas rifle, which was also used during the Kargil war, OFB preferred to eye paramilitary forces instead, said sources. Apart from operational issues reported in the Insas, the Army did not prefer it because Insas having a smaller ammunition of 5.56mm did not have the lethality, It would rather injure the enemy than kill.

Earlier, the Army had preferred the 5.56mm ammunition going by the theory that an injured enemy is of more use than a dead one. Later, considering the requirement in counter-insurgency areas, it was decided to have the 7.26mm round for which TAR was made.

IN A NUTSHELL

AK 203 is latest version of Kalashnikov rifles to be made in Inda

Indo Russian Rifles Private Limited (IRRPF), a joint venture between OFB and Kalashnikov Concern, formed as part of inter-governmental deal

This is part of deals signed after Prime Minister Modi’s Russia visit

Parallelly, Tiruchirapally Ordnance Factory has also developed its own assault rifle —TAR

TAR being suppled to paramilitary forces, and is set to replace imports from Bulgaria

TAR dubbed to be at par with Kalashnikov in terms of functionality

Title: Opposition pokes holes in state’s financial position
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Porvorim: Opposition MLAs are set to ask for a 30-minute discussion on the financial status of the state in the ongoing budget session of the Goa legislative assembly as they feel the state is on a borrowing spree and has entered a debt trap.

While they tried to bring up the topic during Question Hour on Tuesday, it could not be highlighted in totality due to paucity of time. The question, tabled by Goa Forward Party (GFP) MLA Jayesh Salgaonkar, came up for discussion a few minutes before Question Hour ended.

Later, speaking to reporters, opposition members said that they have been provided with different figures on the total debt of the state. “After studying various replies pertaining to state finances, we realised that we have been given different answers to the same question,” said opposition leader Digambar Kamat. “In one reply, the debt is Rs 20,412 crore; in another, liability has been shown as Rs 16,000 crore,” he said.

Kamat said the reply given to his question shows borrowings for 2019-20 to be Rs 1,767.8 crore, but to a question by Ponda MLA Ravi Naik, the figure for the same period was shown to be Rs 2,148.9 crore. The difference in the two figures, he said, could only be explained by the chief minister.

He further pointed out that revenue receipts are of Rs 8,475 crore and revenue expenditure Rs 8,100 crore, a surplus of Rs 375 crore. “The logical question is this, if there is a surplus, why is the government borrowing? It indicates that the figures are fudged,” he said.

GFP president Vijai Sardesai said that as per a reply given to the opposition, the capital expenditure was shown as Rs 859 crore, but it was actually spent on paying salaries. “This is blatantly illegal,” said Sardesai. “We wanted to expose the government today.”

He further pointed out that figures available with them show that the state has only Rs 400 crore to run the government till the financial year ends in March, but it has to pay Rs 767 crore to various contractors.

Salgaonkar pointed out that Goa’s share of Union taxes and duties has reduced drastically. It dropped from Rs 3,330 crore to Rs 2,480 crore, he said.

Title: Notices to 42 mining companies in a month: CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Of the losses, Lourenco said only around Rs 4 crore has been recovered

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant , who also holds the mines portfolio, told the Goa legislative assembly on Tuesday that 42 mining companies would be sent notices within a month for recovery of mining losses.

Sawant was responding to charges by Congress MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco during question hour.

“We will recover all mining losses as early as possible,” said Sawant. “Nobody will be spared. Notices to 42 mining companies will be issued within a month.”

Lourenco said BJP used to be in the forefront to accuse Congress of illegal mining, but that BJP itself has done nothing to recover the mining losses, pegged at Rs 35,000 crore by the Justice M B Shah commission report.

Lourenco said that the government has so far been able to only recover Rs 3.99 crore, and wanted to know when the total losses would be recovered. A committee of 16 chartered accountants appointed by former chief minister Manohar Parrikar had estimated the total loss to the state government on account of illegal mining at Rs 1,200 crore.

Lourenco had sought to know the total loss in revenue Goa suffered as a result of illegal mining.

While declining to reveal figures of mining losses, Sawant said that an exact number would be known once the SIT concludes its investigation. The investigations would be fast-tracked, Sawant said.

Nine cases were registered against various persons and companies for their alleged role in illegal mining, and there has been an acquittal in one case. Sawant said a revision petition has already been filed in the high court against the acquittal.

However, he declined to disclose names of persons and companies involved, since investigations are yet to be completed. Lourenco had wanted to know why the government hadn’t revealed names of the accused and complainants in nine cases. “Are they rape cases that you are not disclosing names?” he asked.

Title: Devotees protest after BMC seals Banke Bihari temple's marriage hall
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Temple committee members and devoteese sit on a dharna near the temple premises in Rajendra Nagar in Bareilly ... Read More

BAREILLY: Committee members of Banke Bihari temple in Rajendra Nagar staged a dharna on Tuesday, after the tax department of Bareilly Municipal Corporation ( BMC ) sealed the rear portion of the temple’s complex, a portion of which is used for commercial activities. The tax arrears of the complex amount to around Rs 60 lakh.

According to information from BMC officials, as soon as the team reached the spot and sealed the area, which is leased out for hosting weddings, scores of temple committee members gathered and staged a dharna near the premises.

Vipin Kuldeep, the zonal officer of BMC’s tax department, told TOI, “There is a space at the rear of Banke Bihari temple that is leased to wedding parties. Although spiritual places such as temples and mosques are exempted from paying tax, if a portion is used for commercial purposes, it becomes taxable. The wedding hall has tax arrears of around Rs 60 lakh for several years. Therefore, tax department sealed the place on Tuesday.”

Around 400 people, including temple committee members and devotees, gathered at the temple premises and sat on dharna against BMC’s move. Agitators also alleged the BMC team had misbehaved with people opposing the move.

The zonal officer retorted, “Protesters tried to create a ruckus, raised slogans against BMC for sealing the property and were demanding we remove the seal. Legal action was initiated after we were given directions by senior corporation officials for the same.”

Speaking to TOI, Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “The civic body has intensified its action against tax defaulters in the city, and have been regularly cracking down on those who have tax arrears. The space at the rear of the temple is being used for commercial activities, and has tax dues pending for several years. Though the seal has been temporarily removed, the concerned people have been directed to clear the dues at the earliest. If they fail to pay up, action will be taken.”

Title: West Bengal works on traffic management for Bypass Metro points
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

The Chingrighata crossing will see a surge in traffic once the Metro station starts operation

KOLKATA: The state government is planning a detailed traffic management masterplan for EM Bypass, with special focus on the Chingrighata crossing and other spots where Metro stations are being set up.

A day-long joint survey was conducted by senior officials of KMDA , RVNL, officers of Kolkata traffic police and bridge experts at the Metro construction sites on EM Bypass.

IIT, Kharagpur , has been engaged to prepare a road map for proper traffic dispersal around Chingrighata, the most important crossings on EM Bypass. A Metro station and the proposed flyover will make the crossing busier.

Officials said the main focus of Tuesday’s survey was to check if the Metro pillars were obstructing the EM Bypass carriageway in any way. “The priority are the locations of the Metro pillars being set up on EM Bypass as they occupy considerable space, resulting in traffic congestion. Besides, with the Metro stations slated to start operations soon, there will be a huge surge of both pedestrian and vehicular traffic. So, a detailed traffic management plan must be kept ready once the stations start operating,” an official said.

A foot overbridge near Dhapa crossing, a vehicle underpass near Captain bheri and a small flyover from the Chingrighata crossing to Hyatt More have been proposed to deal with the surge. KMDA is also working on a proposal to set up a flyover from Captain bheri to New Town via Chingrighata and Sector V.

A foot overbridge is being constructed at Chingrihata crossing. In future, the existing Chingrighata flyover is likely to be razed.

Title: 5 more arrested for tiger poaching in Saoli
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Tiger poaching accused

CHANDRAPUR: Five more persons were arrested on Monday evening in connection with the poaching of tiger in Saoli range last month.

The accused were produced before the court of judicial magistrate first class at Saoli on Tuesday and remanded in judicial custody . With this, total number of arrests in the case has now reached 12.

The poaching was carried out around a month back and it was not clear whether the animal killed was leopard or tiger. However, the whiskers and paw recovered from the poachers suggested that the animal was a tiger. The accused had laid electrified wire in the forest near Kapsi village and the tiger was electrocuted in compartment no. 201.

Forest department had earlier arrested Suresh Gedam and Ramesh Bhoyar and detained a juvenile. They had also recovered bones of the poached animal. Investigation revealed that the accused were habitual poachers involved in herbivore killing.

However, during one such endeavour, a tiger was electrocuted. The accused had confessed to poaching the feline in the last week of December. Later four more accused were arrested.

The five arrested on Monday include Bapu Bhoyar, Madgu Sakhare, Manohar Kosre, Devaji Gedam and Angadas Sakhare. All belong to Kapsi village.

4 detained for poaching leopards, bears

Meanwhile, forest officials of Bhadrawati range have detained four suspects in connection with poaching of two leopards and two bears in DSC Colony area of Chanda Ordnance Factory.

The poachers had laid electrified wire for poaching wild herbivores, but pairs of leopards and sloth bears were killed due to electrocution. Their carcasses were recovered on January 1.

Sources claimed that officials had started searching for the suspects with the help of CCTV footage. They had zeroed in on two suspects from Piparbodi village and two others from Bhadrawati town. All four were detained for questioning on Tuesday, sources in the department said.

Title: Sharjeel Imam, his aides planned CAA blockades on December 3, claim Delhi cops
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Sharjeel was arrested on January 28 after sedition charges were slapped on him in five states. (Photo: Reuters... Read More

NEW DELHI: After scanning the mobile phone and the laptop of Sharjeel Imam , arrested on sedition charges , the Crime Branch has claimed that the plan to block Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia Islamia was hatched on December 3 when the JNU student and some of his associates started chalking out the routes that could be blocked to cause a chakka jam.

The cops have found some pamphlets on Sharjeel’s phone regarding plans to stall traffic in different parts of Delhi for the injustice done to the Muslim community by demolishing Babri Masjid, an officer alleged. The pamphlets also reportedly mentioned that people who would not figure in the list made under the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) would be sent to detention centres.

Sharjeel claimed to have said that the pamphlets were to be sent only on WhatsApp groups of different universities. Police have allegedly found that these were designed just two days before the violence broke out on December 15 in relation to CAA. He would also be questioned regarding his role in the violence, a source said.

It has been found that the pamphlets were shared on two groups, the members of which are being identified. The content of the chat on these groups are being analysed. These were also shared through the Facebook messenger and emails, a source claimed. Police will question Sharjeel’s close friends with whom he had shared the plan.

Sharjeel told the cops that none of the posters was distributed physically and the recipients were asked to forward it only to relevant groups. The pamphlets also had fabricated figures about the deaths in Assam during the anti-CAA protests, the source claimed.

The JNU PhD scholar, who is in the Crime Branch custody, will be separately interrogated for his role in all cases of violence reported in Delhi between December 15 and 20, a source said.

The anti-CAA activist, who was on the run after sedition charges were slapped on him in five states for allegedly making inflammatory statements, was arrested from Bihar’s Jehanabad district on January 28.

Title: Exide net up
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: Storage battery giant Exide Industries Limited, has witnessed over 25% jump in net profit in the third quarter of this fiscal to Rs 195.9 crore from Rs 155 crore in the year ago period. The net turnover for the quarter ended December 31, 2019, of Rs 2412 crore as compared to Rs 2497 crore during the quarter ended December 31, 2018. Profit before tax (before Exceptional Item) was Rs 250 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2019 as compared to Rs. 237 crores during corresponding quarter of previous year, an increase of 5.7%.

G Chatterjee, MD &CEO, said that while OEM demand for Automotive Batteries remain

subdued, growth in Sales in After Market of Automotive and UPS Batteries continue. Exports also did

well. Demand for Telecom and other Infrastructure Batteries were under pressure during the third

quarter. “The Company is focussing on Cost Control and Technology upgradation, as strategies to improve the bottom-line,” he added.

Title: ‘Ponda, Panaji arms of Atal Setu to be ready by February 29’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

GSIDC was eyeing to complete the Ponda and Panaji arms of the Atal setu by April 2019, however, the project is... Read More

PANAJI: The Ponda approach ramp and the Panaji arm of the Atal Sethu project, which have been delayed by over a year, are nearing completion, chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Tuesday. The project is expected to be complete on February 29, he said.

Sawant also informed the legislative assembly that while the contract to construct the cable-stayed bridge was awarded for Rs 403 crore, Goa State Infrastructure Development Corporation has spent Rs 546.8 crore on the project.

The final cost of the project, however, will be known once the work is completed and the final bill is approved. “The final bill is not yet prepared as this work is not declared as complete,” Sawant said in his written response to a question raised by Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte.

Sawant said the expenditure finance committee granted a sanction for Rs 517 crore, which includes contingency costs and consultancy fees, for the 5.14 km long structure.

Larsen & Toubro built the bridge and its approach roads while TPF Engineering Pvt Ltd was selected as the consultant for the massive project.

According to data released, the union ministry of roads, transport and highways sanctioned Rs 290.05 crore for Atal Setu, of which the state has already received Rs 250 crore. Goa took a loan of 462.6 crore from the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development in June 2015.

“The scope of work of the contractor, L&T, is the bridge network along with Atal Setu connection from Porvorim to Panaji, Panaji to Kadamba by-pass junction and vice versa, a flyover from Merces junction into Panaji city and the work is nearing completion,” the chief minsiter said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh pollution board’s lens on capital Vishakapatnam
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

HYDERABAD: Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board (APPCB) has decided to call for tenders to conduct a detailed study of the quality of air, water and other pollution issues plauging Greater Vishakapatnam.

The study has gained significance in the wake of Andhra Pradesh government’s decision to shift the state’s administrative capital from Amaravati to Vishakapatnam.

APPCB member secretary, Vivek Yadav, told TOI that as the pollution levels are high in certain areas in Vishakapatnam due to the presence of port and industries, and usage of coal, a detailed study has been taken up.

“APPCB is floating tenders to finalise an agency to conduct the study. The study will cover all sorts of pollution including surface water, groundwater, marine and air. A detailed study will be done on all environment-related issues in Greater Vizag and the agency will come out with an action plan. This action plan would cover both short term and long term objectives,” Yadav said.

He added, “Vizag has been one of the polluted cities for the last few years. The bowl-shaped area from Yerada to Dolphin Nose records more pollution, specially during winter. Several industries and the port is concentrated along this coast.”

Speaking about the factors contributing to the spike in pollution levels, he said, “ The city has been expanding and SEZ and pharma city have come up. We should have an action plan to mitigate the pollution as Vishakapatnam is one of the largest cities in Andhra Pradesh.” The Air Quality Index Vishakapatnam on Feburay 4 is 68, according to the Central Pollution Control Board and was deemed satisfactory.
