“Further interrogation revealed that the accused persons were actively involved in committing robberies and snatchings in Delhi and NCR area. Chand Mohammad had on one occasion also fired at police officials,” added Arya.

Title: Writing on the wall against NRC, NPR
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: On passing the Ajit Mill Crossroads and looking around localities in the vicinity such as Rakhial and Bapunagar, which are Muslim ghettos in eastern Ahmedabad, protest messages such as ‘No CAA, NRC, NPR’ can be seen on houses and shops nearly everywhere.

Slogans opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) have been visible at several crossroads in these areas and even on government advertisement boards for about 15 days.

Local police have begun an inquiry into who has been posting these slogans and whether these can cause law and order problems, even as two protests are under way, at Ajit Mill Housing Colony in Rakhial and Morarji Chowk in Bapunagar.

A police official told TOI, “We have seen these messages and began an inquiry into who put them up, as it seems as if they have been stamped on to walls. Though the two protests in the area are peaceful, but if such messages are written on houses of other communities, it could create problems.”

A local activist, Kaleem Siddiqui, who has been organizing the protest at Ajit Mill Compound, said he was unaware of who had put them up.

One resident, who had an anti-CAA message outside his house, said it was just his medium for silent protest.

Title: ‘Pag ghungroo’ showcases India’s rich dance culture
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Artistes enthral the audience during the event

Nagpur: It was a lively environment in which four enthusiastic Kathak and Lavni performers captured the audience’s attention in a programme called ‘Pag ghungroo’ which showcased the combination of the two dance forms at Chitnavis Centre on Sunday.

The programme commenced with a salutation to Lord Ganesha in the form of a hymn, ‘Sur niragas ho’. It was followed by performances in ‘gavdan’ and ‘thumri’.

Amruta Guha and Arshia Tarkunde were the Kathak performers while Manasi Sharma and Amiya Anerao came up with performances in Lavni. The dancers kept the audience captivated and entertained throughout the programme with charm and perfection. They were guided by Priyanka Abhyankar from Sanskar Kathak group.

Baithkachi Lavni, a famous variation of lavni, was brought out in a very expressive manner by the performer. It was widely appreciated by the audience and was a big hit.

The other performances, depicting Kathak and lavni in their purest form, were also presented. ‘Aamad’, ‘Tihaayi’, ‘Paran’, ‘Tode’, ‘Atagat’, ‘Gatinikas’ and ‘Tatkaar’ were Kathak-related performances. The performance was quite refreshing. Lavni was performed on ‘Nesali pitambar jari’. ‘Tarana’ was yet another pure Kathak dance performed and ‘Chhabidar chhabi’, a song from the movie Pinjra, was presented in the form of lavni. The audience truly enjoyed the bliss of a combined lavni and Kathak programme performed entirely on instrumental music.

Anchor Ravindra Durugkar highlighted the true meaning of traditional dance forms and stated that such programmes keep the Indian dance styles and Indian culture alive. Avantika Chitnavis, trustee of Chitnavis Centre, welcomed and felicitated Abhyankar.

Sanskar Kathak Kendra presented this traditional programme in collaboration with Chitnavis Centre.

Title: Asked to pay Rs 5 for pakoras, two shoot at vendor in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Is the humble ‘pakora’ costlier than a bullet? Two youths from Buxar district may agree because they chose to fire two costly bullets rather than pay Rs 5 for the local delicacy, leaving the pakora seller and his brother injured.

It all started on Monday evening when two youths refused to pay the paltry sum after having a plate of pakauras from a roadside vendor at a village in Buxar’s Naya Bhojpur area. An altercation followed, which was “settled” after the intervention of local residents.

But the two youths returned on Tuesday and shot the vendor, Kanhaiya Kesari (35), in the leg. His brother Pintu was also shot in the leg when he came to his brother’s rescue. Both were referred to PMCH in Patna.

The victims told police that they were fired upon by two youths—Chunnu Yadav and Golu Yadav, over Rs 5 for the pakaura they had eaten on Monday evening. “Each bullet costs something between Rs 100 and Rs 200. Thus, they spent around Rs 500 but refused to pay Rs 5 to the vendors,” Dumraon SDPO K K Singh told this newspaper over phone.

The SHO of Naya Bhojpur outpost, Rajiv Ranjan Rai , said the accused, stated to be in their early 20s, have no criminal records. “They are absconding after the incident. Raids are on but they are yet to be arrested,” the SHO added. The SHO attributed the spurt in crime in the area to easy availability of illegal weapons at throw away prices.

Title: Experts stress on awareness, screening, treatment to deal with cancer
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

More than 20 organizations, colleges, and social groups participated in events at RST Cancer Hospital. Student... Read More

NAGPUR: With changed lifestyle, pollution, and risk factors like tobacco, cancer is more of a lifestyle disease today. As cancer prevalence is increasing in both urban and rural population, time has come to create public awareness about it. More screening for cancer, early detection, and proper treatment should be the focus to deal with the disease, said experts during World Cancer Day celebrations on Tuesday.

A series of events were organized at Rashtra Sant Tukdoji (RST) Cancer Hospital, National Cancer Institute (NCI), HCG NCHRI cancer centre, and many other hospitals in city on February 4.

RST Cancer Hospital and Research Centre, which is now a tertiary cancer care centre, took out an awareness rally in the premises of the institute. Dr Subrajit Dasgupta, director of the research centre, said Vidarbha youths need to take additional care. “In Vidarbha, tobacco consumption starts as early as 11 years of age, which is a big cancer risk. Kharra, khaini and other tobacco habits must be avoided,” he said.

More than 20 organizations, colleges, and social groups participated in events at RST Cancer Hospital. Students from two colleges performed street plays on cancer. A poster exhibition on cancer was also held. Joint director Dr BK Sharma said the hospital has procured a cancer screening bus, which will travel across Vidarbha and screen people for cancer.

Events at National Cancer Institute (NCI) focused on ‘Freedom from fear of cancer’. Number of cancer cases have risen in the urban areas partly due to lifestyle changes like high stress levels, poor eating habits, irregular sleeping hours, early onset of menarche, late menopause and increasing maternal age. All these points were highlighted in the events at NCI.

On behalf of HCG NCHRI Cancer Center, awareness campaign was organized in the premises of Nagpur Central railway station , where volunteers interacted with commuters and told them about the dangers of cancers and prevention methods.

Title: Pauskar now sets April 2021 deadline for Zuari bridge
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Panaji: Construction of the new Zuari bridge will be completed in April 2021, while the approach road on the Margao side will be completed by September this year, PWD minister Deepak Pauskar said adding that the Panaji side of the bridge will be ready by December 2020.

It was previously announced that a four-lane section of the under-construction bridge would be ready and opened in December 2019.

Pauskar, in a written reply tabled in the assembly on Tuesday, also said that water is being sprinkled two to four times a day near the existing Zuari bridge to control the dust pollution caused by the ongoing construction work.

He further said that after completion of construction of the bridge, dredging will be done of the mud filling, which has been carried out during the work in Cortalim on the left hand side of the Zuari.

The new Zuari bridge project’s four-lane approach road will begin near the Bambolim Cross on the northern end and lead upto Verna industrial estate, covering 13.7km, including the new bridge.

The new Zuari bridge is an ambitious Rs 1,403 crore project funded by the Union ministry for road transport and highways.

Work on the project began in October 2016 and Union minister Nitin Gadkari first announced that the bridge would be ready for use before schedule by January 2019. Later, in the Rajya Sabha though, he announced that it would be in use by November 2019.

Title: Andhra Capital News: Amaravati farmers turn to Venkaiah for help
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vice president M Venkaiah Naidu

AMARAVATI: A delegation of farmers from Amaravati met vice president M Venkaiah Naidu in New Delhi on Tuesday, urging him to stop the state government from moving the capital city from Amaravati.

The group explained to the vice-president their ordeals after the state government decided to trifurcate the capital city and recalled how Venkaiah had fought to protect the interests of the state during its bifurcation, persisting even after the NDA came to power.

The Centre had agreed to several projects and setting up of institutions in the state only due to the proactive role played by Venkaiah, the farmers said, adding that the Polavaram project wouldn’t have been a reality were it not for Venkaiah’s argument in Parliament. “Prime Minister Narendra Modi laid the foundation stone for capital city Amaravati. It would be an insult to the Centre if the state government unilaterally moves it to other places,” a representative of the group reasoned. He added that Amaravati’s farmers had parted with their fields in the faith that their land would be used for the construction of the capital city and would give them reasonable returns. “We thought that future generations would be benefited by the capital city and gave up our lands. The present state government has ruined the state’s future as well as theirs,” a farmer said.

Title: Andhra Capital: YSRC to hold rallies for capital issue awareness
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Vijayawada: YSRC will organise state-wide awareness programmes and protests against Telugu Desam’s opposition to the government proposal to set up three capitals in the state.

MLA Jakkampudi Raja on Tuesday told media that the party’s students and youth wings will launch a week-long programme on February 6. Senior leaders, MLAs and MPs will coordinate the programmes, Raja added.

YSRC will form human chains across the state in support of decentralization of administration and relocation of the executive capital in Visakhapatnam and judicial capital in Kurnool while retaining legislative capital in Amaravati.

Raja said that the central government had said that the capital issue came under the purview of the states and the Centre has no role in deciding it. It was high time that TDP leaders stopped making it an issue at least now, he said.

Raja alleged that TDP and the media were spreading false information among people and were trying to protect their investments in Amaravati. While reiterating that the insider trading in Amaravati would be exposed and the guilty will be punished as per the law, Raja appealed to people not to be carried away by TDP’s false campaign.

Title: ‘Farrukhabad hostage-taker wanted 2 cops who harassed him punished’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

AGRA: Four days after a murder convict was shot dead by police to rescue 25 children, a man who tried to mediate during the nine-hour-long stand-off claimed on Tuesday that the abductor wanted punishment for two policemen who “tortured him” in custody in a theft case and sought “sexual favours” from his wife in lieu of his release.

When contacted, senior district police officials rejected the charges, but assured a probe into the allegation and the role of the two policemen.

Subhash Batham was shot dead on Friday while his wife died hours later on way to hospital after being attacked by locals in Farrukhabad ’s Kathariya village. Batham had organised a birthday party for his daughter and then held 25 children hostage on Thursday.

On Tuesday, when TOI contacted Anupam Dubey alias Balloo, who was shot at by Batham while trying to negotiate peace, said: “During my interaction with Batham, he accused two Farrukhabad police constables of torturing him in custody. He also alleged that the policemen had also asked for sexual favours from his wife in lieu of his release in a theft case.”

Dubey was approached by Bhojpur MLA Nagendra Singh to talk to Batham during the stand-off. “Everyone present there heard Batham but no one did anything. The entire drama was set up to attract administration’s attention to punish those two policemen,” said Dubey.

Additional superintendent of police Tribhuwan Singh said, “Batham planned the entire situation for months to extort money. He demanded Rs 1 crore for each child taken hostage. He constructed a basement in his house months ago and also gathered explosives to target policemen.”

Title: Bill seeking 3 years jail for striking workers introduced
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Panaji: The state government on Tuesday introduced the Goa Essential Services Maintenance (ESM) (amendment) bill, 2020, seeking to increase the prison term for committing offences under the parent law. The bill also makes the offence cognisable.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant moved the bill. It states that violations under the present provisions of the act are non-cognisable in nature, which limit police action as they have no powers to arrest violators without warrant.

This results in cessation of work by the persons employed to provide essential services, thereby inflicting hardship to public at large. Also the period of prescribed punishment is on the lower side, which is required to be enhanced in order to prevent strikes for maintenance of public utility services, the bill said.

The bill seeks to amend sections 4, 5 and 6 of the Goa ESMA, 1988, so as to increase the provisions for punishment in said sections, to have a deterrent effect and prevent offences. Under the bill, those starting, instigating or participating in a strike declared illegal under Goa ESMA will now face possible imprisonment of up to three years.

The bill also gives more powers to police to act against violators.

For commencing a strike, the bill proposes to increase the jail term from six months to three years, and for instigating others to participate in one (Section 5), it has proposed to increase the imprisonment term from one year to three years.

Title: Goa: Not just China, screen tourists from Kerala for coronavirus, say MLAs
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Members of the Goa legislative assembly on Tuesday raised concerns over the detection of coronavirus in Kerala, and demanded the state government screen people travelling to Goa from Kerala ,as well as those flying in from China. Health minister Vishwajit Rane said he has requested the Union government to give the state a thermal scanner to screen for the virus.Leader of opposition Digambar Kamat, who moved a calling attention motion, said there was fear and anxiety in the minds of the people of Goa due to cases of the dreaded infection reported .Replying to the motion, Rane said that they would rope in anganwadi workers and teachers to create awareness about coronavirus among the people of Goa. He also said that since the state government doesn’t currently have a thermal scanner at railway stations, authorities use thermal guns. Benaulim MLA Churchill Alemao said that a lot of tourists from Kerala arrive by train, and that screening should be done at railway stations.“If required, more isolation centres will be created in the state,” Rane said, adding that there is no remedy for the virus and no treatment at the moment.The health minister said that the government is following WHO guidelines strictly, and those coming from China are isolated for 28 days. He also said that Goa now has a health officer assigned to the airport as well as at the port. Besides, he said, two Ayush doctors have been deputed for screening passengers at the airport along with previously posted paramedics.Kamat said Kerala had declared the coronavirus infection a ‘state disaster’, and called for screening of travellers from the state.

Title: We conduct regular drives to apprehend overloaded school buses: C Ramesh
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

C Ramesh

Title: 6 yrs on, cops’ quarters at Arlem yet to take off
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Margao: Nearly six years after the PWD issued tenders for construction of new buildings for police quarters at Arlem after demolishing the existing ones that are in a dilapidated state, the project is yet to take off from the drawing board.

Replying to a question posed by Fatorda MLA Vijai Sardesai, chief minister Pramod Sawant said that the proposal was to construct 42 ‘B’ type police quarters by demolishing existing 48 ‘A’ and ‘B’ type quarters at Arlem, for an estimated cost of nearly Rs 7 crore. He said that though the PWD had tendered the work on May 30, 2014, the tender failed to elicit any response from contractors, leading to retendering of the work by the PWD on April 25, 2016, Sawant said in his written reply tabled in the House.

Subsequently, the estimates were revised by PWD to nearly Rs 10.67 crore as per the revised Goa Schedule of Rates 2019. Following the revision of estimates, the project “is under consideration of the government for taking the work in a phased manner”, Sawant said, while also stating that the work of constructing a new building was taken up upon the recommendation of the PWD.

He said the condition of buildings A1 to A4 (24 quarters) and B1 to B2 (24 quarters) was verified by PWD’s executive engineer at Margao. “It was decided to conduct Non Destructive Test (NDT) on these buildings. After conducting NDT, PWD recommended that the 48 quarters be demolished, and have a new construction in their place due to high cost of restoration, etc,” Sawant said in his written reply.

Title: CAA Protest in Delhi: 66 protests in Delhi against CAA, 99 held, says Centre
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Demonstrators during a protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens (ANI Ph... Read More

NEW DELHI: The Union home ministry on Tuesday informed Lok Sabha that there were 66 protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act in the capital, which led Delhi Police to register 11 cases in which 99 people were arrested.

Replying to a question, junior home minister G Kishan Reddy said around 115 vehicles including four buses, six cars, 80 motorcycles, two police vehicles and 23 other vehicles, as well as 32 barricades, a police booth and a divider railing was damaged during the anti-CAA protests in Delhi. Incidents of violence, unlawful gathering, stone pelting and damage to property marked the protests in Jamia Millia Islamia , Chand Bagh mazaar, Seelampur, Old Seemapuri and Shaheen Bagh.

Meanwhile, the Centre has received anti-CAA resolutions adopted by state assemblies.

Sharing details of police action in the Jamia Millia Islamia campus in December and the January 5 violent clashes in JNU, as reported by Delhi Police, Reddy said three cases were registered against the mob found to be involved in unlawful activities and defacing public property while protesting against CAA in vicinity of Jamia. Police said it entered the campus chasing the violent congregation of students/mob, to nab/disperse the offenders, control the situation, protect government property as well as save the lives of “innocent” students on the campus.

15 people were arrested for the Jamia violence while 62 police personnel and 127 people, including 36 students, were injured.

On the JNU clashes last month, Reddy said a case was registered at Vasant Kunj North police station with regard to the attack against students and teachers by masked people armed with rods and sticks. 51 people sustained injuries and all were medically examined. Some rioters involved had been identified, the minister said. “No case has been registered against the injured students at JNU. Details of probe cannot be divulged at this stage,” Reddy told the House.

Title: Water scarcity, dirty toilets spark health scare
Content: Gurgaon: The quarantine facility set up in Manesar to screen Indians evacuated from China for the Wuhan coronavirus infection has a major scarcity of water and not enough toilets, leaving the few that are there dirty and triggering hygiene concerns, according to those staying there.The camp was set up by the Army at very short notice for 324 Indians brought back home by a special Air India flight on February 1. They have to spend a minimum of 14 days at the facility while they undergo tests to rule out a coronavirus infection.Some of the quarantined residents told TOI they were appreciative of the Army’s hospitality but hoped the camp would fix its sanitation urgently because a hygiene problem cannot be allowed to fester at a sensitive facility like this one.A student who asked not to be named said lack of adequate hot water in the current harsh cold weather conditions was also affecting residents. “The toilets in the facility are a bit congested and dirty,” said another. However, both said Army officers responsible for building the facility are doing the best they could.Another student said, “There are just five mobile toilets for over 300 people here. Each barrack has 22 beds. The toilets are in bad shape but we have been told the issue is being solved. There are only three electricity ports for charging in every barrack accommodating 22 persons. Overall, there are 10 barracks.”The student also claimed there was only one bucket for eight people to use. “And it becomes really difficult to bathe for everyone as hot water is available only for a little over one hour. Hot water comes only during the early hours of the morning. If we miss it, we don’t get it later in the day,” added the student.Only male evacuees are housed at this camp. “The facilities for those who are staying in other places where women and couples are staying are much better. But I don’t want to compare. They are trying their best and we are pointing out if we need any changes,” said another student, who was in Wuhan to study.“When we told them (Army officers) about the issues, they were very warm and listened to us. When we realised they got less than 48 hours to arrange everything from scratch, we understood that time constraint was an issue. They have started cleaning the toilets more regularly and have promised to resolve other issues too,” said one of the residents.There was, however, satisfaction with the food. “From bed tea to dinner, everything is given on time. And honestly, the food is just awesome,” said a student.An Army officer said the facility had been set up in very little time and everything had to be outsourced. “We are cleaning toilets as per the norms prescribed by the World Health Organisation (WHO). The mobile toilet effluent is being treated as per international guidelines so that no infection goes out. Around 2% hypochlorite solution is being used with a contract period of 15-30 minutes in 1:1 ratio. Fomites, including stethoscopes, are being disinfected,” said the officer.

Title: Renovation of vet hospital at Sonsoddo 80% complete
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Margao: Chief minister Pramod Sawant told the state legislative assembly on Tuesday that 80% of the work of renovating/extending the veterinary hospital at Sonsoddo is complete.

Replying to a question by Fatorda MLA Vijai Sardesai, Sawant, in his written reply tabled in the House, said the cost of the project was Rs 3.8 crore.

The upgraded veterinary hospital will have an out-patient department (OPD), x-ray facility, ultrasound room, veterinary officers’ cabin, clinic with sterilisation room, veterinary staff room, pre-operative room, operation theatre, recovery room, drug store, registration room and lobby on the upper ground floor.

The first floor will house the accounts staff room, joint director’s cabin, deputy director’s cabin, assistant director’s cabin, store room, lab staff room, laboratory, dormitory, guest room, training hall and pantry, Sawant said in his reply.

The stipulated timeframe for completion of work is 510 days from the issue of work order, it was informed.

The first floor will house the accounts staff room, joint director’s cabin, deputy director’s cabin, assistant director’s cabin, store room, lab staff room, laboratory, dormitory, guest room, training hall and pantry, Sawant said

Title: Probe into Visionary Co-operative fraud soon: CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday assured the House of conducting a thorough inquiry into the fraud committed by Visionary Urban Co-operative Society and arrest the wrong-doers.

The MLAs also raised concerns over the deteriorating conditions of cooperative societies and banks. “Under the act, we don’t have powers to make arrests in such cases,” Sawant said. Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco and Benaulim MLA Churchill Alemao had moved a calling attention motion to raise apprehension and anxiety in the minds of shareholders and depositors of various co-operative credit societies and in particular, of the Visionary Society, over the alleged Rs 39 crore fraud.

Both sought to know what action the government would propose against the directors, besides the auditors who failed to detect the irregularities in time, and the steps to prevent such scams in the future and recover the amount by attaching properties of those responsible.

Replying to the motion, co-operative minister Govind Gaude said they have appointed auditors in Visionary Urban case, and a report will be submitted within 20 days. “Based on the report, action would be taken,” he said.

He also said the auditors during 2007-2008 to 2009-2010 span had reported various illegalities in the functioning of the society whereby funds were misappropriated by the management and staff members.

Title: Two held for killing, dismembering man in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Pushpender went missing from his house on Sunday evening

NEW DELHI: A 35-year-old man was murdered and his body partially dismembered to be stuffed into a bag in Mangolpuri on Sunday. The accused, Mohammad Saleem and Pankaj, were known to the man and stayed in the same area. Pushpender’s body was dumped in an unused room of a building in which one of the accused stayed.

The accused duo, who were later arrested from the area, had even called up the deceased’s family members to demand a ransom of Rs 15 lakh a day after the murder.

Pushpender went missing from his house on Sunday evening after being invited for dinner by a “friend.” A complaint was later registered with police. On Monday, his father, Ram Ganesh, received calls from Pushpender’s number.

“The caller demanded Rs 15 lakh from us. When we expressed our inability to pay the amount, they suddenly agreed to accept Rs 12 lakh. They were even ready to negotiate more, which raised doubts. We were suspecting the role of his friends,” said Ganesh.

Pooja, the deceased’s sister, added that on Monday, Saleem and Pankaj visited their house to express concerns over Pushpender’s disappearance. “When they heard of police’s involvement in the case, they left the place in a hurry. We informed police about their behaviour and they were detained,” she said.

During questioning, Saleem told the cops that he was having an affair with Pushpender’s wife. He claimed that Pushpender would misbehave with his wife due to which her health was deteriorating. Hence, he decided to teach him a lesson.

He roped in Pankaj, who also had a grudge against Pushpender. On Sunday, Pankaj invited Pushpender to his place for lunch on pretext of helping him settle an old monetary issue. After he reached there, Pankaj hit Pushpender with a gas cylinder on his head due to which he fell unconscious. The duo then slit his throat with a blade and left him to die. They returned after sometime only to dismember his body and stuff the body into a gunny bag. They made the ransom call the next day, presuming that the family had accumulated a lot of money by selling land.

Title: Sand mining comes to rescue of Azhikkal
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kannur: The plan to restart the cargo movement from Azhikkal Port here during the new year is yet to become a reality owing to technical issues, but at the revenue front the port is doing well thanks to the sand mining there as part of dredging to deepen the draft to facilitate the entry of bigger ships.

In December 2019 alone, the revenue from the sales of sand was Rs 4.96 crore, and in 2019 the total revenue was around Rs 38 crore according to the officials.

After the government decided to directly sell the sand and the booking was facilitated through the official website - portinfo.kerala.gov.in - the process has become easier and this benefits both the port and the people, they said.

Previously, there were cooperative societies engaged in sand mining and this had led to many controversies. Later, the government decided to sell it through the local bodies and now it has become more economical, said the port officials.

The rate of the sand has now reduced by over 30% and the quality has also improved, according to them, and the central government is said to be exploring the possibility of extending the Kerala model nationally, they said.

At the same time, the real purpose of the mining is to deepen the channel to bring bigger ships here but the discussions in this connection has not brought the desirable results, they said. The discussion is still going on, as the companies that agreed to operate service demanded Rs 3 per metric tonne per kilometer as incentive, while the government was not ready for this. This was the old rate given to the companies when the cargo ships operated from here for a few months a few years ago, and they want to retain it, said official sources.

The incentive is offered to compensate for the lack of the return cargo. If there is sufficient return cargo it would also solve the issues but for that the shipping service should be established first.

Though the authorities keep on promising that the shipping service would begin from here, the uncertainty has led to the general feeling that the port would end up being a place for sand mining. Though it is a profitable business, the goal of setting up the port is not to mine sand, and the general feeling is that the authorities should expedite the measures to start shipping service from here.

Title: CAA fears hit voters drive in Malegaon, MLA refutes claim
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The district election officials have said that in some parts of Malegaon city, the residents are reluctant to share their personal details for the voter verification drive because of fears regarding the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Population Register (NPR), but local elected representatives have dismissed their claims.

Election officers claimed that the locals are unwilling to share details like Aadhaar number, proof of residence, date of birth, election photo identity card to the booth-level officers (BLOs), who are engaged in the voter verification drive. The Malegaon Central assembly constituency, where the election officials have experienced the reluctance, has been witnessing peaceful agitations over CAA and NPR.

“The exercise is being carried out at a satisfactory pace across the district barring Malegaon Central assembly segment. A section of the residents are scared of sharing any personal data due to issues like CAA and NPR,” a senior official of district election department said.

The voters verification exercise in the district started in November last year in all the 15 assembly segments of the district on the instructions of the Election Commission. It will continue till February 15. In the district, Malegaon Central has reported the lowest verification (54%) till now. The remaining 14 assembly constituencies have reported voter verification in the range of 62% to 88%.

“Electoral verification programme is nothing but updating the voters’ list. Through BLOs, we will try to clarify doubts of people. Voting is a constitutional right and everyone must come forward to keep their voters record up to date,” district collector Suraj Mandhare told TOI.

Local AIMIM MLA, Maulana Mufti Mohammad, rejected the claims of the election department. “The low percentage of verification in our constituency is because the BLOs are not visiting households for verification. There could be a small section of the voters, who are not ready to share their personal data due to CAA. But it is also a fact that BLOs are not working efficiently in the constituency,” he claimed.

He said he had already raised the issue with the sub divisional officer and requested him to direct the BLOs to visit houses of the voters.

Local Congress leader, Asif Shaikh, claimed voters of the constituency are apprehensive that such personal data could be used for CAA and NPR.

“Hence, the voters are not forthcoming to share the personal details to the BLOs. Unless the Centre withdraws CAA, the voters of this assembly segment will continue to oppose any such exercise that deals with furnishing personal details,” he added.

Title: Rajyotsava awardee Rachappa Hadapad dead
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Rachappa Hadapad was a socialist and follower of Ram Manohar Lohia

Dharwad: Rachappa Hadapad, a 2018 Rajyotsava awardee who was ailing for some time, died aged 84 at KIMS Hospital here on Tuesday. Rachappa Hadapad was a socialist and follower of Ram Manohar Lohia’s ideology .

He was attracted to socialism after coming in contact with Shanteveri Gopalgowda who was fighting for the landless in the region. At ‘Samata’, his small barbershop at Grass Market in Dharwad , Rachappa used to discuss socialist ideology with his customers. In the 1970s and early 80s, Rachappa used to keep newspapers and literature containing socialist ideologies in his shop. He was associated with Narayan’s movement in the early 70s. During Emergency , he was actively involved in strengthening the movement in this region.

Karnataka Vidyavardhaka Sangha presented him the JH Patel Award in 2011. Later, the organisation made Rachappa its honorary vice-president for three years. Hailing from Hole Hosur in Bailhongal taluk of Belagavi district , Rachappa spent his childhood at Tirlapur in Navalgund taluk of Dharwad district before shifting to Dharwad.

Title: Mangaluru: Lack of bidders stalls Central Market project
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

A file photo of Central Market in Mangaluru

MANGALURU: The long pending demand of people in the city for a full-fledged market complex at the Central Market area has suffered a setback due to a lack of bidders.

Though the project was envisaged several years ago, it was not implemented due to technical reasons. Mangaluru City Corporation (MCC) had prepared plans to construct a new market complex having all the necessary infrastructure more than 10 years ago.

At present, the Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) has earmarked Rs 145 crore for the redevelopment of Central Market. A proposal to demolish the old Central Market building and build a new one in the Central Market area was approved at the MSCL board meeting in October, 2018. However, no bidders have come forward to take up the work.

MSCL managing director Mohammed Nazeer said the proposed Central Market complex will have a separate space for retail stalls of fruits, vegetables, flowers, fish and meat. It has been designed to give citizens a special shopping experience by providing all modern infrastructure. As per the proposal, the complex will also have a separate space for office premises and other commercial establishments, he said.

“We have plans to build it in the public-private partnership (PPP) model. Since it is a big budget project, most of the contractors are not confident of taking up the project as it requires a huge deposit. We have found two bidders, and very soon the tender process will be completed for the project,” he said.

“In addition to the redevelopment of Central Market, the MSCL also have plans to redevelop the city bus stand. At present, all inter-city buses too are entering the city. After the completion of an integrated bus terminal, which is proposed either at Pumpwell or near Padil, the intercity bus stand will be shifted. To redevelop the city bus stand, the MSCL has allocated Rs 25 crore. It will have 30 bus bays and all other necessary facilities for the convenience of passengers, Nazeer said.

Title: Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde to inaugurate state lawyers’ conf
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nashik: The State Lawyers’ Conference has been organised in Nashik by the Bar Council of Maharashtra and Goa in association with Nashik Bar Association on February 15 and 16. Close to 4,000 delegates from Maharashtra and Goa are expected to participate in the conference which will take place on the theme – ‘Marching Towards Speedy Modern Judiciary’. The basis of the aforesaid theme is Vision Document 2019-2025 published by the Bar Council of Maharashtra and Goa by Justice Bhushan R Gavai, Judge, Supreme Court of India. Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde will be inaugurating this conference.

Title: Aircraft amendment bill proposes fine up to Rs 1 crore
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government on Tuesday introduced a bill in the Lok Sabha to amend the Aircraft Act wherein the fine amount for violations will be hiked from Rs 10 lakh to up to Rs 1 crore. A few other provisions would also be made part of the law that will also help in complying with the International Civil Aviation Organisation ’s (ICAO) requirements.

The Aircraft (Amendment) Bill, 2020 also provides for keeping “aircraft belonging to any armed forces of the Union, other than naval, from military or air force outside the purview” of the Aircraft Act, 1934. Once the amendments are passed, the government would have the power to issue directions to review, if necessary in public interest, any order passed by Directorate General of Civil Aviation, Bureau of Civil Aviation Security and Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau.

Title: Gold chain worth Rs 40k snatched
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nashik: An unidentified biker snatched a gold chain of a 41-year-old woman worth Rs 40,000 from Jijamata Garden area on Monday evening.

The complainant stated in her statement that she was in Trikoni Garden to purchase vegetables from the market. While walking back home near Shankar Nagar, an unidentified biker came close to her and forcefully snatched her gold chain and sped away. Though the woman cried for help the bike-borne criminal escaped from the scene within a matter of seconds.

Lately, many chain robberies have been taking place near Trikoni Garden and Shankar Nagar areas. Given the robbery trend, the police held a surprise check-up of vehicles in the areas.

Meanwhile, police have failed to curb the chain robberies menace as robbery occurring almost daily.

On Thursday a woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 1 lakh near Pathardi Road in the Indiranagar the area by two bike-borne criminals.

On the same day at around 10 pm, a 50-year-old woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 30,000 along the Aurangabad Road near a wedding lawn.

In another case, registered with the Ambad police, a 35-year-old woman riding a scooter was targeted by a chain-snatcher at the Audumbar junction near Mogal Nagar of Cidco at 2.50 pm on Friday. The bike-borne chain the robber snatched the woman’s chain worth Rs 42,000 and fled.

On Saturday, a 60-year-old woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 40,000 by two persons on a bike near a wedding lawn along the Aurangabad road at around 9 pm.

Title: Compost plant for Muhana mandi, solar power for agro mkts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Tuesday gave a nod to projects under which all the agricultural produce markets in the state will be lit by solar power and Muhana mandi will get a compost plant.

The plan is to make these agriculture markets self-sufficient and to create a sanitized environment at Muhana mandi, which is one of the largest agricultural markets in the state. For the Muhana mandi project, a compost machine will be installed and Rs 33 crore has been sanctioned. This will help to utilise all the solid waste generated at the mandi and will help to keep the premises clean.

Moreover, as per the proposal sent by the agriculture marketing department, the agriculture markets that have sufficient funds to construct a solar plant will be given assistance under the CAPEX model and those who do not have sufficient funds will be given assistance under the RESCO model. RESCO and CAPEX are a kind of solar rooftop that have their unique way of functioning.

To make this process a success, about 70-80 per cent funds from various banks will be arranged. Gehlot has given Rs 12.32 crore financial sanction and even administrative sanctions to this project. The idea to install solar plants in the agricultural markets is to provide cheap electricity to the businessmen there.

Title: Local body gives out cloth bags that avails discounts
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Alappuzha: A local body of Alappuzha is distributing free cloth bags to its villagers and giving discount from hospitals and shops if they come with these cloth bags.

It is Thanneermukkom grama panchayat of Alappuzha, which is making a cloth bag revolution with the help of neighbourhood groups (NHGs) of the panchayat. If the villagers come with old clothes, the NGH members will make fine cloth bags from them and these bags will have tags including Aadhaar number and phone number of the villager.

“Two major private hospitals in Cherthala within the limit of this panchayat have agreed to give 15% discount on hospital bills, if the villager comes with the cloth bag that has the tag issued by the panchayat. Selected shops in the panchayat will also give a discount of 10% to the villagers if they come for shopping with these cloth bags. Three shops and two supermarkets have agreed to be a part of this programme till now. The villagers who bring these cloth bags will also get 3kg of free rice if they purchase goods worth Rs 1,000. The panchayat has started to hand over the details of the families, which brought cloth bags from the panchayat, to these institutions,” said the panchayat president P S Jytohis.

The project titled ‘Sanchi Sangamam’ (Meeting of cloth bags) is being executed in all the 23 wards of the panchayat. The grama panchayat has deployed 25 members of Kudumbashree for providing cloth bags to the villagers. If the villagers come with old clothes like sari, dhoti and bed sheets, the trained Kudumbashree members will make cloth bags from those clothes in a short span of time and will give it to the villagers free of cost Thanneermukkom grama panchayat is executing this model programme in association with the Community Development Society (CDS), the apex body of the NHGs in the local body. The project was kicked off in ward six of the panchayat on Sunday and on the first day, 500 families received cloth bags. P S Jyothis said that the panchayat had set aside Rs 2.5 lakh for this programme. “A three- month-long training has already been imparted to Kudumbashree (NHGs) women having tailoring machines. The panchayat will give the remuneration to the Kudumbashree members of this project. Our target is to give cloth bags to all the 20,000 families in the panchayat in a month,” Jyothis said.

Title: CBSE to open DigiLocker accounts for Std IX & XI students
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: CBSE has decided to open DigiLocker accounts for all Std IX and XI students from its affiliated schools and put their registration cards in the secure digital depository.

Till now, only Std X and XII board mark sheets were stored in the accounts of students concerned. A registration card for Std IX and Std XI contains vital details about the student like full name, subjects chosen, date of birth etc, which is then used the following year for board exams.

This registration card helps CBSE prepare well in advance for the board exams as they have a clear idea on potential number of students appearing, for which subjects and their details which need to be printed in the crucial mark sheets. The registration card, made in Std IX and XI itself, helps students identify and then rectify errors like name spelling or date of birth. With ample time in hand, the board can make changes required so that the eventual mark sheet is error free.

CBSE has been on a spree of student-friendly initiatives and this one is the latest that involves technology. The central board had recently issued a circular announcing its decision to allow calculators in board exams for students who have dyscalculia.

From February 5, the download of registration cards (from CBSE portal) will begin for schools. Parents and students both have to sign the card thus verifying that the information is correct.If any errors are noticed, then the rectification application has to be routed through schools. By May 15, CBSE will open DigiLocker accounts for all students and upload their rectified (if needed) registration cards online.

DigiLocker is a flagship initiative of Ministry of Electronics & IT (MeitY) under Digital India programme. DigiLocker aims at ‘Digital Empowerment’ of citizen by providing access to authentic digital documents to citizen’s digital document wallet. The issued documents in DigiLocker system are deemed to be at par with original physical documents as per Rule 9A of the Information Technology.

Title: Politics heat up on drive against encroachments
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Politics is heating up over Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) drive against encroachments . Congress corporators Praful Gudadhe and Kamlesh Chaudhary have demanded an end to the action, terming it against the bylaws, while mayor Sandip Joshi said it would continue as it is legal, and is as per the high court order.

NMC discontinued the drive against vegetable markets on footpaths and roads on Monday and Tuesday, after two days of action on Saturday and Sunday, after municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe left for Mumbai for official meetings. In the last two days, vendors earlier selling vegetables and fruits by encroaching on footpaths and roads have returned as hawkers, selling produce on hand-carts.

Joshi had framed a policy for continuous action against all types of encroachments. He also approved formation of enforcement squads in all ten zones. Through the general body, he also approved a new policy to levy hefty penalties and take action against encroachers.

After assuming charge, Mundhe had directed officials of zone, market, health, enforcement departments and nuisance detection squad (NDS) to take action against encroachments, especially vegetable, fruit and meat markets running outside of designated places. Action was taken against 62 markets in all ten zones on Saturday and Sunday.

On Monday and Tuesday, vendors returned and were seen selling produce in the same spots, especially at Khamla, Mahal, Gokulpeth, Jaffar Nagar etc. Only difference was that NMC had demolished sheds and temporary shops.

Mundhe is in Mumbai since Monday morning and likely to return on Wednesday.

Only NMC Hanuman Nagar Zone conducted the drive on Tuesday and demolished 128 encroachments on footpaths and roads under the guidance of assistant commissioner Raju Bhivgade.

NMC sources told TOI vendors are adapting, and have turned into hawkers to avoid action. “Earlier, they used to sell vegetables, fruits etc by erecting temporary shops. Now, they are selling it on hand-carts, which brings them under the policy related to hawkers,” sources said.

Gudadhe and Chaudhary said in a press conference they will stop action against hawkers by showing provisions in the Street Vendors (Protection of Livelihood and Regulation Of Street Vending) Act-2014. “The ongoing drive is illegal and against the Act. NMC cannot seize materials, hand-cart and levy fine on hawkers. As per the Act, NMC formed Town Vending Committee, which has been submitted to state government for approval. The committee has to conduct survey, register hawkers, develop hawking and no-hawking zones. Action can be taken against hawkers only if they sell outside of hawking zones. We will meet guardian minister Nitin Raut and request for a stay on the action,” he said.

Gudadhe added, the drive is also anti-public as it deprives people of convenient purchase of day-to-day commodities. “There are no designated markets, so existing ones are running for years,” he said.

Gudadhe also said the policy framed by the general body to levy hefty penalties also can be brought into effect only after completing process as per the Act.

In reply, Joshi said, “I am with the people of this city and not encroachers. Maximum people selling vegetables etc by encroaching on footpaths and roads are from out of the city. Even people want action against these encroachments. We are not taking action against hawkers. Action is being taken against encroachers as directed by HC to free footpaths and roads from encroachments,” he said.

Joshi said he was ready to hold ‘Walk and Talk With Mayor’ with vendors in the presence of Gudadhe and Mundhe. “Traffic congestion and accidents are rising due to encroachments. Also, encroachments cause unhygienic conditions,” he said.

Shockingly, NMC administration is yet to implement policy framed last month to levy hefty penalty and take stringent action against encroachments. NMC officials said policy was pending with civic chief for approval.

Title: Rajasthan: Teacher, student spat over CAA
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

JAIPUR: Rajasthan College’s cultural programme ‘Mridang’ was embroiled in a controversy after a teacher and a student got involved in a verbal duel over the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ).

The spat took place when Noman Khan, a student of Rajasthan University’s MA political science (previous), objected to a controversial remark of Shitabh Sharma, an assistant professor of Kanodia College . Sharma was invited as a judge for a debate competition titled ‘CAA Is In The National Interest.’

In the viral 36-second video, Sharma was heard saying, “You (Muslims) are divided between Sunni and Shia and are radically opposite to each other and you talk about not including Muslims in the CAA.” Elaborating her point, she said Gambia was declared the 57th Islamic country the moment it became a Muslim majority nation.

“Hum Hindu zyada hain, hum ne aaj tak Hindu rashtra ghoshit nahi kiya. Aur karenge bhi nahi, kyunki Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam ki bhawna hai (Hindus are in majority, but we have not declared a Hindu nation. And we will never declare India as a Hindu Rashtra as we believe that the world is a family),” Sharma can be heard saying in the video.

The clip ended with Sharma saying “CAA should not be opposed whether you are a Hindu or a Muslim.”

Khan told TOI that he confronted Sharma when she first asked Hindus to raise their hands and then asked Muslims to do the same. (This portion is not in the video).

In the second video which lasted 44 seconds, Khan can be seen confronting Sharma when she asked his name.

“App sacche rashtra bhakt hain toh boliye Godse Murdabad,” Khan was heard as saying in the video amid chaos.

“Principal KG Sharma called police who detained me for two hours. The college didn't allow me to raise a complaint against the teacher for her communal remark,” said Khan over the phone. Despite repeated attempts, Sharma couldn’t be contacted for her comments.

Title: Special ward set up at Udaipur hospital
Content:
Representative image

UDAIPUR: A 14-bed special ward for coronavirus patients has been set up at Maharana Bhupal Government Hospital under RNT Medical College here.A control room has also been established where people can collect information related to the disease. The ward was opened based on instructions from state medical and health department.

Title: 216 kalasha padabhisheka performed to Lord Bahubali
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

RITUALS: D Veerendra Heggade, dharmadhikari, Sri Kshetra Dharmasthala led devotees in performing padabhisheka ... Read More

Dharmasthala: D Veerendra Heggade , dharmadhikari, Sri Kshetra Dharmasthala , led devotees in offering 216 kalasha padabhisheka to Lord Bahubali at Ratnagiri on Tuesday. A grand ‘agrodhaka’ procession was taken out prior to this ritual. Lalithakeerti Bhattaraka Swamiji of Karkala, who offered benedictions, said the sacrifice of Lord Bahubali is important at a time when injustice, anger, hatred and cheating abound in the world.

“India is a land known for its dharma and culture. Qualities of abdication, non-violence and self-control over senses are awakened in individuals by worshipping the statue of Lord Bahubali installed through observing ‘panchakalyana’ rituals. This in turn fosters feelings of love, trust, peace and amity,” the Swamiji said, adding every individual must strive to inculcate the rare and unique qualities inherent in Lord Bahubali in their lives and become better people.

Accordingly, one must pray to the almighty to give all his inherent qualities to one who offers prayer to him, the Swamiji said. Let there be world peace through the qualities of non-violence, sacrifice, abdication that Lord Bahubali practiced during his lifetime, the seer advised. ‘Kshullaka’ Dhyan Sagar Maharaj also offered benedictions. Veerendra Heggade, Hemavathi, his wife, family members, K Abhayachandra Jain, former minister were present.

Title: Gambling den busted in Bhadrakali
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nashik: The special squad of city police commissionerate raided a gambling den in the Bhadrakali area of the city on Monday and booked six people under relevant sections of the Maharashtra Prevention of Gambling Act, 1887.

“The special squad was formed two months ago to take action on the complaints that are received at the police commissionerate-level. On Monday, a call was received at the police control room about a gambling den that as being operated in Bhadrakali area — about 200 meters away from the Khadkali signal,” a police officer said.

“We immediately passed on the information to the special squad. A team then raided the closed room on the premises of a rice mill in which six people were found gambling. The two owners of the gambling den managed to escape from the scene,” he added.

Police have recovered cash and other valuables worth Rs 1.22 lakh from them. “Many times people ignore informing the police about illegal businesses in their vicinity fearing that their name would be leaked and the people concerned could harm them. We ensure that in all complaints coming to the police commissionerate the name of the informer is not disclosed to anyone,” the officer said.

“People can call police on 0253-2305233 and 2305234 without any apprehension and report if any illegal business is carried out in their area,” he added.

Title: Ban on tusker Guruvayur Padmanabhan to be lifted
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Thrissur: The forest department team led by Kerala Veterinary and Animal Sciences University head of the department, Dr Syam K Venugopal examined the Guruvayur tuskers on Monday and submitted a report to Thrissur ACF.

The ban of Guruvayur Valiyakesavan will continue and the ban of Guruvayur Padmanabhan will be lifted, said the team’s report.

After considering the current health condition of Padmanabhan, the report found that he is fit to be used in the routine temple rituals inside the Guruvayur temple. The report also said that the tusker should only be used for parading during the cooler time of the day and should not travel or be paraded between 10am and 4pm. Additionally, the temple authorities should assure proper rest to the elephant and ensure that travel and temple parades are strictly restricted to two times a week. The report also recommends that the tusker should not be made to work in hot and severe weather conditions.

The report also said that the tusker Guruvayur Valiyakesvan, was found to be healthy. To determine if he has been afflicted with tuberculosis we need a specific diagnosis. A special competent team should be constituted to collect clinical samples with intimation to state epidemiology officer and chief disease investigation officer of the animal husbandry department. Till the clinical examination is completed, the tusker should given rest and restricted within the Punnathur Kotta, recommends the report. After the results the forest department will take further action, adds the report.

The forest department had imposed restrictions on Guruvayur Padmanabhan and Valiyakesavan on December 7 from participating in any functions due to age and health-related issues. It was imposed based on the complaint by member of Kerala state animal welfare board M N Jayachandran. Last month chief wildlife warden Surendrakumar formed a three-member expert committee to inspect the health condition of the tuskers.

“We will lift the ban of Guruvayur Padmanabahan as per the report by expert committee. But the elephant is not allowed at any functions outside the Punnathur Kotta. The ban of Valiyakesavan will be decided after completing the clinical examination,” Thrissur ACF P M Prabhu told TOI.

Title: Coronavirus treatment: How far effective are anti-HIV drugs in treating Novel Coronavirus?
Content: With more than 20,000 cases in China and numbers rising outside the country, Coronavirus is fast turning into a global crisis.As experts try and find out how to treat the Novel Coronavirus, which has been declared a public health emergency by the World Health Organisation, a newfound development was made in Bangkok recently when a team of medical doctors reported success rates in treating a patient infected with the virus by using a cocktail of drugs usually given to HIV patients.As per reports, the patient, a 71-year-old woman showed positive signs and better recovery just 48 hours after being administered the drugs. While the case is still under study, there is no sure shot evidence that this is the cure-all drug for treating the deadly disease. There remain a lot of questions to be answered about the same.Applying a clinical approach, Thai doctors used a combination of drugs, mainly, anti-retroviral medicines to treat the disease.Claiming it to be an effective "cure", a report released from the hospital read:"This is not a cure, but the patient's condition has vastly improved. From testing positive for 10 days under our care, after applying this combination of medicine the test result became negative within 48 hours,"With a vaccine still potentially years away, scientists are hopeful the trial could offer a critical breakthrough.Newer case studies and trials have emerged out of China, which show that doctors are actively relying on HIV fighting medications to treat high-risk patients.Of all the experimental studies and trials, a combination of antiviral medicines used in the treatment of severe flu and infections are currently showing the highest potential of all the drugs.The kind of therapy being brought into use, known as combination therapy is not a new concept at all. Combination therapy, in the past, has been used to treat certain regressive forms of cancer and many severe forms of chronic illnesses.The drugs which are being used to treat novel coronavirus on a few patients are lopinavir, ritonavir, which act from the root and strip the virus's ability to attack or reproduce the body's immune system, hence, curbing the problem of further infection as well. This combination acts on an enzyme, protease, which is used by both the Human Immunodeficiency Virus as well as coronaviruses to attack the protein cells in the body and multiply their numbers in the body.Doctors are also experimenting with the added usage of another drug, Oseltamivir, which is used to treat flu, in the hopes that this combination will not strengthen the coronavirus's efficacy and instead, break it down.In the past, anti-HIV drugs have been used to treat patients suffering from SARS, who showed positive clinical benefits after the treatment and the results of the same have been published in The Lancet as well.Chinese doctors, too, are making use of this combination therapy, testing it out on some patients infected with the coronavirus. While some showed a sort of allergic reaction, while some showed positive development.Like with all therapies, while these medicines can prove effective, they do carry certain side-effects. And hence, there is no potential proof that this brand of HIV fighting drugs could work in treating all cases of coronaviruses.A big reason for this is that the family of coronaviruses are comparatively stronger than other viruses and therefore, it has been difficult to find out the root cause of spread till now. Doctors also say that while the medicines may have worked in limited cases, a lot many more studies and conclusive researches are needed before we establish the same. Scientists are also working to prepare potential vaccines which will act as a preventive measure. However, this may take months to come.

Title: Bank frauds fell sharply this fiscal due to better detection: Government
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Minister of state for finance Anurag Thakur (Photo: AFP)

NEW DELHI: Junior minister for finance Anurag Thakur said in Rajya Sabha on Tuesday that bank fraud amount has declined to Rs 5,244 crore in the first three quarters of this fiscal because of improved detection and reporting.

“Bank frauds, which stood at 0.58% during 2009-14, have come down to 0.16% in the last two and half years. In the first six months of this year, frauds were only 0.04 %. This has happened because our government has taken right steps towards fraud reporting and detection,” Thakur said in the Upper House.

According to Thakur, bank frauds reduced significantly from Rs 38,548 crore in the 2016-17 fiscal to Rs 16,084 crore in 2017-18 fiscal.

It rose slightly though to Rs 18,893 crore in 2018-19 but declined again to Rs 5,244 crore in the first three quarters of 2019-20 fiscal, he said during Question Hour . To check fraud, the minister said, “We came out with a framework for improved detection and monitoring. We also reviewed the quality of assets, cleaned up the bank balance, and recapitalised banks.”

Title: Noida: Extra lane created to ease traffic on DND
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

At least 50 extra barriers have been placed to ensure those travelling towards Mayur Vihar don’t merge with th... Read More

NOIDA: The Noida traffic police have created space for an additional lane on the Delhi-Noida side of DND by squeezing a portion of a U-turn, hoping to somewhat ease snarls on the busy arterial road.

The decision has been taken keeping in mind the additional traffic load DND has been witnessing ever since the Kalindi Kunj border was sealed on December 15 in the wake of CAA protests at Jamia Millia Islamia and Shaheen Bagh. So, vehicles, which would have ideally taken the Kalindi Kunj route, are now being diverted to DND. Officers said the DND-Maharani Bagh stretch has been one of the worst-affected in terms of traffic.

After the tweak in arrangement, the U-turn on the Noida-Delhi side, which would earlier lead vehicles to the third lane on the right of the Delhi-Noida carriageway, will now open into a fourth lane. Since the size of the U-turn has been squeezed by placing barriers, it has made available this additional fourth lane, which was already there but not in use.

Officials said the decision was taken on Monday following a survey of master plan 1 road (DND-Sector 12/22/56 intersection) by a two-member team of the Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) and traffic police.

DCP (traffic) Rajesh S said, “The U-turn space has been squeezed in such a manner that vehicles can easily pass through and the extra space is utilised by commuters travelling from Delhi. This minor change will help commuters who get stuck on the stretch towards Mayur Vihar loop”

At least 50 extra barriers have been placed to ensure those travelling towards Mayur Vihar don’t merge with the traffic moving towards Sector 16. The DCP said the situation would be reviewed again after the Kalindi Kunj route opens.

Title: Expel Anant Kumar Hegde and Pragya Thakur, prove ‘love’ for Bapu: Congress to BJP
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BJP MP Pragya Thakur (PTI)

NEW DELHI: Congress Tuesday demanded that BJP expel its MPs Anant Kumar Hegde and Pragya Thakur to prove its “much professed and publicised love for Mahatma Gandhi”.

AICC general secretary K C Venugopal said the BJP leadership was paying lip service to Gandhi while its members were repeatedly insulting the Father of the Nation. He termed as sham the BJP’s demand for an apology from its MP Hegde, recalling that another MP Pragya Thakur recently called Gandhi’s assassin Nathuram Godse “a patriot”.

“It is a sham to maintain the fig leaf that now barely covers the naked hatred and contempt that BJP and RSS have towards the Mahatma, as indeed generations of freedom fighters who gave away their life in the cause of an Independent Mother India,” he said.
