Title: New regulator for medical education coming in weeks: Government
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Union health minister Harsh Vardhan (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The process for creation of the National Medical Commission, which will replace the Medical Council of India as the new medical education regulator, is nearing completion and the body will take shape within the next few weeks , health minister Harsh Vardhan told RS on Tuesday.

“The National Medical Commission is in an advanced stage of formation and the chairman and other board members have already been appointed. In another few weeks, we will see the whole process completed,” the minister said.

Title: Government spends 50% more to buy PDS grain, sells it at FY13 rate
Content:
Representative image (Reuters)

NEW DELHI: The acquisition cost of rice and wheat for subsidised distribution through ration shops has increased by nearly 50% since 2012-13 while the rate at which the foodgrains are sold has not been revised since the National Food Security Act ( NFSA ) was implemented in July 2013, the food and consumer affairs ministry has said.The ministry’s submission to Lok Sabha came barely days after the Economic Survey advocated for revising the price at which subsidised grains are distributed under the NFSA and also to revise the coverage of food security scheme. According to the ministry’s written answer to a question, the acquisition cost of rice has gone up from Rs 2,018 per quintal in 2012-13, to Rs 2,051 during 2019-20 and in the case of wheat the price has increased from Rs 1,483 to Rs 2,115 during the same period.This rise in procurement price along with expenditure to store and maintain the procured grains has further pushed the government outgo, called the economic cost. The price at which the foodgrain is distributed to the beneficiaries is called the Central Issue Price (CIP). According to budget estimates, for financial year 2020-21, Rs 1,15,570 crore fund has been allocated for supplying subsidised foodgrains, which is up by 6.33% from the current year’s revised estimate of Rs 1,08,688 crore. The food subsidy bill was Rs 1,13,171 crore in 2014-15.

Title: Opposition disrupts Lok Sabha business over Anantkumar Hegde’s Bapu remark
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

BJP MP Anantkumar Hegde

NEW DELHI: BJP MP Anantkumar Hegde ’s remarks on Gandhi and the freedom struggle rocked Lok Sabha on Tuesday as the opposition disrupted proceedings and accused the saffron party of being the inheritors of the legacy of Gandhi’s killer Nathuram Godse. The opposition forced adjournment of the House right at the start, washing out question hour.

With members trooping into the well raising slogans, Congress’s leader in the House Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury accused Hegde of denigrating Gandhi, who he said was a “worshipper of Ram”.

Congress members raised slogans of “Godse party, down down”; “Mahatma Gandhi amar rahe”; “maafi mango, maafi mango” as they tried to block the business of the House when it reconvened after an hour of adjournment. They demanded that PM Modi come to the House and clarify the matter.

The protests turned into a clash when parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi said Hegde had been asked to express regret despite having clarified that he did not make the remarks attributed to him. Joshi said BJP MPs took out 150 km of padayatra each to commemorate Gandhi’s 150th birth anniversary.

“These people are unnecessarily making an issue. We are the real followers of Mahatma Gandhi. These people are the followers of Sonia Gandhi and Rahul Gandhi,” Joshi said, as sloganeering targeting BJP became louder.

The comment turned the clash shriller as Chowdhury called BJP “inheritors of Godse’s legacy”.

While this was going on, BJP MP from West Bengal Locket Chatterjee started to allege that the state government was following “appeasement politics” and that Saraswati Puja was not being allowed to be performed in villages, linking it to protests against CAA . She likened the situation in Murshidabad district to that in Pakistan .

Title: ‘Privatising dist hospitals won’t affect patients’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government will not compromise the interest of patients while handing over district government hospitals to private medical colleges through public-private partnership mode, health minister Harsh Vardhan said in the Rajya Sabha on Tuesday.

Such experiments have successfully been implemented in the last 25 years and even government think-tank Niti Aayog has taken note of this and come out with draft guidelines, he said during the Question Hour . The minister asserted that the step is permitted under Sector 2(5) of the Medical Council of India ( MCI ) Act 1999 and made it clear that it is not being done to promote the private sector. Responding to a supplementary query, Vardhansaid: “We will offer district hospitals to the private sector without compromising the interest of patients.”

“A private sector can have medical colleges but cannot have hospitals with patients. The government has many district hospitals with patients. The private sector has money to run the hospitals,” he said. He also disagreed with CPI MP’s view that the entry of private sector in medical education was eroding its quality.

Title: Suspense over GU polls
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: Gujarat University authorities on Tuesday told the committee for student senate election to ensure that the poll takes place according to the schedule. The committee members met GU officials on election duty who had boycotted the process following an altercation with student unions. “The suspense over whether the poll will take place continues as the voter list is still to be compiled and verified,” said a GU official. “Colleges have been instructed on the rules but some discrepancies remain. They are are being discussed.” GU has extended the date for representation related to any dispute till February 7.

Title: ‘Scalp cooling can prevent hair loss’
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: Hair loss is a major cause of concern for women undergoing cancer treatment involving chemotherapy. City-based medical experts said a novel method of ‘scalp cooling’ can prevent this loss to some extent.

Dr Mansi Shah, a medical oncologist, said the initial results of patients undergoing the treatment were satisfactory in terms of physical and psychological well-being. “Chemotherapy targets fast-dividing cells in the body. Hair is the second fastest dividing cell and hence chemo drugs cause hair loss,” she said.

The therapy causes blood vessels in the scalp to shrink, reducing the amount of chemo reaching the follicle cells.

Various city-based hospitals observed World Cancer Day on the theme ‘I can and I will.’ At Civil Hospital, about 100 cancer survivors participated in a celebration-cum-awareness event. Suresh Prajapati, 50, a resident of Naroda, in his speech said that he had lost his grandmother to oral cancer. “Ever since, I have been spreading awareness about the perils of tobacco consumption in different parts of Ahmedabad,” he said.

Tanmay Panchal, a tongue cancer survivor, said that more than the five years of excruciating treatment, it was society’s approach that hurt him more.

“I now run a video channel to dispel myths about cancer,” he said.

Title: Sola canteen contractor ‘back on his feet’ despite potato video
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Ahmedabad: Remember the video of a canteen worker at the Sola Government Medical College using his feet to clean potatoes? The college administration had been forced to ‘terminate’ the contract on January 22, after the video went viral. Now, the same contractor is back, and the medical college has decided to allow him to resume work. The AMC on Monday took off the seal on the canteen after collecting Rs 25,000 in administrative charges.

Students of the college had written to the apex body of medical colleges in India and sent the video with it. The students questioned the authorities’ reinstatement of the contractor even after it was established that the contractor was using unhygienic practices.

A group of students questioned the move and claimed that despite several complaints, the contractor has been continuing since 2011. The students claimed that they had not only stopped using canteen services but had also made several earlier representations.

“The contractor is supposed to get a certificate from the AMC, but no such certificate was acquired, and he was awarded the contract. The contractor even used dirty water for cooking. We made several representations, but the authorities failed to hear the issue after which we went on a strike in 2013. After assurances were made of a new contractor, the same one has continued for more than seven years,” a student said. The contractor has not resumed services since the controversy broke.

“We issued a show-cause notice to the contractor. We have decided to allow him to continue till March 31 after getting his reply,” said a medical college official.

“His contract ends on March 31, 2020, after which it will not be renewed,” said in-charge dean Dr H R Jadav. About the unhygienic methods of the contractor, he said the AMC had taken action against him and then removed the seal. There is no problem in allowing him to continue till March 31.

The contractor claimed the video was an old one. He contended that the potatoes seen were of inferior quality and were being cleaned in that manner so that they could be fed to cows.

Title: Maruti-Auto-Show
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

New Delhi: India's largest carmaker Maruti Suzuki India ( MSIL ) has no immediate plans to launch electric vehicles (EV) and will instead introduce cars with clean fuel and hybrid technology. Mahindra, Hyundai and Tata Motors have already introduced EVs and other auto companies like MG, Kia as well as Mercedes-Benz and Audi have announced plans to introduce EVs later this year.

Speaking to TOI, Maruti Suzuki India Ltd (MSIL) executive director (marketing & sales) Shashank Srivastava said the carmaker was in no hurry to jump on to the EV bandwagon and would wait till it became a viable option for both the customers and the company.

"At present, electric cars are unviable. First, the battery technology is too expensive; second, charging infrastructure is non-existent; and third, there is range anxiety among customers. Unless these issues are addressed, there won't be mass acceptance of EVs," Srivastava argued.

With only 12-15% car owners actually having access to a permanent parking space, even night time charging is an issue. Range of EVs drop dramatically when heater or air-condition is in use.

Though MSIL is currently conducting trials of 50 electric Wagon-R vehicles in different climate and terrain conditions across the country, the company executive said they were leanings for the R&D team and not for introduction of the vehicle in the market.

"We see hybridisation and use of clean fuel like CNG as a practical option in the intermediate stage between internal combustion engines and full EVs. At present, 8% of our sales are CNG vehicles. Going ahead, as the CNG infrastructure improved, sales will increase. In 2020-2021, we are looking at 50% increase in CNG car sales against 2019-2020. We are also using mild hybrid technology in cars and have invested in a battery plant in Gujarat with Denso and Toshiba," he pointed out.

Srivastava also pointed out that the inflexion point for a shift to electric was still a while away and would happen only when battery cost that today comprised 50% of vehicle cost gets reduced substantially.

The company, meanwhile, has stopped manufacturing BS IV vehicles and has migrated nearly all its vehicles to BS VI. The BS VI versions of three models that remain -- Brezza, Ignis and S-Cross -- will be introduced over the next few days. All of them will undergo a makeover during the emission norm migration.

At the Auto Expo 2020, MSIL will showcase the new compact SUV Brezza with petrol only engine; concept car Futuro-e that is positioned as an SUV coupe, New Ignis as a tough urban SUV and Jimny, a compact SUV. The production version of the Futuro-e is expected to roll out in a couple of years but MSIL is yet to take a call on Jimny and says it will gauge customer feedback at the auto show before taking a decision.

Though MSIL has increased marketshare in January 2020 to 53.3%, up from 49.6% in January 2019, it clocked a 11% decline in retail sales. The company top brass remains anxious about how 2020 will pan out given the rise in vehicle cost due to migration from one emission and safety regime to another. Also three-year, third party insurance was introduction following a Supreme Court order. “Between July 2018 and now, cost of acquisition of cars have gone up by 8-14%. Though we have seen good adoption of BS VI products, what happens in the months ahead remains to be seen,” added Srivastava.

Title: Bajaj Electricals
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: Bajaj Electricals Ltd has registered a jump in net profit to Rs 96.7 crore in the third quarter of this fiscal from Rs 60.5 crore in the corresponding quarter of last fiscal. The company has achieved income from operations of Rs1,283.8 crore as against Rs 2,164.5 crore, a decrease of 40.7% over the third quarter of the previous year. For the quarter, Consumer Products segment of the Company has earned total revenue of Rs. 860.2 crore as against Rs. 763.2 crore, a growth of 12.7% over the corresponding previous quarter. EPC segment has achieved a total revenue of Rs. 423.4 crore as against Rs 1401.1 crore, registering a de-growth of 69.8% over the corresponding quarter of the previous year.

Shekhar Bajaj, Chairman and Managing Director of Bajaj Electricals Limited, said “We have been pursuing our stated path of a strong focus on positive cashflow from operations, reducing our debt and strengthening our balance sheet. I’m glad to note that we have done well on all of these parameters and remain committed to it. We continue to drive growth in our Consumer Products segment while adopting a more risk-calibrated approach for the EPC segment with a focus on completion of existing projects on hand.” According to him, it is constantly trying to reduce debt equity ratio and the rights issue of Rs 350 crore will be utilised to further reduce debt.

Title: Health cards, khatas set to be home-delivered in Bengaluru
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: Health cards , revenue khatas and marriage registration certificate are among the 53 services which will be delivered to citizens’ doorsteps in Bengaluru if the Karnataka government’s plan takes shape.A cabinet meeting on Tuesday approved the doorstepdelivery scheme and launched a website — www.janasevaka.karnataka.gov.in — through which citizens can order services. A request could be made on phone too.The Yediyurappa government is the second dispensation, after that of Jaganmohan Reddy’s in AP, to follow the citizen-centric scheme successfully pioneered by the AAP government in Delhi.The project’s pilot is under implementation in T Dasarahalli assembly constituency, and will be extended to three more — Bommanahalli, Rajajinagar and Mahadevapura — as part of the first phase. In the next, the services will be extended to all 27 assembly segments in Bengaluru (excluding Anekal).Here’s how it works: A citizen enters the website, places a service request. A Jan Sevak (or a delivery executive) is assigned for the task. He will go to the citizen’s residence and collect documents required for the service. E-governance minister S Suresh Kumar said, “Once the request is processed, the Jan Sevak will contact the citizen and deliver the document or card at a mutually agreed time.” The service costs a citizen Rs 115, excluding documentation.The government is looking at delivering transport documents like DL, and cards issued by the food and civil supplies department, among others.The delivery executive will carry an identity card issued by the e-governance department, a tablet, a thermal printer and a biometric scanner. At present, every ward in Bengaluru will be allocated a Jan Sevak. More will be recruited if workload increases.

Title: Mumbai Temperature: Expect dip in temperatures from tomorrow in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mumbai's weather department forecast another spell of low temperatures in Mumbai between February 6 and 8. (Fi... Read More

MUMBAI: The city's weather department forecast another spell of low temperatures in Mumbai between February 6 and 8.

K S Hosalikar, deputy director-general (western region), India Meteorological Department (IMD) said, "A small nip in temperatures is expected from February 6-8 in the state and Mumbai due to the northerly winds and their effect on wind direction. After that temperatures will begin to rise."

Track the pollution level in your city

On Tuesday, the minimum temperatures in the city remained near normal at 20.2 C in Colaba and 18.5 C in Santacruz. IMD forecast maximum and minimum temperatures to be 31 C and 20 C respectively on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, the overall air quality index recorded in the city was 184, which is in the moderate category.

Title: Coronavirus China: How Wuhan outbreak became sixth global health emergency in 10 years
Content:
Passengers wear face mask to protect against coronavirus (AFP)

Why is 2019-nCoV a global public health emergency?

What happens in a PHEIC? Why is the Wuhan outbreak called a ‘novel’ coronavirus?

Is this the first time a coronavirus has been designated a global public health emergency? What was the case with Nipah in

?

What is the economic impact of a disease outbreak?

NEW DELHI: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the coronavirus outbreak in China’s Wuhan a global health emergency. More than 20,000 cases of the disease have been confirmed in little more than a month after the first case was confirmed on December 31 last year. Apart from the human toll, the disease is a concern because similar outbreaks in the past have extracted a significant economic cost. Kenneth Mohanty explains what a global health emergency is and why the 2019-nCoV, as the Wuhan virus is being called, has received this tagA public health emergency of international concern, or PHEIC, which is what the 2019-nCoV has been declared to be by WHO, is defined as “an extraordinary event which is determined to constitute a public health risk to other states through the international spread of disease and to potentially require a coordinated international response”. The International Health Regulations (IHR 2005), under which a PHEIC is declared, was enacted in 2007. When a PHEIC is declared, WHO helps coordinate an urgent response with the affected country and the international community. While WHO notes that circumstances that lead to a PHEIC declaration can extend beyond communicable diseases, the six times that PHEIC declarations have been made were all due to communicable diseases:IHR is an agreement between 196 countries and, as an international treaty, is legally binding and all countries must report events of international public health importance. Under IHR, all countries should be able to detect a potential threat, assess its gravity, report its occurrence, and respond adequately to it. It also lays down specific measures countries can take at ports, airports and ground crossings to limit the spread of health risks across borders. But a 2018 article in the BMJ Global Health journal echoed a WHO finding that only about a third of the countries have the ability to satisfactorily assess, detect, and respond to such emergencies. WHO said the key factor behind the global emergency tag for 2019-nCoV is “not what is happening in China but what is happening in other countries” with the concern that it could spread to countries with weaker health systems.It is especially important to note in this regard that the Wuhan outbreak is being called a novel coronavirus as it is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans. Although it is from the same family of viruses as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, or SARS, it is not the same virus.While coronaviruses are nothing new, the 2019-nCoV is the first coronavirus to get a PHEIC designation. You see, coronaviruses are a large family of viruses, some causing illness in people and others that circulate among animals. Three major coronavirus cases — SARS in 2003, MERS in 20112, nCoV 2019 — have all been traced to bats but are understood to have jumped to humans from an intermediary animal, civet cats and camels, for SARS and MERS, respectively. The 2019-nCoV is said to have originated in a seafood and animal market but what the intermediary animal may be has not been established yet.Nipah virus, which struck Kerala in 2018, too, arose from bats, but is not a coronavirus infection even though respiratory trouble is one of the symptoms. In fact, several viruses carried by bats can cause disease in humans and the coronavirus is just one of them. The Kerala Nipah outbreak killed 17 of the total 19 people afflicted with a fatality rate of 89%. WHO was notified within a month of the first death and notes that no new cases or deaths were reported since June 2018 and humanto-human transmission of Nipah virus was contained in Kerala.A 2017 paper published by US National Library of Medicine estimated that the expected losses from pandemic risk stood at about $500 billion per year, taking into account both lost income and the health impact. The total global economic cost of the 2003 SARS outbreak was estimated at $40 billion. It is well-established that disease outbreaks have a slowingdown effect on the economy. Travel and trade restrictions in the wake of the outbreak have already caused big losses to businesses and Bloomberg reported that China may cut its economic growth expectations for 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak with JPMorgan slashing quarterly growth estimates to 4.9% from 6.3%. Why a slowing China is worse for the global economy today than when the SARS outbreak, which too took a substantial economic toll, is because China now accounts for about a third of global growth, a larger share than the US, Europe and Japan combined, Financial Times said.

Title: PWD builds 100m cement concrete road in 6 hours
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

PWD is planning to complete works on the entire road within three days

NAGPUR: The state public works department (PWD) has constructed cement concrete road of 100 metre within six hours using prestressed precast concrete pavement (PPCP) technology, which otherwise takes one month or more in conventional system.

PWD has claimed that PPCP is a solution to various problems of cement concrete roads and sets a role model for other agencies in the state to follow. Becoming the first in the state, the PWD team of executive engineer AD Pohekar, deputy engineer Rehan Khan, assistant engineer Monika Mankar and Milind Digrajkar, in association with Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT), has taken up concretization of a public road with full length using PPCP technology. The selected road is very narrow and situated in a densely populated area.

Khan told TOI that construction of the cement concrete road using PPCP technology has solved various problems. “The PWD got funds for concretization of a road with a length of 480 metre at Rajiv Nagar, connecting two highways, under the central road fund (CRF). The road was around 3 metre in width and is the only access to many areas; so, it cannot be blocked for traffic.

“Curing, which is very crucial for durability of cement concrete road, would have been not possible due to movement of people. Therefore, we used the PPCP technology. Through a private contractor, we cast cement concrete panels at a plant in Khadgaon. We ensured sufficient time for curing. Then, we placed panels on the road. It took six hours to convert a stretch of 100 metre into a cement concrete road,” he said.

PWD is planning to complete works on the entire road within three days.

Khan said, “We ensured the cost of road was less than the conventional system, which is another major achievement. The conventional system costs much more than PPCP technology. We could achieve this by keeping thickness at 200mm as against 300mm in conventional system.”

“But the strength and life achieved is five times more than the conventional system. There will be no cracks as it was cast and cured in a friendly and idle atmosphere. It will be easy to replace panels whenever required in future,” he added.

From the earlier width of around 4 meter, now the road is of 10 meter with a 5.50 metre carriageway, footpath and stormwater drains on two sides. Each panel is 2.75 metre in width and 3.50 metre in length. The two panels have been fixed for a carriageway of 5.50 metre. There is a jetting system in PPCP, which also ensures proper elevation and no undulation.

Khan said the cost of cement concrete road using PPCP technology can be lesser where strength of the existing road is good. “We can mill top of the existing tar road till it gets proper strength, followed by placing of panels. In the conventional system, we need to lay dry lean concrete (DLC) layer before pavement quality concrete (PQC), which is the top layer of cement concrete,” he said.

Khan said urban local bodies can construct cement concrete roads in congested areas, especially slums, using PPCP technology.

The technology can help the NMC to a great extent. Since the last nine years, the NMC is blocking roads for months for construction of cement concrete roads.

VNIT had invented the technology. Thr PWD had concretized a small stretch of Inner Ring Road using the technology in November 2018 on an experimental basis.

Title: Women who rarely step out fill city’s Shaheen Bagh
Content: Nagpur: Wearing burqas, women virtually stepped out of the veil as they prepared to spend a night under the domes at the protest venue in Teka Naka’s Farooq Nagar ground where a Shaheen Bagh-like atmosphere is attempted to be created.Nearly 600 women volunteers stayed put under one of the domes set up at the venue on Monday night until another group took over on Tuesday morning.A majority of them were young girls or women who otherwise remain confined to their homes and also those who work as daily wagers, who had come down at the cost of their earnings. This was the first time Nagpur women agitated all night, though without public address system.“I stay at home,” says 24-year-old Fatima Sheikh from Mominpura when asked to introduce herself. She discontinued education after class XII and went for soft courses like mehandi design and tailoring. “I hardly step out of home but the agitation has instilled courage in many other like me to take to the streets,” says Fatima, one of the volunteers who would take up night time agitation at the venue.Seen at the venue was 68-year-old Habib-un-Nisa who adds up to the family income by working as a daily wager in the onion trade. “I don’t mind if I don’t earn but will continue coming here,” she says.The CAA-NRC has prompted them to step out of homes and protests, was the stock reaction of the women. For CAA , they said the government will allow nationals from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan except Muslims and NRC will lead them to detention centres.“I’ll stay here in nights but not give up my veil. It’s my own choice,” says Fatima.Sheikh said before this, there were unsuccessful attempts to take away their hijaab as well by this government. “Mob lynching and triple talaq were among several other issues on which we remained silent. We never step out of home without a specific reason as we adhere to the purdah system. But, PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah have forced us to step out,” she said.Against the backdrop of shootings at Delhi on anti-CAA-NRC protesters, the women raised the slogan ‘Tum goli chalalo, hum nahi hatenge’ for most part of Tuesday. The second day of the agitation saw a bigger turnout of women who left the venue domes only during namaz timings.Homemaker Yasmeen Sheikh said she stayed back all night, though she rarely ventures out of home for anything else other than household affairs or functions. “At the end, it was announced to volunteer so I stayed back. All women were not allowed because of safety concerns,” she said.Yasmeen said the stay over is a silent protest.Fatima said she was disturbed by what was going on in the country. “Many lawful citizens will be thrown out of country after NRC,” she said.Shehnaaz Abdul Kalam, another homemaker, who prefers to stay within the realms of home, ridiculed Modi and Shah stating that it is because them they have unwillingly stepped out of homes. “To search for some thieves, they are checking the whole city,” she said.Homemaker Shabnam Ansari said they were ready to agitate for any number of years under the Shaheen Bagh dome. Similarly, Shamima Khan said they will not allow division on religious lines.Asked what if they face Delhi-like situation, they said, “Allah is mightier than the evil.”In Video: Anti-CAA protest: Women who rarely step out fill Nagpur's Shaheen Bagh

Title: Congress may spring surprise in Delhi: Randeep Singh Surjewala
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Congress leader Randeep Singh Surjewala (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Congress may spring a surprise in Delhi like it did in the elections in neighbouring Haryana last year, senior party leader Randeep Singh Surjewala claimed as campaigning for the February 8 polls in Delhi closed on Thursday.

"Some news channels were giving us just two seats in Haryana but we won 31. It is going to happen again," he told a press conference.

Terming the BJP , which is in power at the Centre, and the ruling AAP in Delhi as "Jhoothon ki Sarkar aur Jhoothon ke Sardar", Surjewala accused them of failing in areas of health, pollution mitigation, education, clean drinking water supply and public transport in the national capital.

Union home minister Amit Shah has "panicked" as he feels that this time the BJP may not win more that the three seats it had won in the 2015 Delhi assembly polls, the Congress leader said.

Title: Signs of rift in MVA govt? Cong leaders accuse NCP, Sena of ignoring them
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Even as coalition partners in newly formed Maha Vikas Aghadi government are claiming that everything is hunky dory in their ranks, the situation is otherwise. Leaders, particularly from Congress, are deeply upset over the alleged humiliating treatment meted out to them by other two partners, which are stronger in numbers.

A Congress minister told TOI that they were not taken into the confidence by other two partners while taking major decisions. It was initially decided to have two deputy chief ministers from NCP and Congress each but at the end, they were ‘forced to settle’ with the Speaker’s post to Nana Patole, he said.

Endorsing the minister, the newly elected legislators from grand old party said they had even formed a group with a view to pressurize the ministers to do work in their respective constituencies. “We’ve decided to go together to any minister’s cabin so that our voices are heard. Otherwise, we’re hardly entertained by ministers, which included those from our party too. Being first timers, we’re not aspiring for ministerial berths, but want to focus on development works in our constituency, so that voters could re-elect us again,” a couple of them told TOI.

The cracks between the coalition partners are evident even at local level during Zilla Parishad polls. After winning the polls with a big margin, Congress leadership led by animal husbandry minister Sunil Kedar allegedly refused to give deputy chairman’s post to NCP led by home minister Anil Deshmukh. The latter had wanted it for his son Sahil Deshmukh, according to NCP local activists.

While admitting that Congress leadership had denied them deputy chairman’s post, Deshmukh during a media interaction in the city had informed that they had requested for two important posts in the ZP later and expect the Congress to follow ‘coalition dharma’. When confronted, Kedar denied his involvement stating that all decisions were taken by former MPCC chief Manikrao Thakre and others.

A senior Congress leader told TOI that in the cabinet meetings Congress ministers were not given any weightage. “Even portfolios granted to us were of less significance which led to differences between our top party leaders. It was precisely the reason, our high command had earlier opposed our induction into the ministries and suggested only outside support to Shiv Sena and NCP,” he said.

Earlier, relief and rehabilitation minister Vijay Wadettiwar from Congress was upset over allocation of poor portfolios to him, which was later rectified. In the meantime, the sulking minister not only skipped cabinet meetings, but also the special assembly session in Mumbai. There were rumours that he would eventually join BJP and was even invited by former minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule, after which he was allocated proper portfolios.

Title: Mumbai gang siphons off Rs 20 crore with 4,000 fake FASTag refunds
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The cyber crime cell of the city crime branch busted a gang running an online fraud to siphon off crores. By taking advantage of a loophole in a banking system, the gang had made 4,259 fraudulent FASTag recharge-refund claims and siphoned off Rs 20 crore.

A FASTag is fixed onto the windshield of a vehicle, and allows a motorist to make toll payments directly from a linked account, thus reducing the long queues at toll plazas. FASTags use Radio Frequency Indentification (RFID) technology to allow the direct payments.

The cyber crime cell arrested four people from parts of Karnataka who were beneficiaries of the fraud money. The four accused, identified as Purshottam Revanna (40), Kiran Manju (35), Rajesh Shivanna (34) and Rasanna alias Prakash Shivanna (37), were booked under the Information Technology Act and under sections for cheating and forgery of the IPC.

The complainant in the case, a bank, said that they had launched e-wallet services for their customers to purchase FASTags via apps. The bank also purchased software to handle the day-to-day transactions of this system.

After downloading the app, anyone could buy or recharge their FASTags using UPIs, said a police officer. A UPI, or a Unified Payments Interface, powers multiple bank accounts into a single mobile application, merging several banking features under one application.

Initially, the bank investigated the fraud internally, and found that unidentified persons had claimed huge refunds for FASTags. Some of the accounts that had claimed refunds were non-functioning or had zero balance.

A police officer said, "Further technical investigations found that the gang had taken advantage of a loophole in the system to claim 4,259 refunds, and had siphoned the money from the bank ledger account. Between January 2019 and January 2020, the gang made 4,259 recharge transactions on FASTags, and then claimed a refund by showing that the KYC submission was erroneous. They caused a wrongful loss of Rs 19.8 crore."

After forensic investigation, the cyber crime police tracked the beneficiaries of the refunds to Chennai, Bengaluru, and other parts of Karnataka. Four were arrested from Karnataka, while the police are looking for a few more people involved in the racket. The king pin of the fraud is also absconding.

The police added that the investigation would take a little longer to complete, as the accused had transferred money from one account to several different accounts in different parts of the country and withdrawn money from different ATMs, which would take time to track.

Title: Cops to help prosecution in Yug Chandak murder case
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: Lakadganj cops have procured permission from their superiors to visit Delhi to help the prosecution team of counsels, representing Maharashtra, ahead of the final hearing in Yug Chandak case on February 11 before a Supreme Court bench.

Though there was no official compulsion or requirement, cops volunteered to extend help to ensure gallows for the kidnappers and murderers of eight-year-old Yug in September 2014.

Yug’s murderers, Rajesh Daware and Arvind Singh, were awarded capital punishment by the trial court which was later upheld by the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court in 2016. The convicts had preferred appeal before the Supreme Court, which was last heard in 2018.

Following a plea by the counsels of Maharashtra, assisted by private advocates Rajendra Daga and Raheel Mirza, the apex court has fixed February 11 as the date for final hearing.

Senior PI Narendra Hiware of Lakadganj police station said he wanted to rush himself to help the prosecution team with the finer details of the case, but had to alter the plan. “I will send two constables who know the case in detail and share minute details with the prosecution before the hearing. Though there was no compulsion, we thought that it was moral responsibility to ensure gallows for Yug’s murderers for the sake of society,” he said.

Title: Govt to hold meet on civic body’s working
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Nagpur: In probably a first-of-its-kind move, the state government has organized a meeting to take review of Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) working. It is seen as Maha Vikas Aghadi’s (MVA) yet another step to take control over the BJP-ruled civic body.

On February 4, the state urban development department sent a letter to municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe asking him to be present in the meeting organized at 4.30pm on February 7 at Committee Hall, Mantralaya, Mumbai. “Chief secretary will take the review. He has directed him to appear in the meeting with detailed information related to the NMC,” letter stated.

It is a hot topic in the NMC that Mundhe, who is known as no-nonsense officer, has been posted here by the MVA government to take control over the civic body.

Earlier, the MVA government had appointed a committee of its ministers to control Nag River Pollution Abatement Project despite NMC being the executing agency. Guardian minister Nitin Raut had requested chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to again appoint Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) as the planning authority for gunthewari areas, which are currently under the NMC. Accordingly, Thackeray had sought opinions from the NMC and NIT.

To query on Mundhe being sent by the MVA government to take control over the NMC, mayor Sandip Joshi said in a press conference, “The government is the authority to appoint municipal commissioner, so he has nothing to do with it. Mundhe is a good officer and loves transparent governance. Therefore, I have welcomed Mundhe’s appointment at the NMC.”

“Mundhe could not meet me as I was out of the city for a couple of days when he assumed charge. Then, Mundhe went to Mumbai for meetings. Mundhe told me he is implementing decisions taken by me and the general body. The drive against encroachments is a fine example as Mundhe is implementing it because the general body framed a policy,” he said.

Title: It’s a boy! Baby born to Thai mom flying Qatar airline in Indian sky
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: It was a tale of two happy landings. The first happened around 10km above sea level, the second at the Kolkata airport about an hour later.

The first was a touch-and-go affair, ending in the birth of a healthy baby who, legal experts said, could be spoilt for choice of citizenship.

The second, too, was an “emergency landing” but a much smoother affair, which saw a Qatar Airways flight touch down at the Kolkata airport before daybreak. It had taken off from Doha, Qatar, with 370 people on board; by the time it landed here — after a journey of more than 3,800 km — there was one extra flyer, weighing a little more than 2.5kg.

No one aboard flight QR 830 — least of all 23-year-old Wassana Promkasikorn — had bargained for all this when it left Doha at 10.30pm (IST) on Monday. Promkasikorn, working in Oman’s Sohar, was flying back home — in Bangkok, Thailand — to deliver her second child; she was 36 weeks pregnant and labour, her doctors had told her, should be a couple of weeks away.

All that, however, changed mid-air as Promkasikorn complained of labour pains a little less than four hours into the journey. Five crew members, trained to tackle medical emergencies, and a doctor travelling on the same flight gathered around the 23-year-old and helped her deliver a boy, around 2.15am on Tuesday, as the flight passed east of Raipur, Chhattisgarh, at a speed of 900-plus kmph and 10km above sea level.

The pilot, in the meanwhile, had contacted the Kolkata air traffic control, seeking a “medical emergency landing”. The flight landed safely — with one more passenger than it had when it started the journey — at Kolkata airport around 3.15 a.m. with emergency medical officers waiting in the airport’s apron area.

Mother and baby were wheeled into an ambulance and taken to Charnock Hospital on VIP Road, where both were doing fine. Flight 8R 830 continued its Bangkok journey a little later, Qatar Airways officials said.

Single-mother Promkasikorn, however, will have one more decision to make: about her son’s citizenship. “There are two primary options. Article 5 of the Indian Constitution allows anyone born in Indian territory to claim Indian citizenship. But the child is also eligible for a Thai citizenship (based on his mother’s nationality). So it will be the mother’s decision that will determine the boy’s citizenship,” Kolkata lawyer Anirban Guha Thakurta said.

Title: Guv gets chopper, state chief secy meets him
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: Bengal chief secretary Rajiva Sinha paid a visit to Raj Bhavan and spent more than two hours with Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar on Tuesday while the state government provided helicopter service to the governor for his Santiniketan trip during Basanta Utsav on March 6.

The developments came three days ahead of the Assembly session that begins on Friday when the governor will read out the speech prepared by the state government. Sinha called on Dhankhar at 6.10 pm on Tuesday, 24 hours after parliamentary affairs minister Partha Chatterjee and state finance minister Amit Mitra went to Raj Bhavan and spent 90 minutes with the governor. Chatterjee had been to Raj Bhavan even on Sunday.

Even as there is nothing unusual in Nabanna’s coming closer to Raj Bhavan, the recent spurt in visits marks a departure from the state government giving a “cold shoulder” to the constitutional head of state on grounds that he was acting “partisan”. Sources in Raj Bhavan hinted that senior ministers wanted Dhankhar to go by convention, pointing to the practice followed by his predecessors. The request comes a week after Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan put his difference with CM P Vijayan on record over CAA in the Kerala Assembly. Dhankhar has said he will abide by the Constitution in letter and spirit.

Dhankhar has repeatedly flagged his difference on various issues, ranging from the state’s anti-CAA stand to law and order and from running state universities to tackling students’ stir on campus. When CM Mamata Banerjee took to the streets against CAA in December, the governor had said: “People holding constitutional posts are bound by law to follow Constitution. And this law (CAA) is part of the Constitution.”

Dhankhar is likely to reiterate the view to the chief secretary if there is something against CAA in the draft speech. The state government withdrew advertisements against CAA after Dhankhar pointed out that the state government can’t do it. Law and order and higher education could be the other concern areas for agreement between Raj Bhavan and Nabanna.

Sensing this, the state government didn’t want to open another front with Raj Bhavan. The government readily accepted the governor’s requisition for copter service to Santiniketan, though it has denied the services on quite a few occasions.

State urban development minister Firhad Hakim said: “Helicopter service is provided as and when it is available. One should not link this to the other aspects of state administration.” Earlier, the governor was denied the service while travelling to Domkal in Murshidabad, Santipur in Nadia and Visva-Bharati in the recent past.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: 10,000 recent arrivals from China not in home isolation
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: More than 10,000 passengers who have reached Kolkata from China in the past two weeks have been allowed to leave the airport only after a thermal screening and filling up a self-reporting form about their personal and recent travel details. None of the passengers that TOI spoke to said they had been advised “home isolation” for 14 days — one of the most “stressed” points in an 8-point advisory issued by the Union health ministry on January 30.According to doctors, all these flyers are potential “silent carriers” who may show symptoms later, by when they would have already come in contact with hundreds of others and transmitted the disease. The novel coronavirus (nCoV) that has killed 425 people in China has an incubation period of up to 14 days.TOI spoke to multiple passengers who reached Kolkata from China and Hong Kong over the past four days and all of them said that neither the airport health officers nor anyone at the immigration had asked them to stay in home isolation for the next fortnight.“I had no clue I had to stay home. I returned on February 1 and over the next two days I caught up with two sets of friends, watched a movie, visited a shopping mall, ate at a restaurant and attended a family function. It was only on Monday that I learnt from media reports that we are supposed to be in isolation,” said a resident of Gariahat who works in Hong Kong.A student of Shangdong First Medical University who took a China Eastern flight back from Kunming on January 31 said she visited multiple hot spots in Kolkata and stayed at a friend’s house in Odisha before travelling to her home town in Haryana . All the while she used public transport.“At Kolkata airport I was not asked to undergo any tests apart from the thermal scan and was asked to fill up a form that had questions like my name, address and the cities I have visited in China and whether I had been to Wuhan in Hubei province in the last 14 days. It also asked if I had any symptoms of fever, cough or cold. I cleared the test and thought I was safe and didn’t need to stay indoors,” she said.Since January 30, all the three confirmed cases of nCoV in Kerala were diagnosed almost a week after they returned from China. And, all three first touched down in Kolkata and then took domestic flights to Kerala when they were already carrying the virus.“The virus may take up to 14 days to manifest. The majority of the infected people could remain without symptoms for more than a week, but they pose a bigger threat as many unsuspecting people come in contact with them. A fortnight’s screening is the only real full-proof measure to prevent the transmission,” said Joydeep Ghosh, internal medicine consultant at Fortis Hospital.In their defence, airport officials said, the last line of the self-declaration form the passengers have to sign asks the signatory to stay in isolation at home. Besides, fresh notices put up at the airport mentions home isolation.“We are asking passengers coming from Wuhan to stay indoors and are also reporting their details to the state government,” said Kaushik Bhattacharjee, the Kolkata airport director. He added that from Monday they have begun screening passengers coming from Bangkok and Singapore as well. “We have also isolated four aerobridges and flights from these destinations are being attached to these aerobridges only,” Bhattacharjee said.

Title: Darjeeling zoo to get foreign red pandas
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kolkata: Padmaja Naidu Himalyan Zoological Park, also known as Darjeeling zoo, will soon get red pandas from Europe and Australia.

West Bengal Zoo Authority member secretary V K Yadav said the idea is to introduce new bloodlines to the current population at the zoo. “The international studbook keeper and the convener of Global Species Management Plan (GSMP) have agreed in-principle. While the females will be brought from zoos in Europe, the males will be brought from an Australian zoo. We won’t divulge the names of the zoos now,” Yadav said.

Two red pandas, Joel and Shine, will be sent to Berlin zoo from Darjeeling zoo on Wednesday. Yadav said they would be sent under an exchange programme under which five Mishmi takins were brought to Darjeeling zoo.

Title: Mamata Banerjee: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee sharpens NPR attack, says don’t provide family data
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Mamata Banerjee addresses the gathering at Bongaon Stadium on Tuesday

BONGAON/RANAGHAT: Mamata Banerjee reached out to the border districts of North 24 Parganas and Nadia on Tuesday and asked people not to provide family data to census officers visiting them for household surveys.

The National Population Register (NPR) exercise is the first step towards NRC, the chief minister said, evoking epic ‘Mahabharata’ and calling on residents to frustrate “dussashan” BJP and the Uttar Pradesh CM’s ploy to bulldoze their writ by dividing people. “They are talking bullets to silence voices of dissent voices across the country,” she added.

Lashing out at BJP’s “conspiracy trap”, she said: “Don’t tell them everything. Don’t provide documents like land or house documents and ration cards if they ask for them. Don’t entertain them even if they come with West Bengal government identity cards. Some religious fanatics may reach your home with false identity cards. Pay heed only after I tell you to.”

Banerjee instead held that the Narendra Modi government could have emulated the developed countries and introduced green cards that give automatic citizenship to outsiders after some years. “There was no need for CAA. All these are being done to divide people, divert their attention from pressing needs like education and jobs,” the CM said, pointing to the mad rush for certificates in front of ration shops and municipalities. “They (BJP) looted piggy banks of mothers during notebandi, and are now trying to sell out Air India, BSNL, railways and public sector banks.”

Speaking at a packed Bongaon Stadium, she reminded the audience how Bengal gave a miss to the NPR meet in Delhi on January 17. “I didn’t go to the NPR meet. But representatives from other states who attended it said there are six clauses in NPR. Of them, one demands certificates (birth certificates) of three generations as proof of citizenship. States are opposed to the clause. The Centre has said it is not mandatory, but hasn’t dropped the clause. Now, if you don’t provide these documents, they won’t ask for it. They will simply mark you as a D (doubtful) voter. But how many of you have birth certificates of your parents?” the CM said.

Banerjee then strummed the chords of Bengali sub-nationalism to take the wind out of BJP’s sail in the Matua belt comprising as many nine assembly constituencies — Bongaon Uttar, Bongaon Dakshin, Swarupnagar, Bagda, Gaighata, Kalyani , Ranaghat Uttar, Ranaghat Dakshin and Chakdaha — after the Modi government promulgated CAA to provide citizenship to Hindu refugees from Bangladesh.

The new law has traction among the Matuas here as they hail from Gopalganj in Bangladesh.

The CM also cited instances of violence against Bengali labourers in Delhi, Karnataka , Uttar Pradesh and Kashmir in support of her claim that the BJP government at the Centre is out to divide Bengal and Bengalis.

Banerjee donned a gamchha (towel) — the traditional attire of the Namasudras/Matuas — to renew her connect with the community after Matua matriarch Barama’s demise. “We have a living relationship with Matuas for the last 25 years. I will tell you not to fill up the citizenship application form. If you do that, you lose what you already have,” the CM said.

Title: Facts gave way to fiction in President's address, says Tharoor
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Congress MP Shashi Tharoor

NEW DELHI: Congress MP Shashi Tharoor on Tuesday said the government ’s account of its accomplishments, read out by the President, was an exercise in which “facts gave way to fiction” and whose “soaring rhetoric” was divorced from the “abject reality of our country’s worrying social and economic situation”.

Taking part in the debate on motion of thanks to the President’s address in Lok Sabha, Tharoor also made sarcastic references to the government’s flagship schemes like ‘Start-up India’ and ‘Make in India’ among others. The debate will conclude on Wednesday with PM Narendra Modi expected to reply around noon. He accused the Modi government of “partitioning” India's soul by launching a “fundamental assault” on democratic and secular structure of the country by dividing the country into “Hindus vs Muslims”, “us vs they” and “Ramzade vs ...I won’t say”.

“Of course, there was the usual lip service paid to Skill India, Digital India and Start-up India, but no mention of Standup India — since you are so busy banning stand-up comedians — and no admission that your government’s schemes should really be renamed Sit Down India, Shut Down India and Shut Up India,” Tharoor said.

In response, BJP MP S P Singh said Tharoor’s speech was devoid of facts.

Title: BMC to regularise illegal use of building spaces, earn Rs 600 crore
Content:
BMC proposed to raise Rs 600 crore by regularising unauthorised use of flower beds, lofts and car decks by bui... Read More

MUMBAI: With its finances under pressure, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation ( BMC ) on Tuesday kept taxes unchanged, but sought to raise revenue by regularising illegal use of spaces inside buildings, hiking certain fees like trade licences and birth certificates, and ramping up its effort to recover pending property tax bills.The Rs 33,441-crore civic budget for 2020-21, an increase of around Rs 3,000 crore from last year, was tabled by municipal commissioner Praveen Pardeshi in the civic standing committee meeting on Tuesday. No new mega projects were announced, but existing ones like the coastal road and Goregaon-Mulund Link Road received generous funds.The BMC proposed to raise Rs 600 crore by regularising unauthorised use of flower beds, lofts and car decks by building occupants by charging a premium. It also hopes to collect Rs 6,768 crore as property tax, including at least 10% of the outstanding Rs 15,000 crore, in the next financial year. This is bound to be an uphill task because between April 2019 and January 2020, it managed to collect just Rs 2,878 crore as property tax.It will revise charges and fees for trade licences, birth certificates, and market licences by a flat 5% every year to keep up with inflation, said Pardeshi. The commissioner said establishment cost (salaries and wages) had touched 50%, which was very high in comparison to the 35% norm set by the state government. The BMC plans to reduce it to 44% in the budget estimates for the new financial year starting April 2020.Despite the revenue stress, the bigger budget size is due to increased allocation in capital expenditure (Rs 14,638 crore) from last year’s Rs 11,480 crore. Capital expenditure involves spending on development projects to improve infrastructure like roads, drains, bridges, solid waste management, etc.Further, revenue expenditure has been trimmed from Rs 19,205 crore to Rs 18,796 crore after cutting establishment costs like overtime allowances. The BMC proposes to invest surplus money in government bonds and debentures.

Title: Mumbai: 2 companies sacked for Metro project delay; it's second time for Simplex
Content:
Representative image

Work delay costs two firms Metro contracts

Continuing its crackdown on delays in Metro projects, the MMRDA on Tuesday ended the contracts of Simplex Infrastructures Ltd and the MBZ-RCC joint venture that were working on two stretches and a car depot on the Rs 11,000-crore D N Nagar - Mandale Metro 2B corridor. While Simplex was working on an elevated viaduct, MBZ -RCC had been appointed for construction of an elevated corridor and the depot. Simplex has completed only 5% of the work against the expected 65% in 30 months, while MBZ-RCC has finished even less. The action comes a day after Simplex was fired from the Andheri-Dahisar route.A day after annoucing the contract of Simplex Infrastructures Ltd was terminated for Metro Line 7, Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority said it had terminated the contract of the infrastructure major and another firm, MBZ-RCC joint venture, which were appointed to construct two stretches and a depot on the Metro 2B corridor between DN Nagar and Mandale, for delay in executing works.The 23.5-km DN Nagar to Mankhurd Metro-2B corridor is slated to have 22 stations. MMRDA has set a deadline of November 2022 to commission this line. MMRDA will now appoint new contractors. Metropolitan commissioner RA Rajeev said, “We have served termination notices to Simplex and MBZ-RCC for line B. The process of encashing bank guarantee has also been initiated. MMRDA is serious about completing projects in time and will not spare any contracting agency that delays the project. We gave a long rope to these agencies and, after following all procedures, we have terminated their contracts.”MMRDA had appointed Simplex Infrastructure in January 2018 to design and construct a 12-km viaduct and 11 stations, but it has managed to complete only 5% of the work against the expected 65% in 30 months, said a source. It’s the same with MBZ-RCC joint venture, which has not completed even 5% of the work in 30 months, the source added.

Title: No record of Savarkar’s mercy petitions: Govt
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: The culture ministry on Tuesday informed Parliament that there is no record of the mercy petitions by V D Savarkar to the British available with the department of art and culture of Andaman and Nicobar.

Replying to a question on the display of the petitions to the British by the Hindu nationalist leader at the Cellular Jail Museum in the archipelago Union territory, Union culture minister Prahlad Patel said no such record was available with the Andaman and Nicobar administration.

“As per the information received from Andaman & Nicobar (Directorate of Art and Culture), such mercy petitions are not displayed at Cellular Jail since no record is available with the department of art and culture, Andaman & Nicobar administration,” he said.

Title: Road fatalities last year up a tad from 2018
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: The number of road fatalities increased to 417 per day last year till September, the road transport ministry told Rajya Sabha on Monday. In 2018, road accidents claimed 415 lives a day.

In a written reply, road transport minister Nitin Gadkari said road fatalities were maximum at over 1.5 lakh in 2018 and stood at close to 1.13 lakh till September 30, 2019, as per provisional estimates shared by states.

This increase was registered despite several government efforts to put a check on road deaths, including passage of amendments to the Motor Vehicles Act with provisions for higher penalties for violators of traffic rules. “The impact of the change in law can be assessed when we get data of road accidents and fatalities between September and December. The new provisions came into effect on September 1. It will be interesting to see the trends in states that have notified the law and others who are yet to fall in line,” a government official said.

The marginal rise in fatalities also comes as bad news just two weeks before global leaders meet in Stockholm to assess the progress made by countries to check road deaths.

Title: Bengaluru: Old runway at KIA to shut for 7 months
Content:
This story is from February 5, 2020

Kempegowda International Airport

BENGALURU: The old runway at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) will be closed for nearly seven months to facilitate runway upgradation work, including installation of CAT-IIIB landing system that enables pilots to land aircraft in low visibility conditions.

From March 26 to November 4, the New South Parallel Runway, inaugurated in December 2019, will be used for flight operations. The new runway, though fitted with centreline lights, is not CAT IIIB compliant.

The runway is currently CAT-I compliant. A circular issued by Bangalore International Airport said that the new runway is expected to become fully operational by the first week of April 2020.
